story:
The Creator

Hi, my name is Morgan Carlisle. I am a movement artist who creates performance work in Atlanta. My art can be described as Dance Theater as I like to incorporate multiple media and styles. Terabyter will be the first solo show I have created and I am truly excited to share my process with you!

If you live in Atlanta, you have probably seen me around town at different art events. I am a true supporter of the arts scene in Atlanta and currently serve on the Board of Eyedrum: Art and Music Gallery. If I’m not volunteering around town, you can find me instructing/mentoring youth through dance at The Space.

The Project

“TERABYTER” is an evening length show that will premiere in November 6th-8th 2015 at The Space. Dance and technology are utilized to create a futuristic experience. This past March, an excerpt was premiered at the Atlanta Science Festival. The response to the showing was enthusiastically positive and a good sign to continue making this work for the fall. “TERABYTER” takes the audience to a futuristic world, where man has assimilated with machine both in lifestyle and in body. A drone as well as wearable technologies will be portrayed to illicit a highly conceptual and abstracted atmosphere. I believe this world is not too far from our future as my inspiration comes from electronic devices that already exist!

The Space: A movement arts studio, has graciously offered their space for the show. Located on Atlanta road, right off 285, The Space is easily accessible to anyone living in the metro area of Atlanta.  

What does your help do?

Your contribution will go towards the materials needed to produce the show.

Technology: We will need microcontrollers, lots of wire, batteries and all the fancy gadgets to build the costuming and props for this show.

Boring stuff: Like chair rentals, promotional items and all the little stuff it takes to run a show.

Any amount that is left will go towards the people involved with this project. There are seven dancers and many engineers, pilots and designers who have put in their time to help this project come to light.


Thank you!!!

story:
Director's Word

I am Paulius Ignatavičius, Lithuanian theatre director. Together with Klaipėda Youth Theatre now we are making new performance based on Vladimir Sorokin novel “Ice”. In the city of Klaipėda I found a group of wonderful people. They are young, dashing, creative and what is most important - open minded people. We are working all together and feeling a real joy of the process. For me in any creative work it's really important to enjoy life and the creativity which comes from it.

In the early beginning of my works I was analyzing a person as a slave of his own illusion. I thought that a person is what he hasn’t done; he is his own dreams, he is what he believed in and wanted. True face of the man for me was a compound of his unfulfilled dreams and fantasies. Now I am interested in the question: why these dreams are not becoming reality? Why a person can’t be what he wants to be? Why he can’t live always following his heart? Why, instead of living he only exists? Why he is following norms of society, religion, family and becoming hostage and slave of it? Why he dies too early? These questions are essential in my creative works as well as in this production of “Ice”.

About The Performance

In a way, this upcoming show is an ironic utopia about elected race which live in a world full of people who are alive, but dead inside. This race is searching for relative souls and trying to awake them from their useless life to start a new, real life, where people are communicating using the language of hearts. However, final goal of this race is to disappear in the eternal light. Vladimir Sorokin wrote this novel not because of the disappointment of intellectual life, but because of frustration of civilization, modern people, whom forgot the real language of hearts. This novel doesn't try to prove some recipe to fulfilling life therefore we don't want to moralize nor to tell how people should live. In this utopian world of "Ice" a person becomes awakened when he is hit to the chest with an ice hammer. If he is not a "walking corpse", this procedure is enough to hear his real name and person is ready to start live a fulfilling and happy life while understanding the language of hearts. Oh, how nice it would be, if that would be enough to "awake"? Unfortunately that's only an ironic fiction, which asks: are we really alive or maybe our hearts are just sleeping? We are trying to ask spectators this essential question; we don't want to teach them. I think that everybody should find their own personal "Ice". I hope that after the show this search will be at least a little bit easier. 

What We Need & Why

Funding which we got from Lithuania Ministry of Culture is not enough. We need 3000 dollars in order to accomplish our ideas. We have to buy all the decorations needed - now we have 2/3 of it. Also we have to finish sewing all of the costumes. Furthermore, we have to pay all the people who are helping with production: designer, sound engineer, light operator. As well we need to pay to Vladimir Sorokin who wants money in advance for copyrights. We really want to fulfill all of our ideas and to show audiences fully fledged, we want to fully dress actors and make all of the decorations needed, we seek for the dialogue with audience.

For all of this we really need your support. You could be part of it. 

If you can't contribute, we hope you'll help spread the word through social media.

Thank you for attention.

CREW:
Director - Paulius Ignatavičius
Set designer - Neli Ivančik
Light designer - Julius Kuršys
Sound director - Edgaras Žaltauskas
Actors - Klaipeda Youth Theatre
Based on a novel by Vladimir Sorokin
Song arranged by Lebanon Hanover, performed by ICE BAND

story:
Laughter in the Dark

Hi friends, John Reese here. I have a terrific opportunity to do what I love most: direct talented actors in hilarious and thoughtful theater. As part of the Double Take Fringe Festival on October 16 and 17, 2015, I am directing three intriguing one-act plays to present under the collective title, Laughter in the Dark: The Sandbox by Edward Albee is a black comedy that illuminates old age, marital relationships, the youth culture and the passing of loved ones. Shel Silverstein's The Best Daddy  wittily depicts a father who gives his thirteen year old daughter a uniquely startling birthday present. The Tarantino Variation is playwright Seth Kramer's tribute to the disturbing spirit of Quentin Tarantino's artistry. 

This is a wonderful opportunity for all involved and I just need a little bit of help to get it off the ground. Double Take covers the venue, promotion, box office and a few other things, but they can't cover royalties and production costs. Amazingly, these brilliant actors are all donating their time, as am I. Our cast includes local luminaries Bill Stewart, Jon Polgar, Stephanie Carlson, Michael Haley, Joan Haley, Rosie Caine, Marina Goldman, Theo Gabriel, Matt Haas, Deb McIntosh. So this really is a shoestring operation. Won't you play with us and invest just a little or a lot to get us the lighting and script rights that we need? 

Two grand ain't much but you'll get lots for your investment.

We need $500 for the rights to the plays. And to pay for our lighting, sound, props, etc we need about $1500. We figured out that $2000 will completely cover our costs.

$500- 6 free tickets to the show and the cast will take you out for supper!

$250 - 5 free tickets to the show and one of our actors will sing a song for you!

$100 - 4 free tickets to the show and an actor will tell you a funny story.

$50 - 2 free tickets to the show and a backstage tour and intro to the cast.

$25 - a kiss from the cast member of your choice.

$10 - our undying affection because we know you dug deep for that ten bucks.


We Can't do it without you!

We have been doing this for a lifetime in our community. You may have seen these actors in A Christmas Carol, Truth, Little Foxes, Almost Maine, Importance of Being Earnest, Mr. Burns and many other shows. In fact, if you have been to a great local show, chances are good that you have seen members of our cast. And you won't be disappointed. 

Risks & Challenges

Time is our challenge. We just need to raise this money before we go up or we don't go up!

story:
Short Summary

Hello! We are Giant Spider Productions, a new theatre company founded in Milwaukee, WI in 2014. Our inaugural production brought Evil Dead: The Musical to the city for the first time, and we instantly gained attention. Our company celebrates: 

  • new talent
  • new work
  • resurrecting and discovering a fresh take on classics
  • challenging artists to take on roles they wouldn't normally explore  
Our friends at Box Step Productions in London wrote and produced a HILARIOUS show called DEATH SHIP 666 in 2013, and it's an epic disaster-movie parody play! The show has since been produced in various European countries, experience grand success at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, received rave reviews, 5 out of 5 star ratings, been produced on the West End, and is now ready to take it's maiden voyage to North America! 
What makes this production special is that it is one of our largest groups of new talent working on a show! This is our director's Milwaukee premiere as sole director,  the first professional production in the city for a few of our actors post-college, and some leads on the production time are experiencing their first time heading a department! 
SO WHAT'S THE PLOT ABOUT?? The show can only be described as a parody play of TITANIC proportions! 

Mix “Airplane,” (THAT'S RIGHT, WE SAID "AIRPLANE!" HELLO, ZUCKERS!!), “Poseidon Adventure,” a Nancy Drew novel, “We’re Going on a Bear Hunt,” and a Blockbuster or Broadway hit in a big bowl of water, with some explosions and pom-poms, then BOOM! You’ve got DEATH SHIP 666! Serve over ice.

In short, 30 characters. 10 plots. 6 actors. 1 ship. 

And we need your help before we set sail!

What We Need & What You Get

We have a limited budget to work with, but your assistance will allow us to produce the highest quality production attainable! We've been able to already put together the skeleton of the show in ship terms: a charted course (script rights), a port of call (space and theatre rental), shipmates (a full company), and  a map (official performance dates on the calendar). So the show going on is official and will happen. 

But your funds will help soften the costs of the tangible items that build the ship. These items will help make this production a true spectacle. These are items such as: 

  • Shovel and Coal for the Engine (props) 
  • Ship (set construction and material) 
  • Uniforms (costumes)
  • "Board the Ship!" Flyers (advertisement)
  • Investor Publications (programs) 
  • and MORE! 
And we want to thank you for your help! We'd love to give you thank you notes and videos, public recognition, a photo album full of stills from rehearsal and the show, and even a DVD of the show! (hey out of towners! Here's a chance for you to see the ship's voyage!) 
We're also going to be doing 3 FREE talk-backs with the cast and director after 3 of the performances. Our company wants to be close and connected with our city and audience members, and we'd love to answer any questions you may have! 
WE APOLOGIZE BUT THE RAFFLE HAS BEEN CANCELLED DUE TO INDIE GOGO TERMS OF AGREEMENT

The Impact

This show is something special. With this show, we are: 

  • We're introducing new talent! A great handful of our company is tackling new roles they've always wanted to explore, and for others this is a Milwaukee Premiere presenting their craft.
  •  Producing entertainment at a time when theatres are normally dark, or getting ready for winter shows. We're going to ensure that high-quality productions are available in the city year-round!
  • Bringing a North American Premiere of a wildly successful West End production to our amazing city, a place that doesn't get to see too many North American Premieres
  • Building connections with an overseas theatre and film production company that we hope to share with local artists that will join our company for future productions
  • Keeping activity alive at The Alchemist Theatre while the managers work on their next project 
Support local theatre and new work. You can be apart of the start of something great! 

Risks & Challenges

There are so many risks with this show: 

  • This show is brand new to North America, and it's being produced by a new company. Publicly bringing forth new work is a complete gamble. First impressions are everything, and we just want to share this amazingly entertaining story with you!
  • Let's not forget the show is going up in November. Not only will we be battling the weather and football season, but also a time where theatres are normally dark and productions are not in performances yet. Our goal is to keep theatre running year-round, and we're doing that by putting on a production at a time where other companies usually take a break. 
  • Did we mention the weather? Let us offer you a warm and entertaining place to go and something different to do during this time! Also, Thanksgiving will be just around the corner -- bring the family!! Entertain your out of town relatives with something they CANNOT SEE ANYWHERE ELSE IN THE WORLD! WE ARE CURRENTLY THE ONLY COMPANY PRODUCING THIS SHOW!
  • We've noticed original work isn't something people are usually willing to take risks on. We're here to prove why you should -- besides, this show has already been proven successful overseas! It's time to make it success on our land now! 
  • Let's mention this again: 30 characters. 10 plots. 6 actors. 1 ship. Why would you want to miss THAT? 
  • If things go well in Milwaukee,  we plan on taking it to Chicago, going on the road, maybe even NYC! And the original writers have rumored they're dabbling with the idea of turning it into a film...

But we need to get started here first. And that's where you come in. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to donate, there's lots of other ways to help! 

  • Share this page and check out/share our social media pages. Spread the word!! 
  • Participate in our #GSP666 campaign for the show (there will be several opportunities to receive discounted tickets to the show! Watch our Facebook page!) 
  • If you're from the area and you're interested in helping us out with advertisement, house management, building the set, or backstage crew work, feel free to contact us! (This can count as volunteer hours and gaining Thespian points!) 
  • If you have any 1920s costumes or props you'd like to donate, we welcome those with open arms! 
So What's the Information for the Show? I Want to Go See It! 
  • The Alchemist Theatre in the Bay View area of Milwaukee, WI
  • Performance dates and times:
  • 7:30pm: Nov. 13, 14, 20, 21, 27, 28, Dec. 4, 5
  • 2pm: Nov. 14, 21, 28
  • There will be a FREE talk-back with the cast and director after each matinee performance! 
  • Estimated run time: 90 minutes with a 15 minute intermission 
  • Tickets go on sale in October! Link will be HERE when it's available! 
  • MORE INFORMATION:
  • www.giantspiderproductions.com (company site) 
  • www.lindsey-erin.com (director's site) 
  • www.facebook.com/giantspiderprods (company facbeook page) 
  • www.facebook.com/lindseyerin1216 (director's Facebook page) 
  • https://www.facebook.com/events/825935010856435/ (Facebook Event Page)
  • http://gsp666presale.brownpapertickets.com (TICKETS NOW ON SALE!)

story:
Finish Line

Boston Theater Company is creating a world premiere documentary play to honor and remember the Boston Marathon in 2013 - Finish Line.  

To create this piece, we interviewed over 85 whose lives were impacted, and are using their exact words to create a production that will offer powerful, profound and even lighthearted stories of that day and the year that followed.  The piece will end when survivors and runners crossed the finish line in 2014.

Finish Line will tell of the community that arose that day, based in compassion, caring and kindness.

Proceeds from the production will be donated to the Krystle Campbell Memorial Fund, the Lingzi Lu Scholarship Fund at Boston University, and the Martin W. Richard Charitable foundation.


Education

Twelve months ago, we launched a new education program. Our goal is for students of all ages to discover fresh, modern, and personal connections to Shakespeare that will spark a lasting interest in theater, and in classic works. 

In our first year, we reached over 500 students through workshops in Massachusetts schools and Boys & Girls Clubs. We also launched our well-regarded Teen Touring Troupe. TTT is a company of motivated young actors and actresses who get the opportunity to tour a Shakespeare production to local schools and community centers. 

Due to its success and continued demand, our education program is growing and expanding fast! This year, our goal is to triple the number of students we work with. We are on track to double our workshops, grow our Teen Touring Troupe (in addition to offering two full scholarships) and to launch a professional touring production that will perform in schools all around Massachusetts. 
We will also offer free theater workshops to Boston public schools in association with our upcoming production of Finish Line.


Why We Need Your Help

Our goal is to offset the entire production cost of Finish Line through our Indiegogo.com campaign and corporate and business sponsorships. This will ensure that all tickets proceeds will be donated to charity.

Funds raised will directly go to cover costs, including production space in Boston, costumes, props, lights, actor stipends, designer stipends, and printing scripts and programs.

Funds will also help ensure our education program can run in tandem with Finish Line. In addition to offering two full scholarships for our TTT program, we will teach free theater workshops titled “Telling Our Stories, Facing Our Fears." Through movement, storytelling, and tableaux work, students in these workshops will reflect on their own experiences of the Boston Marathon bombing, pairing their own words with Shakespeare sonnets to create an original performance piece. Students in these workshops will also receive free Finish Line tickets and present their original work to the cast. 

Birthday Benefit Concert

We are celebrating Boston Theater Company's Second Birthday!  Join us at a benefit concert on December 8 at Oberon, featuring talent from Boston to Broadway - special guest to be announced soon! Proceeds will support BTC's education program and Finish Line.

OBERON 2015. Photo by Marc J. Franklin

Other Ways You Can Help

Word of mouth is our best form of marketing. Please share our story with anyone you think may be interested! Follow us on Facebook, Twitter/Instagram @BostonTheaterCo, and sign up for our mailing list at http://www.bostontheatercompany.org
story_txt:
Finish Line
Boston Theater Company is creating a world premiere documentary play to honor and remember the Boston Marathon in 2013 - Finish Line.  

To create this piece, we interviewed over 85 whose lives were impacted, and are using their exact words to create a production that will offer powerful, profound and even lighthearted stories of that day and the year that followed.  The piece will end when survivors and runners crossed the finish line in 2014.
Finish Line will tell of the community that arose that day, based in compassion, caring and kindness.
Proceeds from the production will be donated to the Krystle Campbell Memorial Fund, the Lingzi Lu Scholarship Fund at Boston University, and the Martin W. Richard Charitable foundation.



Education
Twelve months ago, we launched a new education program. Our goal is for students of all ages to discover fresh, modern, and personal connections to Shakespeare that will spark a lasting interest in theater, and in classic works. 
In our first year, we reached over 500 students through workshops in Massachusetts schools and Boys & Girls Clubs. We also launched our well-regarded Teen Touring Troupe. TTT is a company of motivated young actors and actresses who get the opportunity to tour a Shakespeare production to local schools and community centers. 
Due to its success and continued demand, our education program is growing and expanding fast! This year, our goal is to triple the number of students we work with. We are on track to double our workshops, grow our Teen Touring Troupe (in addition to offering two full scholarships) and to launch a professional touring production that will perform in schools all around Massachusetts. We will also offer free theater workshops to Boston public schools in association with our upcoming production of Finish Line.



Why We Need Your Help
Our goal is to offset the entire production cost of Finish Line through our Indiegogo.com campaign and corporate and business sponsorships. This will ensure that all tickets proceeds will be donated to charity.
Funds raised will directly go to cover costs, including production space in Boston, costumes, props, lights, actor stipends, designer stipends, and printing scripts and programs.
Funds will also help ensure our education program can run in tandem with Finish Line. In addition to offering two full scholarships for our TTT program, we will teach free theater workshops titled “Telling Our Stories, Facing Our Fears." Through movement, storytelling, and tableaux work, students in these workshops will reflect on their own experiences of the Boston Marathon bombing, pairing their own words with Shakespeare sonnets to create an original performance piece. Students in these workshops will also receive free Finish Line tickets and present their original work to the cast. 

Birthday Benefit Concert
We are celebrating Boston Theater Company's Second Birthday!  Join us at a benefit concert on December 8 at Oberon, featuring talent from Boston to Broadway - special guest to be announced soon! Proceeds will support BTC's education program and Finish Line.


OBERON 2015. Photo by Marc J. Franklin
Other Ways You Can Help
Word of mouth is our best form of marketing. Please share our story with anyone you think may be interested! Follow us on Facebook, Twitter/Instagram @BostonTheaterCo, and sign up for our mailing list at http://www.bostontheatercompany.org

story:
Short Summary

CK Productions Inc. is a New York based entertainment house created to provide people of a wider variety of ages with an opportunity to work and create many aspects of the arts; theatre, music, dance & film. This is all organized through CK's separate branches; CK Films, CK Theatre, CK Dance & Felizzari Records. These projects are led by industry professionals, students & amateurs collaborating together to create true & unique art. 


MISSION STATEMENT

CK Productions was originally created to give students & teens in Long Island, New York (with little to no experience) the experience to create their very own theatrical productions. Recently, we have decided to expand producing not only theatrical ventures, but film, dance and music projects NOW led by not only students, but industry professionals, students & adults collaborating together to create a true art.

CK Productions Inc.'s mission is to create a whole new level of entertainment and inspire everyone to never stop bringing arts into their own communities and to this world. We invite everyone to explore and be apart of CK Productions & never stop "fostering new & creative projects for tomorrow"! ​


What We Need & What You Get

Time to break it down folks:

  • Funding for arts projects go to many different places. For theatre, we will put them directly into our budgets to continue to create high level theatre and better improve our younger performer's program (this includes performance rights for Broadway musicals and plays, producing original works, lighting, sound, etc.)!
  • For our films, we will use it to pay for production costs & post-production costs (such as lights, cameras, sound, editing etc.) & actor/crew transportation and food for upcoming shoot dates.
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, it is not the end of the world! We will still be using any funds we can receive to better CK Productions in any way we can and to shape our youth and our professional productions & films.

The Impact

Every contribution you make, not matter how big or small, is important:

  • Our project is so valuable not only to us, but to the world. Art is a field that needs to flourish. Providing arts for the community and providing opportunities for our youth to perform and create alongside professional actors, directors, editors, writers & others is an experience that any amateur (no matter the age) who works with us will continue to get. It will better the artists of tomorrow and will give them an opportunity to keep on creating the next influential thing to change our society.
  • By collaborating with us, you will be directly involved in, hopefully, making art to inspire others to live each day to the fullest and to always create!
  • We have had successful Indiegogo and crowd funding pages with our films before & have gone on to create some amazing works like LA SANGRE EN NUESTRAS VENAS (in film festivals from Connecticut all the way to California in 2015/2016).
  • We know with your help, you can impact the life of the youth (and adults) of today and the projects and creativity of tomorrow!


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Help us make some noise about our campaign. Spread the word, share the link and follow us on social media! Stay updated with CK Productions & keep spreading the word! 
  • Vote for us for "Best of Long Island" Local Theatre to Spread the word of CK Productions throughout New York by clicking this link: https://bestof.longislandpress.com/voting-open/
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread this campaign around!
  • Spread Hashtags like #CKProductions & #CKFilms to spread the word of CK around the world!


And that's all there is to it. Thank you for supporting CK Productions!

For more information, visit www.ckproductionsnewyork.com!

CK Productions - "Fostering new & creative projects for tomorrow!'

story:
What happens when you write a play, lightening strikes, and it comes together so tightly that in a competitive field of more than 70 plays it wins Best Play, Best Director, Best Actor and Best Actress?

Well, in the case of "It's All About Lorrie" by Joseph Krawczyk, you bring it back to the stage (ATA January 25-February 5, 2016) and then all the way to Off-Broadway and beyond! 

But first things, first... We NEED YOUR HELP... $1, $5, $10...any donation helps! JUST CLICK the pink "BACK IT" Button! 

This comedy deserves to be seen! It NEEDS more than just 3 festival performances to gain the attention of long-term partners. The audience agrees. The critics agree. The festival agrees. This comedy by Joe Krawczyk is a winner. 

And you can be a winner by helping us with any contribution you can afford!

Award-winning playwright Joseph P. Krawczyk is determined to bring this wonderful and talented team to the stage again at the American Theatre of Actors on January 25th - February 5th, 2017 to finally give his show the audience it deserves and he is excited to do so with the help of his friends at ATA and the support and contributions of Arts-Friendly benefactors such as yourself! 

In part, the run will give the show the momentum it needs to make its journey to the professional stage (Off-Broadway), while allowing the team to fine-tune this wonderful, funny and inspiring material about a woman who knows how to take charge and won't take no for an answer!

It's a modern day tale of feminism, with a magical and very funny touch.

Why We Need Your Financial Support. 

Taking this show "OFF-BROADWAY" is an expensive proposition if you want to do it right. Just walking in the door, you need investments in the amount of 175k-250k. We are not there yet, of course. But if we want to get there, we first must run a successful limited engagement "OFF-OFF-BROADWAY" to attract supporters and partners, gather more reviews, and demonstrate that the play has the potential to be successful on the professional stage. We are 110% certain that we have a magical work of theatre here and we want to invite you along on the journey.

To be able to produce the play we will need to budget for:

  • Salaries
  • Fees for technicians
  • Marketing costs
  • Set design and building
  • Materials for sets and props and costumes
  • Transportation
  • Costumes
  • Sound and Lighting Design... and much more.

Every dollar you can donate to help bring these incredibly talented, young performers and our creative team to the stage at ATA will help us not only get to this limited engagement run, but also give us the boost we need to proceed to Off Broadway and perhaps beyond.

Our goal is to raise a little over 14K for this run (average by most OOB standards) and then be in the position to invite larger investments to take us beyond. BUT FIRST, we need your help with the OOB production. Join us on this critical first step of the journey and you will be part of something unique, an off-Broadway hit. We are that certain about this play. 

What's In It For YOU?

Your support for the arts is what sets you apart and above the rest. By helping us achieve this modest goal to run the show at ATA, you also make it possible for us to continue the journey and take many of you along with us....  We're certain that we have a winning script, winning actors, and a winning creative team! So much so, that we have put aside our other projects, gathered our resources, and started on our way. Script revisions are being done. Rehearsals are beginning right after the holidays. We are doing this. Will you help us?

All contributions will be appreciated! But for larger contributions, not only will you get all the goodies described in the "PERKS" section of this Indiegogo Campaign, but you will also get FREE tickets to our OB Previews when we arrive OFF BROADWAY. We are so sure this will happen that we are making the promise now!

We offer quite a few opportunities to be with us as we attempt what only a few have had the chance to attempt! In fact, if you are so inclined, we have opportunities to really become part of our team.

Please go to our Perks Page to see all the levels we offer.  But remember, any help from $1 to $10,000 is greatly appreciated! Hit the pink "Back It" button to make whatever donation you can afford!

Other Ways You Can Help

As we have mentioned, some people just can't contribute, we get that... but thanks to the ease and power of social media, perhaps you can help share our story and encourage your friends to support us. Yes, every dollar helps... even $5, $10, $20... So help us spread the word! SHARE>SHARE>SHARE!

Give any donation of any amount and enter to win 2 Free tickets to the OB opening night production of "It's All About Lorrie!"

And that's all there is to it. 

Lorrie is a magical character. You can be a magical supporter!

And that's all there is to it. Lorrie is a magical character. You can be a magical supporter!

story:
About this project

In the first glimpse I recognize your hands. Slowly I notice your gestures. In her presence I see myself standing there. With her I see the other. Together, "you" and "I" are strangers.

I see you again, and your eyes, in which i encounter the self and recognise a stranger. How many times can we meet one another in one encounter? With this piece an encounter between two people is presented, in which various fragments of gestures, surprises, and playfulness between two are explored.

Stranger is a performance in which music dance and light design are in an interplay with each other. The performance is dealing with two strangers meeting each other, and how such an encounter can change the life of both participants. The same meeting is introduced from different angles on different levels over and over again. The more levels we meet the story, the more apparent it becomes that meeting a stranger is our best chance for understanding our motivation and character.

This is a playful but critical piece related to the self in context of actual political trends and cyber environments, and how fulfilling certain roles in society take away from our experiencing the world surrounding us.

Perhaps solidarity as a term in this case could be replaced with curiosity or self-interest.

The piece is directed by Emese Csornai, a light designer with a visual art background. To confront filmic realities with common space and time, gestures of an edited movie are re-interpreted to the theater space.

Emese has lived in Amsterdam before, and this will be her debut as a director in Berlin. For this reason your support of getting the word out there helps us greatly! We find it great if you share the link of our project, the facebook event or this video with people who you think would appreciate.

Two composers, Gabor Csongradi and Georgi Sztojanov are working on the musical content and its delivery, and Mikel Aristegui, Silvia Bennett and Annapaola Leso are generating the movement material and are dancing in the performance.

We have worked some ten days already, and we need a few more weeks of rehearsal to finish this performance, we must work together in the same time and space. The collaboration is non-conventional, therefore very inspired, all participants are deeply and creatively engaging in the project, supporting it with their best command of their art forms. We are provided access to a great studio equipped for the use of both sound and light. For a concentrated work-period and performances of 3 weeks, productional costs and costumes, we need to collect some budget.

The performance premiers on the 23rd of February 2017, further fixed performance dates are on the 24th, 25th, and 26th of February all at Dock11 theater (Kastanienallee 79 Berlin)

Helpers of the project are Dock11, Tanzfabrik and Wiesen 55 e.V.

Risks and challenges

The risk we are taking is if we have to squeeze too many other works that pay the team their rents and food, we will not be able to realize this piece to its real potential. As for the piece is dealing with multiple media, common rehearsals are necessary and they provide a common conceptual ground upon which the artists can co-create.

story:
Southern Railroad Theatre Company


Bringing the Southern Experience, one hush puppy at a time! 

"Comfort Food Entertainment"

The Southern Railroad Theatre Company has been presenting award winning, critically acclaimed theater in the San Francisco Bay Area since 2008.

We've had the  pleasure of working with some of the best theater companies, theatre makers and artists the Bay Area has to offer. In 2013, we were invited to New York City for Altruistic Theatre Company's Bare Knuckle Theatre Fest.  We've been working to build creative alliances with other companies including the immersion experience theatre producers, Incentives to Intrige. We collaborate with writers, directors and producers from Entropy Productions, Wily West Productions, Pacifica Table Readers, Pear Avenue Theater, PianoFight Productions and  3Girls Theatre.  In 2014, we were invited to participate in the Eugene O'Neill Foundation's Eugene O' Neill Festival where we presented A RAZING IN MISSOURI, written and directed by Susan Jackson.  In 2015 we were invited back to NYC for Midtown's Mid-Winter Theatre Festival. 

Now, we've been invited to our Nation's Capital!  With your help, we'll be traveling to Washington where we'll make our DC Capital Fringe debut.  

Directed by Wesley Cayabyab, co-producers Diana Brown and Susan Jackson will represent the Southern Railroad Theatre Company at the festival in Susan Jackson's two-handed contemporary Southern comedy DEATH BE NOT LOUD!.  

We'll have five performances in the Capital Fringe Festival: July 7 @ 5:45, July 10 @ 1:30 pm, July 12 @ 7:30 pm, July 13 @ 5:45 pm and July 16 at 2:00 pm   

DEATH BE NOT LOUD! 

By Susan Jackson

Directed by Wesley Cayabyab

Featuring: Diana Brown and Susan Jackson

"People are worse than anybody!" - Marion's take on the world after a few martinis collides with Red's pragmatism and profanity: "You just gotta laugh, goddamn it!"  Will they find Southern Comfort as they story down the railroad tracks of life?
Where your contribution will be used:

  • We'll use your contributions to prepare the production for the festival and to travel to Washington, DC to represent.
  • Our Goal of $8,000 will go to pay for festival fees, production insurance, production staff and to compensate our director and collaborators. It will fund economy airfare, ground transportation, food and lodging enabling Diana and Susan to travel to DC and perform DEATH BE NOT LOUD! in the 2016 Capital Fringe festival. And go to pay for advertising to market our participation in the festival and to document the project.

Even if we don't receive our entire funding goal, any contribution will help us to accept the invitation to perform and make our 2016 Festival appearance possible. as well as ensure the continued artistic growth of the Southern Railroad Theatre Company.


In thanks for your support:

  • You'll receive inside access to the production process through special posts and video updates.
  • Souvenirs from our 2016 Capital Fringe Festival experience.
  • At certain levels, Producers will enjoy producing credit in the program, VIP tickets to our World Premiere production TAKEN by Susan Jackson.  A Southern "Comfort Food Feast"  with the cast of DEATH BE NOT LOUD and other Southern Railroad Company Members. All of you will receive our sincere gratitude!

As an independent producing company, we are used finding ways to self fund. Even if we don't receive our entire funding goal, any contribution will help us to accept the invitation to perform and make our 2015 Festival appearance possible. Your support and contributions also ensure the continued artistic growth of the Southern Railroad Theatre Company.


The Impact

Your contributions will go to help us make the most of our Washington, DC debut:

  • This opportunity to travel to and perform at the Capital Fringe will expand our audience base, inform our knowledge of theatre and refresh our perspectives.  We hope to use the opportunity to forge new creative partnerships, possibly bringing DC artists to work with us here in the San Francisco Bay Area, increasing our community at home and on the East Coast.
  • As always a portion of our proceeds will go in support of a charity.  In the past, we've supported Tornado Relief in Joplin, MO., Puppy Rescue Mission, SF Suicide Prevention and Rocket Dog Rescue.  
  • Southern Railroad Theatre Company has been presenting award winning, critically acclaimed theatre in the Bay Area since 2008. 

Risks & Challenges

We're excited to face the challenge of bringing a San Francisco based company to a DC festival.  Co-producers, Brown and Jackson have marketed and presented performances in New York City festivals.  They will rely on what they've learned from those experiences in touring.  Additionally, they are working closely with the DC Capital Fringe Festival producing team to use best practices learned from previous DC Fringe Festivals. They're also collaborating with DC Fringe marketing and PR representatives.  As well as using online and print marketing to reach the general public. 


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can contribute financially:

  • Your good wishes, sharing our story on social media and introductions to your DC friends are just as valuable and appreciated!
  • Indiegogo share tools are a great way to do just that!

We sure thank you for your support!

Diana Brown and Susan Jackson, Co-Producers

Southern Railroad Theatre Company

The Southern Railroad Theatre Company has been presenting award winning, critically acclaimed theater in the San Francisco Bay Area since 2008.
We've had the  pleasure of working with some of the best theater companies, theatre makers and artists the Bay Area has to offer. In 2013, we were invited to New York City for Altruistic Theatre Company's Bare Knuckle Theatre Fest.  We've been working to build creative alliances with other companies including the immersion experience theatre producers, Incentives to Intrige. We collaborate with writers, directors and producers from Entropy Productions, Wily West Productions, Pacifica Table Readers, Pear Avenue Theater, PianoFight Productions and  3Girls Theatre.  In 2014, we were invited to participate in the Eugene O'Neill Foundation's Eugene O' Neill Festival where we presented A RAZING IN MISSOURI, written and directed by Susan Jackson.  In 2015 we were invited back to NYC for Midtown's Mid-Winter Theatre Festival. 
Now, we've been invited to our Nation's Capital!  With your help, we'll be traveling to Washington where we'll make our DC Capital Fringe debut.  
Directed by Wesley Cayabyab, co-producers Diana Brown and Susan Jackson will represent the Southern Railroad Theatre Company at the festival in Susan Jackson's two-handed contemporary Southern comedy DEATH BE NOT LOUD!.  
We'll have five performances in the Capital Fringe Festival: July 7 @ 5:45, July 10 @ 1:30 pm, July 12 @ 7:30 pm, July 13 @ 5:45 pm and July 16 at 2:00 pm   
DEATH BE NOT LOUD! 
By Susan Jackson
Directed by Wesley Cayabyab
Featuring: Diana Brown and Susan Jackson




"People are worse than anybody!" - Marion's take on the world after a few martinis collides with Red's pragmatism and profanity: "You just gotta laugh, goddamn it!"  Will they find Southern Comfort as they story down the railroad tracks of life?


Where your contribution will be used:



 


We'll use your contributions to prepare the production for the festival and to travel to Washington, DC to represent.

Our Goal of $8,000 will go to pay for festival fees, production insurance, production staff and to compensate our director and collaborators. It will fund economy airfare, ground transportation, food and lodging enabling Diana and Susan to travel to DC and perform DEATH BE NOT LOUD! in the 2016 Capital Fringe festival. And go to pay for advertising to market our participation in the festival and to document the project.

Even if we don't receive our entire funding goal, any contribution will help us to accept the invitation to perform and make our 2016 Festival appearance possible. as well as ensure the continued artistic growth of the Southern Railroad Theatre Company.



In thanks for your support:

You'll receive inside access to the production process through special posts and video updates.
Souvenirs from our 2016 Capital Fringe Festival experience.
At certain levels, Producers will enjoy producing credit in the program, VIP tickets to our World Premiere production TAKEN by Susan Jackson.  A Southern "Comfort Food Feast"  with the cast of DEATH BE NOT LOUD and other Southern Railroad Company Members. All of you will receive our sincere gratitude!

As an independent producing company, we are used finding ways to self fund. Even if we don't receive our entire funding goal, any contribution will help us to accept the invitation to perform and make our 2015 Festival appearance possible. Your support and contributions also ensure the continued artistic growth of the Southern Railroad Theatre Company.

   The Impact 
Your contributions will go to help us make the most of our Washington, DC debut:

This opportunity to travel to and perform at the Capital Fringe will expand our audience base, inform our knowledge of theatre and refresh our perspectives.  We hope to use the opportunity to forge new creative partnerships, possibly bringing DC artists to work with us here in the San Francisco Bay Area, increasing our community at home and on the East Coast.
As always a portion of our proceeds will go in support of a charity.  In the past, we've supported Tornado Relief in Joplin, MO., Puppy Rescue Mission, SF Suicide Prevention and Rocket Dog Rescue.  

Southern Railroad Theatre Company has been presenting award winning, critically acclaimed theatre in the Bay Area since 2008. 

    Risks & Challenges We're excited to face the challenge of bringing a San Francisco based company to a DC festival.  Co-producers, Brown and Jackson have marketed and presented performances in New York City festivals.  They will rely on what they've learned from those experiences in touring.  Additionally, they are working closely with the DC Capital Fringe Festival producing team to use best practices learned from previous DC Fringe Festivals. They're also collaborating with DC Fringe marketing and PR representatives.  As well as using online and print marketing to reach the general public. 
   Other Ways You Can Help We understand that not everyone can contribute financially:  Your good wishes, sharing our story on social media and introductions to your DC friends are just as valuable and appreciated!
Indiegogo share tools are a great way to do just that!
   We sure thank you for your support!Diana Brown and Susan Jackson, Co-ProducersSouthern Railroad Theatre Company

story:
Emily Wolfe Travels to India to Create Art

June 2016


I am Emily Wolfe, an emerging performer and choreographer from Winston-Salem, NC and currently working in New York, NY. I have spent my life passionately exploring the potential of physical expression. After attending North Carolina School of the Arts for high school and receiving my BFA from Florida State University, I am now dancing with Natalie Johnson Dance and creating my own work.

This summer, I plan to travel to India to pursue an incredible opportunity to research, gain new artistic perspective, and to grow as a choreographer, dancer, and contributor. I will be traveling with Kelsey Vidic, a professional costume designer and artistic collaborator. Kelsey and I share a common curiosity and desire to be immersed in this foreign culture. We will be beginning in Mumbai, and will travel along the south to Bangalore, Goa, and Kerala. This will be my first experience traveling abroad; a chance to broaden my artistic horizons and assuredly change my life. In our travels to India, we will collaborate, share stories, and cultivate artistic habits. More specifically, I plan to study street harassment, political activism, cultural contrast, dance, and healing practices.

Kelsey and I have collaborated on an extensive research project before, and this trip will allow us to further develop our professional artistic relationship. With my offerings of choreography and dance, and Kelsey’s expression of costume, theater, and visual art; we will seek to use our art forms as a form of meaningful storytelling. By being immersed in a new culture and environment, we anticipate collecting countless adventures of our own, in addition to the tales and histories of the people who we meet. It is our intention to explore different processes and methods of collaboration through our commitment to create an original project each day. These daily creations will include a variety of mediums: a movement phrase, drawings, installations, text, monologues, clothing, conversations, songs, videos, and possibly more.  As young, emerging artists, the most advantageous way we can grow and better ourselves is to develop our be in the habit of continually creating. By practicing our passion every day in India, we will extend ourselves to explore original questions and new ideas without the goal or added pressure of a final performance. As an artist, I have found that process is of higher importance and depth than a final product. The experiences and knowledge we gain, along with the and  material we develop, will influence our future methods and productions we create. One of the challenges of being an emerging artist in New York City is the pressure to make tremendous and unique works under a deadline, often in uninspiring spaces. These conditions add up to produce an artistic environment that can be stifling and nearly impossible to afford. We are rarely given the opportunity to develop organically and to take those risks that are so critical to our expressive minds, because “time is money”. Traveling to India will allow us to temporarily escape this typical work setting, and process of making and to be inspired and refreshed by new external stimuli.

This trip to India will satiate all aspects of my being. as I develop my knowledge in collaboration, politics, dance education, history, spirituality, and personality. I am at a time in my career where I could use support in my creative growth, and I have the drive and vision to keep making work. This creative trip will open my mind to opportunities and push me to learn to communicate with a wide variety of people. I look forwards to the challenges and surprises. Being in India will be an important incubator outside of the United States and is bound to bring growth.

The material and experiences I develop will be continued in a collaborative piece with Kelsey Vidic. This will be performed in New York with the possibility of an opportunity in Austin, Texas. Stay tuned!

Questions I am asking to motivate research

What are my creative habits, successes and failures?
What happens when I combine traditional and contemporary practices?
What is my role in the future of contemporary dance? How do I advance the field?How much does our environment influence the way we work? As an emerging artist, how do I  balance of create investment and financial stability?
What is my potential as an interdisciplinary artist?
What are my methods of spreading dance as a community tool?
How do I create flexible meaning? How can I communicate broadly and specifically at the same time?
How many different ways can I tell a story? How do I share someone else's story? (Can I?)
What are ways of responding to harassment?
What are my tools for creating dance as an activist and therapist?  How is art a healing practice? How do I integrate the spiritual and physical practices of Kundalini yoga and dance?


How do I continue building my artistic career?

I need your help! I am passionate and committed to this opportunity of concentrated research in India this summer. I would love your support and investment to the future of my career and ultimately the future of the dance world.
Any way you can help, whether its financially, through sharing experiences of travel, or connections in India, will be incredibly beneficial. I need help with housing, food, and travel costs.
Your generosity will directly support the growth of my career. You will receive the gift of movement with any donation. I look forwards to this opportunity to share my art with you!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • My name is Richard Mazda. I founded the theatre to create opportunities for creatives and to provide a cultural harbor for Long Island City. I began my adult life as a teenage actor and then switched to making music as a songwriter/producer before switching back over 20 years ago.
  • We have big dreams at The Secret Theatre and this campaign is just one way in which we make those dreams come true. In 2017 we will raise the bar again with a fresh take on the iconic show Cabaret which is followed by King Lear which will feature a Tony nominee in the role of Cordelia and award winning and beloved character actor/director Austin Pendleton as Lear.  This campaign will enable us to continue to mount shows and productions that are closer to Broadway's level of skills and production value and will also help us continue to provide incredible programming for years to come.
  • By supporting us you are going to help us bring actors, directors and other artists to an area of Queens that needs a diverse and exciting cultural life that will support and keep pace with Long Island City's exponential growth.   You are helping to ensure that great theatre is available to all in the most diverse borough in the country.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Let's Break it Down! 

  • We are asking for $10,000 but would accept a lot more!  Our rent, electricity costs and other running costs are almost $10,000 per month.  If we are successful with our fundraising target this will help us improve our facilities and raise the quality of our productions.   Although we did not fund the theatre as a way of making money we have to consistently raise money through tickets, concessions, donations and other means in order to keep the doors open. We have had many sell-out shows, we have won awards and have seen thousands of delighted happy customers enter and leave our doors but in common with many theatres we are constantly fighting to keep ourselves open and relevant.  You can help to change that reality
  • We  have some typical perks for your contributions including free Tickets, a custom designed shirt, credits and thank yous; one of the most sought after rewards will be the 'Ten Years of Secrets' book which will have pictures, stories, playbills and anecdotes from our first ten years.
  • If we are not successful in reaching the full target undoubtedly we might need to cut back on some ambitions but it will not stop the production of Cabaret or King Lear or indeed any of our planned season.

The Impact

THE difference YOUR contribution will make:

  • The Secret Theatre pioneered eclectic theatre in the LIC area and has become the closest thing to an arts center for the area.
  • We have been called one of the best 50 theatres in New York. Playbill choose use alongside BAM, The Lehman Center for the Arts and The St George theatre as they go to theatre in Queens. This year we received 6 off off 'TONY' nominations from NYIT
 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

  • The power of 'word of mouth' recommendation scannot be underestimated.  If you share our aims and goals please take a moment to mention us on your Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or other social media accounts.  This can have an unbelievably positive effect. Thank you for sharing - those kindergarten teachable moments are useful after all!
  • Also you will find Indiegogo share tools on our page!

story:
Summary - Zuccotti Park

"Zuccotti Park" examines the  human side of economics:  the CEO of a large corporation, a homeless veteran, a laid off factory worker,  a family buying their first home, a student who can't find a job.  The play takes place as Cooper, a soldier on leave from Afghanistan, visits childhood friend, Kate, in NYC and finds that she is now totally devoted to the Occupy Movement. Cooper is attracted to grown up Kate, despite the fact that they disagree on almost everything.

"Zuccotti Park" has been accepted into the Venus Adonis NYC Theater Festival. It will open on February 26th at the Robert Moss Theater.  The play was written by Catherine Hurd, Music by Vatrena King, will be produced by Salgado Productions, and directed by Luis Salgado. The Music Director is Joshua Coyne. 

We need funds to help produce this very unique and important musical in NY City.  Our team is incredible, we've worked very hard on the project, and we we believe that what we have to say in "Zuccotti Park" will touch people emotionally and also add to their understanding of the way things work both politically and economically. www.zuccottiparkmusical.com

Creative Team

VATRENA KING, COMPOSER:   Vatrena King graduated from Berklee College of Music with a degree in Music Production and Engineering before becoming a 1st-call recording session singer. Credits include a recurring singing role on the hit TV show “Ally McBeal,” performing and/or recording with such artists as Melissa Manchester, Rod Stewart, Mariah Carey, Whitney Houston, Ray Charles, Barry Manilow & Barry White, several Disney children’s albums, television and film theme songs. Original songs can be heard in the independent film “All About Us,” (2007). In 2000, L.A.'s Music Connection Magazine rated Vatrena the Top Unsigned Artist.

CATHERINE HURD, WRITER/LYRICIST:  Catherine graduated from UCLA with a Master’s Degree in Screenwriting, and from Florida State University with an MFA in Film Production. She received her BFA from Florida Atlantic University in Theater. Screenwriting awards include the Writer’s Digest Writing Competition, Chesterfield Film Company Writing Award, Marty Klein Comedy Writing Award, Moondance Film Festival Writing Award and several others. She also optioned three feature film scripts in Los Angeles. 

LUIS SALGADO, DIRECTOR/PRODUCER:   Luis has directed and choreographed musicals and plays, as well as conceived and developed many others. He won "best director" at the 2014 Thespis Festival Awards. Luis was the Latin Assistant Choreographer of the Tony Award winning musical "In The Heights" and wants to pass all of his experiences in art to potential new projects that serve a purpose. http://www.salgadoproductions.com/

JOSHUA COYNE, MUSIC DIRECTOR:   Joshua is a young Black musician and composer who took his first lessons at the Cedar Rapids Symphony School, where he studied with Dr. Stephen Shepherd and later with concertmaster Taki Horiuchi. Later, Joshua moved to the Washington, DC area, where he continued his violin studies with Lya Stern and began composition study. After moving to D.C., Joshua performed for then candidate Barack Obama at the Stand for Change Rally, as well as for the Haitian Embassy. Coyne composed the score to Anne and Emmett, a play about Emmett Till and Anne Frank written by Janet Langhart Cohen.

What We Need & What You Get

Producing a musical play in NYC is a huge deal. It can be expensive, but because we have a creative and passionate producer, who comes up with great ideas that are also less expensive, we have manageable budget.  So we are trying to raise $10,000 for the production. That money will pay for the director, musical director, props, costumes, musicians, stipend for the actors,  etc.  Of course, if we raise more money that would be awesome. It will be put to work improving the show. But we can DO the show for $10,000.  For anyone interested, we will provide you with a detailed cost breakdown.

For incentives, people donating $200.00 or more will be given two tickets to the show, $100.00 or more... a DVD of the show.  $50.00 or more... a Zuccotti Park mouse pad, $10.00 or more... a thank you email from the writer, composer, director and musical director.

The Impact

"Zuccotti Park" is a play that seeks to pull people together rather than drive them apart.  It is the opposite of mainstream media in that regard. It highlights our commonalities rather than differences. One reason that our director, Luis Salgado, took on the project was because of its objectivity in presenting many sides of the economic picture.

We had a very successful reading at the Woodland Opera House.  We distributed a comment sheet to the audience, and without exception, the answer to the question: "Would you recommend this musical to a friend?" was "YES!"

Risks & Challenges

We have already had successful auditions in NYC.  Some amazing talent showed up despite the 10 degree weather. The only difficult part was selecting the best out of a stellar group. 

There will be hurdles to jump in this production, but the one thing I can say about this team, is that they have a can-do attitude.  If an obstacle is thrown in our path, we consider ourselves creative enough to figure a way around the obstacle.  And sometimes the path around is more interesting that our original intention!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, but still want to help, please, please, please, get the word out to your friends, neighbors, significant other, and his/her friends, your church group, your Facebook friends. If you live in or around NYC, please come to see the show, and bring your friends!  I guarantee, even if you've seen a lot of live theater before, this experience will be different, unique, something you've never seen before.

Use the Indiegogo share tools to help get the message out there.

Thanks you so much for your help!

story:
Though world peace seems increasingly elusive these days, may we finally achieve it 50 years from now in an explosion of carnivalesque camaraderie among international soldiers holding a Christmas Truce in the Mato Grosso jungle of Brazil? 

Truce, a futuristic musical for peace running April 9-19 at Theater for the New City, enacts this imagined possibility, inspired by recent collective imaginings of peace as the world celebrated the 100th anniversary of the World War One Christmas Truce of 1914 when soldiers converted the battleground to common ground, exchanging gifts and sharing songs.

Funds raised will pay production costs for TRUCE, an intercultural musical with book and lyrics by Gene Ruffini, music by Barney Griffin, and directed by Elizabeth Ruf. The action opens in the year 2064 as US and Brazilian soldiers celebrate a Christmas Truce with soccer, capoeira, and samba. The cast of characters includes politicians, a television evangelist, media moguls, young activists, Christ, and the Pope, among others. The original music hits dissonant tones as well as the popular sounds of Broadway and the Brazilian streets. TRUCE offers no one-dimensional characters and no pat solutions. It hopes to spur audiences to more dynamic relationships within their own cultural and political communities and, above all, to entertain. TOTAL Proposed Budget - $3,000 breaks down as follows: Sets - $900 (designer, labor, and materials); Lights - $900 (designer, labor, and materials); Costumes - $800 (designer, labor, and materials); Publicity - $400 (photos, posters, postcards, ads); Any additional funds raised will go for Stipends for Cast, Musicians, and Crew.
story_txt:
Though world peace seems increasingly elusive these days, may we
finally achieve it 50 years from now in an explosion of carnivalesque
camaraderie among international soldiers holding a Christmas Truce in the Mato
Grosso jungle of Brazil? 
Truce, a futuristic musical for peace running
April 9-19 at Theater for the New City, enacts this imagined possibility,
inspired by recent collective imaginings of peace as the world celebrated the
100th anniversary of the World War One Christmas Truce of 1914 when soldiers
converted the battleground to common ground, exchanging gifts and sharing
songs.
Funds raised
will pay production costs for TRUCE, an intercultural musical with book and
lyrics by Gene Ruffini, music by Barney Griffin, and directed by Elizabeth Ruf.
The action opens in the year 2064 as US and Brazilian soldiers celebrate a
Christmas Truce with soccer, capoeira, and samba. The cast of characters
includes politicians, a television evangelist, media moguls, young activists,
Christ, and the Pope, among others. The original music hits dissonant tones as
well as the popular sounds of Broadway and the Brazilian streets. TRUCE offers
no one-dimensional characters and no pat solutions. It hopes to spur audiences
to more dynamic relationships within their own cultural and political
communities and, above all, to entertain. TOTAL Proposed Budget - $3,000 breaks
down as follows: Sets - $900 (designer, labor, and materials); Lights -

materials); Publicity - $400 (photos, posters, postcards, ads); Any additional
funds raised will go for Stipends for Cast, Musicians, and Crew.

story:
Who We Are

We're an a cappella group whose focus is singing the stories of the African Diaspora. We began life as part of the theatre group NITRO - the music part of their theatre projects.  After a few years of being under the umbrella, we're emerging into the sunshine on our own!  We want to sing your  stories.

Our past: http://www.nitro.co.uk/projects/now/nitrovox/

Our present: https://vimeo.com/123429406

Listen: https://soundcloud.com/nitro_vox/07-it-aint-jus...




What We're Doing

Our début project is called "The Prize".  Those words are taken from the folk song "Keep Your Eyes On The Prize", which was hugely influential during the American Civil Rights Movement of the 50s and 60s. We will be exploring the history of protest and struggle through text and song, looking at the ongoing desire for freedom - freedom to be. To be black, to be LBGT, to be a woman, to be young, to be whatever you are and to believe in whatever you want. We will be working with the Devas Youth Club (South London). Over a period of eight days, eight members of NitroVoX will be working with 8-10 members of the club who will be contributing to and helping to create the piece. The result will be a joint performance on 15 May, 


What We Need

This project is going to happen.  With your support, the road will be a lot smoother. We need funding for:

Singers (rehearsals and performance x 8)                                   £6400

Research/development                                                                      £1000

Composition/arrangement                                                               £1000

Video documentation/editing                                                           £800

Marketing/administration                                                                  £300


We need your help.  Any donation, no matter the size, is HUGELY appreciated. We've got some nifty perks to encourage the giving (check it out!).

Please follow/"like" us on Twitter and Facebook (links at the bottom). We will keep you updated on the progress of both this campaign and the project, itself.


Just giving up one day's worth of latte and muffin to go will help the journey progress and get us to our goal.  Let the songs fill your soul.


                                                             THANK YOU!

story:
Panto? Science? Oh yes it is...

Science and pantomime: two disparate worlds.  Or so we thought, until we pipetted them into the Large Hadron Collider and forced a collision…

Imagine a world where Puss in Boots moonlights as Schrodinger's Cat; Jack genetically engineers beanstalks; Snow White is an esteemed toxicologist; and Aladdin's genie really is made of genes!  

Panto Science: The Periodic Fable is an exciting new theatre production for young and old, packed with geeky gags to tickle the funny bone and test your grey matter. 

As the story unfolds, discover the little-known science dimension of panto-land through live experiments, music and audience participation.  

What We Need  

Panto Science: The Periodic Fable is co-written by Dr Zara Gladman and Bruce Morton and produced by Fair Pley, with support from Glasgow Science Festival.

We've been offered a full run at The Assembly Rooms during this year's Edinburgh Fringe Festival.  This is a huge opportunity to take Panto Science to big, international audiences at one of the most prestigious venues in the city.  But it's also a risk, with high production costs and limited time and resources.

We are seeking funds to support the following minimum costs and get our project off the ground:

  • Writers and cast - £1500
  • Rehearsal room hire (40 hours) - £400
  • Costumes - £300
  • Props - £200
  • Set - £200
  • Publicity images/audio - £300
  • Lighting design - £200
  • Sound design - £100
  • Experiment consumables - £500
  • Travel (Glasgow-Edinburgh for Fringe run) - £1000
  • Flyering - £300
Total: £5000

All donated funds will be put to good use in bringing our show to life!

What You Get

In return for your kind support we are offering a range of perks:
  • A personal thank you on our social media and website
  • A personalised thank you video message from the Panto Science team
  • A selection of fun Panto Science experiments to try at home
  • A special programme signed by the cast and crew
  • An invitation to meet the cast and crew and take exclusive photos behind the scenes. Take a #ScienceSelfie with your favourite characters!
  • Your name or logo in our programme, distributed daily at our shows (audience of 380 x 25 shows = 9500 capacity)
  • Take home a prop!  Own a piece of Panto Science forever.
  • A once in a lifetime cameo in the show, plus reserved seating for your friends to watch your moment in the spotlight!
  • A warm and fuzzy feeling

The Impact

By supporting Panto Science, you'll be helping us share our passion for science - and pantomime - with hundreds of people at the biggest arts festival in the world! 

Science is often perceived by the public as too difficult, dull or confusing to learn, or reserved for the 'brainy' few. Children who do not see themselves as 'brainy' are unlikely to view science careers as achievable, even if they attain well in the subject. 

The gender gap in science remains a big challenge, with the UK ranking particularly poorly. A recent study by the OECD attributed poor performance among British girls to "a lack of self confidence" rather than a lack of ability.


Through Panto Science, we want to break down these perceived barriers. In particular, we hope to:

  • Use pantomime as a 'hook' to inspire an interest in science among children and families who would not otherwise engage with the subject. Panto Science will bring fun and engaging science to thousands of children.
  • Use interactive elements and audience participation to build confidence, have fun and show that anybody can do science!
  • Combat stereotypes about scientists and women scientists in particular.  By casting strong, female protagonists as role models, we hope to foster a positive image of women in science. No helpless princesses here! Snow White has a PhD and she knows how to use it.
  • Give scientists a place to develop skills in science communication and share their amazing (and often little-known!) research with the public. We'll be working closely with Glasgow Science Festival, the University of Glasgow and others to ensure the scientific integrity of the show and promote collaboration between scientists and artists.
Depending on the success of the Fringe run, we would love to take Panto Science on tour across the country. There is also scope to develop the production for schools as an education tool.  We are very excited about the possibilities!  It all starts here.


Risks & Challenges

Panto Science is led by a highly experienced and passionate team who care deeply about the project.

If we don't reach our funding target, every penny raised will still go towards putting on the best production we can with the resources available.


Other Ways You Can Help

Anything you can do to get the word out about the show is a huge help and greatly appreciated!  'Like' us on Facebook at /PantoScience and follow us on Twitter @PantoScience.  Visit and share our website at pantoscience.co.uk

You can also use the Indiegogo share tools to link to our campaign page.

Thank you for your support!  Let's make it happen.

story:
Mission Statement

“Dry with a Twist” is taken from how our founding director takes his martinis: gin, dry with a twist of lime, stirred never shaken. And in this we find our philosophy of theatre. We feel that theatre should be like a martini: made of top shelf material, crafted with care, precision and expertise, and with a presentation that is both classic and intriguing. With a twist. And by the end, one should be knocked on one’s ass.

When the Cat’s Away is a brand new comedy that tells the story of the Sea Hawk Inn on Nantucket Island. Its proprietor, Henry Gooding, disappeared at sea a year ago, and in his absence his son, Matthew, with the help of his cousin, Mark, has been throwing wild parties. Mrs. Wilder, the nosy neighbor of the Sea Hawk Inn, has had enough of the noise and Mark and Matthew are faced with eviction on the day they have planned their biggest party, a “midsummer masquerade”. Things become complicated when Iolana, a virginal courtesan, and her identical twin sister, Anastasia, arrive and fall in love with Matthew and Mark; the ever tipsy Luke and Lucille get into a jealous spat and Henry returns from sea. It is a madcap farce about sand, sorrow, and silliness which will receive its world premiere at the Robert Moss Theater in New York City with a three week Actors’ Equity Showcase Code production from June 18th through July 5th !

What We Need

With a big show, comes a big budget and we are hoping to raise roughly $15,000 which will help us secure our venue, provide the necessary insurance, rent and build costumes and set pieces, and jumpstart our marketing campaigns. Every cent helps us get closer to our goal, and we have several giving levels and exciting gifts for your contribution. Dry with a Twist Theatrics is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Dry with a Twist must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Our mission with this show is to invite everyone to the party. We've an enormous cast and crew and we want you to join us on this adventure! This is just one way you can.

The Impact

This production is a culmination of music, dance, theatre and humor. It's a massive show which will give opportunities to over thirty artists at all points in their careers, from those who are just starting out to those who've been working in the industry for fifty years! It's an incredible opportunity for this new work to be welcomed to life and for these actors, designers and all creative members to have their passionate work seen.

Risks & Challenges

We know that this is a huge budget, but without this stable financial grounding we won't be able to house, insure or produce our work. This is only a major fraction of our production costs and this funding will go directly to necessary elements like our venue, costumes, sets, insurance and marketing. It's an ambitious undertaking, but with your help we can make it happen!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that you may not be able to make a financial contribution at this time; you can support the campaign by helping us get the word out about our efforts. Please feel free to forward the information about our campaign to any friends and family who may be able to support us in our efforts and be sure to stay up to date with our progress by liking our page on Facebook www.facebook.com/whenthecatsawayplay.

You can also find a list of "in kind" donations that we'll need, like paint and brushes, newspaper and other items that you may have lying around the house, which can be donated. One man's trash is another man's production materials!


Thank you!

story:
Nancy Evans Dance Theatre (NEDT) is a collection of dance artists telling stories through movement under the artistic direction of Nancy Evans Doede. Our work exposes us—dancers and audience members—as imperfect, vulnerable, sometimes ludicrous… humans. Sweet Sorrow, an evening-length collaboration with guest choreographer and novelist Leigh Purtill, is the next step in our evolution as creators and performers. 

NEDT is raising funds to create the first phase of Sweet Sorrow. Using the language of dance we explore what becomes of Shakespeare’s Romeo and Juliet after their deaths. It is a dramatic contemporary ballet that explores the beauty of undying love in stark contrast to the gruesome embodiment of jealousy, revenge, and power. 

This new work is a media cross-over that blends story, theatre, improv, visual arts, design, and dance. NEDT is thrilled to be working with choreographer Leigh Purtill (original story & concept) and costume designer Jordan Waterman. 

NEDT aims to produce Act One of Sweet Sorrow in May of 2015 (May 29, 30 at 8PM & 31 at 4PM), with an evening length debut in the Fall of 2016.

Read more about the collaborative process from the choreographer's perspective.


The Cast

Katrina Amerine - Rosaline

Ashleigh Doede - Juliet

Scot Tupper - Romeo

Jenn Logan - Zombie Queen

Nancy Evans Doede - Apothecary

Jen Hunter - Zombie

Natalie Kramer - Zombie

Karina Jones - Zombie

Elise Holmes - Party Guest

Abby Quinn - Party Guest

Anna Biosca - Party Guest

Grace Tiangco - Party Guest


Production

Choreography by Leigh Purtill

Artistic Direction by Nancy Evans Doede

Costume Design by Jordan Waterman

Creative Direction & Marketing by Jenn Logan

Photography by Cortney Armitage & Karina Jones


$10,000 will fund:

- $1,200 cast performance fee (12 cast members at $100 for the run)

- $3,500 - $5,000 costumes

- $500 pointe shoes

- $700 Lighting Design/Technical Direction

- $250 make-up

- $450 photography

- $2,500 marketing/publicity

- $500 venue

Surplus funds will go to:

- Paying dancers for rehearsal time

- Local touring opportunities

- Paying our costume designer what he’s worth!

- Paying our choreographer!

A portion of your donation to the NEDT Indiegogo campaign will be tax-deductible. Nancy Evans Dance Theatre is in fiscal receivership under Outpost Theatre Ensemble.


Risks & Challenges

Like all creative endeavors this project comes with its own risks. If we are unable to raise all of the funds needed we will have to scale back on production. Costumes will be more basic and some set elements may eliminated. We are a very resourceful bunch though and are all deeply committed to this project. We will make it work!


Other Ways You Can Help

Come sees the show — Works 2015 is happening May 29, 30 & 31

For tickets visit: http://www.nancyevansdancetheatre.com

Like us on Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/pages/Nancy-Evans-Danc...

Follow us on Instagram @nancyevansdancetheatre

Tell your friends! Did we mention this is a ballet with zombies?!
