story:
InVersion Theatre is going places. And we need your help.


InVersion has relocated to New York City. Will, Rebecca and Johnny are excited to produce cutting edge theater in our new zip code – but it’s an expensive place!


New York City is the nexus of American theatre, but renting performance and rehearsal space here can cost more than an entire production elsewhere. So, we are asking for help from the extended InVersion family. And that means you!


We’re raising $7,500 in the next 30 days. This will allow us to premiere our new adaptation of Franz Kafka’s “The Metamorphosis.” It also makes our continued work on "The Most Excellent and Undead Tragedie of Romeo and Juliet" possible.  $7,500 is more than we’ve sought in the past, but it’s only a fraction of the cost of producing in New York City. Grants, partnerships with other organizations and private donations will also fund our work. But crowd-sourced fundraising is our favorite fundraising because it allows us to speak directly with you, the extended InVersion family. Many of you have been an integral part of our artistic conversation for years. We love you, and we hope the feeling's mutual. 


What Will Your Contribution Do?

  1. Secures rehearsal and performance locations.

  2. Compensates artists

  3. Builds sets and sews costumes

  4. Supports marketing and publicity pushes that will help familiarize people with our work

  5. Helps us pay the bills! Website, fiscal sponsorship, insurance, and all of the other odds and ends a company needs to make it work.


Follow us on social media for updates on these exciting productions. And join us on April 10th at the Drama League in TriBeCa for a sneak peek of "The Most Excellent and Undead Tragedie of Romeo and Juliet". Then check out our public workshop of “The Metamorphosis” this fall. Enjoy the full “Metamorphosis” in early 2016.

We're excited for you to join us in this new era of InVersion. If you have any questions, feel free to reach out to us at inversiontheatre@gmail.com.

story:
This fundraiser is to help Memories of Children get to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe in August 2015, one of the biggest art festivals in the world. This current group of performers are students at Stony Brook University on Long Island, where they most recently performed this piece in November. Their dedication inspired me to share their hard work and passion for this subject with the world. We have registered for the festival, but we do not have the means to get there or to perform yet. That’s where you come in. We are asking for $10,000 to help us pay for transportation, the performances, the space, and to help us finish getting our props, sets and costumes. We are offering different levels of perks for your generosity. But, of course, any donation will be greatly appreciated. As we are a non-profit organization, all donations are tax-deductible.

This trip to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe is an amazing, once in a lifetime opportunity. The festival focuses, not on main-stream, commercial theater, but on theater that pushes the boundaries of what we consider art. By going to the festival, we are able to perform for an international audience, as well as having an opportunity to see and enjoy other shows that are participating in the festival. We are a completely student run show, including the director and crew. We would be one of the youngest participants in the festival’s history. By being so young, we get to show the festival, and the world, that the festival's legacy will live on through our work. This, as well as spreading the message of the piece, has become the dream of the cast and crew.

Memories of Children is a multimedia interactive performance piece about those who endured the Holocaust. This production was originally created to teach young people about the Holocaust. According to a study done in 2014, a quarter of the world’s population is Anti-Semitic. We live in a society in which half the population has never met a Jew. A third of American’s do not believe that the Holocaust actually happened.  If the hatred that provoked the Holocaust is thought to be irrelevant to our time, we will allow it to happen again. This is proven by recent events in both the United Stares and Europe. Tolerance for all races, religions, and cultures should be actively fought for by every single human being.

Memories of Children helps us fight for this cause. In a little under an hour, we take the audience though an experience that helps open their eyes and broadens their perspectives. The audience leaves changed, a little more tolerant and the piece allows them to give a face to the nearly 6 million Jews who died because of hatred in the Holocaust. They need to be remembered as more than a number, because they were all people, they were all loved by someone, and their memory should be honored.

story:
Why fund The Accessible Theatre? 

The Accessible Theatre is founded to Create Art: With Everyone. The company was started by Producing Artistic Director Beth Peters with the aim of bringing theatre to special populations including adults and children with disabilities. 

  • We are committed to producing professional theatre that explores disability.
  • We create only high-quality educational programming with highly trained educators.
  • We help arts organizations enact strong policy around disability onstage - and off.
Your donation will makes Boston theatre more inclusive for all people, with and without disabilities. 

What we've accomplished since our last campaign!

Our last funding campaign closed a year ago, launching our first year of work. Since then we . . . 
  • Partnered with theatres such as Wheelock Family Theatre, American Repertory Theater and Central Square Theater to increase and improve their access programming.
  • Provided and consulted inclusive theatre education in Boston, Natick, Watertown, Cape Cod, and other communities.
  • Produced a Reading Series featuring new plays expressly exploring disability issues. 
  • Hired our first (very part time) employee
  • Started an "Access Army" of volunteers
  • Partnered on an American Associate for Theatre Education (AATE) event for Theatre in Our Schools Month, in March!

What We Need & What You Get

We need different kinds of support:

  • Administrative - to support personnel including American Sign Language interpreters and disability consultants, and simple things like postage and ink cartridges.
  • Artistic - to support hiring high-caliber artists with and without disabilities, and making it possible for them to perform, including transportation and support personnel. 
  • Educational - to support highly trained teachers to bring theatre to special environments including those serving adults and children with disabilities, and to provide supportive teaching tools for this worthy endeavor. 
  • We will use our funds equitably to support these aims and we will update you on our progress!

What you get:

  • An acknowledgement in print for the duration of our 2014-2015 season!
  • An online "shout-out" to thank you via social media!
  • A variety of acknowledgements ranging all the way up to . . .  2 pairs of complimentary tickets to the opening night performance of our first fully produced play (May 2014), acknowledgement on our website and in our program materials, and a personal thanks to you during our curtain speeches.
  • Check out our donor perks at each level! 

The Impact

  • Many theatres in Boston want to develop policies and personnel training so that they can better serve patrons with disabilities, but they don't know how to get started. We want to help them. 
  • Many artists with disabilities find that they are not even considered for roles in the Boston theatre scene. We want to see them onstage - in our shows and by educating existing organizations about diverse casting options, particularly for characters written with disabilities. 
  • Organizations serving people with disabilities are looking for theatre artists to serve their communities. We want to be the resource for theatre artists trained in work with special populations. We provide theatre education to diverse populations.
  • We are the only organization of this type in Boston. It is necessary that we succeed. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Join us on  facebook and twitter
  • Share this campaign with friends and colleagues, and show them you support us!
  • Email us to volunteer ! info@accessibletheatre.org

Learn more about us at http://accessibletheatre.org

story:
Short Summary

Social responsibility does not exempt from the obligation of individual responsibility. Let’s create art together, with the city’s most progressive company, in the city’s most open-minded theatre.

011 Production Group and Atrium Film-Theatre would like to collaborate on the premiere of Patrick Marber’s Closer, to be directed by the young Hungarian artist, Márk Radnai (26). The production will be the continuation of our two-year-old collaboration. 011 collects young, creative actors, artists, filmmakers, and designers, whom the management of Atrium Film-Theatre thinks important to support. The English playwright’s play premiered in 1997 in London; making Marber and his work immediately world-renowned. Since then, the play had been on the program of several Hungarian theatres.

Responsible for the program production in Atrium Film-Theatre is the English Language Theatre Charitable Foundation, which tends to its philanthropic cultural activity since 1991. With its programs and genre-diversity, the cultural center in Buda functions as a professional and local meeting point and host theatre. The program is made up by contemporary Hungarian and international theatre, dance, classical music, film, and fine art. For Atrium Film-Theatre, it is of utmost importance to assist contemporary young directors in staging their new projects. For the staging of this production – besides own and sponsorship resources – 011 Production Group and Atrium Film-Theatre would like to set up an Indiegogo project for the first time in their joint history to acquire the necessary funds.

With supporting our project, you contribute to…

- a young group working with new artistic methods and representing a fresh trend to prepare their next premiere

- helping young artists to produce the funds necessary for their work with an independent campaign

- furthermore, you get involved with the creation of a theatre performance

Premiere: 11th May, 2015. Budapest, Atrium Film-Theatre


Synopsis of the play

Patrick Marber’s play is about love, the desire to own each other, and revenge, and shows it through the story of four people. It is the love rectangle of two men and two women, where fundamentally lonesome and interdependent people look for happiness and fulfillment in each other, trying to redeem their own lives through one another.

In London a taxi accidentally hits a girl, who introduces herself to the passenger of the taxi as Alice when he is taking her to the hospital. Dan, who wants to be a journalist and works for a newspaper’s obituary column, is immediately mesmerized by the girl’s straightforwardness and strong sexual aura. Alice has just arrived at home from New York where she was working as a stripper. Dan writes a novel based on the girl’s story, and he does a photoshoot for publicity where he meets the older and less vulnerable Anna. Dan is unable to get Anna out of his head, so he starts writing in the photographer’s name on a sex-chat page to Larry, the doctor, who is dumbstruck by the dirty-mouthed erotica that Dan beleaguers him with. Dan goes even further: he arranges a date with the doctor in Anna’s name to an aquarium he knows is Anna’s favorite place…

The plot takes place in London where the photographer, the stripper, the writer, and the doctor fatalistically meet. They keep cheating on each other, and they are cheated on, too. Love is vital to them, but only if they cannot get it. If it is at hand, it’s not exciting anymore.

Kata DOBÓ as Anna

Judit OSVÁTH as Alice

Zsolt ANGER as Larry

Ádám KOVÁCS as Dan


Cast and Crew

Set design: Renátó CSEH

Costume design: Júlia Luca ERDŐS 

Dramaturge: Ambrus IVANYOS

Lighting design: Miklós MERVEL

Sound design: Zsolt BALOGH

Production manager: Nóra ZÁGONI

Assistant: Nikolett MAGÓCS

Head of Communication (011): Csaba GOSZTONYI

Project supervisor: László MAGÁCS

Project manager: Anna KUDRON

Director: Márk RADNAI

Cast:

Zsolt ANGER

Kata DOBÓ

Ádám KOVÁCS

Judit OSVÁTH

(Márk RADNAI and Renátó CSEH during planning the show.)

Set design for "Aquarium", "Exhibition" and "Home" scenes by Renátó CSEH

Set design for "Lapdance", "Restaurant" and "Museum" scenes by Renátó CSEH


About 011 Production Group 

Every theatre production has to create a unique world, system in which the spectator can recognise the events important for him through a series of partial truths; he can put the pieces together like in a puzzle. A good theatre is like the rabbit’s hole for us, where space and time changes every minute, where the actor turns into something different, he is a machine, a plant, an animal and human, statue and animation. Where the memories of our subconscious are connected to the main storyline with a thousand threads, where the numerous manifestations of the world around us can be animated within moments. Where in a concentrated moment I can feel the pouring rain, last year’s love, the fantasy comics or my latest family meal. Where the scenes don’t follow each other in a linear way, but every small unit can stand on its own as an individual vision, social message or even just an impression, but if I want, I can add to the plot by simply creating a story and going on writing my own story. The question ‘what is this scene or sentence doing here?’ cannot come up in theatre. It has to create a system in which these specks of dust roll by themselves and I can either identify myself with them or they disturb me. If the theatre doesn’t carry this kind of freedom, this kind of interpretation network, then it becomes predictable and transparent.

Since the founding of 011 Production Group they have created productions in a wide variety of genres. What connect them are the modern, non-conventional film-like narratives and visuals, furthermore, the experimentation with technologies not fundamentally connected to theatre. There is no company behind the group, though mostly they work with the same group of young actors in their productions. The members of the creative team are: Márk Radnai, director; Renátó Cseh, designer; and Ambrus Ivanyos, dramaturge. The performances aren’t usually created from already existing plays, but are written by the creative team, using actors’ improvisations, situation practices, and outside sources to create the script. The younger generation follows the production group’s work closely, as well. Another thing that makes 011 Production Group exceptional is that they create unique promotion campaigns for each of their performances. They have organised the first 011 Festival between 7-11 June, 2014, in Budapest.

WEB: www.011production.com (videos and more press information)

Facebook: www.facebook.com/011csoport

You can read some press releases about 011 Production Group’s previous works. You all know these stories and dramas, but the interpretation, the techniques, mixing the different art genres, and such a visual quality on stage is very unique.

3D MAPPING, NEW INTERPRETATION: MEANWHILE IN KANSAS

“The world of The Wizard of Oz was never exactly close to me. Márk Radnai and the production directed by him and, of course, the techniques used, however, offered an interpretation of the story through which an interpretation yet unknown was added to the stumbling along of Dorothy and her friends.”

http://www.szinhazkolonia.hu/kritika/Ozhoz-vezeto-utak

THE PILLOWMAN

“Director Márk Radnai has staged something that is rarely seen in Hungarian theatres. Martin McDonagh’s Pillowman namely mixes the genres of a thriller, a horror or a revenge play, a whodunit, a black comedy, and a political play.”

http://www.prae.hu/prae/articles_ny.php?aid=6948


About Atrium Film-Theatre 

Atrium Film-Theatre is a cultural center and theatre. The beautiful art deco building of Atrium was reborn after 12 years of neglect, with a new function and a new vocation. It was converted into a theatre, café, and community place, where art meets entertainment and quality leisure time. Its programs include contemporary Hungarian and international theatre, dance, and music performances; films and fine art. Besides offering public relations and artistic, technical, and financial support for artists, Atrium also stages its own productions every year, participates in theatre and performance festivals, and cooperates with cultural institutions. Atrium hosted „bEUgró” festival with almost 1500 performers, held as part of the jubilee celebrations of Hungary joining the European Union in 2004. Atrium’s current director, László Magács supervised the event.

Atrium opened its gates in October 2012, in Budapest. Atrium is a good example of how a civil association can build a new financial model to effectuate a cultural institute. Atrium’s funds come mostly from ticket sales and sponsorships, which give the financial base for the 10-13 premieres per season, the assistance to host several independent theatre companies, and to house around 250 performances and almost 60,000 visitors each year. Our technical facilities, the capacity, and the professional catering personnel make Atrium an ideal venue for various events in a wide variety of styles and forms. Atrium invites young artists, dramaturges, actors, directors, and designers to collaborate on projects. Atrium is open to artistic projects that discuss important social topics, such as gender issues, violence, social changes, and exclusion in Hungary. Both entertainment and education are an important part of the artistic concept, as well as offering a place for local and professional communities. The staff is skilled for both working on hosted shows, as well as on original productions, with an entire artistic crew at the ready.

Atrium is an important platform for international collaborations, utilizing the different areas of performing arts to create new productions. Film, contemporary visual culture, and the elements of theatre combined create the unique image of Atrium. The 20-years-old relationships of Merlin Theatre (the previous institute run by the foundation), and the European and American collaborations help us exhibit the most contemporary, new theatrical directions and successes in Budapest.

More detailed program (mostly HUN) 

www.atriumfilmszinhaz.hu

http://www.facebook.com/atriumfilmszinhaz


About Closer

English playwright, Patrick Marber’s play premiered in 1997 in London; making Marber and his work immediately world-renowned. Closer did not only conquer stages all around the globe, but the 2004 movie directed by Mike Nichols had famous actors like Natalie Portman, Julia Roberts, Jude Law, and Clive Owen starring in the lead roles.

In Hungary, several theatres had the play previously on show: the former Vidám Színpad (Central Theatre, 2006), Móricz Zsigmond Theatre (2009), Merlin Theatre (2011), Vörösmarty Theatre (2012), National Theatre of Pécs (2014).


What We Need & What You Get

With this Indiegogo campaign, we would like to raise $16,800 that would be distributed in the budget as follows:

Set and costume design: $7,500

Honorariums (director, dramaturge, assistant, actors, set and costume designers): $7,500

Advertising, PR: $1,800


Risks & Challenges

By 2015 the Hungarian culture funding has reached the point where the layer of consumers who can afford it need to step up and become a part of supporting culture, thus taking individual responsibility for it. Without it, the financing and freshness of culture, art and theatre, and the work of artistic communities will be impossible. The whole budget of the campaign will become a part of an easily traceable accounting system, with the whole accounting done by the charitable foundation behind Atrium (English Language Theatre Charitable Foundation), that will also be responsible for signing contracts with the creative personnel working on the production. 011 Production Group and Atrium aspire to create a clear and optimal budget with the campaign that will ensure the quality of the production.

theatre. It has to create a system in which these specks of dust roll by
themselves and I can either identify myself with them or they disturb me. If
the theatre doesn’t carry this kind of freedom, this kind of interpretation
network, then it becomes predictable and transparent. 


Since the founding of 011 Production Group
they have created productions in a wide variety of genres. What connect them
are the modern, non-conventional film-like narratives and visuals, furthermore,
the experimentation with technologies not fundamentally connected to theatre. There
is no company behind the group, though mostly they work with the same group of
young actors in their productions. The members of the creative team are: Márk
Radnai, director; Renátó Cseh, designer; and Ambrus Ivanyos, dramaturge. The
performances aren’t usually created from already existing plays, but are
written by the creative team, using actors’ improvisations, situation
practices, and outside sources to create the script. The younger generation
follows the production group’s work closely, as well. Another thing that makes
011 Production Group exceptional is that they create unique promotion campaigns
for each of their performances. They have organised the first 011 Festival
between 7-11 June, 2014, in Budapest.
WEB: www.011production.com (videos and more press information)
Facebook: www.facebook.com/011csoport
You can read
some press releases about 011 Production Group’s previous works. You all know
these stories and dramas, but the interpretation, the techniques, mixing the
different art genres, and such a visual quality on stage is very unique.
3D MAPPING,
NEW INTERPRETATION: MEANWHILE IN KANSAS
“The world
of The Wizard of Oz was never exactly
close to me. Márk Radnai and the production directed by him and, of course, the
techniques used, however, offered an interpretation of the story through which
an interpretation yet unknown was added to the stumbling along of Dorothy and
her friends.”
http://www.szinhazkolonia.hu/kritika/Ozhoz-vezeto-utak

THE PILLOWMAN
“Director
Márk Radnai has staged something that is rarely seen in Hungarian theatres.
Martin McDonagh’s Pillowman namely
mixes the genres of a thriller, a horror or a revenge play, a whodunit, a black
comedy, and a political play.”
http://www.prae.hu/prae/articles_ny.php?aid=6948


About 
Atrium Film-Theatre 

Atrium Film-Theatre
is a cultural center and theatre. The beautiful art deco building of Atrium was
reborn after 12 years of neglect, with a new function and a new vocation. It was
converted into a theatre, café, and community place, where art meets
entertainment and quality leisure time. Its programs include contemporary Hungarian
and international theatre, dance, and music performances; films and fine art.
Besides offering public relations and artistic, technical, and financial
support for artists, Atrium also stages its own productions every year,
participates in theatre and performance festivals, and cooperates with cultural
institutions. Atrium hosted „bEUgró” festival with almost 1500 performers, held
as part of the jubilee celebrations of Hungary joining the European Union in
2004. Atrium’s current director, László Magács supervised the event.
Atrium opened its
gates in October 2012, in Budapest. Atrium is a good example of how a civil
association can build a new financial model to effectuate a cultural institute.
Atrium’s funds come mostly from ticket sales and sponsorships, which give the
financial base for the 10-13 premieres per season, the assistance to host
several independent theatre companies, and to house around 250 performances and
almost 60,000 visitors each year. Our technical facilities, the capacity, and
the professional catering personnel make Atrium an ideal venue for various
events in a wide variety of styles and forms. Atrium invites young artists, dramaturges,
actors, directors, and designers to collaborate on projects. Atrium is open to artistic
projects that discuss important social topics, such as gender issues, violence,
social changes, and exclusion in Hungary. Both entertainment and education are
an important part of the artistic concept, as well as offering a place for
local and professional communities. The staff is skilled for both working on
hosted shows, as well as on original productions, with an entire artistic crew
at the ready.
Atrium is an
important platform for international collaborations, utilizing the different
areas of performing arts to create new productions. Film, contemporary visual
culture, and the elements of theatre combined create the unique image of
Atrium. The 20-years-old relationships of Merlin Theatre (the previous
institute run by the foundation), and the European and American collaborations
help us exhibit the most contemporary, new theatrical directions and successes
in Budapest.
More detailed program (mostly HUN)  
www.atriumfilmszinhaz.hu
http://www.facebook.com/atriumfilmszinhaz

About Closer

English
playwright, Patrick Marber’s play premiered in 1997 in London; making Marber
and his work immediately world-renowned. Closer
did not only conquer stages all around the globe, but the 2004 movie directed
by Mike Nichols had famous actors like Natalie Portman, Julia Roberts, Jude
Law, and Clive Owen starring in the lead roles.
In Hungary,
several theatres had the play previously on show: the former Vidám Színpad (Central
Theatre, 2006), Móricz Zsigmond Theatre (2009), Merlin Theatre (2011),
Vörösmarty Theatre (2012), National Theatre of Pécs (2014).



   What We Need & What You Get 
With this Indiegogo
campaign, we would like to raise $16,800 that would be distributed in the
budget as follows:
Set and
costume design: $7,500
Honorariums
(director, dramaturge, assistant, actors, set and costume designers): $7,500
Advertising,
PR: $1,800


Risks & Challenges  
By 2015 the Hungarian culture funding has reached the point where the
layer of consumers who can afford it need to step up and become a part of
supporting culture, thus taking individual responsibility for it. Without it,
the financing and freshness of culture, art and theatre, and the work of
artistic communities will be impossible. The whole budget of the campaign will
become a part of an easily traceable accounting system, with the whole
accounting done by the charitable foundation behind Atrium (English Language
Theatre Charitable Foundation), that will also be responsible for signing
contracts with the creative personnel working on the production. 011 Production
Group and Atrium aspire to create a clear and optimal budget with the campaign
that will ensure the quality of the production.

story:
About:

CoreDance Contemporary is an Australian Modern Dance Company residing in New York City. Founded by Artistic Director Rebecca McCormac in March 2011, the company is comprised of seven female dance artists who bring different cultural and dance backgrounds to the fore, to form a hardworking and dedicated ensemble.

CoreDances' objective is to investigate choreographically, different and oft times contradictory movement vocabulary through the physicality of one’s kinetics and to explore the realization of this physicality as it takes form in the space.  Ms McCormac has an interdisciplinary approach to her work drawing ideas both contextually and visually to create work that is engaging for herself and her audience.  CoreDance has presented work at:  APAP, Your Move NJ, Alvin Ailey, Steps on Broadway, DANY Studios, PMT, Dixon Place, White Wave, Triskelion Arts and Green Space. 

Campaign:

CoreDance Contemporary's "From Without And Within" Campaign is being launched to assist the company produce and present it's 2015 Spring Season.  This venture is an important goal at this stage in the company's timeline as we are trying to make a name for ourselves in the ever competitive dance industry that is New York City.  Contributions will help pay for:

*  Theatre Rental

*  Rehearsal Space

*  Costume Design and Manufacture

*  Graphic Design and Printing for Marketing Purposes

*  Lighting Design

*  Videography

Goal:

Our goal is to raise $1000.00 to help with production values.  If our goal is not reached the amount obtained will be used solely for Theatre Rental at The Actors Fund Arts Center in Brooklyn, NY.

Perks:

We are providing an opportunity to observe CoreDance Contemporary in Rehearsal to anyone who contributes $50.00.

Any contribution is helpful, so even if you can't make one of monetary value we would just love it if you could spread the word and make some noise about our campaign. 

You can find us at www.coredance.com.au and/or  www.facebook/CoreDanceContemporary and or use the Indiegogo Share Tools!

To reserve tickets to "From Without And Within" please visit:  

http://fromwithoutandwithin.bpt.me

Thanks so much for showing your interest in our campaign.

Artistic Director:  Rebecca McCormac

Dance Artists:  Rebecca Allen, Kate Bishop, Rose Buis, Kate Dougherty, Hsia-Hua Liang, Jessica Nolan and Erica Saucedo

story:
Short Summary

Welcome to our Indiegogo page!

We would like to thank you for visiting our page and taking an interest in our project.  As you will see from our video, we already had a trial run of our show last year and it went very well. Our aim is to build a following for the show and we need your help to take the show to the Fringe. We are a hard working, well organised team with a talented cast and hilarious script and with your help we can make our run at the Fringe, a roaring success.

What We Need & What You Get

• We have been working on this show for over a year now, getting the script just right by trialling the show in front of an audience and getting feedback from The Comedy Unit and Channel 4 Comedy. Your contributions will help us take it to the next level.

• We have a professional team of make up artists, stage production crew and actors and as well as paying for production and promotion of the show we need to make sure these guys are fed and watered and have somewhere to rest their head during their time at the Fringe. Your contributions can help make that happen. 

• As we have already produced the show last year, we have the advantage of having our set, props and costumes all ready to go but we still need to pay for a theatre venue, insurance, registration costs, advertising, travel, accommodation and expenses. 

• We will be doing our best to fill the theatre and sell as many tickets as possible  but the Fringe is an expensive festival and even if we sell out our shows there is no guarantee we will be able to cover our expenses. Which is why we need money raised from crowdfunding and sponsors to help us cover the costs.

• We hope that our unique perks will encourage you to part with your hard earned cash, some examples of these are: a sneak peek at our latest feature film "The Bench" before anyone else, VIP treatment and playing the dead body in the opening act of the show – and even a private performance of the show in your living room!

• We also want to say that we will use all donations with the greatest of care and gratitude.

The Impact

"The Graduettes" began as a sitcom pilot and a further five episodes were written. The fourth episode "The Girls Solve a Murder" was chosen to be performed as a live sitcom for two nights in Glasgow in August 2014. After the show, the script (now in it's 8th draft) was sent to The Comedy Unit and Channel 4 Comedy as well as the BBC Writers room, the feedback from these sources and the audience at the Webster's Theatre was used to perfect the script. Before we tell you a little about the impact you can make by donating to the film, let us tell you a bit about the story.


Described as Sex and the City meets The Inbetweeners or a Scottish version of It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia - The Graduettes tells the story of three girls who graduate from University and realise life is not everything they thought it would be. Sophie and Andrew barely know each other when they find out they are having a baby, Rachel is a virtual recluse who hasn't gotten out of her PJs since she heard she had cancer and Grace is strict Christian who only likes spooning - and hand jobs.

In the stage play, Andrew's mother is coming to Christmas dinner where she will meet Sophie for the first time and find out she is pregnant. Rachel has recently split up with her longterm boyfriend and Grace thinks she might be hash-tag lesbian. When the girls find the landlady dead on their newly polished floors they must decide whether to hide the body or solve the crime before Sophie's future mother-in-law arrives.

This is a story about friendship, self discovery and romance - actually it's about dead bodies, porn, lesbians, dodgy websites, stolen babies, handguns and learning how to change a nappy - but at some point they put up with their friends. 

 We can’t take this project to the Fringe without funding and sponsorship so the impact that our backers have by donating any amount is absolutely massive and so greatly appreciated.

Risks & Challenges

There is always the risk that we won't raise the amount we need from Crowdfunding alone, that is why as well as our Indiegogo campaign, we are talking to small businesses about sponsorship, as well as putting on five nights of the show in Glasgow at The Webster's Theatre in April to help spread word of mouth and raise funds for the show. We will also be filming the show in Glasgow and selling DVDs packed with extras to raise more funds.

Other Ways You Can Help

We  understand that sometimes it is not possible to contribute financially so we would also like to stress that we would love to have your support in any way. 


If you are able to spread the word and let people know about the film then that is a huge help to us and the Indiegogo share tools are easy to use.

If you have enjoyed finding out about our project "The Graduettes" then please share share and share some more! 

Again, we would like to thank you very much for taking the time to have a look at our page!

story:
Short Summary

“BOSS: The Untold Danza Story” is the 2014 Hollywood Fringe Festival Producer’s Encore Award-winning play from Damien Luvara and Jennifer Monce.  As a kid, Damien was inspired by Tony's work on "Who's The Boss" and wanted to pay homage to one of his childhood heroes.  Since opening, the show has grown and been lauded by audiences! At a new home at the Complex Theaters in Hollywood, the newest version of “BOSS” is set for it’s first extended run!  But we need your help!



What We Need & What You Get

Here's a little breakdown of what the money goes towards:


-Theater rental

-Technical needs for the show

-Advertising

-Costumes

-Programs


If we don't raise all of our goal, then what  money we do get goes towards the cost of the space first.


For those of you who want to contribute but don't live in the area, don't fret! In lieu of a physical ticket to the show, we will make sure you get a link to watch the taped show from the comfort of your own home!


Now, of course, we are obligated to tell you that the delivery of rewards or perks are subject to best efforts and not guaranteed. We don't foresee this being a problem, but we gotta throw it in there. Just in case. And we thank you from the bottom of our Danza-loving hearts for understanding!

               



The Impact

We have a great producer who is helping us push this show and your contribution, no matter what the size, helps us make “BOSS” available to new audiences!  Help spread the gospel of Danza!



Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word for us! If you don't feel that you can contribute monetarily, then you would help us out enormously by spreading the word! Social media like Twitter and Facebook, as well as word of mouth, are fantastic ways to spread the Fanza love! #untolddanza

story:
What is Miss Saigon?

Miss Saigon is a musical based off of Puccini's Madame Butterfly, inspired by the fall of Saigon in 1975, and written by the same composers/lyricists as "Les Miserables": Claude-Michel Schoenberg and Alain Boublil. In the show, Chris, a disillusioned soldier in Vietnam, discovers new life when he meets Kim, a simple girl from the Vietnam countryside, at a local stripclub/brothel. As their romance blossoms, Vietnam begins to fall apart, forcing them to make important decisions about their future with the "help" of Chris' army buddy, John, and a local pimp and facilitator, simply known as "The Engineer." 

Who is the production team?

The director/co-producer is film & TV actor and magician Naathan Phan [Currently typing. Hi!]. We also have Marla Ladd as producer and artistic director, Kevin Phan as musical director, Rob Ramirez as vocal director, Alison Boresi as choreographer, Eugene MacDonald as set designer, and Paul Thomas Kosmala as lighting designer.
Why are you mounting this production?
This year marks 40 years since the fall of Saigon (learn more about it here: www.wikipedia.org/wiki/fall_of_saigon), which is when Naathan's parents came to the United States. We feel that opening this show on April 30th (the first day of the fall of Saigon in 1975) is culturally significant especially given the large Vietnamese population in Southern California.

What makes this production so special?

The director is Vietnamese and is using his family's history and direct involvement in the events that happened in Vietnam in 1975 to help the actors understand the show and their characters better. This is also going to be a production that emphasizes the story by utilizing live musicians and cutting down on the "spectacle" which the director feels can detract from the story. Marveling at the theater's technical capabilities can take an audience out of the moment. We specifically selected a smaller theater (134 seats) with an intimate feel to be able to scale down the production and tell the story in a different way without compromising the artistic value and heart of the piece.

What do you need the money for?

Without going into too much boring detail:
  • $1,600 to recoup the money Naathan fronted for the rights to a 4 weekend run.
  • $2,800 to pay the crew and production team (i.e. musical director, choregrapher, set designer, lighting designer, music arranger, stage manager, prop master, etc.) [Myself not included]
  • $5,600 to pay the live 8 piece band that will be accompanying each performance
  • $6,000 to compensate the actors (i.e. rehearsal and performance stipend, which is nowhere near non-union professional theatre pay)
  • $1,000 to advertise the show.

What if you raise less than $17,000?

Mysterium Theater does have funds set aside for the show, but I know that they are also preparing for a very ambitious year of shows at the space and I would like to help them out as much as possible. However, I am prepared to make up the difference from my own pocket where needed and even not get my money back for paying for the rights. I have started the casting process and most of the actors I've spoken to are will to do the show without compensation so that would be the first place to cut money from the budget. Some of the production team and crew are also willing to take a cut in pay if necessary. I can also cut down on the advertising budget. As long as we can raise $6,000 for essential crew, production team, and musicians, we can get by. But I'd much rather the production flourish and thrive than barely scrape by... wouldn't you?

What if you raise more than $17,000?

Everyone gets paid more! [Except me, haha.] As I mentioned earlier, the stipends I'm offering the actors are a few dollars away from being insulting so that's probably the first place extra funds would go. Some of the production team are friends who have agreed to do this for substantially less than they normally charge so I'd also like to pay them more. More money for advertising also couldn't hurt, maybe air an advertisement for the show on local television.

A note from the director:

Thank you so much for even visiting this page. Obviously because of my heritage, this project means a lot to me. I was in a production of this show once, years ago, and I was disappointed by the casting; two leading and one supporting characters that are supposed to be Vietnamese, played by Caucasian actors. Don't get me wrong, they were great actors and played their parts wonderfully, but I think the piece loses something without the right ethnic look for certain characters... especially with a show that is centered around race as much as this one is. And given my background and family history, I know I can bring a different and more authentic feel to this show. I know there are many much more worthy and noble projects on IndieGoGo and times are still tough for many people, so if you can't or won't donate, please share this project on social media: Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, whatever; Every dollar and every share helps. Thanks again and I hope to see you at the show!
Cheers,
"Naathan" Bao Quoc Gia Phan

I have started the casting process and most of the actors I've spoken to are will to do the show without compensation so that would be the first place to cut money from the budget. Some of the production team and crew are also willing to take a cut in pay if necessary. I can also cut down on the advertising budget. As long as we can raise $6,000 for essential crew, production team, and musicians, we can get by. But I'd much rather the production flourish and thrive than barely scrape by... wouldn't you?


What if you raise more than $17,000?
Everyone gets paid more! [Except me, haha.] As I mentioned earlier, the stipends I'm offering the actors are a few dollars away from being insulting so that's probably the first place extra funds would go. Some of the production team are friends who have agreed to do this for substantially less than they normally charge so I'd also like to pay them more. More money for advertising also couldn't hurt, maybe air an advertisement for the show on local television.


    
A note from the director:

Thank you so much for even visiting this page. Obviously because of my heritage, this project means a lot to me. I was in a production of this show once, years ago, and I was disappointed by the casting; two leading and one supporting characters that are supposed to be Vietnamese, played by Caucasian actors. Don't get me wrong, they were great actors and played their parts wonderfully, but I think the piece loses something without the right ethnic look for certain characters... especially with a show that is centered around race as much as this one is. And given my background and family history, I know I can bring a different and more authentic feel to this show. I know there are many much more worthy and noble projects on IndieGoGo and times are still tough for many people, so if you can't or won't donate, please share this project on social media: Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, whatever; Every dollar and every share helps. Thanks again and I hope to see you at the show!Cheers,"Naathan" Bao Quoc Gia Phan

story:
Who are We?

Dex! the killer musical is an all-volunteer team of NYC based theater professionals with one thing in common - a love of Dexter. We want to share this project with fans across the world and we need your help! After a successful set of Cabaret performances at "Times Scare" and "54 Below" "Dex!" has been accepted to the NYC Fringe Festival for 5 performances at the Lynn Redgrave Theater with prospects for an off-broadway run. This is where you come in! Browse the list of incentives to the right, and find out how you can share in the fun. From blood-slide keychains to signed posters from our wondeful cast, we're hoping to bring "Dex!" to fans everywhere. We even have ways to bring the show to you! 

What We Need & What You Get

Since we're an all volunteer team, expenses are tight - crowdfunding has become an excellent way to spread word and show producers that a show has legs. We all passionately believe in "Dex!" and need your help to spread the word. By donating at least $5, you're joining "Team Dex!" and letting us know you want to see Dex! up in lights!

Donate higher and there's all kinds of excellent rewards waiting for you. Can't make it to the big apple for the bloodfest in person? No problem! Since all work on the show (to date) has been the work of fans like you - we have full rights to share the songs and performances with the backers of our work - including the upcoming fringe festival performance!

We are also excited to announce that the Elektra Theater is willing to host "Dex!" for an off-broadway run (following the closing of the 50 Shades parody musical and Silence! the musical) but for that we need to realize the show. NYC Fringe shows the world we have a show and our next step is getting it produced.


The Impact

Producing an off-broadway show requires multiple departments working together to make it a success. From costumes, lights, scenery, props, sound, video & management - the list goes on and on. Each department needs resources. By donating to "Dex!" -  you're not only helping make a grassroots musical come to life - but you're also helping add resources to the toolkits of each department, which attracts better talent for our show and ultimately, makes it that much more impressive.

Additionally, with the advent of crowdfunding - the show stays in the hands of those who helped make it come to life. Instead of one or two large producers coming in with big wallets and calling all the shots, by raising the money socially, we get to keep "Dex!" in the hands of the fans.


Risks & Challenges

Producing theater always carries the risk of flopping. Not getting the word out, bad PR, weak performances or scripts - these all contribute to the reasons a show may or may not take. Buzz is already in the air however for Dex! to be a hit and with your help we can spread the word and ensure we get the butts in seats we need to make the show a hit


Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign with your friends and fellow fans! No contribution is too small. Tweet about it, share it on your Facebook wall, Reddit about your passion for musical theater and blood and help spread the word!

story:
Our Project

At freeFall Theatre, we pride ourselves on presenting theatre with acoustic sound. This is very rare especially in musical theatre. We rarely amplify a production, and only when it is important for the style of the show (usually rock musicals). But sometimes this presents a challenge for audience members who experience hearing loss.

We need your help to install an infrared assisted listening system, so that our patrons with diminished hearing can be better served when they come to see our award-winning theatre. We can't wait to see those bright eyes and smiling faces replace the squinty eyes and whispers of "what did he say?" when an audience member has trouble hearing.

This technology will also create the future possibility of offering audio described performances and other types of enhancements to create greater access and enjoyment of our work.

Our Goals

We need $5,740 to purchase and install the basic system with 5 headsets for use at each performance. If we can stretch that goal and raise $7,720, we can offer twice as many headsets at each performance, a total of 10.

How it works

An array of four Sennheiser ME66 shotgun mics will capture high quality audio from the entire performance space.

This audio signal is sent to a number of infrared transmitters that project the signal around the room with technology similar to what your household TV remote uses.

This signal is picked up by the headset that the patron wears. These headsets will be offered free of charge to patrons who need them. If we meet our goal ($5,740) we will be able to offer 5 of these at each performance. If we reach our stretch goal($7,720) we can offer 10!

story:
My name is Caroline Horton, I am a theatre maker. My new show Islands has been lifting the lid on the poisonous world of tax havens. Since it premiered earlier in the year, all has gone very quiet on the tax evasion front following the general election. Excitingly, we’ve been invited to present Islands at the British Council Showcase at Edinburgh Festival Fringe this summer. So, this time round and with your help, we’d like to make an even bigger racket!

THE SHOW

Islands is an obscene, ink-black comedy about tax havens, greed and the few who have it all. Olivier nominee Caroline Horton (Chrissy, Mess, Penelope Retold) and her foul ensemble plunge us into a monstrous world where no-one has to pay… for anything.

Islands spits in the face of polite political debate. Incandescent with rage, it hurls out images of the putrid end-times of ultimate freedom and the rotten, violent underbelly of offshore finance.

‘…the year’s most talked about piece of theatre’ - Andrew Haydon, Postcards from the Gods

'a disgusting, exuberant, foul, eloquent, lavatorial, piece of popular theatre mashed up with performance art' - Dan Rebellato, Spilled Ink

A BIGGER RACKET

We were so grateful to those of you who supported us for the Islands premiere enabling us to create one of the most talked about shows this year. We now have the extraordinary opportunity to present Islands as part of the British Council Showcase at Edinburgh Festival Fringe in August. The show was seen by over 3,500 at the Bush Theatre alone; performing as part of the British Council showcase means that we have the potential to reach a much bigger audience (and hopefully an international one) spreading our very own brand of disgust about offshore finance and tax evasion. We’d love you to help us keep making a stink.

Taking work to the Edinburgh Fringe is an extremely costly experience. We have been successful in securing some financial support from our venue partners, but even with ambitious box office targets (and me re-running my first show You’re Not Like The Other Girls Chrissy at the fringe too!) this still leaves us £1500 short of breaking even. So many of you have supported the show already and we completely understand if you can’t support us on this occasion, and I know many of you will have as little spare cash as this show or are attempting to fund your own projects at the moment, we’d be so grateful if you could shout about our campaign on social media or forward it onto anyone you think might be interested.

WHY PUT ON A PLAY ABOUT TAX HAVENS?

Oxfam estimates that there is $18.5 trillion siphoned out of the world economy into tax havens by wealthy individuals alone. Christian Aid has calculated that the lives of 350,000 children under the age of five could be saved every year by tackling corporate tax abuses. This is not just a political or economic problem; it's a matter of human rights.

In the last years and especially in the run up to the recent election, we’ve heard a lot about tax avoidance in the news, and the occasional strongly worded "ticking off" is issued by a government minister or the G8 - there's a reluctance to act because we're scared of big business taking their big business elsewhere. Governments are reluctant to clean up their own back yards - happily pointing fingers at Jersey or the Cayman Islands whilst conveniently disregarding the City of London right here on our doorstep. So we allow the charade to continue and taxes continue to be ‘just for the little people’ - everyone else does what they like.

The Edinburgh Showcase gives us an even greater opportunity to make some noise about it, in our own way.

I teamed up once again with producers China Plate, Warwick Arts Centre and for this project, the Bush Theatre in London, Harlow Playhouse and The Tax Justice Network.

"I have spent my career investigating the scandal of Britain's tax haven empire. The political failure to tackle this scandal epitomises the corruption and hypocrisy at the heart of our Establishment." John Christensen, Director, The Tax Justice Network.

"As you know, I have made fighting the scourge of tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance a priority…" David Cameron

Well ... while good intentions aren't to be dismissed, we thought the PM might need a hand.

And so do we! 

HOW YOU CAN HELP 

Any contribution large or small will be greatly appreciated to offset the costs of accommodation and travel for the team in Edinburgh. In return we’d love to thank you with a bunch of excellent rewards especially sourced for our Islands backers – we hope you enjoy them! 

 If you’d like to know more about me, the company or the show check out: carolinehorton.net, chinaplatetheatre.com, @carolineplays, #IslandsPlay

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

Islands is an ambitious and uncomfortable piece of theatre. During the run at the Bush Theatre in January 2015 it comprehensively split the critics prompting a very active media debate about the piece.

The British Council were hugely excited about the show and have demonstrated great faith in it in programming it for their International Showcase. This exceptional opportunity will give us the chance to put it on in front of promoters and programmers from around the world helping us ensure that its impact continues long into the future.

story:
Who we are

We are Flying High Theatre Company. We are a group of young people aged 15-19 who have a real passion for theatre and the arts. Being a part of Flying High has provided us with the opportunity to perform in productions at theatres and venues around the UK, such as Sheffield Crucible, Derby Theatre, Nottingham Playhouse, Edinburgh Fringe Festival and the celebrated National Theatre in London.

What we are doing

This year we will be performing an adaptation of William Shakespeare's A Midsummer Nights Dream at the fringe from the 7th-22nd of August and with this being our 8th year at the festival, we want to have as great an experience as the previous years.

A Midsummer Night's Dream

theSpace @ Niddry Street

Aug 7-8, 10-15, 17-22

12:30pm (50 mins)

This adaptation of A Midsummer Night's Dream is based on the dreams of the characters and their worlds linked to the bizarre, magical mishaps in the forest. The lovers, mechanicals and fairy worlds collide and are orchestrated by the mischievous sprite Puck in a visual, musical portrayal of one of Shakespeare's best loved plays. There are dark moments contrasted with comedy and farce but the magic of the dream pervades and will appeal to all ages. **** (BroadwayBaby.com and ThreeWeeks 2013 and 2014).

Previous Shows

                    Forty-Five Minutes                                                     Jungle Book

                      Alice by Heart                                                   Peter Pan

“An energetic young cast deliver a slick performance capturing the kookiness and humour that is synonymous with Carroll's Wonderland tales.” – **** Three Weeks (2013)

“Flying High Theatre Company is aptly named; that is exactly what this group of lively youngsters do throughout this performance.” – **** Broadway Baby (2014)

“The acting as a whole was largely impressive… a recommendable adaptation for both those who are new to the material and those who know it well.” – *** Broadway Baby (2014)

What we're hoping for

We are looking to raise £2,500 to help the company of 24 with costumes and living cost whilst at the festival. With your contributions you will not only be helping us with dressing and feeding the company but also providing us with the chance to see pieces of theatre that will inspire and motivate us in our passion for theatre. 

We are a young peoples company and so anything you can contribute will be very much appreciated, as you will helping to provide us with a great experience as part of one the world's largest arts festivals, for which some of the company members is their first time.

What you will receive

As a thank you for your donations you will receive something in return, for example for a £10 donation you will receive a a signed copy of the shows poster or a £50  donation will provide you with 2 free tickets to either our Nottingham previews on the 4th August or to any of our shows in Edinburgh.

Thank you in advance for your consideration and we hope you can find something to contribute. If not, thank you anyway and help us to raise our funds by spreading the word either via our twitter: @FlyingHighCo or via Facebook Flying High Theatre Company.

Thank you again and happy donating

Flying High Theatre Company

story:
UN GRAZIE A TUTTI QUELLI CHE HANNO CREDUTO IN NOI!


...ED ORA VI ASPETTIAMO A VEDERE LO SPETTACOLO!

                                             Beyond Vanja al Teatro Litta


Il Progetto

Una rilettura nuova, in chiave contemporanea del capolavoro “Zio Vanja” senza snaturarne le tematiche, il clima e la storia che Cechov ci ha trasmesso attraverso i suoi testi.


Perché scegliere un  testo classico in un periodo storico dove siamo idealmente sempre più spinti verso la drammaturgia contemporanea?

Primo su tutti la voglia di raccontare l'identità dell'uomo, attraverso i personaggi cechoviani, nei quali ritroviamo una contemporaneità disarmante.

Secondo motivo, non meno importante del primo, il rinnovare una scelta già proposta in altre occasioni, il voler sperimentare partendo dall’elaborazione drammaturgica anche attraverso la sottrazione di alcuni personaggi; ciò non si traduce nella loro assenza, ma al contrario essi sono presenti nelle parole e nel pensiero degli altri.

C'è inoltre la volontà di proseguire il percorso che il Teatro del Simposio ha intrapreso, ossia quello di contaminare i nostri lavori con altre forme espressive, come l’arte performativa, l’installazione, il lighting design. In tale contesto la scelta del titolo, “Beyond Vanja”, indica proprio questa necessità di andare oltre la semplice trasposizione del testo, cercando invece nuove forme di rappresentazione senza mai tradire l’essenza delle atmosfere e delle tematiche.


Il tuo contributo potrà coprire i costi relativi a

·  riconoscimento agli attori per le prove,

·  riconoscimento per l'aiuto regia, 

·  consulenze per la scenografia,

·  consulenze per i costumi,

·  consulenze per il lighting design,

·  scenografie,

·  costumi,

·  materiali di scena,

·  oneri organizzativi.

Vogliamo che sia sostenuto da coloro che amano il teatro, l'arte, la cultura, ciò che ci rende migliori. Ragioni sufficienti per aiutarci a realizzare questo nostro progetto che sarà presentato a in prima nazionale a novembre a Milano, al teatro Litta (sala La Cavallerizza, dal 17 al 27 novembre)

Vi chiediamo di sostenere il nostro progetto, perché pensiamo che il modo migliore per aiutare il teatro italiano, in special modo chi lo fa basandosi solo sulle proprie forze ed entusiasmo, sia quello di fare gruppo, seguire la realizzazione di uno spettacolo in maniera attiva, e assistere poi alla messa in scena finale.

Soprattutto, potrai essere felice di aver contribuito a tenere ancora vivo il teatro che si autoproduce.

Ricompense

Per ringraziarvi abbiamo pensato ad alcune ricompense:

donando 10 €  riceverai un ringraziamento ufficiale sui nostri canali (sito, social network)

donando 25 €, un biglietto ridotto per lo spettacolo + ringraziamento ufficiale sui nostri canali

con 50 €, un biglietto ridotto per lo spettacolo + un bicchiere di vino con la compagnia + ringraziamento ufficiale sui nostri canali

con 100 € 1 biglietto omaggio per lo spettacolo + un bicchiere di vino con la compagnia+ DVD dello spettacolo + ringraziamento ufficiale sui nostri canali

donando 200 € riceverai 2 biglietti omaggio per lo spettacolo + 2 bicchieri di vino con la compagnia +  DVD dello spettacolo + ringraziamento ufficiale sui nostri canali

chi vorrà sostenerci con 400 € riceverà 2 biglietti omaggio per lo spettacolo + 2 biglietti ridotti + una cena con la compagnia +  DVD dello spettacolo + ringraziamento ufficiale sui nostri canali


Grazie in anticipo se vorrai far parte di questo sogno. Se invece non te la senti di sostenerci economicamente, ma pensi che qualcuno dei tuoi amici potrebbe farlo, puoi aiutarci segnalando il nostro progetto a chiunque tu ritenga opportuno!
story_txt:
UN GRAZIE A TUTTI QUELLI CHE HANNO CREDUTO IN NOI!

...ED ORA VI ASPETTIAMO A VEDERE LO SPETTACOLO!
                                             Beyond Vanja al Teatro Litta

Il Progetto 
Una rilettura nuova, in chiave contemporanea del capolavoro “Zio Vanja”
senza snaturarne le tematiche, il clima e la storia che Cechov ci ha trasmesso
attraverso i suoi testi.


Perché scegliere un  testo classico in un periodo storico dove siamo
idealmente sempre più spinti verso la drammaturgia contemporanea?
Primo su tutti la voglia di raccontare l'identità dell'uomo, attraverso i
personaggi cechoviani, nei quali ritroviamo una contemporaneità disarmante.
Secondo motivo, non meno importante del primo, il rinnovare una scelta già
proposta in altre occasioni, il voler sperimentare partendo dall’elaborazione
drammaturgica anche attraverso la sottrazione di alcuni personaggi; ciò non si
traduce nella loro assenza, ma al contrario essi sono presenti nelle parole e
nel pensiero degli altri.
C'è inoltre la volontà di proseguire il percorso che il Teatro del Simposio
ha intrapreso, ossia quello di contaminare i nostri lavori con altre forme espressive,
come l’arte performativa, l’installazione, il lighting design. In tale contesto la
scelta del titolo, “Beyond Vanja”, indica proprio questa necessità di
andare oltre la semplice trasposizione del testo, cercando invece nuove forme
di rappresentazione senza mai tradire l’essenza delle atmosfere e delle
tematiche. 

Il tuo contributo potrà
coprire i costi relativi a 
·  riconoscimento agli attori per le prove, 
·  riconoscimento per l'aiuto regia, 

·  consulenze per la scenografia, 
·  consulenze per i costumi,
· 
consulenze per il lighting design,
·  scenografie, 
·  costumi,
·  materiali di scena,
·  oneri organizzativi.
Vogliamo che sia sostenuto da coloro che amano il teatro, l'arte, la
cultura, ciò che ci rende migliori. Ragioni sufficienti per aiutarci a
realizzare questo nostro progetto che sarà presentato a in prima nazionale a
novembre a Milano, al teatro Litta (sala La Cavallerizza, dal 17 al 27
novembre) 
Vi chiediamo di sostenere il nostro progetto, perché pensiamo che il modo
migliore per aiutare il teatro italiano, in special modo chi lo fa basandosi
solo sulle proprie forze ed entusiasmo, sia quello di fare gruppo, seguire la
realizzazione di uno spettacolo in maniera attiva, e assistere poi alla messa
in scena finale. 
Soprattutto, potrai essere felice di aver
contribuito a tenere ancora vivo il teatro che si autoproduce.

Ricompense
Per ringraziarvi abbiamo pensato ad alcune ricompense: 
donando 10 €  riceverai
un ringraziamento ufficiale sui nostri canali (sito, social network) 
donando 25 €, un biglietto ridotto per lo
spettacolo + ringraziamento ufficiale sui nostri canali
con 50 €, un biglietto ridotto per lo spettacolo +
un bicchiere di vino con la compagnia + ringraziamento ufficiale sui nostri
canali 
con 100 € 1 biglietto omaggio per lo spettacolo +
un bicchiere di vino con la compagnia+ DVD dello spettacolo + ringraziamento
ufficiale sui nostri canali
donando 200 € riceverai 2 biglietti omaggio per
lo spettacolo + 2 bicchieri di vino con la compagnia +  DVD dello
spettacolo + ringraziamento ufficiale sui nostri canali
chi vorrà sostenerci con 400 € riceverà 2 biglietti
omaggio per lo spettacolo + 2 biglietti ridotti + una cena con la compagnia +  DVD dello spettacolo + ringraziamento ufficiale sui nostri canali

Grazie in anticipo se vorrai far
parte di questo sogno. Se invece non te la senti di
sostenerci economicamente, ma pensi che qualcuno dei tuoi amici
potrebbe farlo, puoi aiutarci segnalando il nostro progetto a
chiunque tu ritenga opportuno!

story:
Our Pitch

The Write New Festival is the annual new writing theatre festival at the Jack Studio Theatre, in Lewisham, London, and is happening this year from the 9th-30th May 2015.

The festival, now in its 6th year, celebrates new work, providing one full scale production, two staged readings, the production of seven shorts, writing workshops and conversations.

The festival is passionate about engaging with its community, and strives to allow young local people the opportunity to see these new plays being performed.

We are seeking support for Young People between the ages of 16-25 to attend the Write Now festival for free.

Your donations will help this happen.

What We Want

We want young people to be able to attend the festival, for FREE.

  • Your donation to this funding moment will enable that to happen
  • Any funds raised will mean that we can offer FREE tickets to young people within the borough of Lewisham
  • Further donations will be used throughout the year to support access for Young People to the programme of theatre work at the Jack Studio Theatre

What We Can Offer

A chance to support young people in the borough of Lewisham attend an extra-ordinary and exciting new writing theatre festival

And we have some Perks* too:

  • A Mention on our website
  • A Free programme (posted or picked up at the theatre)
  • 2 Free tickets to attend any theatre performance in 2015

(* each offer is subject to availability and is limited to the 'perk'. But then we will do our utmost to make it worth your while)

Our Risk

The Jack Studio Theatre likes nothing more than a good challenge, and taking a leap of faith into new adventures.

With your support and belief we will reach our goal, and we are going to do our utmost to make it happen.

The Jack Studio Theatre Team

story:
BuSSy's Story  

BuSSy is a performing arts project/movement that documents and gives voice to censored untold stories about gender in different communities in Egypt.

BuSSy challenges Egypt's social boundaries. Women step on stage to share stories about harassment, rape, gender discrimination, honor killing, forced marriage, Female genital mutilation, motherhood, domestic violence, child abuse, mass sexual assaults  and many others, from different communities and cities in Egypt.

BuSSy's Birth 

In 2005, the American University in Cairo hosted a performance of the Vagina Monologues. Many female students felt the performance was daring but irrelevant to Egyptians. And in reaction to that ... BuSSy was born!

In 2006, a group of female students started The BuSSy project; An annual performance of true Stories of Women in Egypt. The very first BuSSy performance was a collection of Stories submitted by women in response to a flyer that read: “If you have a story about yourself or a woman you know, please pick up a submission form and share it". 

The monologues, which were written and performed by women, for women, exposed real women’s stories and provided for the first time in Egypt, a space for free expression on issues that society often failed/refused to address. 

Despite  being constantly subjected to censorship attempts from both the Private theaters and state owned ones, BuSSy was able to carry on and expand further.

In 2010 the project developed its scope to include stories of both women and men. Both genders are invited to share their personal experiences during the workshop and later on stage. 

In 2012, we began working on a larger scale, instead of one workshop and one performance. We started conducting several workshops around Cairo to produce different performances each year that include stories of both genders. Some of the performances and workshops revolved around specific timely/relevant themes such as: harassment incidents during protests and domestic violence. 

 In 2013 and 2014 BuSSy travelled to different cities in Egypt to hold community based storytelling workshops and performances. BuSSy also performed and participated in different conferences and festivals in different countries. 

Since 2006 we have...

...Held 40 storytelling workshops...

...Performed in Cairo, Alexandria, Minya, Assiut, Port Said...

...Held more than 20 performances for women by women in Egypt...

...Gathered stories from over 500 people...

...Reached Thousands of others online and through our performances...

"Bussy"--which means "look!" in Egyptian Arabic-- provides not only a space, but also, opportunities for individuals to look within themselves.

Ever since it's birth BuSSy has been facing a lot of difficulties finding spaces to hold the workshops and rehearsals. 
We have held workshops and rehearsals in school court yards, garages, flats, public cafe, rented rooms, bookshops ... 
For BuSSy to continue to share with the world the remarkable histories of our storytellers, we need a safe and open space to hold our workshops, create other activities that would help sustain the project on the long run, and help it operate independently away from censorship and content-controlling funding – which is commonly practiced by hosting venues. 

A Place for Stories...A Place for BuSSy 

“A Place For Stories” campaign will be used to provide an office workshop and rehearsal space in Cairo for:

  1. Storytelling workshops
  2. Performance Rehearsals
  3. BuSSy's Administrative and planning team
  4. Income generating activities such as film screening, storytelling, writing and theater workshops. 
  5. Host individual storytelling sessions with men and women
  6. filming and editing different stories and testimonies 
  7. Serve as offices for BuSSy’s growing team and a home for BuSSy's growing family ... 
Your support will help BuSSy become sustainable. Your contributions will fund a work space and necessary equipment that will help us reduce long-term operating overheads and create revenue streams that will make BuSSy self-financing movement after 2 years.
Our Perks!

We are very thankful for your effort to help, and as a gesture of our gratitude :
  • If you donate +10$, we will send you a customized and personalized thank you note from the whole team.
  • If you donate +20$, you will receive a BuSSy pin in a color of your choice
  • If you donate +50$, we will send you 4 free tickets to our upcoming show and a chance to meet the team.
  • If you donate +75$, you will receive a personalized poster of a BuSSy performance of your choice
  • If you donate +100$, you will receive a handmade BuSSy storyteller bracelet
  • If you donate +150$, you will receive a tote '10 years of Storytelling' Bag with inspiring quotes from different stories of women & men in Egypt.
  • If you donate +500$, we will dedicate a space for you on our wall at our new space in recognition for your support As well as recognizing you as our top supporters on the website +  a personalized poster of a BuSSy performance of your choice + BuSSy pin in a color of your choice
  • If you donate +750$, we will dedicate a space for you on our wall at our new space in recognition for your support As well as recognizing you as our top supporters on the website + customized and personalized thank you note from the whole team + a tote '10 years of Storytelling' Bag with inspiring quotes from different stories of women & men in Egypt  
  • If you donate +1000$ you will support a storytelling workshop for Egyptian women and men in Cairo
  • If you donate +5000$ you will support a storytelling workshop for Egyptian women and men in either Alexandria, Tanta, or Fayoum

#SupportBuSSy

Other Ways You Can Help

If can't make a contribution, help us spread the word:

  • Host a crowd funding party at your facility
  • Post our crowd funding posters and flyers at your facility (reach out to us at bussy@monologues.co for collateral)
  • Share the campaign on your social media via indiegogo
  • Follow us on Facebook and Twitter @thebussyproject, and share our campaign updates
  • Get the word out using the #supportbussy and #aplaceforstories

Thank you for your support!

Contact the team!

For any questions or comments about our crowd funding campaign, or to learn more about BuSSy please:
Email us: bussy@monologues.co
Message us: www.facebook.com/thebussyproject
Send us a tweet: @thebussyproject
Check out our website: www.bussy.co

حكاية بـــُــصى

بصي هو مشروع فنى يهدف إلى تمكين السيدات والرجال المصريين، ورفع الوعى حول مشاكل النوع الإجتماعي من خلال الحكي المسرحي.

بصي تحاول مقاومة القيود المجتمعية فى مصر. السيدات في مختلف المجتمعات والمدن المصرية يقفن على خشبة المسرح لمشاركة حكاياتهم عن التحرش والإغتصاب، والتمييز، وجرائم الشرف، والزواج القهري، والختان، والأمومة، والعنف الأسرى، والاعتداء الجنسي على الأطفال، والإعتداء الجنسي الجماعي، وغيرها من الموضوعات التى يصنفها المجتمع كتابوهات ممنوع الكلام عنها.

بداية بــُـــصى

فى 2005، استضافة الجامعة الأمريكية بالقاهرة عرض The Vagina Monologues.

العديد من الطالبات شعرن أن العرض جرىء لكنه لا يعبر عن المصريات، وكان رد الفعل على ذلك ... ميلاد بصى!

فى 2006، بدأت مجموعة من الطالبات مشروع بصى؛ عرض سنوى لحكايات فتيات وسيدات من مصر. العرض الأول لمشروع بصي كان لحكايات مجمعة أرسلتها سيدات ردًا على منشور كُتب فيه: "لو عندك قصة عن نفسك أو سيده تعرفينها، برجاء سحب استمارة ومشاركتنا القصة".

ولأول مرة في مصر، المونولوجات التى كتبتها وحكتها نساء، أظهرت حكايات حقيقية، وقامت بتوفير مساحة حرة للتعبير عن مشكلات فشل المجتمع أو رفض، الاعتراف بها.

على الرغم من استمرار تعرض المشروع للمشكلات الرقابية، في المسارح الحكومية والخاصة، إلا أن بصي استطاعت أن تستمر وتتطور.

في 2010، تطور المشروع ليتضمن حكايات نساء ورجال. ودعي المشروع النساء والرجال لمشاركة مشكلاتهم الشخصية والتعبير عنها في ورش الحكي، وعلى المسرح لاحقًا.

فى 2012، بدأنا في توسيع مجال عملنا. بدلًا من ورشة واحدة وعرض واحد فى السنة، بدأنا في عقد العديد من الورش في مختلف مناطق القاهرة، للخروج بأكثر من عرض يتضمن حكايات نساء ورجال. بعض الورش والعروض تركزت حول تجارب متعلقة بموضوع بعينه مثل: حوادث التحرش الجنسي أثناء المظاهرات، والعنف المنزلي.

في 2013 و 2014، سافرت بصي إلى العديد من المدن في مصر لعمل ورش حكي وعروض خاصة بكل مدينة؛ كما شاركت بصي في العديد من المؤتمرات والمهرجانات الدولية.

منذ 2006 قمنا بعمل

40 ورشة حكي ...

عروض في القاهرة والإسكندرية والمنيا وأسيوط وبورسعيد...

أكثر من 20 عرض للنساء، بطلاته نساء في مصر ...

جمعنا أكثر من 500 حكاية...

منذ بداية "بصي" والمشروع يواجه العديد من المشكلات في إيجاد أماكن لعقد ورش الحكي وبروفات  العروض.

قمنا بعمل ورش حكى وتدريبات فى ساحة مدرسة، وجراجات، وشقق أصدقاء، ومقاهي عامة، وغرف اجتماعات ومكتبات ... إلخ.

حتى تتمكن بصى من الاستمرار في الحكى والتوثيق، نحتاج لمساحة عمل.

مكان للحكايات... مكان بصى

"مكان للحكايات" هى حملة لإيجاد مكان وتجهيزه في القاهرة حتى نتمكن من:

1-عقد واستضافة ورش الحكي

2-استضافة تدريبات وإستعدادات ما قبل عروض بصي

3-عقد لقاءات فردية مع نساء ورجال لتوثيق قصصهم فى سرية

4-  توفير مكاتب لفريق عمل بصي الادارى والفنى

5- استضافة جلسات حكى مفتوحة

6- عقد اجتماعات

7- تنظيم أنشطة تساعد على دعم استمرارية المشروع مثل: ورش حكى ومسرح وكتابة، وعروض أفلام

8- توثيق تجارب شخصية من خلال الفيديو

على الرغم من استمرار تعرض المشروع للمشكلات الرقابية، في المسارح الحكومية والخاصة، إلا أن بصي استطاعت أن تستمر وتتطور.
في 2010، تطور المشروع ليتضمن حكايات نساء ورجال. ودعي المشروع النساء والرجال لمشاركة مشكلاتهم الشخصية والتعبير عنها في ورش الحكي، وعلى المسرح لاحقًا.
فى 2012، بدأنا في توسيع مجال عملنا. بدلًا من ورشة واحدة وعرض واحد فى السنة، بدأنا في عقد العديد من الورش في مختلف مناطق القاهرة، للخروج بأكثر من عرض يتضمن حكايات نساء ورجال. بعض الورش والعروض تركزت حول تجارب متعلقة بموضوع بعينه مثل: حوادث التحرش الجنسي أثناء المظاهرات، والعنف المنزلي.
في 2013 و 2014، سافرت بصي إلى العديد من المدن في مصر لعمل ورش حكي وعروض خاصة بكل مدينة؛ كما شاركت بصي في العديد من المؤتمرات والمهرجانات الدولية.
منذ 2006 قمنا بعمل
40 ورشة حكي ...
عروض في القاهرة والإسكندرية والمنيا وأسيوط وبورسعيد...
أكثر من 20 عرض للنساء، بطلاته نساء في مصر ...
جمعنا أكثر من 500 حكاية...
منذ بداية "بصي" والمشروع يواجه العديد من المشكلات في إيجاد أماكن لعقد ورش الحكي وبروفات  العروض.
قمنا بعمل ورش حكى وتدريبات فى ساحة مدرسة، وجراجات، وشقق أصدقاء، ومقاهي عامة، وغرف اجتماعات ومكتبات ... إلخ.
حتى تتمكن بصى من الاستمرار في الحكى والتوثيق، نحتاج لمساحة عمل.
مكان للحكايات... مكان بصى
 "مكان للحكايات" هى حملة لإيجاد مكان وتجهيزه في القاهرة حتى نتمكن من:
1-عقد واستضافة ورش الحكي
2-استضافة تدريبات وإستعدادات ما قبل عروض بصي
3-عقد لقاءات فردية مع نساء ورجال لتوثيق قصصهم فى سرية
4-  توفير مكاتب لفريق عمل بصي الادارى والفنى
5- استضافة جلسات حكى مفتوحة
6- عقد اجتماعات 
7- تنظيم أنشطة تساعد على دعم استمرارية المشروع مثل: ورش حكى ومسرح وكتابة، وعروض أفلام 
8- توثيق تجارب شخصية من خلال الفيديو

story:
Promethean Theatre Company Presents:
The Flick by Annie Baker

Promethean Theatre Company is proud to present Annie Baker’s The Flick, winner of the 2014 Pulitzer Prize for Drama, directed by Stephen M. Eckert and featuring Stephen Foley, Khiry Armstead, Susan Lannigan. 

WHEN
   August 11-28, 2016
   Thursday-Saturday 7:30pm
   Sunday 2pm Matinee
WHERE
   The Lagniappe Stage at Rivertown Theaters for the Performing Arts
   325 Minor Street, Kenner, LA 70062
WHO
   Directed by Stephen M. Eckert
   Staring: Stephen Foley, Khiry Armstead, and Susan Lannigan
TICKETS   
   Online at rivertowntheaters.com   
   By phone at (504) 461-9475   
   In person at the Rivertown Box office, 325 Minor Street, Kenner, LA 70062
BE THE BUZZ
  Facebook: facebook.com/PrometheanNOLA
  Twitter: @Promethean_NOLA

WHO WE ARE

Founded by Stephen M. Eckert in 2012, Promethean is a New Orleans-based company interested in presenting diverse theatrical experiences of the highest quality. Nearly all of the artists working on this production are New Orleans locals.

THE PLAY

Annie Baker's The Flick won the 2014 Pulitzer Prize for drama as well as the 2013 Obie Award for New American Play. In a run-down single-screen movie theater auditorium in central Massachusetts three minimum wage employees sweep popcorn, mop the floors, and tend to one of the last 35mm projectors in the state. The daily monotony of the cinema becomes a backdrop for the small milestones and challenges of their lives as they each search for authenticity in world often filled with insincerity.

THE DIFFERENCE YOU'LL MAKE 
Promethean is proud to have always paid every member of the cast and crew of its productions. While we are glad to have raised over $5000 towards the costs of The Flick, we are asking for your support to help us pay for the rest. Theatre is expensive! Your contribution will go towards rent, performers, designers, costumes, set, and printing.
