story:
Although Santa Fe has a large LGBTQ population, there is still a need for more diversity in the performing arts community, so we would love your help by supporting this new production or original plays. 

Almost Adults: 5 Plays about Sex, Love, and Immaturity by Aaron Leventman will be held at Warehouse 21 Warehouse 21, Santa Fe Teen Arts Center 1614 Paseo de Peralta at the SF Railyard, September 17-27, 2015, directed by Alaina Warren Zachary. These one-act comedies and dramas have been published and performed in New York City and Provincetown MA in 2012-2014.   They speak to the issues of gay marriage and parenting, coming out and coming of age, care-taking and terminal illness, and teen disenfranchisement.  Eight performances, a Q&A panel discussion, and a fundraiser for a social institution that provides services to our LGBTQ community have been scheduled. 

We're excited to be the recipient of a grant from The Envision Fund; the largest philanthropic entity in New Mexico dedicated to serving the LGBTQ  population.  But we still need your help in order to make this exciting production happen. Contributions of any amount are greatly appreciated to support all areas of production and marketing.  This includes advertising, print materials, production elements, the theater rental, and stipends for the talent and staff.  Every contributor will be acknowledged in our program.  Plans for future LGBTQ themed events will commence to include film screenings, other theatrical productions, and literary events given the success of this initial production.  Your contribution will help pave the way for bringing more diversity to the Santa Fe arts by helping this initial production come to life.

Mayor Javier Gonzalez will kick-off our first performance weekend by declaring opening night Almost Adults: LGBTQ Theatre Day.

In addition to a team of professionals enlisted in the acting, writing, and producing of this production, Santa Fe teens and young adults will volunteer to work in the areas of acting, design, technical, marketing, and administrative assistance.  Free tickets will also be given away to clients from like-minded organizations and schools for educational purposes. 

Director Alaina Warren Zachary has a professional career that’s spanned more than 45 years, including Broadway and local credits in film and theatre.  Playwright Aaron Leventman has not only had plays performed all over the country but is a vested member of the local acting community and has been bringing LGBTQ films to Santa Fe for the last decade through the Santa Fe Film Festival and formally the Film Center.

story:
We Believe Theatre Should Be Accessible and Engaging


Who We Are

Canada’s Magnetic North Theatre Festival is our country’s only touring national theatre festival. For thirteen years we’ve been bringing together audiences, artists, and theatre industry delegates from across Canada and around the world to celebrate excellence and innovation in Canada theatre.

Canada is producing world-class theatre, and sharing it across the country is what makes us unique. Supported by our National Resource Council, which includes members such as Sandra Oh and Marti Maraden, we make our home in Ottawa and travel the Festival to a new host community every other year. We’ve traveled to Edmonton, St. Johns, Vancouver, Kitchener-Waterloo, Calgary, and Halifax. Next year we are heading to Whitehorse.  Then in 2017 we will return to Ottawa to celebrate our 15th Anniversary and Canada's sesquicentennial. Traveling allows us to share our passion for Canadian theatre with new audiences across the country.

“Magnetic North had a huge impact in St. John’s. It sold like gangbusters, invigorated our community’s taste for theatre, [and] served as an affirmation for the work we had been doing in that far off corner. That visit to St. John’s knit our community closer to each other, and in turn, to the rest of the country”.

- Jillian Keiley, Artistic Director, National Arts Centre English Theatre


What We're Doing

We’re running this campaign to bring Guerrilla Theatre to Ottawa, ON during our upcoming Festival, running from June 4th to 13th , 2015.

Our Guerrilla theatre program lets us create performances that are accessible to everyone, engaging, and fun! Through short pop-up performances in public spaces, Guerrilla Theatre artists engage passers-by in the spontaneity and surprise of theatre, exposing them to the creative process in a personal and exciting way.

Your support will make it possible for 8 local theatre artists to take their shows to the streets of Ottawa during our festival this June. Our artists will create short (5 - 10 minute) pop-up theatre pieces to be performed on the streets, on buses, in shopping malls—essentially anywhere people gather.

These performances will create art in unexpected places for everyone to enjoy, and animate public spaces, turning your everyday walk or commute from ordinary to extraordinary, all while giving local artists the opportunity to display their talent and passion for theatre in an exciting way.

Our goal of $5000 will allow us to:

  • Employ 8 local theatre artists/companies
    • We will select 4 pieces to be performed multiple times during the Festival, which runs from June 4th to 13th
    • An additional 4 pieces will be chosen to be performed during Verso la Fiamma, (link) our outdoor walking carnival performance in the Byward Market on June 7th
  • Publicize the performances
  • Provide site specific support
  • Cover the costs of the campaign perks

If we exceed our goal we will be able to pay our performers a higher rate.

If we don’t reach our goal, we will reallocate funds from other programs to make sure these Guerrilla Theatre performances happen.  With your support we hope we won't have to do that.

What You Get

There are lots of ways to support our Festival endeavors! 

For only $5 you can become a Festival Insider: you will get the inside scoop on  festival happenings and where the guerrilla performances are happening.

If you will be in Ottawa during the festival, donate $10 and receive a Drink Voucher for our festival bar, open nightly from 9pm, June 6th to 10th.  Each night will feature an exciting event hosted by various Ottawa arts organizations including Herd Magazine, Thunk! Theatre, the Spiderweb Show, and Canada Dance Festival.

Supporters who donate $30 or more will receive a printable copy of our Festival Poster,

                                    


a colourful 1.75" Festival Button,

                                                             

and our 12" by 9" Festival Tote Bag, perfectly sized to carry lunches or shoes and show off your festival support!               

   As a registered Charitable Organization, we are also able to issue Tax Receipts for contributions over $30.From $55 reward levels up you can don a Festival T-shirt featuring this year’s eye-catching graphic.

Choose from black, purple, or turquoise in fitted or unfitted.


For $250 you will also get all the above, plus a bound copy of an Original Canadian Play Magnetic North has featured, randomly selected from our collection.


For $500 you can create and name a Festival Drink to be featured at one of our festival bar nights. We'll also throw in 5 drink tickets so you can bring a few friends down to enjoy your signature drink with you.


For $1000 you can enjoy an evening out with with Brenda, the Artistic Executive Director of Canada's Magnetic North Theatre Festival.  At some point in the next year, when her travels take her to a city near you, Brenda will take you and a friend out to dinner and a theatre performance, where you hear about her plans for the upcoming festival season.  Cities Brenda visits regularly are Ottawa, Toronto, Montreal, Vancouver, Calgary, Halifax, Whitehorse, Edmonton, St. Johns, Regina, Winnipeg, Camloops, Charlottetown, and Fredericton.


For $5000 you can be a VIP in Whitehorse for the opening of our 2016 Festival on June 9th. Includes return airfaire for 1 from any major city in Canada, 2-night stay in a hotel in Whitehorse, 1 ticket to each performance during the 3-day stay, and an invitation to our opening night reception. Allowances for additional guests, show tickets, or a longer duration stay can be made for additional costs. 

If you will be in Ottawa during the festival you can pick your physical rewards up in person at the National Arts Centre, otherwise they will be mailed to you in July of 2015.


Why It’s Important

Like we said above, we believe theatre should be two things: accessible and engaging.

Our Artistic Executive Director spends months traveling around the country seeing shows in order to curate each year’s Festival line-up, putting together a collection of the freshest and most innovative theatre Canada has to offer. She selects programming to engage, challenge, and entertain our audiences.  We present some traditional main-stage pieces—though there is nothing traditional about the topics—and we also love to push the envelope with multi-disciplinary theatre that incorporates dance, music, film, and audience participation.

We want everyone to have access to these great theatre experiences, so we keep our tickets affordable and include free Encounters as an essential component of our programming. Encounters allow the public to interact with Festival artists in unconventional ways, and include open rehearsals, panel discussions, workshops, and much more.

This year we’ve introduced two outdoor, Pay-What-You-Can shows to engage audiences who would not normally attend a traditional theatre performance. We want to take accessibility even further; our goal is to make most of the Festival free by 2017 so everyone can enjoy some of Canada’s best theatre without barriers!

Our Festival is a launching pad for Canadian artists.

We host national and international theatre delegates looking to book shows in their venues. Over 65% of our shows have gone on to tour the country and the world, to locations as far as New Zealand, Australia, India, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Iceland, Denmark, Italy, and Ireland.

The Guerilla Theatre performers we feature in Ottawa this year will gain exposure that could also lead to further opportunities—one of our 2014 Guerrilla theatre performers was invited to perform in India! So your contribution really does make a difference.

Risks and Challenges

It takes a lot of resources—both human and financial—to put on a successful ten day festival that attracts audiences, artists, and theatre industry delegates from across the country and around the globe.

As a moving festival, Magnetic North faces additional challenges in building returning audiences and securing recurring sponsorships.

We believe that increasing accessibility will not only increase our profile, but also increase our support from audiences, donors and sponsors.


Like what we're doing, but low on spending money?

If you like what we’re about, but can’t support us financially, there are other ways you can get involved.

  1. Volunteer at our festival.  We are still seeking volunteers to help out with various tasks at this year's festival.  If you will be in Ottawa from June 4th to 13th, consider signing up to be a driver, usher, bartender, or another one of our many volunteer positions.
  2. Attend one of our shows. We have two pay-what-you-can shows this year, and would love to have you join us for the Magnetic North experience.
  3. Attend one of our Magnetic Encounters.  These free events include open rehearsals, pitch sessions, and panel discussions with theatre experts.
  4. Come to our Festival Bar in the NAC's 4th Stage at 53 Elgin St.
  5. Join our Board of Directors or Fundraising Committee.  We are always looking for fresh blood to help us plan the future of our Festival.  If you have time and interest in innovative Canadian theatre, contact us.
  6. Share our campaign and Festival with your friends and family!

Images Copyright Michelle Ducet Photography.

story:
Let’s bring back The Tiny Theater!

Poultney is a fantastic place to live - I may have only lived here for a year and a half, but I’m already in love with it. I want to provide the good people of Poultney with another option on boring Friday nights and rainy Sunday afternoons by hosting movies and other events at The Tiny Theater!

My name is Nicole Rabiega and I work at Green Mountain College. I’ve always been a bit of a movie buff and back home, I used to book bands and help run a small weekly coffeehouse. Now I want to bring some of that fun to Poultney.

The Theater will show movies on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday each week, and have other events scheduled throughout the week. Saturday mornings will feature a family film and then we’ll bring out the action packed blockbusters (as well as interesting documentaries, critically acclaimed comedies, and everything in between) for the rest of the day.

We will have a license to serve beer and wine and will have a variety of local snacks and drinks to enjoy while watching the movies or attending other events.

With your help, we can bring back The Tiny Theater and create a positive space to have some fun in Poultney.


What Is Needed & What You Get Out Of It

I need your help to make this dream a reality! I am raising money to purchase new (comfortable!) seating, as well as a projector and sound system. The money raised will also help with the costs of getting the business up and running. I am looking to raise $7500 to help pay for these items and start up costs.

In exchange for all your help, I’ve come up with some perks. There are some pretty fun things over there, like 10 movie passes, a limited edition T-shirt or Sticker, tickets to the Grand Opening event!, and even a lifetime pass for free movies!


Thank you!

Thank you so much for your support and for considering donating to help make The Tiny Theater the best that it can be. The community that Poultney has is truly unique and I feel blessed to be in such a place.

Please share this with family, friends, and anyone else who may be interested!

If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to email me at info@thetinytheater.com. I would be more than happy to answer any and all questions, comments, or concerns!
story_txt:
Let’s bring back The Tiny Theater!
Poultney is a fantastic place to live - I may have only lived here for a year and a half, but I’m already in love with it. I want to provide the good people of Poultney with another option on boring Friday nights and rainy Sunday afternoons by hosting movies and other events at The Tiny Theater!My name is Nicole Rabiega and I work at Green Mountain College. I’ve always been a bit of a movie buff and back home, I used to book bands and help run a small weekly coffeehouse. Now I want to bring some of that fun to Poultney.The Theater will show movies on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday each week, and have other events scheduled throughout the week. Saturday mornings will feature a family film and then we’ll bring out the action packed blockbusters (as well as interesting documentaries, critically acclaimed comedies, and everything in between) for the rest of the day.We will have a license to serve beer and wine and will have a variety of local snacks and drinks to enjoy while watching the movies or attending other events. With your help, we can bring back The Tiny Theater and create a positive space to have some fun in Poultney.What Is Needed & What You Get Out Of ItI need your help to make this dream a reality! I am raising money to purchase new (comfortable!) seating, as well as a projector and sound system. The money raised will also help with the costs of getting the business up and running. I am looking to raise $7500 to help pay for these items and start up costs.In exchange for all your help, I’ve come up with some perks. There are some pretty fun things over there, like 10 movie passes, a limited edition T-shirt or Sticker, tickets to the Grand Opening event!, and even a lifetime pass for free movies! Thank you!Thank you so much for your support and for considering donating to help make The Tiny Theater the best that it can be. The community that Poultney has is truly unique and I feel blessed to be in such a place.Please share this with family, friends, and anyone else who may be interested!If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to email me at info@thetinytheater.com. I would be more than happy to answer any and all questions, comments, or concerns!

story:
Welcome!

We are the Manayunk Theatre Company, a small non-profit theatre in the Manayunk neighborhood of Philadelphia. After the success of our first performance during the 2014 Philadelphia Fringe Festival (fully funded by our community), we're excited to bring you a new show, the US premiere of Paul Shapera's The Dolls of New Albion. The production will run from September 3 to 12 for eight showings at the Venice Island Performing Arts Center in Manayunk, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

Not familiar with Steampunk? We'll get you up to speed.

Steampunk is an aesthetic and a lifestyle bringing together Victorian Era culture with elaborate machine-powered technology. Everything is exquisitely detailed and centered around a maker-culture.

So now that you're more familiar with what Steampunk is, we'll tell you a little bit more about our latest project.

The Dolls of New Albion is a Steampunk Opera. The show revolves around the soul of a human being that is trapped in a mechanical artifice. The show grapples with  the questions of: What is a human? What is humanity? What are our needs? How do we define ourselves? These questions are explored through a drama of romance, heartbreak, and death.

So you know a little bit about the company and about the show, but what about the details? What will you be paying for?

We are committed to bringing the best possible performance to you, but we'll need your support. First, we would like to rent a 250-person seat theatre at the Venice Island Performing Arts Center. Second, the show needs actors, and we at Manayunk Theatre Company value our extraordinarily talented cast. Our actors are deserving of the best and we want to compensate them the most we can. This show also calls for intricate sets and detailed costumes and we plan to give you the best possible performance with every detail well planned. With your help, we can hire a great team of designers, musicians, and technicians who will help us bring this show to life.


And last, but certainly not least, why does it matter?

Manayunk Theatre Company loves to bring new and interesting pieces to the community, and the Philadelphia Fringe Festival is a great way to bring this show to fruition. The Dolls of New Albion is important to us for many reasons, and one of those reasons is Manayunk's industrial past. The Philadelphia Fringe Festival allows us to celebrate that history and Steampunk culture as a whole. Steampunk's maker-culture goes hand in hand with Theatre, which is filled with makers and doers.

In the words of Director Gabe Henniger, “IT'S HELLA COOL! This is the first time this show is going to be performed on US soil and it is a series of firsts. For an off-the-market show, it has great character development and explores a city and a lifestyle throughout several generations. The Dolls of New Albion uses Steampunk rhetoric and symbols to give insight into humanity itself. It's going to be an audio-visual spectacle. I'm thrilled to bring Paul's vision to the stage.”

 Challenges.
  • This is a complex show with masterfully crafted music and movement. However, our team is devoted to finding the truths in the piece and bring them to life for you.
  • The real challenges are that operas are expensive. They are so much more demanding then a regular staged show. We have a vision for this show that will truly be an adventure. However, if we don't raise enough money that adventure could turn into a little walk around the park. That's why we need you to get a space, hire talented actors and designers, and make the sets, props and costumes that this show needs.
 Other Ways You Can Help.
  • This goes for all you Steampunks and excited theatre dreamers, please share this fundraiser so we can make this show happen.


Stretch Goals!

  • If we reach $60,000, we will bring Paul Shapera, the Opera’s composer, to the show’s run in America!

  • If we reach $65,000, we will bring in Mano Divina of the Divine Hand Ensemble to accompany the Opera’s score with his Theremin! (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-e1-9igy3nE)

  • If we reach $75,000, we will bring in the entire Divine Hand Ensemble to accompany the traditional score of the Opera!
But Who Are We?

Gabe Henninger (Director & Company Founder). This is Gabe's second opportunity to direct for the Manayunk Theatre Company. Born and bred in Philadelphia, Gabe loves dressage, long walks in the park, and making up hobbies for bios. He spends much of his time reading classic literature trying to rid himself of his horrendous Philadelphian accent. He is incredibly excited to be directing Dolls.

Joshua McHugh (Music Director) is graduate of Temple University with a Bachelors of Music in Music Education. He is an avid science fiction fan, and loves the steampunk genre. The Dolls of New Albion is a glorious combination of two of his favorite things: Geek culture and Music.

Thomas E. Delfi (Executive Producer) is a Historian, Museum Professional, Pennsylvania Steampunk, and Executive Producer of The Dolls of New Albion. Mr. Delfi approached the Manayunk Theatre Company last fall on the possibility of bringing the The Dolls of New Albion to the stage for the first time in America. He is an old friend of both fellow producer Sean Connolly and composer Paul Shapera and is the co-founder of the Pocono Comic Expo in Stroudsburg, Pennsylvania.

Sean Connolly (Producer) is the Artistic Director and a Founding Trustee of the Manayunk Theatre Company, a historical interpreter and Producer of The Dolls of New Albion. He holds a B.A. in History from York College of Pennsylvania and is seeking a Masters of Arts in Theatre from Villanova University this fall. Sean is very excited to bring this show to the Manayunk community.

As we continue this campaign, we'll begin to introduce you to the professionals who will be responsible for putting on a stellar performance, again, all thanks to you!

*All discounts and free tickets will delivered in the form of a discount code that can be used for a presale general admission ticket.

**"All previous perks" does not include tickets in previous tiers.

*** Those who want a tax credit for their donation, please make a notation of that. Tax receipts will be issued by the Manayunk Development Corporation, a 501(c)(3)  non-profit corporation  that fiscally sponsors Manayunk Theatre Company, and will be issued in accordance with IRS Publication 526.

story:
Short Summary

You Can't Do That is a new youth musical specifically designed for participants aged 12 to 21, written by Derek Martin and Michael Betteridge and directed by emerging director Dan Jarvis.

  • So far, this piece has been partly devised by the participants during a week's workshop in the summer of 2014
  • This July, the project continues with another workshop week using the script and music which has been developed by the writers over the last 12months.
  • The script provides the structure but incorporates collaboration processes that will engage and develop the participants artistically.

This project provides an opportunity for young people to produce a piece of original work which engages them as collaborators.

The finished product will be a brand new musical written specifically for young people for young voices that we can distribute all over the country to youth groups and drama clubs to perform in their own community.

What We Need & What You Get

This project has been supported by Arts Council England but we are actively seeking the remaining 10% of our budget.

  • We need £750 to help towards the production and marketing costs of the Summer performance - props / costume / programmes / posters etc
  • Every person to donate more than £15 will recieve an free invitation to the performance as our special guest
  • If we don't reach our total funding target, we will continue to use the funds towards production and marketing costs.  If we recieve more than our target, this additional money will go towards next summer's workshop.

The Impact

At the start of this project we asked young people - "What do you think is missing from Musical Theatre for young performers? What could a new musical offer that others haven't before?"  Here are some of their responses:

  • A musical with bullying as the central theme
  • More bass roles / more lead alto roles for lower female ranges
  • Storylines that aren't always about love!
  • Better use of technology and interactive social media
  • Catchy songs
  • More small solo and ensemble parts
  • Shows with more LGBT or POC characters
  • More regional structural support for non funded performance groups
  • More 'raw' and less 'showbizzy' musicals

During the 2014 workshop we asked the young people what sort of ending they would like. The most popular choice was for a mysterious ending or an ending in which the young people do not win. When asked why, the answer was “well… it wouldn’t happen. Why would they listen to a group of kids?”

We have to wonder what sort of environment we have created if young people feel they don’t have the potential to change the world. How can we empower young people so they feel their voices are heard and are as equally as important as adults who often speak in place of young people?

Other Ways You Can Help

We are planning forward for a further workshop in Summer 2016 to finish off the script and preview it to programmers and youth groups who might want to use it.  We are therefore looking for in-kind support to help with the production costs for this.

  • Can you donate free rehearsal or performance space in Manchester?
  • Can you offer cheap / free printing services for marketing?
  • Can you provide materials for set / costume / props?

For further information or to donate support in kind please email rebeccajennerproducer@gmail.com

story:
About Me and My Project

I'm Foluke Beveridge, a grad student in the Arts Administration program at SCAD Atlanta and I'm about to embark on the last step in my degree program: the final project.  
For my project, I'll be setting up a digital archive for the Atlanta Black Theater Festival (ABTF) and I'm trying to raise money to get materials.  For those who don't know, a digital archive is a means of preserving historical materials online.  It makes it much easier to access than a physical archive because all you need is access to a computer and the internet.
Through my research for this project, I understand the importance of preserving theater, particularly African American theater, since our history is so often incomplete.  This is near and dear to my heart because it will help create a more complete picture of American theater and the role of people who look like me in that landscape.  This project also shows that although archiving is not easy, it can be done; the resources to save that legacy are available.
My project is two-fold: a digital archive as well as a basic print archive for the original objects and recommendations for future preservation.

Why That's Important

This project will contribute to the growing effort to record and preserve history and will inspire cultural groups to do it themselves.  Too often, theaters and other arts organizations of color do not have the resources to preserve their history.  In other cases, the story-telling is left to someone else.  Projects like this show that it is possible to preserve our history and memories and add them to the larger history of the arts.  

The biggest question is, where would we be today if people didn't salvage the past?

What I Need

I'm asking for $750, which will mainly go to the print archiving portion of my project.  I couldn't ignore the importance of protecting ABTF's original materials, and to do that, I need:
  • special acid-free boxes, folders, and dividers
  • archiving labels and pens
  • protective covers
For the digital component, I will need:
  • an external hard drive to protect the digital copies I make
  • domain and web hosting so that people can access the archive

What You Get

If you contribute to my campaign, I will:
  • Personally shout you out on Facebook, Twitter, and/or Instagram.
  • Sing your favorite song in a Youtube video.
  • Recite your favorite monologue in a Youtube video.
Since my project doesn't lend itself to tangible perks, I am playing to my strengths!  I will show my appreciation through social media as well as my singing and speaking talents. 

How You Can Help

You can help my campaign by:

  • contributing what you can
  • sharing my campaign, and using the Indiegogo sharing tools!
Thanks for your time! Comment with questions.

story:
A Permanent Home for the Arts: The Journey

Founded in 1959 by West Indian poet and Nobel Laureate Derek Walcott and a group of Trinbagonian actors, Trinidad Theatre Workshop (TTW) is the longest running theatre company in the Caribbean. We have trained many of Trinidad's foremost actors, and educated students across the region, spawning a generation of leaders in the arts, locally, regionally and internationally. 

Over our 56 years of existence we have developed groundbreaking productions which have toured extensively around the world, spreading Caribbean theatre to a wide range of audiences from St. Lucia to Boston, Uganda to Singapore. Our seasons reflect our diverse culture and its diaspora, original local plays, as well as indigenous interpretations of global classics: TTW's first season included Jean Genet's The Blacks, Eric Roach's Belle Fanto, and Wole Soyinka's The Road. Over the years we have performed acclaimed Walcott works, including Joker of Seville, commissioned by the Royal Shakespeare Company in 1974, and productions of Dream on Monkey Mountain and Pantomime, both of which premiered in Trinidad. Elders of the regional theatre arts, such as Errol Jones, Eunice Alleyne, and Albert Laveau, our Artistic Director, have all passed through our doors, as well as many emerging artists of today.

Through years of change and occasional upheaval, we have persevered in our pioneering work. We expanded our community outreach through the School for the Arts, founded in 1991, where we provide instruction in the dramatic arts to students of all ages, and our Theatre in Education programme, began in 1992, where we bring classic theatrical productions directly to schools across Trinidad & Tobago. 

Though we continue to be a creative home for so many, we have never had a permanent location from which to operate. Over the years we have moved from place to place, leasing various buildings, all the while continuing to produce quality work. Since 2004 we have been renting a little blue house in Belmont, on the outskirts of Port of Spain, our capital city. Sitting near the creative heart of Trinidad and Tobago, where the arts have always been the centre of community life, this house is where we have built a black-box theatre and held countless classes, productions and events. This has been our longest home so far. Recently our landlord offered us a chance to purchase this 100+ year old landmark, and we jumped at the opportunity to finally claim a permanent place of our own. 

This is where you join us on our journey. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise $300,000 USD to purchase our current building. All funds raised in this campaign will go directly towards buying the building from our current landlord. 

Your donation will have far reaching effects that go beyond simple ownership. You are helping to uphold a major cultural institution, strengthen a historic tradition, and support a tight-knit family. As such, donors will receive a piece of our priceless legacy as a token of our thanks. 

Prizes include limited edition posters from our numerous productions, signed copies of classic Caribbean plays, archival photographs from the early days, t-shirts, recordings of past productions, and much more. And, if we meet our initial goal of $300,000 USD, we have an incredible array of secret prizes that you can unlock for our stretch goals - but only if you donate today!

Please take a look at our perks list to see a more in depth description of our prizes and benefits for donors. 

The Impact: Furthering the Legacy

We are proud to develop productions and programmes that showcase new and unheard voices of the Caribbean region, as well as its diaspora. In a world with few avenues for people of color to share their stories, TTW has been a pioneer and a model for others. TTW offers a critical place for artists of color to not only grow, participate and lead in the arts, but also to create vital work reflecting our communities, traditions, concerns, and histories. In this way, we have been providing a home where none previously existed, making art for us and by us. There are still few places where local playwrights, actors, technicians, designers, and first-time artists can develop their ideas and work in a supportive, nurturing environment. In order to continue offering such a crucial space, we need a permanent home-base.

Risks and Challenges

If we are unable to purchase our building, our work will remain unstable and tenuous, dictated by the whims of rising rent prices and economic change. Our reach will remain stunted and focused on only what we can afford. 

Here in Trinidad & Tobago, giving to the arts is often not a priority. In our mission to provide scholarships for deserving students and develop innovative work, we have a difficult time just meeting monthly operating costs. As a non-profit company with little financial returns, based in a small island nation, our ability to raise the adequate funds through shows, programmes, and local fundraising efforts alone is very limited. Only the combined support of our regional networks and a broader international audience will allow us to reach our goals.

We need your help so that a major Caribbean institution can push forward stronger than ever as a long standing leader in the contemporary theatre world. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Other than your financial support and donations, we need your help in spreading the word widely. Our networks only reach so far, and we need as much exposure as possible if we want to achieve our goal. If you are interested in supporting us in other ways, please do not hesitate to contact us directly here .

original local plays, as well as indigenous interpretations of global classics:
TTW's first season included Jean Genet's The Blacks, Eric Roach's Belle Fanto, and Wole Soyinka's The Road. Over the years we have
performed acclaimed Walcott works, including Joker of Seville, commissioned by the Royal Shakespeare Company in 1974, and
productions of Dream on Monkey
Mountain and Pantomime, both of which premiered in Trinidad. Elders of the
regional theatre arts, such as Errol Jones, Eunice Alleyne,
and Albert Laveau, our Artistic Director, have all passed through our
doors, as well as many emerging artists of today.


Through years of change and occasional upheaval, we have persevered in our pioneering work. We expanded our community outreach through the School for the Arts, founded in 1991, where we provide instruction in the dramatic arts to students of all ages, and our Theatre in Education programme, began in 1992, where we bring classic theatrical productions directly to schools across Trinidad & Tobago. 
Though we continue to be a creative home for so many, we have never had a permanent location from which to operate. Over the years we have moved from place to place, leasing various buildings, all the while continuing to produce quality work. Since 2004 we have been
renting a little blue house in Belmont, on the outskirts of Port of Spain, our capital city. Sitting near the creative heart of Trinidad and Tobago, where the arts have always been the centre of community life, this house is where we have built a black-box theatre and held countless classes, productions and events. This has been our longest home so far. Recently
our landlord offered us a chance to purchase this 100+ year old landmark, and we jumped at the
opportunity to finally claim a permanent place of our own. 
This is where you join us on our journey.    What We Need & What You Get We are trying to raise $300,000 USD to purchase our current building. All funds raised in this campaign will go directly towards buying the building from our current landlord. 
Your donation will have far reaching effects that go beyond simple ownership. You are helping to uphold a major cultural institution, strengthen a historic tradition, and support a tight-knit family. As such, donors will receive a piece of our priceless legacy as a token of our thanks. 
Prizes include limited edition posters from our numerous productions, signed copies of classic Caribbean plays, archival photographs from the early days, t-shirts, recordings of past productions, and much more. And, if we meet our initial goal of $300,000 USD, we have an incredible array of secret prizes that you can unlock for our stretch goals - but only if you donate today!
Please take a look at our perks list to see a more in depth description of our prizes and benefits for donors. 
    The Impact: Furthering the Legacy 

We are proud to develop productions and programmes that
showcase new and unheard voices of the Caribbean region, as well as its
diaspora. In a world with few avenues for people of color to share their
stories, TTW has been a pioneer and a model for others. TTW offers a critical
place for artists of color to not only grow, participate and lead in the arts,
but also to create vital work reflecting our communities, traditions,
concerns, and histories. In this way, we have been
providing a home where none previously existed, making art for us and by us. There are still few places where local playwrights, actors, technicians, designers, and first-time artists can develop their ideas and work in a supportive, nurturing environment. In order to continue offering such a crucial space, we need a permanent home-base.Risks and ChallengesIf we are unable to purchase our building, our work will remain unstable and tenuous, dictated by the whims of rising rent prices and economic change. Our reach will remain stunted and focused on only what we can afford. Here in Trinidad & Tobago, giving to the arts is often not a priority. In our mission to provide scholarships for deserving students and develop innovative work, we have a difficult time just meeting monthly operating costs. As a non-profit company with little financial returns, based in a small island nation, our ability to raise the adequate funds through shows, programmes, and local fundraising efforts alone is very limited. Only the combined support of our regional networks and a broader international audience will allow us to reach our goals.We need your help so that a major Caribbean institution can push forward stronger than ever as a long standing leader in the contemporary theatre world. Other Ways You Can Help


 Other than your financial support and donations, we need your help in spreading the word widely. Our networks only reach so far, and we need as much exposure as possible if we want to achieve our goal. If you are interested in supporting us in other ways, please do not hesitate to contact us directly here .
campaign_city: Port of Spain, Trinidad and Tobago

story:
WHAT IS BROKEN MOMENTS?

"...Bars are places we go when we can't go to those who are supposed to love us unconditionally. But here it's different." - Carlos
Welcome to Broken Moments!  No matter where you come from or where you're going, this is your bar family.  Birthday Drink?  Mourning the Passing of a Loved One?  Bachelorette Party?  Trouble With A Complicated Relationship(s)?  Just Looking to Take Someone Home?  Take a seat, get reacquainted with your good pal, Whiskey..."Me and Whiskey"...And let the music move you.  No judgment.  It's all here and it's "All About Love"...

And we are excited to announce that we have been accepted into the 2015 New York City International Fringe Festival!!!!

WHAT MAKES YOUR PROJECT SPECIAL?

This bar musical and labor of love, created by Leo Rodriguez, began as a vehicle to honor the memory of an influential mentor and served as a project for his CSU Hayward friends to transition into post-college life.  It has a rich history (brewed since 2007!) and a family of performers who have come and gone (and returned!) through incarnations and concerts that have played at the Legendary Birdland, The Lower East Side Theatre Festival, and Tammany Hall, where it officially became a professional Equity Showcase. 

At Tammany Hall, Broken Moments became an interactive bar experience, where the audience became part of the bar family.  Broken Moments: A Bar Musical played to sold out performances with an extension, due to the popularity of the piece.  We even got a visit from Perez Hilton!

And now we have been selected to share this musical as part of the NYC International Fringe Festival!!!! 

HOW WILL MY DONATION BE USED?

Performance 

$2,275 – actors (13 actors = $35-$40 per performance)

$1,000 - musicians (4 musicians = $50 per performance)

$750 – stage manager/lighting designer ($150 per performance)

$250 - director (one time stipend)

$250 - arranger (one time stipend)

$125 – Insurance

$650 – Programs and Publicity

$375 – Props/Set/Costume

Miscellaneous Administrative Costs (IndieGoGo Fees/Publicity/Etc.)

$6000 total estimated needed


I'D LOVE TO DONATE BUT I CAN'T RIGHT NOW, IS THERE ANY WAY I CAN SUPPORT?

  • You can tell EVERYONE you know! The more visitors to our Indiegogo page, the more likely we will be able to make our goal. So please spread the word! (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Email, etc.)
  • If you have suggestions of any organizations that might be willing to contribute, please let us know.
  • If you can donate rehearsal space or gift cards toward costuming/props/set or want to help out in any way, please let us know!

BE A PART OF THE BROKEN MOMENTS JOURNEY...

Broken Moments started with a college family and as the journey continues the cast has become its own family.  We’re all working together to tell these stories and bring this music to people. We’re together because we believe in the project.  We’ve come this far with hard work and dedication to our craft – please be a part of our journey!  On behalf of all of us at Broken Moments: A Bar Musical – THANK YOU!

"You Gotta Believe" that it's "All About Love!"

story:
Introduction 

My name is James Pierce and I am an author and screenplay writer.  I work with a team of literary professionals whose goal is to promote literacy and educate youths in the area of writing.  Our nonprofit organization is named J.P. Incorporated and it is based in Lancaster California. Our program is dedicated to providing people with equal access to education, art, and culture.

J.P. Incorporated is dedicated to improving the lives of individuals and their community. J.P. Incorporated is a growing literary, visual, and performing arts program that is nurturing an artistic community around socially conscious venues such as book writing, screenplay writing, stage play writing and performances.

All of our plays are geared toward a social message and justice.  The first production in our line of venues will be  "Wake up call: The Bully, The Bad, and The Gang-banger.
ABOUT THE STORY
Nathaniel is an old wise guy who had once walked the life of being in the role of a bully, the bad and the gang- banger.  He paid the price of having to do twenty years in prison.  He learned his lesson and changed his life.

The youngster that he was grooming at that time and had left behind when he went to prison was now an adult named Jeff.  Jeff had looked up to Nathaniel and was now carrying out what he had learned back in the day from Nathaniel.  Jeff was now grooming his own followers and was conditioning them to be bullies, bad, and gang-bangers.  When Nathaniel got out and hooked back up with Jeff, he saw the ills of Jeff's ways and was trying to get him to see that what he was doing was wrong.  Nathaniel even went as far as correcting the young followers that Jeff was grooming, but they did not want to hear what he had to say.   At the end, Nathaniel had to make a judgment call...does he save the youths, or does he save Jeff? 

"Wake up call: The Bully, The Bad and The Gang-banger" is an educational stage play with great music written by Najay Coleman . The play and the lyrics of the music are designed to detour young men and women from getting involved in activities that demean our fellowman and can lead to prison or death. The stage play deals with the attitude and behavior of many youths of today and their actions; which we have come to learn stem from family and social issues.  The play reveals how once  a child accepts the role of being a Bully, Bad or Gang-banger, he or she, preys upon others as a mirror image of being preyed upon themselves by the very one's they look up to.  It underlines the deeds of mistrust and misdirection amongst our youth, and highlights how we as a community must work together to upbuild and empower our youth to be better leaders.  
The play exposes bullies, gang-bangers and those who negatively use their influence over others for wrong doing to show victims, or those who may display these characteristics, a different way of doing things that can have a positive effect on an individual's life and our community.                                 

THE TEAM

I am fortunate to have a hard working production team and cast to take this journey with me. We are determined to find a way to produce the play, we believe the issue is that important and we want you to be apart of our dream. Help us make this a reality even the smallest donation helps, and we can't do this without you.

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising $ 15,000 to cover the basic costs of our endeavor.
(1) Venue location rental
(2) Hiring professional actors, staff and crew
(3) Rehearsal space rental
(4) Marketing costs
(5) Website creation and maintenance
(6) Insurance
(7) Purchasing or renting Props an Costumes
(8) Transportation

Other Ways You Can Help
We have created a piece of theater work filled  with engaging characters, global themes, and great musical scope.  With your financial help, we can debut this play on a theatrical stage in a matter of three (3) months.  If we do not reach our entire goal, the funds will go toward offering free writing seminars and classes to the community we serve.

However, just because you may not be able to monetarily  contribute to this campaign, you can contribute in many other ways by:
(1) Coming to the show
(2) Spreading the word verbally and via social media
(3) Volunteering your time
(4) Volunteering your skills
(5) Other means of donating (ie. materials, networking, professional contacts, etc.)

story:
The Northwest Screendance Exposition

The Northwest Screendance Exposition brings the art of Screendance to Eugene! Screendance results from the collaboration of film and video artists with choreographers and dancers. The finished piece is something that can only exist on the screen, not on a stage or a studio. Check out the piece, Portals, by John Watson, Enissa Harris and Elana Sutton for an example!

The Expo coordinators, Dorene Carroll, a dancer and choreographer, and John Watson, film maker, have worked with dance and film making for 8 years. Dorene has taught dance and works independently in the community to create new works for stage and screen. John is the marketing specialist for Lane Community College's performing arts program where, among other things, he creates videos that tell a dance piece's creation story. He has made several screendance works of his own, such as Portals, featured above.
The Northwest Screendance Exposition will be Eugene's premiere screendance event! The Exposition happens October 6th, at the Bijou Art Cinema, 492 E. 13th Ave. at 7:30 pm. A video introducing screendance through behind-the-scene clips and interviews with the artists  kicks off the evening, followed by a 90 minute program of new screendance work selected especially for the Exposition. We wrap up with a Q&A session and reception with the artists.

We need to raise $4,000 by September 1st for the following:
Bijou Rental: $800
Video advertising:  $200
Print advertising, posters and programs: $200
Artist's honoraria: $1,500
Curatorial assistance: $400
Reception: $200
Production costs: $700

The Impact:

Screendance works have been created since the birth of cinema. Dance and moving images are, after all, a natural combination. In the past, the technical and financial barriers to producing even a short screendance project were prohibitive. Now, with the proliferation of digital video recorders and user-friendly editing software, artists in film and dance are coming together across the globe to create screendance works. Eugene can be a part of this art form that’s becoming popular worldwide.

The Internet is the warehouse and distribution source for most of these works. But like all material on the web, you have to know what you are looking for to find it. The purpose of the Northwest Screendance Exposition is to create a greater awareness of this art form and build a community for it by taking it off the web and presenting it in the same immersive, theatrical context that builds community around other performance genres.

Early Endorsements for the Expo include:

Edward Schiessl, Owner, Bijou Art Cinemas
Rick Williams, Dean, Division of the Arts, Lane Community College
Jeff Goolsby, Faculty Lead, Media Arts Program, Lane Community College
Bonnie Simoa, Faculty Lead, Dance Program, Lane Community College
Brad Garner, Assistant Professor, Dance, University of Oregon; co-director, Harmonic Laboratory.

How You Can Help!

  • Donate today! Our funding deadline is September 1, 2015!
  • Tell your friends! Share our campaign on Facebook, or anywhere else you have connections!
  • Volunteer to staff the Expo! We will need good hands in the days leading up to the Expo!
  • Buy tickets to the Expo! Tickets are a very affordable $10, and there will only be 90 sold! Tickets go on sale September 10th.

Screendance is more than a hybrid medium, it's a performance genre in its own right. Donate today, and help create a home for screendance in Eugene and the greater Northwest!

story:
A BROADWAY STAR-STUDDED HOLIDAY SHOW

The New Paradigm Theatre Company, Inc. (NPT) connects the Fairfield County communities through its upcoming 2015 Holiday Show extravaganza!  NPT created an “all-in-one” performance collaborating with and benefiting the various communities of Fairfield County.

Continuing NPT's unique holiday season tradition, Kristin Huffman will produce a NYC-esque customized holiday show featuring Broadway, Film and TV stars for Fairfield County on Dec 11th - 8:00pm and Dec 13th - 2:00pm, 7:00pm at the Fairfield Theatre Company StageOne, Fairfield CT.

This 2015 Holiday Show will entertain audiences with Broadway dancers, singers, instrumentalists and “Ms Clauz with a Z”©.

It will also include a theatre arts education mentoring outreach piece that will include & provide selected student participants with a chance to be live on stage with the Broadway pros at the Holiday Show.  Show features will include:

  • The Fairfield County Children’s Choir, Cloonan Middle School & YMCA CASSA students from Stamford, CT and the ASK after-school students from The Klein Auditorium - Bridgeport, CT in production numbers alongside the Broadway professionals
  • A twist of advertising and sponsoring...NPT will feature local Fairfield County businesses onstage in “The 12 Days of Christmas” piece with each business sponsoring a “Day” (or their favorite charity) in holiday spirit
  • Singing Chef and TV star, Neil Fuentes from the Food Network, with a “foodie” showstopper performance that will leave the audience laughing into the holidays

YOUR INDIVIDUAL SUPPORT & DONATIONS

Help us reach our $12,000.00 goal to cover production costs and beyond!

Here's the beyond: you will become a key "tribe" member of NPT's efforts to bring the community back to the theatre, along with assisting our county's overall community-based organizations' mission to advance theatre arts programming for youth development and community engagement.

You'll also receive some fun, cool perks in return!  Some multifaceted perks in addition to show tickets may include:

  • Business advertisement and a chance to put your business executive(s) or your  company's favorite charity in the holiday show
  • Sponsorship of a youth to be a "Santa Letter" reader in the holiday show
  • Sponsorship of a participant for NPT's 2015 October's "So Ya Wanna be a Broadway star" event. 
  • Sponsorship of an after-school student from NPT's ACTS (Acting Class Teaching Stars) program in Bridgeport and/or Stamford, CT

Video of Youth involvement: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K7iY4Fttoiw

Your cash contributions are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

NPT is primed for success.  But like many theatre companies, we need your support to bridge the gap so we can continue our holiday season tradition at the Fairfield Theatre Company StageOne in Fairfield, CT.

For more info. on NPT, visit www.nptheatre.org to see our various theatre arts education and production initiatives year round.

PRODUCTION BUDGET BREAKDOWN

40% = Rehearsal & performance space rentals (lights, sound etc.)

40% = Casting, directing, and technical crew fees

15% = Production values

5%  = Advertisement & marketing

Thank You for your support!  

Additional ways to show your support: 

Share, like, and follow us on Facebook - “The New Paradigm Theatre” 

https://www.facebook.com/pages/The-New-Paradigm-Theatre/112332212178935

season tradition at the Fairfield Theatre Company StageOne in Fairfield,
 CT.
For more info. on NPT, visit www.nptheatre.org to see our various theatre arts education and production initiatives year round.





PRODUCTION BUDGET BREAKDOWN
40% = Rehearsal & performance space rentals (lights, sound etc.)
40% = Casting, directing, and technical crew fees 
15% = Production values
5%  = Advertisement & marketing









Thank You for your support!   

Additional ways to show your support: 

Share, like, and follow us on Facebook - “The New Paradigm Theatre” 
https://www.facebook.com/pages/The-New-Paradigm-Theatre/112332212178935

story:
This Is the Thing
I'm Mike Iveson. I'm trying to raise $15,000 to pay for my show, a show with words and music, called SORRY ROBOT - it just finished its run at the New Ohio Theatre, in New York City, to sold-out houses and nice reviews. We received a wonderful commission from Performance Space 122 to get it up and in front of people as part of their excellent COIL Festival. However, the thing has not even come close to paying for itself. It's like a teenager who refuses to get a job at this point and instead sits around at home playing video games, or maybe furiously knitting a cozy for something that doesn't need a cozy, like a futuristic telephone in a Keanu Reeves movie. You see where I'm going here.

No, This Part Is Really the Thing

The play I wrote: SORRY ROBOT. It has eight songs in it, and now, with the production's run behind us, we are hearing repeatedly that we need to make recordings of these songs available to our demanding and intensely sensory-deprived audience.

More on this in a minute, but first, here is an example of a song in the play. It's called FEELINGS (EMOTIONAL FEELINGS). 


Why Though? No, Honestly, Why.
PS122 has reached deep with this commission, part of their amazing Ethyl Eichelberger Award, and provided funds that have allowed me to pay many astounding people - not super generously, but adequately: performers Tanya Selvaratnam, Nicky Paraiso, and Anthony R. Brown (standout luminaries all), the wonderful lighting designer Lucrecia Briceno, the marvelous set and costume designer Parker Lutz, the incomparable stage manager Maurina Lioce, and last but not least the incredible director, Will Davis. But the commission can’t cover things like weeks of rehearsal space we needed to get this up and running, or nominal fees for the many people who have stepped up to help out in rehearsal and administratively, or the materials we used to make the visions of all these hard-working brilliant thinkers come to life.

Plus, like I said above, the songs. Many wonderful people got to see the show and hear the songs in it - and many wonderful people didn't, because of its short run and the intimate nature of the awesome New Ohio (around 80 seats). Getting us out of debt for the first run for the show can hopefully put us in the position where we can get a remount of the show on its feet. And as a thank-you to our crazy-generous supporters who can help us do that, we are going to provide everyone who contributes downloads of some of the final-night live recordings of some of SORRY ROBOT's songs.

I'm going to reiterate this below, mostly to make sure that I actually did just write that.

And Now, a Final Attempt at Clarity

Okay, I'll say it again. A contribution of any amount gets you some downloads of a number of songs from the show -- "Tears on the Treadmill" and a couple others. Whew. Get it!

In closing, here's some more words.

This is my first full-length play. It builds on years of writing songs for performance art, dances, and plays, and of writing short plays and pieces of my own. It's pretty exciting to have to hold an audience's attention for a whole hour and a half. I feel like I've always been making singles and am now tackling a full LP. But not like a greatest hits, if we are going to ride this metaphor into the dirt. I think the songs in my show are great hits but as a whole it has the integrity of an LP, like, uh, Dusty in Memphis or Houses of the Holy. I would say OK Computer but I'm trying to distract your attention away from like technology ideas because my play is essentially about robots, and then you might start thinking about "Mr. Roboto" by Styx, and I encourage that but then someone's gonna say "dad rock" and then I'm going to have to emotionally abuse myself, for obvious reasons. 

So do me a flavor, watch the video which provides some visuals to accompany one of the songs you can hear in SORRY ROBOT – and then see where you're at.

Your donations are tax-deductible to the extent provided by law.

*********
SORRY ROBOT is written and composed by Mike Iveson, directed by Will Davis, produced by Ariana Smart Truman, scenic and costume design is by Parker Lutz, lighting design is by Lucrecia Briceno, and production stage management is by Maurina Lioce. The cast includes Anthony R. Brown, Mike Iveson, Nicky Paraiso and Tanya Selvaratnam.

*********

SORRY ROBOT at New Ohio Theatre (154 Christopher St, Manhattan) 
Previews Jan 6 & 7 at 7pm; Jan 8 (Benefit Performance) at 7pm; Jan 9 at 10pm; Jan 10 at 6pm; Jan 11 at 2pm; Jan 12 at 5pm; Jan 14, 15, 16 at 8:30pm; Jan 17 at 2pm & 8:30pm

Showtimes, Info & Tickets: ps122.org/sorry-robot
SORRY ROBOT was commissioned by PS122, the Jerome Foundation and the Ethyl Eichelberger Award with funding generously provided by the Gesso Foundation. SORRY ROBOT was developed, in part, with assistance from The Orchard Project, a program of The Exchange (exchangenyc.org), and made possible with the support of Collapsable Giraffe.
Note that your acknowledgement for any contribution to this campaign will come from Collapsable Giraffe, our fiscal sponsor.

*********

About Me

Mike Iveson is a performer, composer and 2013 Ethyl Eichelberger Award winner. He wrote the music for plays: Dot, by Kate E. Ryan (Clubbed Thumb/Ohio Theatre), Potatoes of August, by Sibyl Kempson (Dixon Place, Red Eye Theater/MN), and You For Me For You, by Mia Chung (Woolly Mammoth), and is currently composing music for Kempson’s Fondly, Collette Richland (Elevator Repair Service) to premiere in 2015. The Kitchen has commissioned a new original play with music from Iveson, The Tear Drinkers, to premiere in 2015. He has also composed music for many of choreographer Sarah Michelson’s dances, including commissions for France’s Lyon Opera Ballet's Love Is Everything and for Mikhail Baryshnikov & the White Oak Dance Project's The Experts, as well as for many Michelson shows including Group Experience (PS122), for which he won a Bessie Award for music composition; Shadowmann (The Kitchen and PS122); Daylight (PS122); and Dogs (BAM). As a performer he has appeared in Elevator Repair Service’s Arguendo, The Select, The Sound and the Fury and Gatz, in a number of Sarah Michelson’s dances, as well as shows by Richard Maxwell/NYC Players, Dancenoise, Charles Atlas, Aaron Landsman, Erin Courtney, Yvonne Meier, Kate Benson, Tom Murrin/Jack Bump, Mike Taylor, and many others.

About the Ethyl Eichelberger Award

Since 1995, PS122 has given this commissioning award annually to an artist or group that exemplifies Eichelberger’s larger-than-life style and generosity of spirit; that embodies his multi-talented artistic virtuosity, bridging worlds and inspiring those around them. Each winner receives an initial $5,000 commission to create a new work along with full production support when the work premieres. Previous winners of the award include Justin Vivian Bond, Julie Atlas Muz, Peggy Shaw, among many others. The Ethyl Eichelberger award is made possible by the generosity of the Gesso Foundation. 

PS122 Artistic Director Vallejo Gantner commented on Mike Iveson winning the 2013 award, “As an actor, writer, composer and performance artist, Mike Iveson has been an essential collaborator with great dance and theater artists. His generosity and goodwill is well known. My hope is that the Ethyl Eichelberger Award will push Iveson to focus on his own creative project. The award has a history of encouraging artists to commit to their unique creative vision for the first time.”

About New Ohio Theatre

New Ohio Theatre is a two-time OBIE Award-winning performance venue that serves the vast independent theatre community of New York and the adventurous audiences who love them. As a small, downtown, artist-run organization with a twenty-plus year history as a beacon for bold and inventive work, we know the challenges and rewards of producing and presenting alternative, groundbreaking theatre. In any given year, there are over 500 independent theatre companies working for opportunities to develop and present new work. We believe the best of this community operates at the core of the contemporary theatre conversation (about both content and form) and acts collectively to expand the boundaries of the public imagination. With our move to Christopher Street, we aim to establish a professional, high-profile platform for the independent theatre community, reestablishing the West Village as a destination for mature, ridiculous, engaged, irreverent, gut-wrenching, frivolous, sophisticated, foolish, and profound theatrical endeavors. The New Ohio was founded as Soho Think Tank, Inc., in 1994 by playwright/director Robert Lyons.

About Performance Space 122

Performance Space 122 (PS122) provides incomparable experiences for audiences by presenting and commissioning artists whose work challenges boundaries of live performance. PS122 is dedicated to supporting the creative risks taken by artists from diverse genres, cultures and perspectives. We are an innovative local, national and international leader in contemporary performance.

Beginning in 2011, PS122 embarked on one of the most unusual and potentially radical shifts in its history, including a re-structuring of artist support, a business model overhaul, and the renovation of our building. As PS122’s East Village home undergoes a much-needed interior renovation supported primarily by the City of New York, DCA and DDC, PS122’s core activity continues to be providing audiences with contemporary live performance.

For over 3 decades, Performance Space 122 has been a hub for contemporary performance and an active member of the cultural community. Under the curatorial vision of Vallejo Gantner (Artistic Director 2005 – present) PS122 has developed a set of programs designed to re-establish the value of live performance, provide singular experiences for audiences that inspire critical thinking, and sustain the creative process for artists throughout their career. Largely in partnership with peer organizations, PS122 currently presents artists in all disciplines in spaces all over the city during an annual fall & spring season and COIL festival in January.

In addition to the commissioning and presenting of artists from NYC across the US, and around the globe, PS122 has increased our activity off the stage to provide audiences with a variety of access points and context for the work on stage. These activities include both talkbacks with the artists as well as in depth conversations that bring together luminaries from non-arts disciplines to discuss a variety of topics including everything from religion, to migration, to queer real estate and cultural diplomacy. PS122 encourages the asking of questions and debate of contemporary society’s issues in both artistic practice and audience experience.

mikeiveson.com

story:
Update: Double Your IMPACT! 5 Days Only

We have a very exciting update to share with you! MT Space recently received a special pledge from our friend and long-time supporter, Inga Petri.

Inga is the founder and principal of Strategic Moves, a strategy and marketing consultancy. Up until August 26, Inga will match any incoming donations, up to $1,000!

If we all pitched in another $5 and helped spread the word, we will hit that $20,000 mark in no time!

On behalf of the MT Space team, thank you! Your continued support means the world to us.

 

What is... Help Us Make IMPACT?


The story: Fifteen years ago, visionary and founder of MT Space (Multicultural Theatre Space), Majdi Bou-Matar, created a dynamic week filled with eclectic, contemporary and physical theatre and a platform for artists from all backgrounds to showcase their work. He saw a cross-pollination of artistic practices that can transform differences into innovation and spark dialogue.


Despite our recent funding shortfall, #IMPACT19festival marks its 10th-anniversary appearance in the Waterloo Region this September. 

September 24-29, we are presenting powerful productions from Tunisia, Ecuador, Mexico, and more.

Now we invite you to celebrate with us! Help us continue to raise important questions, push the boundaries, and bring stories that reflect our diverse Waterloo Region.



MT Space (founded 2004, Kitchener) is a multicultural theatre company that creates, presents and tours challenging work locally, nationally and internationally. Find out more at mtspace.ca or follow us on Facebook.



How Can We Make IMPACT Together?

Help Us Make IMPACT is the 4th Indiegogo Crowdfunding Campaign held by MT Space. This year, your contributions will help us:

  ⋅  Keep our ticket prices low! ($20/show)

  ⋅  Pay our artists, relieve their transportation and accommodation costs 

Together, we can enrich our community with space for all voices.
Together, we can create the conditions for innovation and connection.
Together, we can make IMPACT!

 


 

If you are unable to donate, there are many other ways you can help us. If you would like to show your support for the belief in the need for diversity of voices in arts and culture, please consider getting involved in any of the following ways:

  ⋅  Attend our events - be part of our community, volunteer, say hi and get to know us

  ⋅  Spread the word online - share our campaign, like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, your blog or anywhere else online

  ⋅  Talk to your friends – discuss the ideas behind Together We Make IMPACT with those you know, like co-workers or members of your book club

  ⋅  Subscribe to our MT Space newsletter

 

 

Donating to this campaign comes with many perks - see the list on the sidebar! You can also choose to donate without claiming a perk! MT Space is a registered charitable organization and is able to provide you with a tax receipt for donations $20 or higher.

Thanks for reading, and we hope to see you at this year's IMPACT Festival!
