story:
The Campaign:

This campaign will assist us, DUMB Theatre Co., to produce our first union production as a company, and will help to launch us into a non-profit status in the coming year so that we may continue to make work and facilitate new voices.

This June, we will be creating a 90min version of Twelfth Night on Outdoors at The Old American Can Factory June 20-23. In this production, we will examine the relationship between self identity and the restraints of the constructed social system, the inherent duality of our natures as human beings, and the hilarity and severity of forbidden love. We will also explore the clown's relationship to the ethereal and Feste’s role as a Facilitator of change/chaos.

The construct of the space will be simple. 10 black theatre boxes which will be configured by the cast into varying shapes to create new environments, with highly stylized movement transitions and mask work, in addition to original music performed by the cast and composed by William Bednar. All actors will be onstage for the entirety of the run and will work diligently throughout to create the world and community of the play. Without the ease of exiting the space to change, and will the added challenge of actors playing multiple characters, our costume design will be integral to the success of our storytelling. Our costumes will be contemporary with influence of Edwardian shapes, designed by the ineffably talented Clare Parker.

All funds raised in ticket sales and concessions for this project will be put towards developing into an official non-profit organization with the goal of fully producing an original play created by one of our Lab members in addition to hosting multiple seminars, workshops and developmental labs in the next year.

 

Our Mission:

DUMB Theatre Co. is dedicated to developing work in a collaborative nature and providing leadership opportunities to women and under-represented groups. We strive to create resonant theatre which inspires reckless abandon, rebellion and courage in the face of adversity. Through simplicity in production values, clear storytelling, and robust performances, we reimagine classical text and develop new works from fresh voices.

 

Our Story:

In 2017, Peter Hedges (What’s Eating Gilbert Grape; Dan in Real Life) envisioned a writer’s group where early career creators could gather, discuss, and share their work. Lindsay Bednar-Carter, our company’s founder, was inspired to actualize this community and thus “The Lab” found it’s home in the Old American Can Factory on Sunday afternoons. After a year of developing new work through “The Lab”, it became apparent that our creators were in need of an in house production team. Thus DUMB Theatre Co. was born to fully realize the new works developed in “The Lab”, as well as to provide opportunities for artists with a passion for leadership to discover their voice. We are dedicated to facilitating a collaborative atmosphere and asking our artists to step outside the box to create the unseen, unheard, unsaid and unknown.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We're well on our way: our theatre and rehearsal space rental and several other essential expenditures are already paid for through private investments and donations.

With your help we will raise the majority of the funds we need to raise are for our 10 actor’s stipends. We have committed through AEA to pay a $350 stipend but we are hoping to raise this amount to $500 which doesn’t even truly begin to fairly compensate them for their time and effort. We are so thankful to our cast for volunteering their abilities in order to support our growth as a company.

In addition to raising their stipend from $350 to $500, this will require us to purchase Workers Comp insurance, in addition to Volunteer Accident coverage. Raising our budget by a quoted $2,300.

We also would like to serve adult beverages at our event. A rooftop in NY in the summer can be decorated nicely with a beverage or two, even if it’s just with some cold bubbly seltzer! The cost of alcoholic beverages for 99 people over 4 days would be about $1400. But the insurance and license required with it are an additional quoted $2,500.

We also would like afford our production team and designers a small stipend each all under $500. To pay for their time and efforts.

We will need $682.50 for our crates used to construct our set. And a very small budget of $250 for our costume designer to use towards dry cleaning and the purchase of proper undergarments for the performance. $40 towards mask making supplies, and $50 towards the rental of weaponry.

We would also would like to have a very small budget of $450 to put towards camera rental, website fees, Facebook and Instagram advertisements as a part of our marketing campaign.

If you did the math, you will see that if we got absolutely everything we wanted, we would need to raise more than $11,000. So we hope you will please help us meet this goal and then some!

 

REWARDS!

We are offering a diverse selection of rewards in exchange for your early support.  

***

Please note that you may need to double click on the reward square to see the full contents.

Also, you'll be able to choose which night you'd like to attend at the end of this campaign, after you've purchased your tickets through the perk of your choice.

***

Not in New York? Good for you! As a part of our mission, DUMB Theatre Co. believes in making theatre accessible to everyone which is why we keep our ticket prices so low. If you would like to give the gift of theatre to one of Young Dancers in Repertory’s scholarship students and their families, you can purchase and donate those tickets for just $20 each. And, we'll send you 5 digital production photos and a signed program from the cast, so you can feel like you were there!

 

Please see the side bar for other reward details.

 

Who’s Involved?

 

 

Our cast is outstanding and teeming with fresh, exciting talent. Viola will be played by Leigha Sinnott a UNCSA and Juilliard graduate who recently wrapped filming on Jay Craven’s new film Martin Eden. Emily Jeanne Brown* (also a managing director for our company) will be playing Olivia. Emily has performed at Forestburgh Playhouse, American Shakespeare Center, Texas Shakespeare Festival, and Guthrie Theater and is an MFA graduate of ACT. This Fall, she performed her one-woman show, SHE WOLF, about Shakespeare's portrayal of Margaret of Anjou, at The Tank in New York. Sam Massaro* will be playing Sir Toby. Sam has a plethora of credits with BEDLAM and a history at Folger Shakespeare. He also can be seen at Gulfshore Playhouse and Alabama Shakespeare in the coming year. Maria will be played by Narea Kang* a New York based actor, producer and director. She has worked at Ars Nova, New Ohio Theatre, Lyra Theater, Corkscrew Theater Festival and has participated in readings and new play development at La MaMa, New Dramatists, New Georges, Intar Theatre. Regionally she has worked at Intiman Theatre, American Conservatory Theater, and Livermore Shakespeare Festival. She also has an MFA from ACT. Emma Factor will play Feste. Emma is a graduate of UNCSA and can be seen as as Johnny Weir's co-host, Jenna, on Syfy's Happy! and as Lucinda in her recurring role on CBS' Madam Secretary. William Bednar (also our composer) will be playing Sebastian. After Twelfth Night, he will begin rehearsals for Harry Potter and the Cursed Child. He is a UNCSA grad in addition to Tij D’oyen, Tony Jenkins, and Cody Robinson.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

 

Make a contribution! Any amount helps. Even a single dollar gets us one step closer to our goal.

Share the campaign on your social media platforms and/or via email. Tell people why you’re excited about DUMB Theatre Co.’s production of Twelfth Night and invite them to be part of our future!

Follow us on Instagram and Facebook.

Join our email list, and stay in the loop.
story_txt: The Campaign:This campaign will assist us, DUMB Theatre Co., to produce our first union production as a company, and will help to launch us into a non-profit status in the coming year so that we may continue to make work and facilitate new voices.This June, we will be creating a 90min version of Twelfth Night on Outdoors at The Old American Can Factory June 20-23. In this production, we will examine the relationship between self identity and the restraints of the constructed social system, the inherent duality of our natures as human beings, and the hilarity and severity of forbidden love. We will also explore the clown's relationship to the ethereal and Feste’s role as a Facilitator of change/chaos.The construct of the space will be simple. 10 black theatre boxes which will be configured by the cast into varying shapes to create new environments, with highly stylized movement transitions and mask work, in addition to original music performed by the cast and composed by William Bednar. All actors will be onstage for the entirety of the run and will work diligently throughout to create the world and community of the play. Without the ease of exiting the space to change, and will the added challenge of actors playing multiple characters, our costume design will be integral to the success of our storytelling. Our costumes will be contemporary with influence of Edwardian shapes, designed by the ineffably talented Clare Parker.All funds raised in ticket sales and concessions for this project will be put towards developing into an official non-profit organization with the goal of fully producing an original play created by one of our Lab members in addition to hosting multiple seminars, workshops and developmental labs in the next year. Our Mission:DUMB Theatre Co. is dedicated to developing work in a collaborative nature and providing leadership opportunities to women and under-represented groups. We strive to create resonant theatre which inspires reckless abandon, rebellion and courage in the face of adversity. Through simplicity in production values, clear storytelling, and robust performances, we reimagine classical text and develop new works from fresh voices. Our Story:In 2017, Peter Hedges (What’s Eating Gilbert Grape; Dan in Real Life) envisioned a writer’s group where early career creators could gather, discuss, and share their work. Lindsay Bednar-Carter, our company’s founder, was inspired to actualize this community and thus “The Lab” found it’s home in the Old American Can Factory on Sunday afternoons. After a year of developing new work through “The Lab”, it became apparent that our creators were in need of an in house production team. Thus DUMB Theatre Co. was born to fully realize the new works developed in “The Lab”, as well as to provide opportunities for artists with a passion for leadership to discover their voice. We are dedicated to facilitating a collaborative atmosphere and asking our artists to step outside the box to create the unseen, unheard, unsaid and unknown. What We Need & What You GetWe're well on our way: our theatre and rehearsal space rental and several other essential expenditures are already paid for through private investments and donations.With your help we will raise the majority of the funds we need to raise are for our 10 actor’s stipends. We have committed through AEA to pay a $350 stipend but we are hoping to raise this amount to $500 which doesn’t even truly begin to fairly compensate them for their time and effort. We are so thankful to our cast for volunteering their abilities in order to support our growth as a company.In addition to raising their stipend from $350 to $500, this will require us to purchase Workers Comp insurance, in addition to Volunteer Accident coverage. Raising our budget by a quoted $2,300.We also would like to serve adult beverages at our event. A rooftop in NY in the summer can be decorated nicely with a beverage or two, even if it’s just with some cold bubbly seltzer! The cost of alcoholic beverages for 99 people over 4 days would be about $1400. But the insurance and license required with it are an additional quoted $2,500.We also would like afford our production team and designers a small stipend each all under $500. To pay for their time and efforts.We will need $682.50 for our crates used to construct our set. And a very small budget of $250 for our costume designer to use towards dry cleaning and the purchase of proper undergarments for the performance. $40 towards mask making supplies, and $50 towards the rental of weaponry.We would also would like to have a very small budget of $450 to put towards camera rental, website fees, Facebook and Instagram advertisements as a part of our marketing campaign.If you did the math, you will see that if we got absolutely everything we wanted, we would need to raise more than $11,000. So we hope you will please help us meet this goal and then some! REWARDS!We are offering a diverse selection of rewards in exchange for your early support.  ***Please note that you may need to double click on the reward square to see the full contents.Also, you'll be able to choose which night you'd like to attend at the end of this campaign, after you've purchased your tickets through the perk of your choice.***Not in New York? Good for you! As a part of our mission, DUMB Theatre Co. believes in making theatre accessible to everyone which is why we keep our ticket prices so low. If you would like to give the gift of theatre to one of Young Dancers in Repertory’s scholarship students and their families, you can purchase and donate those tickets for just $20 each. And, we'll send you 5 digital production photos and a signed program from the cast, so you can feel like you were there! Please see the side bar for other reward details. Who’s Involved?  Our cast is outstanding and teeming with fresh, exciting talent. Viola will be played by Leigha Sinnott a UNCSA and Juilliard graduate who recently wrapped filming on Jay Craven’s new film Martin Eden. Emily Jeanne Brown* (also a managing director for our company) will be playing Olivia. Emily has performed at Forestburgh Playhouse, American Shakespeare Center, Texas Shakespeare Festival, and Guthrie Theater and is an MFA graduate of ACT. This Fall, she performed her one-woman show, SHE WOLF, about Shakespeare's portrayal of Margaret of Anjou, at The Tank in New York. Sam Massaro* will be playing Sir Toby. Sam has a plethora of credits with BEDLAM and a history at Folger Shakespeare. He also can be seen at Gulfshore Playhouse and Alabama Shakespeare in the coming year. Maria will be played by Narea Kang* a New York based actor, producer and director. She has worked at Ars Nova, New Ohio Theatre, Lyra Theater, Corkscrew Theater Festival and has participated in readings and new play development at La MaMa, New Dramatists, New Georges, Intar Theatre. Regionally she has worked at Intiman Theatre, American Conservatory Theater, and Livermore Shakespeare Festival. She also has an MFA from ACT. Emma Factor will play Feste. Emma is a graduate of UNCSA and can be seen as as Johnny Weir's co-host, Jenna, on Syfy's Happy! and as Lucinda in her recurring role on CBS' Madam Secretary. William Bednar (also our composer) will be playing Sebastian. After Twelfth Night, he will begin rehearsals for Harry Potter and the Cursed Child. He is a UNCSA grad in addition to Tij D’oyen, Tony Jenkins, and Cody Robinson. Other Ways You Can Help  Make a contribution! Any amount helps. Even a single dollar gets us one step closer to our goal.Share the campaign on your social media platforms and/or via email. story:
What's the Project?

Epic Party Theatre will be producing the immersive ball experience slay / werk / strut  at A.C.T.' s Costume Shop Theater in San Francisco, CA for a limited run of 5-performances in June 2020

The show description:

Epic Party Theatre is throwing a ball! Audiences will have the chance to re-live the fabulous queer ball scene made famous by the 1990 documentary "Paris is Burning". Get ready to form your own legendary house, snatch trophies, and dance the night away, children! Will you get 10’s across the board? Or will you strut away empty-handed? Slay the game and serve femme realness in this one of a kind theatrical experience, honey!

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are commissioning a fabulous playwright Nick Hadikwa Mwaluko to write the play
  • We are hiring a fantastic team of people, and we need to pay them for their efforts:
    • Technical Director
    • Costume Designer
    • Ball Consultant
    • Choreographer
    • Scenic Designer
    • Lighting Designer
    • Dramaturg
    • Ensemble of Dancers and Actors
  • Donors can receive perks like Social Media Shout outs, Complimentary Tickets, Ad Space in Our Playbill, Signed Posters, Walk-on Role in Our Production, Invitation to First Rehearsal, and Invitation to Opening Night!

Does Epic Party Theatre know anything about the queer ball scene?

We hear you! We do have limited knowledge about ball culture, but that's right we're reaching out to the ball culture! We'll be reaching into the ball culture to be sure the experience is as authentic as possible.

  • We'll be hiring a Ball Consultant, Real-life voguers/dancers, and engaging the local ball scene as much as possible.

If you are unable to donate, please help us spread the word!

  • Share the campaign with your network of people!
  • Be sure to come see us when the show goes up!

story:
Short Summary

Well, Well, WELCOME to the Orange County Rehabilitation Center for desperate and washed up celebs. I’m Jason Newsom, director and co-creator of Orange is the New Comeback, and I’ll be taking you on your tour today.

Let me start out by telling you a little bit about myself. My sole mission in life has been to help people through the power of laughter and the effectiveness of experiencing someone’s story. Storytelling can have profound effects not only on the people listening, but also the storyteller themselves. I love what I do because of the ability to evoke even the smallest positive change can have amazing effects on everyone involved.

Orange is the New Comeback will hit your funny bone, but it will also hit you smack dab in the feels. This project is one that we are super proud of because it goes beyond the confines of your typical parody and truly brings these women’s stories to the front. In doing so, we hope you walk away still giggling, but also thinking about what you just saw.

With you help, we can turn this project into something that will live beyond just our 8 performances in May. This has the potential to be brought to different cities. We want this to be a project to be recognized for its production quality along with the amazing talent we have in the cast and creative team.

What We Need & What You Get

We want to produce a stellar multimedia theatrical production, and YOU can help:

The amount we have donated to us will help us turn this into a kick ass show. The funds we raise will be used in three different ways.

  • First and foremost we would like to compensate our talent for all of their hard work. These actors are seriously some of the best comedians and artists in the Chicago area. We are excited to afford them the opportunity to get paid for their hard work, which is not something we, as non-union actors, are accustomed to getting, which is NOT OK. Many of them have gone to college to study their craft. I am of the mindset that people should be paid for doing their jobs, especially when they do them as well as these ladies and gentleman.
  • The second way we will be using the funds created is to help us compensate the people working hard on the production side. This would first and foremost include the team we have set in place to help us with the parts of the project that are filmed. There is a lot of filming and editing that will go into this production. It is our job to make sure that we are bringing the best product to our audiences, but also that we are taking care of the talent that we have producing this amazing content.
  • And finally, your donation will help us in promoting this show; creating opportunities for us to involve and connect with the community. We are here to make you laugh, but we are also here to make a difference. This show touches on heavier subjects such as race, sexuality, and sexual identity. Our diverse cast will be bringing these issues into the light, and if they can do so through laughter, all the better. 

The Impact

The difference your contribution makes:

  • A portion of the proceeds made from the show will be donated to The Gateway Foundation. The Gateway Charitable Foundation raises dollars to fund critical elements of Gateway substance abuse programs for early intervention for drug rehab and alcohol treatment.  Gateway Foundation Alcohol & Drug Treatment helps individuals, regardless of economic status, get their lives back on track.
  • As a small theatre company in Chicago, we strive to put on entertaining shows for our audience to enjoy. To make this the best independent show we can, we need your help.
  • With your help, we can make this show more professional and more entertaining for our audience.
  • We have an idea, vision and passion for this show, and with your contribution, we can actualize it.

Risks & Challenges

Obstacles we face:

  • Chicago has an amazing independent and professional theatre scene, and some smaller shows get lost in the shuffle. We are trying to do something different than other groups in the city and with this fundraiser, we want to bring the community together, to show what we can do, if we work hard.
  • This show is completely different than anything you will find in Chicago. And as such, there isn’t a huge market that currently exists for it. OITNC is not just a parody on Orange is the New Black. It takes its own shape and has become something different entirely. We need your help to stake a claim in the theatre scene for shows that want to think outside of the box.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • If you aren't able to donate to the campaign, it's okay! Please spread the word and use social media to get the word out.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Bionic Ballerina

Informed by my journey of advanced robotic surgical hip replacement, this fine art dance film incorporating smart technology light suits will tell the story of my re-awakening. I threw myself into ballet to overcome my daily challenges, and I now have followers that put their hope in me to show them ultimately what is possible in a new human condition.

Visual Concept:  A Cyber Ballet

  • I am not a professional dancer. By day I work full time and have an Engineering degree, by night I study the body with illustrations to make a come back from my joint disease.
  • I did a final year dissertation years ago on stress transfer through a hip arthroplasty, 20 years later I did not anticipate becoming the subject of my own biomechanical study.
  • I have come so far with my own personal financing, but you can make it a dream come true for others. Your contribution not only helps me pay towards the professional artists and stunt people who are working with me, but bring the dance film to a stunning hyper-reality which will show young athletes what they can be capable of.

I am not under any illusion that I can match the standards of a professional ballet dancer, but I have pushed myself to work with what I've got and enjoy what I have. I hope this can pave the way to show aspiring young athletes to find new ways to work with their bodies.


What We Need & What You Get

I have so far paid for private tuition, begged and borrowed equipment and stages for testing, laboured long into the nights constructing bionic suits, but I can't finish without your help. I'm feeling pretty drained and there's still things I need to pay for.

I have 3 tiers of goals. The 1st is simply to pay for what I already owe for choreography and training. The 2nd is to shoot this as cleanly as possible with minimal crew on location. The ultimate goal of 60k would see my dream come true to hire the stage and production I need, and take my story to film festivals.


  • I want to reimburse every artist for working with me, I have come so far paying out of my own pocket, but we could go so much farther. If this campaign is minimally funded, we will shoot as cleanly as possible on location. If we exceed our initial goal, I will be able to hire a visually stunning stage to go with the stunning costumes I'm building.
  • If I don't reach my goal, the funding received will simply reimburse many of the artists who have spent their time working with me on private coaching, as well as pay for much of the materials and electronics I still have extended on credit card.
  • Our perks are to allow you to collaborate with us and amplify our voice. By donating to this project we will share and shoutout your message to our audience across various channels of 25-30k followers. We can offer online ballet lessons and online social media consultancy.
  • I also have secret perks for industry level sponsors and partners who wish to either show their philanthropic support in exchange for licensing of the dance film, brand awareness, or in exchange for a specially customised piece of wall art.

Improving the Human Condition

Despite appearances I really am just an average human being, I've failed against degenerative joint disease and have worked and studied hard to enjoy the different range and mechanics that the man-made arthroplasty has given me. This fine art dance film is a celebration of the conjunction of high performing athletics, science and medicine, at a time when hip surgery has become ubiquitous at younger ages like myself.

  • Injuries and degeneration are to be expected among high performing athletes. The ominous fear of surgery becomes the psychological transition point for most athletic careers. I hope to relieve some of that traumatic burden with hope that if I can do it, perhaps you can look forward to a different condition after your own personal battle too. 
  • I am an engineer-artist. I have not gone into this blindly, with the guidance of my surgeon and professionals, I am exploring my limits and want to make this a technologically visual celebration. 
  • I have built sci-fi costumes for feature films, and I am midway through a detailed construction, I need funding to finish this. My exploration of movement has already gone beyond the known range of science that surgeons are used to seeing for this kind of surgery. All the ingredients are there, I just need your help to bring it together.
Before surgery, I always wanted to be "better" whatever that meant, but my biggest hurdle was after surgery, to let go and allow myself to be different. My joint cannot be compared to what it was before, and to do so puts me in a psychological bind I'm sure anyone who feels trapped in their bodies can relate to. Now I simply accept that "progress" is on all levels, mind, body and spirit. My spirit was never taken down by the hip joint disease, instead I am entirely grateful that modern science and medicine filled in the gap that I studied 20 years ago on arthroplasties.

Risks & Challenges

I am not a performer, I don't have any belief that I will be able to continue training my body in this way as a professional career. I am genuinely scared that the rate at which my body heals and recovers is less responsive now and I feel I have this last chance to archive what I can do on film. 

  • What qualifies me to "Leonardo myself" is that I am thoughtfully studying,  strengthening and adapting my patterns of movement. You won't know that I've had a hip replacement. My flow is unique and focuses on my strengths. We can make ourselves superhuman in different ways.
  • I am not opening myself up to excessive risk by over-training and overwork. That was something I could do before my hip surgeries, but I have no buffer left in me. No safety cushion. My physiology is changed and the future for me now means I have to look after what I've got as it doesn't self-repair. My hip replacement needs to last 30 years. I hope by the time my other hip goes, I will not only be better prepared but also able to have some engineering input of my own toward changes I would like to be made. Dear Stryker [Manufacturers of my hip], I hope you are reading...

Other Ways You Can Help

Can you help in any other way?  This fine art dance film is depending on the collaborations of many artists and engineers, private message me if you have a personal interest. I have secret perks for collaborators:

  • Follow me on Instagram and YouTube to get a feel of how far this network extends, maybe you or someone you know could be a valuable part of it.
  • Share with professionals and friends alike, it's easy to do, use the buttons on the top left. 
  • Leave me a comment I would dearly LOVE your feedback on where this leads your thoughts for improvement of the human condition.
  • Put me in contact with anyone you might know who could network with me and share our reach. I intend to submit this film to festivals and promote it long after I've produced it.

And that's all there is to it.

Despite appearances I really am just an average human being, I've failed against degenerative joint disease and have worked and studied hard to enjoy the different range and mechanics that the man-made arthroplasty has given me. This fine art dance film is a celebration of the conjunction of high performing athletics, science and medicine, at a time when hip surgery has become ubiquitous at younger ages like myself.  Injuries and degeneration are to be expected among high performing athletes. The ominous fear of surgery becomes the psychological transition point for most athletic careers. I hope to relieve some of that traumatic burden with hope that if I can do it, perhaps you can look forward to a different condition after your own personal battle too.  I am an engineer-artist. I have not gone into this blindly, with the guidance of my surgeon and professionals, I am exploring my limits and want to make this a technologically visual celebration.  I have built sci-fi costumes for feature films, and I am midway through a detailed construction, I need funding to finish this. My exploration of movement has already gone beyond the known range of science that surgeons are used to seeing for this kind of surgery. All the ingredients are there, I just need your help to bring it together. 
Before surgery, I always wanted to be "better" whatever that meant, but my biggest hurdle was after surgery, to let go and allow myself to be different. My joint cannot be compared to what it was before, and to do so puts me in a psychological bind I'm sure anyone who feels trapped in their bodies can relate to. Now I simply accept that "progress" is on all levels, mind, body and spirit. My spirit was never taken down by the hip joint disease, instead I am entirely grateful that modern science and medicine filled in the gap that I studied 20 years ago on arthroplasties.
   Risks & Challenges 

I am not a performer, I don't have any belief that I will be able to continue training my body in this way as a professional career. I am genuinely scared that the rate at which my body heals and recovers is less responsive now and I feel I have this last chance to archive what I can do on film.   What qualifies me to "Leonardo myself" is that I am thoughtfully studying,  strengthening and adapting my patterns of movement. You won't know that I've had a hip replacement. My flow is unique and focuses on my strengths. We can make ourselves superhuman in different ways. I am not opening myself up to excessive risk by over-training and overwork. That was something I could do before my hip surgeries, but I have no buffer left in me. No safety cushion. My physiology is changed and the future for me now means I have to look after what I've got as it doesn't self-repair. My hip replacement needs to last 30 years. I hope by the time my other hip goes, I will not only be better prepared but also able to have some engineering input of my own toward changes I would like to be made. Dear Stryker [Manufacturers of my hip], I hope you are reading... 
   Other Ways You Can Help Can you help in any other way?  This fine art dance film is depending on the collaborations of many artists and engineers, private message me if you have a personal interest. I have secret perks for collaborators:  Follow me on Instagram and YouTube to get a feel of how far this network extends, maybe you or someone you know could be a valuable part of it. Share with professionals and friends alike, it's easy to do, use the buttons on the top left. 
Leave me a comment I would dearly LOVE your feedback on where this leads your thoughts for improvement of the human condition.
Put me in contact with anyone you might know who could network with me and share our reach. I intend to submit this film to festivals and promote it long after I've produced it.   And that's all there is to it.

story:
PIONEERS!#goforth

@ JACK March 24th-April 9th

Hello. I'm William Burke. I'm a playwright. This will be the 4th play I've produced myself in New York since 2013. For those plays we've made a bar with working taps, we've turned an audience into an army of street Elmos and we've had three live dogs on stage. Each time we've been able to make bold yet economical choices that have transformed the space and blurred the lines between the observers and the event and have expanded the theatrical circle of performance to include you, the audience. 

This play is about how we look and encourage and discourage youth and artistry as a society and as people. It contains a great deal of personal writing and observations but it's filtered through 3 dynamic actors and a composer. I'm hoping to achieve a sense of catharsis and together, through the performance, the audience and performers can recognize each other and know that we're not alone and that our choices, good and bad, inform and contribute to the greater bucket of life. It's about how are we are all stuck in our own way but also engaging in our own courageousness and worth to struggle to disentangle ourselves.

We're going to suspend the actors from the ceiling in a net above the audience.  We need your support so we can actually support the actors. Like LITERALLY support the actors. 

We need $4,863 for...

A big ass net
Platforms
Weights
Lumber
Beam Clamps
Carabiners
Harnesses
Transportation
Artist fees
And things we haven't thought of.


Producing is stressful...

BUT, I love it. It would be great to be produced by a large company but there is certain freedom that a space like JACK gives you and the limitations of a tin-foiled room only invigorates us to find more creative ways to melt your brain. I only ask people for money when I need it and I can't tell you how much energy it gives me and how much it makes me work harder to make something impactful and relevant.

    ...but the people are where it's at.

    Let's be honest. People don't do my plays or lot of other people's plays for the money. They do it because they believe in the work. I'm fortunate that they are passionate and talented and awesome. I try to pay them as much as I can and respect their time and talents but we all know that they are worth much much more. These are those people this time around:

    Carolyn Mraz
    Megan Lang
    Catherine Brookman
    Ugo Chukwu
    Nikki Calonge
    Zoe Geltman
    John Del Gaudio

story:
We are 17 days away from premiering our musical about motherhood, Gross Domestic Product. I have been working on this play for 3 years and although it has been a "labor of love," the labor part is real. 

This project has been my baby and she is almost ready to make her debut but we need one last big push and it can come from you! 

Since we know that 10 is the magic number here (think centimeters) we are asking you to donate $10 - or even better, any multiple of $10* - to bring this show to life. 

Our goal is to raise $4,000 by opening night. This will fund final production costs so that our talented design team's full vision can be realized. 

About Gross Domestic Product

When a trailblazing senator holds a public forum to unveil her new economic agenda for mothers in America, she is slapped with realities that are far more harsh than she could have imagined. Gross Domestic Product  traverses the heartfelt as well as the outrageous, while examining what this "labor of love" is actually worth to society.

The script comes from interviews with over 40 mothers throughout Connecticut spanning both race and economic class.  It is obviously an extremely personal piece for me and yet it it will reach anyone who's been a mother or had  a mother because it seeks to make visible the invisible.  Gross Domestic Product asks the question: What is the human cost to society, to mothers, to children, to families when "invisible" work is not included in our nation's  GDP?

Check out our amazing cast and creative team!

Please spread the word about the this campaign and don't forget to get your tickets as soon as possible.

*All donations go to HartBeat Ensemble so they are tax-deductible.

Thank you for your support!!

These performances of Gross Domestic Product are supported in part by the National Endowment for the Arts, The Edward C. & Ann T. Roberts Foundation, Permanent Commission on the Status of Women and the Connecticut Office of the Arts, Artists Fellowship Program.

story:
My name is Teddy Fatscher and I am Artistic Director of Matter Movement Group. I possess a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree in Modern Dance Performance and Choreography from The University of the Arts. I have danced professionally for companies such as MOMIX and Brian Sanders' JUNK for the last 9 years. My performing has reached all over Philadelphia and the U.S. as well as taking me to Dubai to perform for National Emirates Day celebrations. While working for the aforementioned JUNK I was given creative agency to invent vocabulary of movement that the company performed in previous Fringe Festival works and other touring shows. I also Co-Direct a resident performance group, Bradley's Bucks, at Franky Bradley's which is a local artist hub and watering hole. Bradley's Bucks is known for bringing aerial performance and extensive set design to an otherwise strictly cabaret/burlesque performance venue. I plan on turning Matter Movement Group into an all-encompassing Non-Profit Organization with regular performances, workshops, and accessible classes for all experience levels.

In order for Matter Movement Group to launch into the exosphere, we need to establish a reputation with the community. "UNHINGED" will help introduce our mission and our work to the large audience of the Philadelphia Fringe Festival. In doing so MMG must hire trained professionals from performers to lighting designers to sound technicians and many other hands that will help carry the work. Being a performer first, I know the amount of work that each artist will pour into this project and how much that time and energy is worth. Picasso's paintings wouldn't be the same without oil-paint, Diaghilev would fall from our history books without the Ballet Russe. Point being, an artist needs to know the worth of his assets and how to utilize them appropriately. As Artistic Director, I find that the people you work with are endlessly inspirational. They harbor the ability to teach everyone else involved  about creation and working with other artists outside of their specific focus or skill set. 

Im asking YOU not just as a donor but as a part of our family to help bring this project to life. Your contribution will aid in artist compensation, set materials and construction, rent for our venue throughout the month of September and most importantly giving MMG the ability to make a strong opening statement in the Philadelphia Fringearts Festival. This will ensure the future prosperity of our movement and mission.

What We Need & What You Get

MMG is attempting to raise $6,000 to fund artist compensation and venue rental fees/insurance. Each performer will be compensated $500 for their part-time work not only as performers but also as devisors. This work will span over the months of August (rehearsals) and September (Shows). The remaining $1000 would cover most if not all of MMG's rental fees and insurance.

So what do you get? There will be different levels of sponsorship offered based upon your donation. Perks include but are not limited to VIP tickets to "UNHINGED", Season Subscriptions to future works of MMG and Bradley's Bucks, An Invitation to our Sponsor Appreciation Party (which will include catered food, an open bar and pop-up performances throughout the night), A spot in our program for your name/buisness logo and MMG apparel. 

 

The Impact

Matter Movement Group is promoting a distinction in the community by creating live renderings of Artistic Director, Teddy Fatscher's visions. Utilizing a collaborative approach MMG relies heavily on the brains and bodies involved with individual projects. Amongst annual seasons and tours, MMG uses its art and entertainment to raise awareness and funds for local non-profits and charities. Here's a link to a benefit show that we held at Franky Bradley's for Family Support Line with the Bradley's Bucks.

https://vimeo.com/271224159

Also here is another link that will introduce you to some of the cast from the Bucks that will also work with MMG on "UNHINGED"

https://vimeo.com/274817380

Risks & Challenges

"With great risk often comes great reward. There are failures, setbacks and even complete start-over's along the way, but if you don't risk something, you'll never gain anything." -Thomas Jefferson

There are inevitable risks that every artist takes. Whether the superficial "Will anyone like what I'm doing?" to the more serious "Will anyone get seriously hurt during our performance?" These are questions that will only be answered when the show happens. But the show needs backers and supporters who believe in the greater mission beyond the spectacle of performance. I have a decade of experience in creating and performing works and have confidence and the drive to make this show better then the last. Im insured to cover myself, performers, venue and audience members attending the show.

Other Ways You Can Help

YOU DON'T NEED TO FINANCIALLY BACK MMG TO MAKE A DIFFERENCE IN OUR MISSION. At the very least tell a friend. Tell all your friends. Tell your mom and Dad. Tell your co-workers. Tell your dog. Just spread the word and help MMG make their first appearance in the Philadelphia Fringe Festival one for the books.

story:
This is it!

For the past ten years, I have been honing the craft of acting. First at the wonderful Booker T. Washington High School for the Performing and Visual Arts in Dallas, Texas, then at University of North Texas receiving my BA in performance and now at The Theatre School at Depaul University! These past few years have not been the easiest, but through consistent perseverance, and constant emotional, mental, and financial support from friends and family I have been given the privilege to reach this moment. 

 

However, It doesn't end here

This is really only the beginning of my journey. Though I have been training for quite some time, I still must enter the professional world. My trips to New York and LA is going to cost money, and though I'm working I"m also a full time student and I will need help. It is my hope that the continuous faith that has been put in me, still exists and with the help of you guys I can continue doing what I love. 

Breakdown

So, just to give you guys an idea of what I would need help with as I go on my journey to NY&LA, here's what everything will roughly cost:

Flights:$ 800 (including LA & NY)

Prints for Headshots: $200

Hotels/Air BNB: $400

Audition Clothes: $300

Expenses: $800 (for both LA and NY)

story:
Scrambled Porn

is an experimental play about why people build relationships only to destroy them—unearthing the fear and longing buried underneath it all. In the aftermath of their relationship, in the abyss of someone’s front yard, Adam, Sam, and June try to prove why they couldn’t be alone, but can’t stay together. At their individual mics like a busted En Vogue live set, the ‘throuple’ share the creation of their own suffering.

Featuring: Brennan Vickery, Cassandra Paras, and Niccolo Walsh

Opening Night Wednesday, April 17th at The Flea Theater

 

Eden Theater Company (ETC)

was founded by Diane Davis Steiker and Cassandra Paras, mother and daughter working together to bring original experimental theater to New York City stages.  We strive, as a tribe of artists, to devise courageous stories that question the unknown. ETC’s mission is to provide a variety of opportunities for the development and production of original works of theater of emerging writers and innovators, while also building and sustaining a collective of artists supporting each other’s work.

 

WHAT WE NEED!

Every dollar of your donation invests in our mission, and participates in making our inaugural production a success.

It all goes to => Artist Pay => Crew Pay => Theater Rental => Insurance => Workshop Space => Rehearsal Space => Workshop Space => Props => Costumes => Set Design => Lighting Design => Sound Design => Promotion => and more…

...Our budget is $13,000.00 We’re hoping to raise half of our budget here, with you as our advocates and partners. 

 

The Challenges

of our organizational efforts to run theatrical productions are tremendous. Our company has a staff of 5 people pulling it all together, and then the set, lighting, and sound technicians needed to transform our stage to another world. Where most artistic work is motivated by the passion to create, we hope to provide compensation for an artist’s efforts, as well as become self-sufficient in carrying on the production needs for future productions of emerging playwriters.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Sponsor Us: 

  • Share our campaign and mission online:  Facebook | Instagram
  • Do you operate a company looking for artistic ventures to support?  Contact us to discuss potential company or seasonal sponsorships.
  • Send a tax-deductible donation to us through our fiscal sponsor, Fractured Atlas.
  • Looking for more information or have a question? Email us at edentheatercompany@gmail.com

story:
Story?

This campaign is important to us not only to fund and bring an important piece of theatre to an audience but also to highlight the struggles that people with additional needs face in a world where perfection is worshiped and tabloid media are ruthless in their pursuit of a headline.

We are passionate about sharing the talent of our creative team from both sides of the border. New and emerging talent will work hand in hand to bring Quicksand from the page to the stage, with the support of this campaign.

This campaign gives our subscribers an active role in the making of Quicksand. As an unfunded company we want to reward you for your support and passion. Your generosity here will give you a more interactive experience in the lead up to and beyond the performance.

What We Need & What You Get

While we can't wait to share Quicksand in the intimacy that The New Theatre offers, we also cannot expect the team to be able to thrill and shock you while working for free. Our next biggest costs are venue rental and insurance. And then we have things like a set, some costumes and some theatre magic to draw you into the warped world of Joy & Joe. All in all our target of €5,000 is just a little over half of the overall cost of production.  

We will draw you into the world of Joe and Joy with our unique rewards. Get your own tabloid cover complete with headline. Meet the cast and crew and have your own VIP experience when you come to see the show. 

We will supplement our fundraising with pop-up opportunities in the next few weeks but with none of the rewards?! Why wait?? 

The Impact

Otherness and Isolation are something that all human beings have experienced. A woman who has raised her additional needs son (himself locked-in through his challenges) with a lack of support from services, friends and family is all too familiar. Quicksand pushes back the boundaries of theatre in the style in which it is staged and the themes which speak to an audience beyond our shores.

You can be a part of bringing this piece of work to the world and in doing so maybe open up or change your way of thinking.

Who are we?

Both the writer Elizabeth Moynihan and the producer Idír Mná have a history that puts diversity and inclusion at the heart of their work. Never more so in the case of Quicksand. Elizabeth Moynihan has won several awards and has a proven track record for her work for LGBTQ+ and also for her award winning radio series Cider Queens which explored the theme of addiction. 

Idir Mná has had sell out runs of an all female(ish) 'Glengarry Glen Ross' by David Mamet, 'Airswimming' by Charlotte Jones, as well as producing staged readings at The Attic Studio and The New Theatre. Yvonne was one of the producers behind 'The Big Green Apple', a transatlantic collaboration between the Attic Studio in Dublin and the 1st  Irish Festival in New York.

Meet the rest of the team:

EMILY FORAN is our extraordinary directer. She currently works in both Belfast and Dublin. She trained at The Lir Academy, Dublin and is a graduate of Queen's University Belfast. Her recent credits include: Extremities at The New Theatre; Fake I.D. at the MAC Belfast; SHARKTANK at Stockholm Fringe Festival (Winner of the Audience Choie Award); We Like It Here at The Lyric and After The End at The Lyric and The New Theatre. 

REX RYAN trained at The Gaiety Schoool of Acting. He recently performed on the Peacock stage at The Abbey in Philip Ridley's Tonight With Donny Stixx directed by Karl Shiels. Rex is Artistic Director of Glass Mask Theatre Company; the Resident company of Smock Alley Theatre Dublin, 2018/2019. Rex recently performed in a critically acclaimed debut production for Glass Mask; Idlewild - A gangland tragedy by Associate playwright Jimmy Murphy. 

DONNA DENT trained at the Brendan Smith Academy and the College of Music. With more than 40 theatre credits in Ireland's biggest shows, we can't possibly mention them all here. Like seriously - Miss Havesham in GREAT EXPECTATIONS and Sally Brass in THE OLD CURIOSITY SHOP! Not to mention (but I'm totally gonna) ALL MY SONS, ARCADIA, UNCLE VANYA, A STREETCAR NAMED DESIRE, LEAR, OTHELLO, A DOLLS HOUSE - the list goes on. Donna is excited to be returning to theatre after a 5 year hiatus. We are so incredibly lucky to have her.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help: We would ask you  to get the word out about Quicksand on your social media platforms and make  as much noise as you can about our campaign.  And may we remind you to use the Indiegogo share tools! We would be so very grateful to you for that as it gets the word out to many more people that may be able to help make QUICKSAND  happen. Le Grá, Idír Mná and the Quicksand company.
story_txt:
Story?
This campaign is important to us not only to fund and bring an important piece of theatre to an audience but also to highlight the struggles that people with additional needs face in a world where perfection is worshiped and tabloid media are ruthless in their pursuit of a headline.
We are passionate about sharing the talent of our creative team from both sides of the border. New and emerging talent will work hand in hand to bring Quicksand from the page to the stage, with the support of this campaign.
This campaign gives our subscribers an active role in the making of Quicksand. As an unfunded company we want to reward you for your support and passion. Your generosity here will give you a more interactive experience in the lead up to and beyond the performance.
What We Need & What You Get

While we can't wait to share Quicksand in the intimacy that The New Theatre offers, we also cannot expect the team to be able to thrill and shock you while working for free. Our next biggest costs are venue rental and insurance. And then we have things like a set, some costumes and some theatre magic to draw you into the warped world of Joy & Joe. All in all our target of €5,000 is just a little over half of the overall cost of production.  
We will draw you into the world of Joe and Joy with our unique rewards. Get your own tabloid cover complete with headline. Meet the cast and crew and have your own VIP experience when you come to see the show. 
We will supplement our fundraising with pop-up opportunities in the next few weeks but with none of the rewards?! Why wait?? 

The Impact
Otherness and Isolation are something that all human beings have experienced. A woman who has raised her additional needs son (himself locked-in through his challenges) with a lack of support from services, friends and family is all too familiar. Quicksand pushes back the boundaries of theatre in the style in which it is staged and the themes which speak to an audience beyond our shores.
You can be a part of bringing this piece of work to the world and in doing so maybe open up or change your way of thinking.
Who are we?
Both the writer Elizabeth Moynihan and the producer Idír Mná have a history that puts diversity and inclusion at the heart of their work. Never more so in the case of Quicksand. Elizabeth Moynihan has won several awards and has a proven track record for her work for LGBTQ+ and also for her award winning radio series Cider Queens which explored the theme of addiction. 
Idir Mná has had sell out runs of an all female(ish) 'Glengarry Glen Ross' by David Mamet, 'Airswimming' by Charlotte Jones, as well as producing staged readings at The Attic Studio and The New Theatre. Yvonne was one of the producers behind 'The Big Green Apple', a transatlantic collaboration between the Attic Studio in Dublin and the 1st  Irish Festival in New York.
Meet the rest of the team:
EMILY FORAN is our extraordinary directer. She currently works in both Belfast and Dublin. She trained at The Lir Academy, Dublin and is a graduate of Queen's University Belfast. Her recent credits include: Extremities at The New Theatre; Fake I.D. at the MAC Belfast; SHARKTANK at Stockholm Fringe Festival (Winner of the Audience Choie Award); We Like It Here at The Lyric and After The End at The Lyric and The New Theatre. 
REX RYAN trained at The Gaiety Schoool of Acting. He recently performed on the Peacock stage at The Abbey in Philip Ridley's Tonight With Donny Stixx directed by Karl Shiels. Rex is Artistic Director of Glass Mask Theatre Company; the Resident company of Smock Alley Theatre Dublin, 2018/2019. Rex recently performed in a critically acclaimed debut production for Glass Mask; Idlewild - A gangland tragedy by Associate playwright Jimmy Murphy. 
DONNA DENT trained at the Brendan Smith Academy and the College of Music. With more than 40 theatre credits in Ireland's biggest shows, we can't possibly mention them all here. Like seriously - Miss Havesham in GREAT EXPECTATIONS and Sally Brass in THE OLD CURIOSITY SHOP! Not to mention (but I'm totally gonna) ALL MY SONS, ARCADIA, UNCLE VANYA, A STREETCAR NAMED DESIRE, LEAR, OTHELLO, A DOLLS HOUSE - the list goes on. Donna is excited to be returning to theatre after a 5 year hiatus. We are so incredibly lucky to have her.

Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help: We would ask you  to get the word out about Quicksand on your social media platforms and make  as much noise as you can about our campaign.  And may we remind you to use the Indiegogo share tools! We would be so very grateful to you for that as it gets the word out to many more people that may be able to help make QUICKSAND  happen. Le Grá, Idír Mná and the Quicksand company.

story:
What is Wanderlust?

Wanderlust puts musicals on location. By staging immersive productions in site-specific environments, patrons are transported to a liminal space where artist and audience exist together in the world of the show.​

Wanderlust is not bound by any one geography. Because each of our shows is staged site-specifically where the story actually takes place, Wanderlust presents the unique opportunity of bringing theatre to a broad range of communities. Local spaces are reimagined and reinvigorated as they provide essential, authentic backdrops and bring musicals to life. 

 

Our Vision

Wanderlust believes in the magic of telling stories "on location," staging beloved musicals at site-specific venues to illuminate local identities. While initial stages of the company's work will focus on the existing musical theatre canon, future developments will include the commissioning of new musicals inspired by locations across the country. ​

Wanderlust aims to bring the vitality of professional site-specific theatre into communities nationwide. By partnering with participating regional theatre companies and universities, Wanderlust provides opportunities for students and local artists to work alongside notable theatre professionals.​

Dedicated to giving back to the communities we partner with, Wanderlust will work with and on behalf of local and national charitable foundations specific to the location of each production.

 

Our First Adventure: Musicals on the Move

As Wanderlust's inaugural performance, Musicals on the Move will put songs from beloved musicals on location at sites and businesses across Midtown Tallahassee! This one-night only theatrical cabaret experience will feature songs from a variety of award-winning musicals.

Participating sites include SoDough Bakery, Vocelles: The Bridal Shoppe, CHOP Barber Shop, A Country Rose Florist, Finnegan's Wake Irish Pub, and Fire Betty's Barcade.

The cast, comprised of Tallahassee's finest talents, will debut this exlusive one-night-only event on July 18, 2019!

 

Trailblaze With Us

Wanderlust believes that theatre should be limitless and accessible for all.
In pursuit of our vision and purpose, Wanderlust needs the support of imaginative individuals and organizations who will enable us to explore new possibilities in site-responsive musical theatre.

Your contribution will help bring our inaugural production of Musicals on the Move to life!

Your vital donation helps us:

  • Officially file for and establish our non-profit 501c3 status
  • Provide foundational framework for a thriving, innovative organization
  • Bring nationally acclaimed theatre artists to work on Wanderlust productions
  • Support local and visiting theatre artists through ethical, industry-standard compensation (this includes paying our actors, choreographer, musicians, designers, and stage management teams)
  • Contribute to production costs related to costumes, sets, props, recording, sound, lighting, etc.
  • Help us spread the word through an effective marketing campaigns

  • Partner effectively with local businesses

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If a monetary donation is not possible, there are still ways you can help!

  • Volunteer to be a part of our run and house crew!
  • Subscribe to our Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram!
  • Share this link on your social media!
  • Use  the Indiegogo Share Tools!

 

Thank you so much and welcome to the Wanderlust family! Adventure awaits...

 

*Looking for more info or have a question? Check out out FAQ page.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Roger Mathey and I have been doing theatre for nearly 30 years, running a small non-profit company called seat of your pants Productions. I was made aware of this one woman show a number of years ago and have wanted to stage it ever since. 

This show is about a young woman from Washington State who goes to the Middle East to find out how she can help in the Palestinian/Israeli conflict. Having grown up in the Middle East, I found Rachel's story hit me in many ways.

Rachel's story, developed by actor Alan Rickman from her writings, journals, e-mails, and letters home, is the true story of a young woman who went to Israel to see first hand of things she had only heard of and in her journey she is killed trying to defend people from what she saw as an injustice.

What we are hoping to do by telling her story is open more dialogue about the conflict and enlighten people to the situation from a first hand view.

What We Need & What You Get

As a non-profit, we survive based on donations. Independent theatre is a dying art, but we feel it is an important medium and one that truly expresses emotions that people can feel.

We are hoping to raise $5000 here (along with funding from other sources) in order to pay for things such as the theater space (an expensive commodity in San Francisco), the talent (our actor, crew, designers), publicity (posters, postcards, etc), and all the things that go into making a play such as lighting, set materials, costuming, and make up.

We have several perks to offer including original signed artwork, free tickets, and free drinks and food! Check out our perks.

The Impact

We are hoping to open audiences' minds to what is going on in the Middle East. We are not looking to argue or take a side, but desire to make people think. Theatre is such a powerful venue for that and we are performing this show in an intimate space (with only 25 seats), so the audience can really feel the energy coming from the stage.

We have staged a number of productions over the years with the intent of provoking thought, so that when the people leave the theater, they continue to think about the subject matter see what they can do to help.

This show tackles a very sensitive subject in this day and age. We are not looking to point blame. Rachel became an activist to help people she thought were in need of it and for that she paid the ultimate price.

Risks & Challenges

As we have said, independent theatre is a dying art form. But we also know it's a vital one.Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles. It does not have the explosions and special effects of movies or the glitz and glamour of Broadway, but it does have an intimacy like no other art form.

We are looking to rent a 25 seat space (not only because it's more affordable for us) to make the one woman show even more intimate. The audience will see, feel, and experience Rachel's journey through her words. They will be so close as to experience it for themselves. This is what theatre is to us. Personal storytelling that people can experience on a deeper level

Other Ways You Can Help

We realize these are tough times for people and that not everyone can contribute financially. If you can't, please share the link to your other social media platforms or e-mail to people you know who may be able to and have a desire to support the arts and this show.

Indiegogo has a number of share tools that people can use to spread the word.

Thank you.

story:
Who are we?

The Torch Sisters are a group of 10 women that are passionate about sharing circus arts with the community. We began approximately 8 years ago as a group of friends hooping at bars, who created a demand in the community. With time we have added additional flow props as well as aerial arts and acrobatics to our performances. We went from payment in beer to our own solo show in the brand new Jamf theater of the Pablo Center. 

What can we do for you?

In order to perform at high-level events, we need to carry performer's insurance for each member of the troupe. This insurance covers the audience and the performance space for any unforeseen events that could occur. This will cost our troupe $3,000 annually.

When you contribute to our campaign, you will receive perks that have never been previously offered by Torch Sisters, ranging from merchandise to semi-private classes taught by members of the troupe. You will be the first people to receive merchandise with our brand new logo.

Why is this important?

Torch Sisters are a unique group in the region, that has only grown since its inception. In the past year requests for performances have increased exponentially, leading to the culmination of a solo show. The shows are requiring more professionalism while drawing larger audiences. We plan to continue to expand our repertoire to continue to bring new talents and surprises to our community.

What if we can't achieve our goal?

If we are unable to raise the funds for insurance, the cost will negatively impact our member's abilities to perform. We need our whole troupe performing to carry on the best shows possible without leaving members with a costly financial burden.

What else can you do?

  • Like and follow us on Instagram and Facebook.
  • Share this campaign with everyone!
  • Come see our inaugural solo show on March 22nd at the Pablo Center in Eau Claire, Wisconsin! Tickets can be purchased if you click here.

story:
Back for its second compelling season, SheWolf strives to recall what is natural and uplift those affected by systems of oppression. SheWolf: Sacred Movement presents the Chicago premiere of original, dynamic, and collaborative work in May 2019 at the Center on Halsted. This campaign sets the foundation for current success and future growth of our community, regionally and nationally.  

WHO WE ARE

SheWolf Sacred Movement is a Chicago-based, global purpose revolution to venerate the embodied feminine soul.

We commit to embody authenticity, collaboration, creativity, excellence, harmony,  inclusivity, and universality. We strive to foster community through the process and application of healing arts, performance as therapy, and integrated story-telling. We empower individuals to raise consciousness, summon instinctual nature, claim sovereign knowing, cultivate wholeness, ignite passion, enliven health and healing, and thrive in creative power. 

PROCESS AND PHILOSOPHY

SheWolf aims to provide intersectional feminist approaches to community and collective liberation.

Through interdisciplinary artistic mediums, we create a process and platform for stories of divine resilience. Our intention is to center voices, bodies, and hearts that have been impacted by violence, marginalization, disempowerment, oppression and imbalances. As a channel of unity consciousness, performers and audience alike move and witness to engage in collective transformation and liberation. Our works range from ancient ritual practices and classical cultural dances to contemporary expressions and exchanges.

2019 PRODUCTION TEAM & COMMUNITY ARTISTS

Julie Brannen, Jen Halman, Krystle Aguilera, Sarah Lemley, Sondra Malling, Tracy Mihaljevic, Kristen Perry, Jess Fialko

Victoria Boateng, Lexi Weintraub, Frediliza David, Gabriela Mejia, Ellen Dancer, Jane Justice, Jean Edrada, Radia Ali, Veronika Nelson, Tara Luther, Gaea Lady, Catherine Hepler, JCSpace Radio, Huu Nguyen, Audrey Herrington, Karen Lum, Laksha Dantran, Brandice Manuel, Sojourner Zenobia, Cher Nicolas, Olya Prohorova, Octavia Marie Madeleine, Melissa Larson 

Theresa Fernandez, Antonia Callas, Ellen Geis, Cassandra Justine, Theresa Virgilio, Laura Monsreal, Lizzie Monsreal, Teria Stamatis, Janine Tvrz, Heidi Woelbling, Courtney Elizabeth Ticsay, Vivian Sakellariou, Ashley Meyer, Karen Lum, Jordan Lohf, Sarah Winkler, Norma Bucholtz, Sabrina Washington, Becca Wiseman, Maura Tobin, E’a Williams, Shannon Tudor, Bridgette Hammond, Kavi Elijah

IMPACT

Your support helps us cover fair and equal wages to our production team, rehearsal and venue rentals, production costs, and allows us to offer a tiered pricing ticket model to our audience. It gives us the ability to provide high quality events, while still supporting artists, and helps us work towards our vision of expansion in the Chicago dance community and beyond.  

WHERE WILL YOUR CONTRIBUTIONS GO?

Venue Rental

Rehearsal Studio Rental

Lighting Design/Technical Direction

Technical Equipment/Assistance

Costume Design 

Marketing Materials and Programs 

Music Rights 

Performance Stipend to Production Team

Videographer / Photographer

ASL Interpretation Access

Fundraising Fees

Insurance

HOW CAN YOU HELP?

We are a grassroots, blooming company with big hearts and dreams. We are passionate, compassionate, ambitious, dedicated, and hard-working. This project is a labor of Love. 

Whether it's a financial contribution, taking a moment to spread the word, or simply sharing your excitement for the project, we are eternally grateful for your help! SheWolf: Sacred Movement takes a village to make happen and could not be possible without you.

1. Contribute to our campaign!

2. Come to our show at Center on Halsted, Chicago May 23-26th, 2019

3. Share this campaign with friends and other folks in any way you can: social media (Facebook, Instagram, etc), e-mail, conversation, dancing, singing...

THANK YOU FOR VISITING!

We cannot express how much your support means to us!

You ~yes, you ~ play an essential role in the growth of our work and community.

Please join us on this journey and help us spread the word! Thank you for your support!

Wild Love, 

Julie and the SheWolf community 

Learn more about us at www.shewolfsacred.org

Campaign Photos by Rossi Joy

story:
Project Description & History

My name is Michael Gorman. I'm a playwright, installation artist, and the founder and director of The Forty Hour Club—a resident company of La MaMa Theatre in NYC where I am currently the Playwright in Residence.  My plays and the work of the Forty Hour Club focus on the economic, environmental and systemic destruction facing working communities and the paramount issue of sustainability.

For the past two decades I have been writing and producing plays about the opiate epidemic—most often financed out of my own pocket and through the generosity and deep commitment of a group of artists and friends dedicated to shedding light on this issue.  I am amazed by what The Forty Hour Club has been able to accomplish.  It is a true testament to the power of community and what can be achieved despite a lack of mainstream institutional support. The time has come, however, to ask for help and the support of a larger community.

We are in danger of losing a whole generation of young people to the plague of opiate addiction, and we desperately need a more “creative” approach with which to attack this epic foe.  It is my belief that with your support, “Chasing The New White Whale” and its innovative art & advocacy model has the potential to not only change perceptions about addiction but to also save lives.

I have my own connection to the opiate epidemic: my brother, a commercial fisherman, lost his life to a heroin overdose in 1998—a tragic event that effected me deeply and inspired me to embark on the creative journey that has culminated in this project.  But CTNWW is not simply about personal sadness and loss; it is about a regional and national health crisis and an artistic call to action.  It is not intended to be my plaintive voice but the echo of the over 70,000 lives lost to opiate addiction each year.  

Your Contribution & Impact

By helping to support this project, you will be giving voice to all those caught up in the storm of addiction and whose stories I have been inspired by in creating and producing “Chasing The New White Whale”— fishermen, recovering addicts, family members, law enforcement, health practitioners, politicians, economists, journalists, spiritual leaders, artists and the ghosts of those who have passed.  To make visible the invisible.

Theatre has the power to heal; to create constructive dialogue; to reduce the stigma and shame around addiction; and to help to change the perception of addicts in our community.  I have likened the effort needed in confronting addiction to that of Ahab and the sailors aboard the Pequod in confronting the White Whale: it requires all hands on deck.  I hope you will join me in this challenging but deeply rewarding pursuit.  

Gratefully, Michael Gorman—Playwright

You can read more about CHASING THE NEW WHITE WHALE—the project & the play, HERE.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need funds to help us cover the large expenses associated with producing our productions and bringing them to working communities throughout New England that are hardest by the opioid epidemic.

Theatrical productions are expensive to produce: Our production company—The Forty Hour Club— recently produced "Chasing The New White Whale" in New York City at The Ellen Stewart Theatre at La MaMa for a total cost of $24,000 for a 3-week run. Ticket sales (which we split with the theatre) made up a very small percentage of that (10%).  Like many times before, I paid for the cost of this production out of my own pocket—even going so far as to refinance my home and take out substantial loans. However, this is not sustainable, and we are looking at alternate ways in which we can carry out our mission and fund our work in the future—including grants, donations, and other forms of creative financing.  

Funds donated to this campaign will also enable us to launch—"Chasing The New White Whale"—our art & advocacy project, and begin regional and National outreach efforts—including upcoming programs and performances on the Maine island communities of North Haven & Vinalhaven. 

Future goals for the project include touring "Chasing The New White Whale"  to venues and working waterfront communities across the country most hard hit by the opiate epidemic.  Our next planned production will take place in historic New Bedford, MA— a fishing port at the center of the epidemic.  Your donation to this project will help us get there.  Funds will go directly to help pay for the costs associated with producing a successful event, including: hiring actors; renting performance spaces and equipment; lodging and transportation; outreach; administration; and more.

PERKS

In exchange for your donation, we are offering some unique perks!

  • A 3-day/3-night stay at the playwrights beautiful home in Maine.
  • A handmade life-like "toggle" harpoon made by Maine artisan and maker Andrew White (used in the NYC production).
  • A collectable edition of the Melville classic novel "Moby Dick"
  • Maine-made "Sea Bags" totes made from recycled sails and featuring the artwork of "Moby Dick"
  • New "Harpooning Addiction" tee shirts featuring our new tribal-inspired logo design.
  • And more!
     

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is in the position to donate money at this time.  And thats OK! There are other ways that you can show your support:

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools, or share this campaign via email or social media with those who might be interested in helping us with this important cause.
  • Workplace Sponsorship of a CTNWW future event.
  • In-kind donations such lodging for actors; hospitality; etc

My name is Michael Gorman. I'm a playwright, installation artist, and the founder and director of The Forty Hour Club—a resident company of La MaMa Theatre in NYC where I am currently the Playwright in Residence.  My plays and the work of the Forty Hour Club focus on the economic, environmental and systemic destruction facing working communities and the paramount issue of sustainability.
For the past two decades I have been writing and producing plays about the opiate epidemic—most often financed out of my own pocket and through the generosity and deep commitment of a group of artists and friends dedicated to shedding light on this issue.  I am amazed by what The Forty Hour Club has been able to accomplish.  It is a true testament to the power of community and what can be achieved despite a lack of mainstream institutional support. A collectable edition of the Melville classic novel "Moby Dick"

New "Harpooning Addiction" tee shirts featuring our new tribal-inspired logo design.
And more!

story:
Artemis, The Merry Misadventures is a puppet show unlike any other and we are taking it to Edinburgh Fringe festival this year from 3-8 of August at PQA Riddle's Court. Fringe is about discovering the new and Artemis is unique for its unique flair, wit and fun puppeteering! All donations will go directly to taking the show to our dream at Edinburgh, so your much appreciated generosity will fund a production that aims to bring laughter and misadventure to the stage!

Floral Rhino Productions produced Artemis through many misadventures of our own but the show is a celebration of the unique, the irreverent and the fun that we hope you can share with us at Edinburgh. By supporting the project, you're not just helping a first-time production to grow and thrive on the stage, but you're also injecting a little bit of merriness (and a whole lot of misadventure) into the world...

If you can't contribute, please help in other ways!!! Your support is appreciated and sharing is caring - so please share this project with others on social media. And, of course, if you're heading to Fringe this year, we'll see you there

story:
If our goal is met, Branford High School Performing Arts Directors, Mike Martone Jr. and Colin Sheehan will bring an all day theatre arts camp to children AND an evening performance option for high school students and adults from Connecticut.

More to come... VERY soon!
