story:
The House is a site specific devised Immersive Theatrical Event - with our first presentation to be held on May 19th 2018, in Park Slope Brooklyn at the historic The Montauk Club.

The production is inspired by the Rural Trilogy by  Spanish playwright Federico García Lorca. Over the course of the 2 hour production, the audience will be invited to explore the house, where all stories intertwine with the life of Lorca himself, primarily through movement, dance, music, improv and minimal dialogue. One story, leading up to a wedding, the other in the aftermath of a funeral, as the playwright looks on, unable to save his characters and ultimately unable to save himself.

Experientially, the audience will be free to discover characters going through both the dramatic, and mundane, parts of their evenings within the house. The exquisite interior of The Montauk Club will act as the set for the production, playing as much a role as the actors.

This will be the first stage of development and our contributors will get to witness first hand the "behind the scenes" creation into the the developed production.  With your help we will continue to grow this story and shape the characters and event, so that it may travel and be presented both locally and eventually on a national level, utilizing special and unique spaces to partner and present with.

Our perks include the obvious, which is the opportunity to experience The House first hand, but also listen to the lilting sounds of Lorca’s poetry read in Spanish, various lessons with our artists, advance purchasing opportunities and discount codes, keepsakes and one - on -one personalized experiences, and so much more.

We invite you to join us in laying the foundation and starting bricks of “The House”!
We can not embark on this spectacle and creation without your support!

Quite Simply, We need your help!

What we have in place:

  • The Amazing Support and Location of our House which will be “The Montauk Club”
  • Support and rights from the Lorca Estate
  • An Exciting Choreography & Movement Team
  • A Thrilling Sound & Music Composer
  • Our Brave & Talented Cast!
  • A Producer to help us see this through to the next stage

Now we need funds to put all of the elements together.

Funds from this campaign will go to:

  • The Venue  & Associated Costs
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Design Elements
  • Marketing
  • Most importantly Funds for Artist Stipends for their time & work
  • And the Creation of this piece for further installments and events

We would love to exceed our immediate fundraising goal so that we can ensure The House lives beyond this one night event.

PLEASE HELP US BUILD THE HOUSE FROM GROUND UP!

$7,500 is just the first step, and that will only cover the very basics towards the stage of growth for THE HOUSE.

Other Ways You Can Help:

Can’t contribute financially right now? That’s OK, just by visiting our page you have already helped! Here are some BIG ways that you can make a difference in our campaign and season!

Help us go viral!  Spread the word about our campaign, share it on Facebook and Twitter, invite your friends to view our campaign and ask them to share it too! Be an online cheerleader for THE HOUSE!

Every time our campaign is shared and viewed it brings us up higher in our category and helps get potential donors outside our network! IT REALLY DOES HELP! And don’t forget Indie Go Go has made sharing and promoting our campaign super easy!

Want to help in other ways? WOW! Thanks you rock! Sign up to volunteer!
Email us at thehouseproductionmgmt@gmail.com and we’ll put you to work!

THANK YOU FOR READING OUR CAMPAIGN & FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

Love The House Team: 
Elizabeth Haag, Akia Squitieri, William Ruiz-Morales, Gabriela Burdsall, Ian Turner, Emily Newhouse,  Gabriel Torres, Sara Fellini & Lee Hubilla (With more to be announced soon!)

story:
In The Heart of the Wasp's Nest

Frank and Norman are well at home in their castle as the technicians of a Fashion College. When new recruit Carol makes an allegation of sexual misconduct, the team are thrown into chaos, where difficult questions are asked, and allegiances are tested. Slapstick and tragedy combine in this unflinching, hilarious, in-your-face Liverpool comedy.

For this new play, theatre-makers Karl Falconer and Natasha Ryan have pulled together interest from some of the UK theatre industry's biggest players to showcase new talent and champion new working-class voices on stage and off. We're small on resources but big on ambition, and after 10 years of hard toil, exposure is finally coming our way. We have a strong script, a ridiculously talented cast and some of the UK's top up-and-coming crew, so now we need some resources to put our best work in front of the biggest audience. Your support will make that happen.

The Target. 

Money raised through this avenue of support will go towards production costs including:

  • Set design and scenic construction
  • Van Hire and Set Storage
  • Prop Design and development
  • Costume design and creation
  • Sound Design
  • Printing, Advertising and Promotion

Alongside this, we have secured significant in-kind support for rehearsal space, technical equipment and some basic elements of design. We want to use the resources we have to go a long way, and we have a fantastic crew with dedicated specialist experience in producing and designing for low-budget theatre. We will be able to use these funds to produce something far beyond its budget limitations.

What's It All For?

We've been producing theatre for a long time but this project is unique.

The tide is changing on the unfair arts world, and about time too. Movements such as #MeToo and the Diversity School initiative are sparking fierce debate about who can access opportunities and what power means. But we don't want to talk. In the spirit of 2018 being the year of Deeds Not Words, it's time to make a statement. This is how we're doing it:

  • Taking our work to England's biggest arts festival as well as on tour; we want to take our message to the widest audience we can
  • Being dedicated to supporting an all-female crew
  • Sharing our work with top-theatre critic Lyn Gardner and the Young Vic's Director's Network
  • Supporting and championing a working-class, Northern cast and crew who might not have the opportunity for exposure that this project could provide
  • Putting new voices on the stage and using this as a way to get new audiences involved in theatre
  • Discussing the potential to stream our work with Digital Theatre+

We have secured the support of Happy Valley and Cucumber star, Con O'Neill, and have already had interest from HOME, the Lowry, the Oldham Coliseum, Theatre 503, the Young Vic and SlungLow in coming to see the production with a view to further collaborations. We have secured a central London venue and we're delivering on our promise to get this show in front of the right people. Our list of supporters is growing by the day, but now we need to make sure that the show we put in front of them is the best it can be. This will give our talent the best chance to shine, and give this important story its best chance of future success.

Can We Do It?

In a word, Yes. We have 10 years of producing theatre, and of helping others to achieve something special. We've built our company up, year on year, to be hailed as 'one of the UK's fastest rising ensembles' and we've done it all from our own hard graft. No startup funds, no helping hand. We know how to produce theatre, we just need the resources to achieve it.

Because of our experience, we understand the pitfalls, and most of these come from lack of planning. We have prepared ourselves for contingency and started the ball rolling early to ensure proper planning. We're really blessed to have pulled together a fantastic cast and crew with extensive experience, who are going to add to our own expertise to ensure this project is a success.

We're used to working with limited resources, and even if we don't reach our full target, any finance will make a significant contribution to enabling us to showcase the production and our talent as best as we can.

It's Not Just About Money

Hey, we get it. And we know that everyone says that 'every little helps'. But here's the thing. There's a lot of 'new' theatre and with a 'new' play our greatest asset is word of mouth. We believe this is a project worth shouting about, with a cast and crew who deserve to have their work seen. If you're inspired by our ethos and want to help, here's how you can:

  • Tweet and shout and let it all out - the more people who know about the crowdfunder and the project, the further we can take our message
  • Do the fangirl thing - a show ain't much without an audience, and we're going to need one if the show is going to be a success. Come catch us on tour!
  • Take the bins out - hey we'll take your bins out for you. Our set needs a lot of props, decoration and clutter, so if you've been waiting 15 years to throw out that Windows 95 desktop or trade that sandwich maker, let us take it off your hands. Genuinely.

We believe the time is right, we've learnt enough and some luck is on our side. With your help we can take that further.

Thank you

Karl Falconer and Natasha Ryan

story:
The Show

A Trilogy of Horrors is a collection of three classic tales, updated and adapted into a chilling storytelling set. It features:

Charles Dickens' The Signal Man
A schoolmistress tells of an unnerving meeting with a railway signalman, who claims to be visited by a prophetic ghost.

Mary Shelley's The Mortal Immortal
Follow a man's tale of his youth working as an apprentice to an alchemist trying to
create the elixir of life.

Edgar Allen Poe's The Tell-Tale Heart
A chilling account of a woman’s descent into paranoid madness, which
drives her down into the darkest parts of the human soul.

Described as 'masters of storytelling' by the Wee Review, we're incredibly proud of this set which has previously been performed at The Bread & Roses, The White Bear, and the Horniman Museum. This is our chance to take it up to new audiences, in a venue well known for it's storytelling reputation.  

What We Need & What You Get

Theatre is, unfortunately, expensive to produce, especially during the Fringe. We've managed to reduce our costs due to a great venue, but we've still got expenses to cover. We'll be taking the show up either way, but any help you can provide will make it that bit easier for us.

We've set our goal at the minimum IndieGogo let us (£500), but we're using flexible funding so if we don't hit that, we can still do wonders with whatever lovely donations we do get! Any money received will go on:

- The big expense: Edinburgh Fringe Registration Fee (£300)
- Marketing materials
- Upfront assistance for travel + accommodation for cast and crew*

*Providing assistance here allows us to support performers and crew members who may otherwise be at a financial disadvantage and unable to participate. We're constantly working on being more inclusive, more diverse and more accessible, so this would be a great help!

The Impact

With a (hopefully!) successful ten day run at the Fringe under our belts, we'll have more clout to do even more things. We've got more upcoming projects in the works - including another, different, set of monologues happening at the Camden Fringe - and the better we do with this show, the more we can pour back into future shows. What does this mean?

- More new writing and support of new writers
- More assistance available for people working with us
- More shows!

Risks & Challenges

Are there risks and challenges? Definitely, as there are with any theatre production. However, the important thing to note is that this project will be going ahead regardless of money raised - we're all funding out of pocket to make this happen. Your help is exactly that - help, rather than the sole source of funding! This means that we won't end up in a position where the show doesn't go ahead.

In terms of getting the perks out, we've spoken with other groups who've ran similar campaigns in order to get advice, and have kept it simple. One non-physical perk means that the fulfilment doesn't require postage costs, and the other one is designed to keep those postage costs as low as possible. This means the cost to us (and you) is minimal for these, and instead, the money can be channelled into where we need it - the show itself.

Other Ways You Can Help

The big one is, of course, to share this with your friends, or come and see us when we're performing!
story_txt:
The Show
A Trilogy of Horrors is a collection of three classic tales, updated and adapted into a chilling storytelling set. It features:
Charles Dickens' The Signal ManA schoolmistress tells of an unnerving meeting with a railway signalman, who claims to be visited by a prophetic ghost.
Mary Shelley's The Mortal ImmortalFollow a man's tale of his youth working as an apprentice to an alchemist trying tocreate the elixir of life.
Edgar Allen Poe's The Tell-Tale HeartA chilling account of a woman’s descent into paranoid madness, whichdrives her down into the darkest parts of the human soul.
Described as 'masters of storytelling' by the Wee Review, we're incredibly proud of this set which has previously been performed at The Bread & Roses, The White Bear, and the Horniman Museum. This is our chance to take it up to new audiences, in a venue well known for it's storytelling reputation.  

What We Need & What You Get
Theatre is, unfortunately, expensive to produce, especially during the Fringe. We've managed to reduce our costs due to a great venue, but we've still got expenses to cover. We'll be taking the show up either way, but any help you can provide will make it that bit easier for us.
We've set our goal at the minimum IndieGogo let us (£500), but we're using flexible funding so if we don't hit that, we can still do wonders with whatever lovely donations we do get! Any money received will go on:
- The big expense: Edinburgh Fringe Registration Fee (£300)- Marketing materials- Upfront assistance for travel + accommodation for cast and crew*
*Providing assistance here allows us to support performers and crew members who may otherwise be at a financial disadvantage and unable to participate. We're constantly working on being more inclusive, more diverse and more accessible, so this would be a great help!

The Impact
With a (hopefully!) successful ten day run at the Fringe under our belts, we'll have more clout to do even more things. We've got more upcoming projects in the works - including another, different, set of monologues happening at the Camden Fringe - and the better we do with this show, the more we can pour back into future shows. What does this mean?
- More new writing and support of new writers- More assistance available for people working with us- More shows!

Risks & Challenges
Are there risks and challenges? Definitely, as there are with any theatre production. However, the important thing to note is that this project will be going ahead regardless of money raised - we're all funding out of pocket to make this happen. Your help is exactly that - help, rather than the sole source of funding! This means that we won't end up in a position where the show doesn't go ahead.
In terms of getting the perks out, we've spoken with other groups who've ran similar campaigns in order to get advice, and have kept it simple. One non-physical perk means that the fulfilment doesn't require postage costs, and the other one is designed to keep those postage costs as low as possible. This means the cost to us (and you) is minimal for these, and instead, the money can be channelled into where we need it - the show itself.

Other Ways You Can Help
The big one is, of course, to share this with your friends, or come and see us when we're performing!

story:
Short Summary

In 2015, I produced my original musical The Katrina Roadhouse, set in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. It was a fundraiser for the New Orleans organization Common Ground Relief. The performances sold out in two weeks. This was also a successful Indiegogo campaign. Since then, I've had two short plays produced in New England: Wrong Place, Right Time and Getting Old is Getting Old.  I've been a musician  in local bands for the past 40 years and  one of my bands won 4 consecutive Boston Music Awards .  I've written over 50 songs  and recorded 11  CD's during my career. I am about to launch  this major production I'd Rather Be Lucky Than Good  which contains 10 of my originals. I've been working on the script, the music, and the lyrics for the past five years.

This campaign means a great deal to me. I've put in hundreds of hours in preparation to make this musical an event that provides for the audience: entertainment, humor, and some thought provoking questions about golf, fate, and friendship. I'm very pleased that the noted Boston area director, Haris Lefteri, will direct our fantastic cast: Arthur Williams III, Ken Brassard, Michael Joseph Reardon, Sonya Joyner, Adjovi Koene, Alanna Lynch, and Larry Segel. The Squeezebox Stompers Trio which includes, Larry Plit, Geoff Wadsworth, and myself will provide musical accompaniment for the actors as they sing and dance.

I've enlisted two Suffolk University interns, Donovan Skepple and Dan Silvia to provide technical support in photography and marketing. The table is set; however, we can use financial assistance for the extensive costs involved in producing a musical:

  • stipends for the cast, crew, and band
  • rehearsal and performance venue fees
  • props and set design
  • advertising
  • costumes
  • recording  of the accompanying CD
  • costs of the perks: postcards, hats, T-shirts, CD's, and scripts
  • numerous miscellaneous costs

By contributing to this campaign, you can help us make this production an outstanding and memorable event.  As far as I know, no one else has written a musical about golf and the characters who frequent this sport. You can play a major role in this play by providing some financial backing that can help us meet the initial start up costs. This will carry us through to the performances where we'll get additional money from the ticket sales to meet all of our expenses. The show  will go on no matter how much we receive from this kick-starter campaign.  We're dedicated to making this play come alive!

For our contributors, we have some limited edition perks available : postcards, hats, T-shirts, CD's, scripts and listing in the playbill as a donor.  You can come to  a performance of the play , wear your T-shirts and hats, and join in the fun. We ask that you also support us by sharing this Indiegogo.com website with your friends.  Please spread the word on your social media sites as well.  Together we can make this production a memorable "hole-in-one."

story:
Sindy and the Girlfriends are stamping their GoGo boots all over Hull’s music scene.

Hull. 1965. Five young women from Hull decide to start a girl band. Within months they are touring the local pubs & clubs & are soon asked to play for the US Troops in Germany. Leaving behind their jobs as cleaners, dental assistants & waitresses, the teenagers embark on their journey to 'freedom'. However, reality soon hits; the troops are more interested in the length of their skirts rather than their talent. If they want success they will have to bite their tongues & learn to live with it- 'it's a man's world'.

2017-18. Harvey Weinstein, the first of many perpetrators in the entertainment industry, is publicly outed for years of sexually assaulting young actresses. His accusers have given victims of sexual violence a voice to stand up & be heard. However, for a long time this has not been the case. It’s Different for Girls documents the vulnerable position women were & are still often placed in when silence is their only option.

 

THE PROJECT

It’s Different For Girls is an original sixties musical inspired by Hull girl band, Mandy & the Girlfriends, about gender, consent and sexuality. Devised by She Productions, with direction by Becky Hope-Palmer (RSC Romeo & Juliet and The Hypocrite) and musical supervision from Paul Frankish (Wicked, RSC), It’s Different For Girls explores issues around consent & the isolation caused by abuse. At a time where the #metoo and ‘Time’s Up’ campaigns rule the headlines, It’s Different For Girls asks ‘how much has really changed since 1965?’

It’s Different For Girls will tour the North of England in Autumn 2018 with wrap-around workshops that explore themes of 'Consent, Respect & Relationships'. 15 free workshops for ages 13-18, reaching over 400 participants, will be delivered to young people, particularly vulnerable groups. In association with Hull Rape Crisis, these have been designed through forums with parents & teens where themes from It’s Different For Girls including consent, & sexual violence were discussed.

“It’s Different for Girls is a fun rock 'n' roll musical with catchy numbers and a positive message that manages to be both fun and feminist—with a small ‘f’.”- British Theatre Guide

Last year's production of It's Different For Girls was a huge success at East Riding Theatre, bringing in a diverse audience and attracting a large volume of media attention - we even had a slot on BBC's The One Show and met Spice Girl Geri Halliwell. 

In 2017 we delivered these workshops to 7 schools & participants agreed they engaged with issues that are underexplored in the current PSHE National Curriculum. Further collaboration with schools & youth services local to touring venues will aid us to adapt workshops for specific area needs. We have created online resources which will be distributed to the participating groups for further exploration.

"The vulnerable group gained a lot from this important workshop- thank you." Nicole Sullivan, Head of Drama, Selby High School.

SHE PRODUCTIONS

She Productions formed in 2015 after benefit performances of The Vagina Monologues which raised £4000 for Hull Rape Crisis. Since then, She Productions have become Company in Residence at East Riding Theatre. We have written & produced 9 original productions including Arts Council funded, The StorytEllas; a family musical for children aged 3+ with free workshops at local libraries, primary schools & SEN schools. Other family shows include outdoor promenades, The Lightless Pumpkin & Alice’s Eggstravaganza in Wonderland, commissioned by Beverley Racecourse.

She Productions have also produced 2 revue shows for adult audiences: Beverley Does Broadway, a cycle of musical theatre songs with a Northern twist and MissCast, a comedic satire about the struggles of being an actor which premiered in May 2017.

As part of Hull City of Culture 2017 She were invited to deliver an Under 10's Feminist Corner at Hull’s first WOW Festival. Subsequently we were commissioned by Assemble Fest to develop the workshops into a 30 minute piece called Honey, I Stereotyped the Kids in a co- production with See Gold. The piece explored the adult perceptions of gender equality that children are often subject to.

AIMS

  • To share and celebrate Northern stories & female Northern artists since the 1960s.
  • To provide accessible educational opportunities in drama and PSHE to young people across the North of England.
  • To diversify She Productions’ audiences beyond Beverley and East Riding Theatre.

HOW ELSE YOU CAN HELP

We know that not everyone can contribute financially, but there are other ways in which you can support us. We are going to be touring across the North of England and anything you can do to help promote the production would mean the world to us. If you know anyone who would be interested in the production or our workshops then please email us on: sheproductions15@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary

Emerging stage director, Dan Smith has always been fascinated by the theatrical nature of Carlo Collodi's "The Adventures of Pinocchio", and has wanted to write an original adaptation that focuses on the more humorous and grotesque elements of the story. In spring 2016, Smith began writing his own adaptation that both celebrated and critiqued Collodi's story through the lens of a young adult/college student.

Smith approached emerging film director, Riley Bartolomeo about the possibility of hopping onboard as co-director to infuse the project with cinematic elements such as projections and multimedia. Bartolomeo joined the project as co-director, and the two began to dig into Smith's script while asking such questions as:

- Should you NEVER lie? 

- Does the truth hurt?

- Can kindness kill you?

- Why am I here?

- Why should I wake up tomorrow?

- Is death the end all, be all?

- Why should I care about YOU?

- Why should YOU care about ME?

Over the past month, Smith & Bartolomeo have been working with an ensemble of actors to workshop the piece, with the goal of beginning rehearsals for the summer production in March. The project is slated to be performed in July 2018, for a limited weekend engagement. 

What We Need & What You Get

Through our fundraising efforts, we have already covered more than half the costs of a deposit for the space, pre-production expenses, and rehearsal expenses. However, we still need to cover the costs of:

- Space Use (Performance & Rehearsal)

- Costumes, Props, Sets, etc.

- Paid Labor (Carpenters and Designers)

- Compensating All Parties Involved

With your help, we can produce family friendly theatre for a NYC audience in Summer 2018! All proceeds will go towards production costs, and will ensure that we can provide quality theatre for families at a low rate. 

QUICK FACTS:

- Theatre 54 is a 60-seat house that would be utilized for a weekend/six-performance run

- Ticket prices will ideally be between $15-20, depending on costs

- All creatives, actors, and production team members will be college aged artists/professionals

story:
In short...

I, Janelle Hacault, am a professional contemporary dancer/choreographer who recently moved from Winnipeg (hi PegCity family) to Montréal to further develop my passion for dance. Upon meeting these extraordinary humans (the dancers you see in the video), I was quickly convinced we needed to create together in a positive and open environment.

The result is "Shapeshifters", a dance piece about the many sides of one woman's inner self that collide, confuse and eventually co-exist.  It's quirky and endearing with a touch of crazy. It is my creative baby, first group work, and the first time I'm presenting my choreography in Montréal thanks to Festival Quartiers Danses... and it's NOT done.

We have to finish creating the piece by Sept. 11th in order to put it on stage. We need to pay for costumes, lighting design, music composition (did someone mention a harp player is in the show?), and artist fees.

Once the dance is done, national and international presenters will see the show and potentially offer us more performance opportunities. This campaign is to help launch the work and allow my baby to live!

What We Need

To date, approximately 60 hours of research and rehearsal have been invested voluntarily into this project. By September 12th, this number will increase to a total of 400 hours collectively. The $3,000 of contributions will help go towards the following:

  • Finishing the creation process
  • Rental space
  • Artistic fees
  • Costumes
  • Music composition
  • Lighting design

What You Get

It takes a tribe to create a dance baby and to thank you for supporting us, we want to give back. Here are some of the perks to look forward to:

  • Personalized email from yours truly
  • Social media shout-out for all to read
  • Handwritten postcard addressed to you
  • Invitation to a rehearsal
  • 1 minute dance clips sent to you every day for a week!
  • Tickets to the premiere of the show
  • Dinner with the cast, cooked by me

The Impact

Due to the high competition for government funding and the continual decrease of public support for the arts, all too often artists have to juggle 2 full-time careers in order to create work out of their passion. As George Bernard Shaw puts it, "Without art, the crudeness of reality would make the world unbearable." Help us change this.

In the past, I have raised over $5000 for projects put on by Nova Dance Collective, touring for .6 Ricochet and more recently, a collaborative work called "Falling" that toured to Toronto and Winnipeg. Rest assured, your contributions are in good hands going to good people!

Other Ways You Can Help

I get it, we all go through seasons where giving monetarily is not viable. It's ok! We value any help we can get. So please, consider:

  • Getting the word out by posting on your preferred social media platform. Make a buzz!
  • Sharing by word of mouth with friends and family
  • Asking your workplace if they would consider sponsoring us
  • Comment and like the posts I share on social media about the project
  • Come to our Fundraising Party on September 1st and tell your friends (details to come)
  • Check out Indiegogo's share tools.

 

If you are in Montreal on September 12th, come see the show by clicking this link: https://quartiersdanses.com/events/12-septembre-janelle-hacault-jane-mappin/

story:
(l-r) Indiia Wilmott, Aejay Mitchell, Aaron Wilton, Kehinde Koyejo, Rotimi Agbabiaka

Who We Are

We are an award-winning, multi-ethnic, multi-generational and multi-faceted theatre company focused on Black theater and performance.  We seek to perform work that offers an expanded idea of Black theater in content, form, look and presentation. We find it necessary to work within artistic processes that do not reinforce the dominant paradigm and current power structures.  We are inspired by inclusivity and plurality of thought; the black avant-garde, and work that immediately challenges our most entrenched assumptions.

Currently, we are an ensemble of seven core members: Rotimi Agbabiaka, Edris Cooper-Anifowoshe (co-founder), Kehinde Koyejo, AeJay Mitchell, Shirley Smallwood (co-founder), Indiia Wilmott and Aaron Wilton.  We are in residence at Brava! for Women in the Arts, a community non-profit in San Francisco's MIssion District.  At Brava, we have premiered three plays by Black playwrights - In A Daughter's Eyes by A. Zell Williams; Sweet Maladies by Zakiyyah Alexander and last season's Bootycandy by Robert O'Hara. 

  • We are San Francisco's only theater dedicated to new work and the black avant garde.
  • We have presented more than 10 new works by Black playwrights to San Francisco audiences - plays by Keith Josef Adkins, Robert Alexander, Pearl Cleage and Robert O'Hara and numerous staged readings of new plays.
  • We have received critical acclaim for all of our productions and formal recognition from Theater Bay Area Awards , in 2014 - Outstanding Ensemble for Sweet Maladies & 2017 - Acting nominations for Bootycandy. 
  • We are prepared to respond to the moment!  We participated in the New Black Fest national play event, Facing Our Truth, seven short plays by seven playwrights surrounding the murder of Trayvon Martin. 
  • Our So Soul San Francisco salons are part of a larger effort at documenting the Black performance history of San Francisco and the Bay Area. 
  • We are all separate and successful artists who have committed ourselves to building a company together - taking charge of our careers and taking responsibility for what's on stage.
  • This work is fiercely important and fills a myriad of voids, builds a bucketload of bridges, smashes seas of stereotypes and provokes a plethora of potent pontifications.

 

Project #1 - So Soul San Francisco: Black Art Salons

In  2018, we are curating a series of monthly Black Art Salons, on third Thursdays in Brava's new cabaret space.  We kick it all off on February 1 with Black Heaven: A Spiritual House Party.

  The first six salons are -

  • February 15 - Oju Ibeji features the work of  Melorra Green and Melonie Green who will offer ways to look and participate art that we guarantee you have not experienced.
  • March 15  -  Afro Present: Dreamtime in the endless twilight of 24/7 features the work of dancer/choreographer, Amara Tabor Smith and the legendary Ellen Sebastian Chang 
  • April 19  - Black Benatar's Black Magic Cabaret  with guest host, Beatrice Thomas (aka Black Benatar) 
  • May 17 - Black on Black: High Crimes and Misdemeanors, hosted by BACCE
  • June 21 - Black Music Salon featuring local musicians

We are seeking funding to pay salon artists and offer adequate technical support for each salon.

Project #2 - Robert O'Hara's An American Ma(u)l

A dsytopian comedy that is a bit too close to home right now.  A newly elected,rogue president jump starts a failing economy by reviving domestic slavery.  Mayhem ensues as neighbors - a black family and a white family, fight for a new normal.

Robert O'Hara, author of  Bootycandy and Barbecue, is in fine satiric form with the timely script.  We can't wait to bring this to the stage!

We are committed to paying  a decent wage to everybody - our artists, techs and all who work on our show from front to back.  We are committed to a professional and safe work environment which includes working with professional designers and quality production values, hiring fight choreographers, dramaturgs and vocal coaches when necessary. 

This is our largest production to date. We need to pay 10 actors; set, light, costume and sound designers, a fight choreographer and backstage personnel including an Equity stage manager.

The Breakdown

We want to raise $15,000 towards our season.  Here is what we will use it for:

$5000 for our salons to pay stipends for guest artists, salon production manager and lighting design. 

$10,000 for An American Ma(u)l) to pay for set, costumes, props, sound and lights  and additional actors.

One of our greatest challenges is balancing the cost of rehearsal, artists fees, production costs  (costumes, sets, props) and venue costs with an affordable ticket price.  We want to do excellent work and keep it affordable and accessible. It is a giant undertaking but with your help, we can complete this work and build our capacity as a theater company and continue to bring you excellent work.

If we don't reach our goal we will, of course, have to adjust our budget, maybe fewer light and sound cues, use the rickety chair in the hallway that rocks, wear our own clothes - but you don't want to see that happen!  Help us meet our goal.

Perks! Perks! Perks!

In exchange for your support, we will share as much of the BACCE experience as you can stand. We offer chances to see the work in process, get to know the ensemble members,  participate in our process, break bread with us, listen to our music, wear our clothing and accessories and for the really brave - some deep black experiences like you can only get with BACCE.   Support our cause and we will pelt you with proper perks!!!  And of course, some really great performances!
story_txt:
(l-r) Indiia Wilmott, Aejay Mitchell, Aaron Wilton, Kehinde Koyejo, Rotimi Agbabiaka
Who We Are
We are an award-winning, multi-ethnic, multi-generational and multi-faceted theatre company focused on Black theater and performance.  We seek to perform work that offers an expanded idea of Black theater in content, form, look and presentation. We find it necessary to work within artistic processes that do not reinforce the dominant paradigm and current power structures.  We are inspired by inclusivity and plurality of thought; the black avant-garde, and work that immediately challenges our most entrenched assumptions.
Currently, we are an ensemble of seven core members: Rotimi Agbabiaka, Edris Cooper-Anifowoshe (co-founder), Kehinde Koyejo, AeJay Mitchell, Shirley Smallwood (co-founder), Indiia Wilmott and Aaron Wilton.  We are in residence at Brava! for Women in the Arts, a community non-profit in San Francisco's MIssion District.  At Brava, we have premiered three plays by Black playwrights - In A Daughter's Eyes by A. Zell Williams; Sweet Maladies by Zakiyyah Alexander and last season's Bootycandy by Robert O'Hara. 


We are San Francisco's only theater dedicated to new work and the black avant garde.
We have presented more than 10 new works by Black playwrights to San Francisco audiences - plays by Keith Josef Adkins, Robert Alexander, Pearl Cleage and Robert O'Hara and numerous staged readings of new plays.
We have received critical acclaim for all of our productions and formal recognition from Theater Bay Area Awards , in 2014 - Outstanding Ensemble for Sweet Maladies & 2017 - Acting nominations for Bootycandy. 
We are prepared to respond to the moment!  We participated in the New Black Fest national play event, Facing Our Truth, seven short plays by seven playwrights surrounding the murder of Trayvon Martin. 
Our So Soul San Francisco salons are part of a larger effort at documenting the Black performance history of San Francisco and the Bay Area. 
We are all separate and successful artists who have committed ourselves to building a company together - taking charge of our careers and taking responsibility for what's on stage.
This work is fiercely important and fills a myriad of voids, builds a bucketload of bridges, smashes seas of stereotypes and provokes a plethora of potent pontifications.


 
Project #1 - So Soul San Francisco: Black Art Salons
In  2018, we are curating a series of monthly Black Art Salons, on third Thursdays in Brava's new cabaret space.  We kick it all off on February 1 with Black Heaven: A Spiritual House Party.
  The first six salons are -

February 15 - Oju Ibeji features the work of  Melorra Green and Melonie Green who will offer ways to look and participate art that we guarantee you have not experienced.
March 15  -  Afro Present: Dreamtime in the endless twilight of 24/7 features the work of dancer/choreographer, Amara Tabor Smith and the legendary Ellen Sebastian Chang 
April 19  - Black Benatar's Black Magic Cabaret  with guest host, Beatrice Thomas (aka Black Benatar) 
May 17 - Black on Black: High Crimes and Misdemeanors, hosted by BACCE
June 21 - Black Music Salon featuring local musicians

We are seeking funding to pay salon artists and offer adequate technical support for each salon.

story:
A Dance Piece about angels, gods and humans

is a way to investigate the sacred in the heart of mankind. Inspired by the work of Ovid in this dance  the bodies of the performers become a living collective, flowed through by an ethereal energy that transforms, adjusts and renames what hitherto was just formless. Watching it It's hard to avoid a certain spirituality because what you see and experience there is a bit of life from the outside, detached from stories and objects, fixed on the movement of their never-ending form-finding. Everything flows, Everything is changing!

Alessio Trevisani, known for his rich, poetic choreographies is now Artistic Director and Choreographer of the new founded Freies Tanz Ensemble.

Supporting this campaign you will help to give Dance and Art more visibility in daily life and contribute to stop what we call self- exploitation of dancers.

Our heart will beat for those who are supporting us!

 

Everything started from the fact that

the Freies Tanz Enseble has been invited to perform this beautiful piece in Siena  in Italy on January 31st after having being performed already in Rome last summer. Unfortunately the organizers are not able to provide any gage for us, just travel costs and accomodation. To cover the expenses of rehearsing and catering  and  transport and organize the quite difficult stage setting to Italy we need  5000 Euros more. 

  •  About angels, gods and humans is an  exceptional production: the 6 dancers  move in a water stage on the big topic of transformation - transformation in nature, in the animal world, in the life of man and in Myths and Mysteries from Ovid's Metamorphoses. "For" about angels, gods, humans " we have developed our own movement language, which is dominated by fluid and dynamic movements. Our Review of some narratives and metamorphoses around Mars and Venus, Daphne and Apollo, and Orpheus and Eurydice connects the dance with fascinating transformations of our time.

  •  The Impact of your support
  • The Free Dance Ensemble is deeply concerned about the dialogue of cultures. With the different religious, political and social Backgrounds of the ensemble members  Alessio Trevisani has already staged dance performances like "Engelszeit" and "Interbeing" which have  actracted a big deal of attention. 
  • We pursue the idea  to conceive projects able to connect together different religions, nationalities, gerder and  world views. 

  • Production crew

  • Choreographer: Alessio Trevisani - (Italy/Germany)
  • Dancers: Aya Mishkelboim (Israel) - Dario Bezer (Syria/Italy) - Charlie Fouchier (France) - Matteo Magnabosco (Italy) - Linda Weißig (Germany) - Claire Wolff (Germany) -
  • Stage setting.: Jürgen Kirner (Germany)
  • Costumes: Mehrbood Mokarram (Iran/Germany)

How we will use this funds

German legal Insurance  for Artist 10% - Travel costs 5% - Campaign perks 3% - Campaign fees 12% - Production cost and rehearsal gage, stage setting transport, wardrobe, logistic, rehearsal space rent, video of the performance  53% - Post production costs:  editorial video Mix and promotion 17%

We invite you to be a part of a very unique creative statement that will have positive reverberating effects for years to come! 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about our issue.
  • Do not forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
What We Need

Impulse Repertory Co. is a small professional theatre company dedicated to producing intimate, provocative works that nurture the actor-audience relationship at the core of theatre through the lens of classical works.

As a newly minted 501(c)(3) nonprofit theatre company serving Atlanta by continuing to develop the talents, skills, aspirations, and contributions of the City's actor-artists, Impulse Rep is raising funds to produce its first professional rep season in August of 2017.

In light of recent uncertainties in the artistic community, donated funds are becoming the life blood of artistic ventures nationwide. Smaller arts ventures are coming to rely heavily on the generosity and artistic foresight of their patrons. If the arts are important to your community (and they are), your dollars represent your vote to keep them present and available, to nurture artists, and to develop future audiences by getting them up close and personal with the art itself.

Your donations also represent an opportunity to let your own voice be heard in the conversations that artists start, nurture, and provoke in the community.

What We Need & What You Get

In this campaign, we are seeking $20,000 (or more) in funding to produce the Summer 2017 Impulse Rep season: 

ANTIGONE by Sophocles
directed by Kara Cantrell

JULIUS CAESAR by William Shakespeare
directed by Matt Lewis

Donors will receive recognition in our season materials, performance tickets, VIP treatment at our performances, gifts from our sponsor partners, and more depending on their giving level.

What happens if we don't reach our goal here on Indiegogo? The good news is: we still produce! Indiegogo will take a percentage of the funds and send the rest to us to continue towards our production goals. The bad news is: we'll be seeking further funding from other sources that may or may not be able to continue funding arts ventures in our community, and the depth and breadth of our productions becomes severely limited.

The Impact

The growing impact of the arts in Atlanta is undeniable. As you may know, the film industry has exploded in our City and our state in recent years. This has prompted a huge influx of artists and craftspeople in our region. These artists come for the jobs, certainly, but they stay in communities and environments that nurture them by allowing them to explore and appreciating their work. Our goal at Impulse Rep is to become a home base for actor-artists to create projects for themselves, to explore their craft in new and exciting ways, and to try their hands in different roles or positions.

In 2011 and 2012, Kara Cantrell produced three plays under the name, Impulse Rep, with great success. Partnering with the Alliance Theatre Education Department as our hosts, as well as directors Rachel Jones, Justin Anderson, and David Crowe, the productions of Medea, No Exit, and The Darker Places Trilogy by Atlanta playwright, Daniel Guyton, we had our first financial and critical successes. Now that the company has gone "legit," we've onboarded six new members drawn from Atlanta's finest actor/directors to round out our resident company: Ken Hornbeck, Jessica McGuire, and Vallea Woodbury.

Risks & Challenges

Nonprofit arts ventures are often difficult to get off the ground and we know we're entering the field at a time when major funding sources are being diminished.

Our plan for overcoming these challenges rests in the resident company's desire, expertise, and networks as artists. Our passionate team casts a City-wide, even region-wide net to pull and pool resources from fellow artists and art institutions, local and national businesses, personal relationships, and community service endeavors. A big net catches many fish.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please know that even the smallest monetary donation helps, but if you're just not in a position to help financially at this time, you can still help in profoundly valuable ways:

Please share this campaign with your friends, family, colleagues, and neighbors via social media, e-mail, and one-on-one interactions. Be sure to use the Indiegogo tools!

Volunteer! We need people to assist with services such as house and box office management, set and costume building, securing loans of scenic, lighting, and sound equipment, running lighting, sound, or wardrobe during shows, and the list goes on. Please let us know if you can help out!

story:
I have been performing spoken word poetry since the age of 16. It has been taking me places, physically and mentally. I travelled to more than 10 countries through my poetry, and have been discovering many different performance art forms and artists since. I mainly focus on Arabic spoken word poetry, because I feel that it is a still a growing platform. My Arabic spoken word videos got a lot of support and were the reason for my relative fame. Below are the links to the most important ones:  

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_bF7FNoJfGs

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vVodbIi798w&t=1s

I will also share other links of my work:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m5fAxr0t5xc

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Akcs4yCfDeg

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h_djdVQfFVU&t=1s

Going to London to study performance is very important for my performance career, and for my desire to make things happen in Arabic and in the Arab world. After sharing my spoken word poetry on YouTube and getting more recognition that I ever thought I would, especially from the Arab world, I realized that there is a dire need of artistic expression. During my last show in Amman, on December 1st 2016, the audience knew some of my poetry pieces by heart. This moment made me realize how influential performance is, even when it’s the work of a 22 year-old that still has got a lot to learn. I am applying to Goldsmiths with a huge desire to grow as a performer by acquiring theoretical and practical knowledge. I would like my work to grow beyond spoken word poetry, and I am sure that this MA will expose me to new art forms that will inspire me to leave my performance comfort zone.  

When I started performing in different Arab cities, such as Amman, Beirut, Doha, and Dubai, I felt that the so-called “underground” and alternative scenes are very limited and are still at their beginning stages. After completing my MA at Goldsmith’s, I would like to take an active part in this growing scene. At this stage, I can only imagine working at a cultural space that would become a hub for performers. Amman is my first Arab city option for now.

Your contribution is therefore essential for me to be able to get my MA. I do not think I will be able to fund my studies without your help.

If this campaign is successful, it will help me cover my university tuition fees. Please find the link stating the fees of postgraduate programs at Goldsmiths (look for MA Performance and Culture): http://www.gold.ac.uk/media/study-section/fees/PG-Fees-17-18.pdf

 

 I also attached my MA acceptance letter and my scholarship rejection letter.

Even if I do not receive the full amount, I will only be using the money to pay off my tuition fees.

If you cannot financially contribute to this campaign, I would appreciate any form of sharing. Indiegogo offers great sharing tools for their campaigns. Also, feel free to give me advice on how to raise these funds if you know of other ways to do so!

I am so happy to be able to ask for help, even if a part of me is burdened by it. Thank you thank you! 

And oh, I would like to express my gratitude to those of you who contribute financially. On the right, you will find some perks. This is the least I could do. And I would like to give a hug to anyone who took the time to read this or to share it. So much love to you.

story:
PRELIMINAR OFICIAL DE TANGO BUENOS AIRES, FESTIVAL Y MUNDIAL  

OFFICIAL PRELIMINARY OF TANGO BUENOS AIRES, FESTIVAL AND WORLD

Hace más de una década el Cameponato mundial de tango que se realiza anualmente en Buenos Aires, Argentina, realiza eliminatorias preliminares oficiales en varios paises del mundo, entre ellos Colombia. Este evento dá entrada a una pareja de cada categoría (tango de escenario y tango de pista) directamente a las semifinales. Las parejas que van a competir por Colombia han resultado entre los finalistas, incluyendo dos parejas que han logrado ganar el más alto reconocimiento al que puede aspirar una pareja de bailarines de este género. 

En el año 2006, por primera vez se coronó a una pareja no argentina como campeones mundiales tango en la categoría de tango de escenario, Carlos Paredes y Diana Giraldo, ambos nacidos en Cali, Colombia. Nueve años después esta pareja ha empezado a producir esta preliminar en Colombia, a través de su Fundación.

En esta ocación y por tercer año consecutivo la Fundación Jacaranda Centro Cultural dirigida por los campeones mundiales de Tango en Argentina 2006, Carlos Paredes y Diana Giraldo, producirán la Preliminar Oficial de Tango Buenos Aires, Festival y Mundial,  capítulo Colombia,  para conocer los talentos que representarán al país en las modalidades de Tango escenario y Tango de pista en Buenos Aires, Argentina, en agosto próximo.

La preliminar oficial de Tango Buenos Aires Festival y Mundial en Colombia tendrá lugar en el Teatro Jorge Isaacs del 20 al 23 de julio en la ciudad de Cali, Colombia.

Debido a la importancia mundial que tiene el tango como patrimonio inmaterial de la humanidad, y al desarrollo especialmente destacado que tiene en Colombia, es escencial que esta preliminar de realice anualmente. Aunque los costos son altos, por esta razón nos gustaría que ustedes nos ayudaran a hacer posible esta importante plataforma para el arte y la cultura.

---

More than a decade ago, the world tango championships, held annually in Buenos Aires, Argentina, were holding a preliminary in several countries of the world, including Colombia. This event gave a pair of each category (stage tango and track tango) a ticket directly to the semifinals. Two of the couples that have competed for Colombia have been among the finalists, and have managed to win the most recognition that can be aspired by a pair of dancers of this genre.

In 2006 Cali born, Carlos Paredes and Diana Giraldo, were the first non-Argentine couple were crowned world-wide champions of tango, in the stage category. Nine years later this couple has become the hosts of this preliminary in Colombia, through their foundation. 

On this occasion and for the third consecutive year, the Jacaranda Cultural Center Foundation, directed by the world champions of Tango in Argentina 2006, Carlos Paredes and Diana Giraldo, will produce the Official Preliminary Tango Buenos Aires, Festival and World, chapter Colombia. Here in this preliminary the talents that will represent Colombia in the modalities of Stage Tango and Track Tango in Buenos Aires, Argentina, next August, will be chosen. 

The official preliminary of the Buenos Aires Tango Festival and the World Cup in Colombia will take place at the Jorge Isaacs Theater from July 20 to 23 in the city of Cali, Colombia.

Due to the worldwide importance of tango as an intangible heritage of humanity, and to the outstanding development that it has in Colombia, it is essential that this preliminary be held annually. Although the costs are high we want to help make this important platform of art and culture a possibility. 

Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes

Para realizar esta nueva edición de la preliminar colombiana del campeonato mundial de tango necesitamos reunir 2.000 USD o 6 millones de pesos colombianos aproximadamente. Esto será utilizado para pagar los premios a los ganadores en las dos categorías oficiales, que incluyen tiquetes aéreos hasta la ciudad de Buenos Aires.

Dentro de nuestras recompensas tenemos clases personalizadas con los campeones mundiales de tango, dvd de la competencia.

De no lograrse la meta, igual utilizariamos los recursos para cubrir parte de los gastos mencionados, y buscaríamos el resto con otros patrocinios. 

What We Need and What You Get

To make this new edition of the Colombian preliminary of the world championship of tango we need to raise approximately 2,000 USD or 6 million Colombian pesos. This money will be used to pay the two winners in the two official categories, and as well as, provide airfare to the city of Buenos Aires.

Within our rewards we have personalized lessons with the world champions of tango, competition dvd.

If we do not achieve the goal, we would use the resources to cover part of the expenses mentioned, and we would look for the rest with other sponsorships.

El impacto

El tango es uno de los géneros más conocidos en el mundo, se puede disfrutran tanto de la música como el baile, en esta ocación la preliminar permitirá que se reunan los mejores exponentes de este género del país, todos compitiendo para ser elegidos una de las dos parejas que representará a Colombia en las semifinales del Campeonato Mundial de Tango, a realizarse en Buenos Aires, Argentina.

Con su apoyo esperamos ofrecer un gran espectáculo a toda la ciudadanía. Cali siempre se ha destacado como un ciudad con talento para la danza y en el tango no se queda atrás, dos de las parejas campeonas, coronadas en Buenos Aires, tiene componentes de origen caleño; Colombia ha tenido varias parejas finalistas en cada edición de este campeonato, por esta razón es importante que esta plataforma para los bailarines de este género se mantenga.

The Impact

The Tango is one of the most known genres in the world, it can be enjoyed in music and dance. This time the preliminary will allow the most talented competitors of this genre of the country to meet, all competing to be chosen as one of the two couples who represent Colombia in the semifinals of the World Tango Championship, in Buenos Aires, Argentina.

With your support we hope to offer a great show to all citizens. Cali has always stood out as a city with talent for dance and the tango is not an exception. Two of the championship couples, crowned in Buenos Aires, has components of Caleño origin. Colombia has had several finalists pairs in each edition of this championship, so it is important to maintain this platform for dancers of this genre.

Riesgos y desafíos

Diferentes empresas y entidades se unen para hacer posible este evento, sin embargo los costos no podrán ser cubiertos en su totalidad si tu ayuda. No contamos con financiación estatal y aunque algunos de los eventos que están planteados tiene un costo simbólico, no nos garantizan que recojamos el dinero necesario para cubrir los gastos. 

Risks and Challenges

Different companies and entities come together to make this event possible, however costs can not be fully covered without their help. We do not have state funds and although some of the events that are presented do collect donations, they do not guarantee that we will collect the necessary money to cover expenses.

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

Recuerda que necesitamos que esta campaña llegue a la mayor cantidad de personas para lograr nuestra meta, ayúdanos con la difusión compartiendo esta campaña en tus redes sociales.

You Can Help in Other Ways

Remember that we need this campaign to reach the greatest number of people to achieve our goal, to help us with the spread by sharing this campaign in their social networks.

story:
Short Summary

Nearly Naked Broadway needs your help to produce our first show. Venues in San Jose, CA are incredibly expensive (and the ones that aren't weren't particularly excited to host burlesque), and we want to be able to afford to produce more shows AND pay all of our contributors (dancers, tech, hosts, etc.!). We also want to make sure we have a marketing budget so people know when and where to show up.

Why do this show? Because we want to bring the South Bay theatre and burlesque communities together in support of one another's art:

This show is for burlesque dancers and theatre artists who wish they could show off their belting skills while taking off their belts and want to give a new definition to Kander & Ebb's ol' razzle-dazzle. Everyone is encouraged to apply, regardless of their theatre resume, gender, abilities, etc. This show is intended to create a space for anyone who wants the chance to sing and dance their dream role — as long as they do it in their underwear. (Performers must, of course, submit an audition, but we’ll be casting a wide net for our casting!)


It’s also for (adult) theatre audiences who want to see a whole new side of their favorite Broadway musicals. This show brings the Bay Area's burlesque and theatre community together, one musical theatre sacrilege at a time. If you’ve got an open mind, a good attitude, and a love for anyone from Cole Porter to Pasek and Paul, then we have a seat for you in our theatre. 

We’re also giving back to the community: once we hit a certain ticket threshold (which is determined by the size of our theatre, so we can pay back the artists who contribute their time to this show), a percentage of the proceeds will be donated to a San Jose community charity. 

This will be a regular show, produced either monthly or every other month. 

What We Need & What You Get

Here's what your funds will help us accomplish: 

THEATER COSTS: 

  • $385 - Theater from 6:30 - 10 pm 
  • $192.50 - Supervisor
  • $140 - Custodial 
  • $210 - A/V
  • $75 - Liability Insurance 
  • $25 - Application Fee
  • ~$600 - Parking fee

TALENT COSTS 

  • $810 - Performers, Hosts, Kittens 
  • ~$400 - A/V (Photo/Video)

MARKETING COSTS 

  • $150 - Theatre Bay Area Membership 
  • $270 - Audience Database 
  • $368 - Theater Insider Email Promotion 
  • $613 - Theatergoer Audience Email Promotion 
  • $154 - What's Playing Promotion 
  • $45 - Postcard Distribution Network 
  • $300 - Facebook Ads 
  • ~$50 - Postcards
  • ~$170 - Postage

What do YOU get out of all this? You get a professional quality show that will knock your socks off (while we take off our own). If you're interested in performing, you get a new venue to do so, where we'll challenge your creativity and give you a chance to sing and dance to the songs you've always dreamed of performing. You'll be keeping the spirit of Broadway alive here on the West Coast...and you'll be helping to keep Silicon Valley full of artists and makers and weirdos and sparkly unicorns. 

The Impact

Our Commitment

Nearly Naked Broadway is committed to body positivity, gender inclusivity, racial equity and justice, and community involvement. Our goal with this show is to give people of all abilities and backgrounds the chance to be cheered for, accepted, and appreciated. We strive to put on high quality performances to engage our audiences and to give back to our community and support our local artists whenever financially possible. 

Risks & Challenges

There is inherent risk in producing a show. If we don't reach our financial goals, then we run the risk of being unable to pay performers or, worse, have our producer go into serious debt. Art isn't easy -- and it's not cheap either. Until we can afford to run our own venue, we're at the mercy of rental prices in Silicon Valley -- which are skewed high by the tech folks who can afford $4K for a single event without batting an eye. We need to keep the arts alive in Silicon Valley, but we can't do it without your support! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't afford to support the show financially? We understand! Please share this campaign with people you know who might be able to support us, and consider saving up for a ticket to the show! 

If you want to see the show, “like” our Facebook page for updates (http://facebook.com/nearlynvkedbroadway) and sign up for the newsletter to get first dibs on tickets here: http://eepurl.com/c0tXvT

You can also sign up to take Broadway burlesque dance classes at Ariel Dance in Campbell, CA. Proceeds from the classes will also go toward this show. Sign up here: 

https://app.acuityscheduling.com/schedule.php?o...

Want to be involved some other way? Get in touch with producer DeeDee Queen at deedeequeenburlesque@gmail.com and share your ideas!
