story:
Who and What is Downstage Honolulu?

Downstage Honolulu is a collaborative performing arts space for interactive performances featuring stand-up, improv, theater, music and any art that can fit on our stage. It is the combined vision of Think Fast Improv and Powerful Comedy to create an entertainment venue with a stage, bar and education center for performing arts. 

Think Fast Improv has been performing and teaching the art of improvisation in Honolulu since 2011. We have performed over 700 shows, 5 festival appearances and taught close to 900 classes and workshops, cultivating new generations of improvisers into the Honolulu scene and beyond.

In 2017 Pepper Lamb decided to combine his love of weightlifting with his love for comedy and created Powerfull Comedy. Since its founding, Pepper has opened for multiple mainland comedians and produced events all over Oahu. 

After performing and promoting together for a few years we found a unified desire for a space of our own. A space that was not a bar first, stage second and a place where we could perform more than twice a month. We visited many potential locations around Honolulu until we found a perfect space for our new home. Located on 1128 Smith Street in Chinatown Honolulu, downstairs in the historic Tan Sing building built in 1900 (across the street from the delicious Little Village Noodle House) Downstage Honolulu was born. 

Downstage Honolulu is quickly becoming ready to open our stage and training rooms to whatever art will fit on our stage! We’ve been blessed by an amazing community of volunteer improvisers, comedians, poets, musicians and people that just love the arts who have helped us on our way. We are constantly reminded though their excitement and passion that this space is ultimately for them. 

 

What do we need help with?

So far, we have overcome and completed some pretty big accomplishments:

  • Paid our 3-month deposit
  • Covered our Insurance
  • Revived the rock wall once hidden by drywall and plaster
  • Hired a lawyer and began the process of acquiring our liquor license
  • Removed the old office layout with our own hands and sheer determination
  • Booked contractors to help us navigate our construction, plumbing, electrical and AC needs. 

The Education Center, bar and podcast side of the basement are nearing completion. The podcast room is taking shape, complete with some great podcast chairs Pepper acquired. We have even begun taking room reservations for podcast recording sessions, improv team rehearsals and classes, as well as welcomed established show promoters planning to move their events over to our stage. It is all very exciting for us and for the community!

With the guidance of our general contractors, we have done most of the heavy lifting for the demolition and remodeling on our own which also help us save money. We were able to salvage much of the previous tenant’s reception desk and will be re-purposing the wood for the ticket booth and theater area. Our friends have also helped us secure discounts on construction materials for the rebuild as well as donated wood for the stage from our good friend Shain Miller.  

We have invested 8 years of savings and sweat into Downstage Honolulu. As with 120-year-old buildings, a couple of surprises were hidden behind walls, in the ceiling, and under tiles. Even with extra budgeting for unseen expenses, the costs are beginning to exceed the extra budgeted for surprises.

We are turning to Indiegogo for your help to get our community center back on track to open as a gathering space for improv, stand-up, and whatever art will fit on our stage. While we are on target to meet our immediate goals, this fundraiser will be an immense help to our future goals to take off running towards bigger productions and broader classes. 

Here is where your support will go towards:

AC System:  We were told that the unit had AC, and it does, it just needs some serious ductwork and maintenance that we discovered after starting renovations. We’re going to get some contractors to tell us what the cost of reworking the ducts is or if a new AC system is cheaper. 

Theater Floor: The huge reception desk was sunk below and attached to the subfloor instead of on the floorboards. Our friend Shane shared that patching would be more expensive in the long run than putting in a new floor now. He is going to get us additional quotes from his industry friends on floor replacement options. He has a very creative and cost-effective idea that will look amazing. 

Main Entrance: Our main entrance is in the center of the exterior of the building, opening into a grand staircase that descends down to our future ticket booth. The natural lighting in the day makes the entry look fantastic. However, because the previous tenants were all daytime hours, they never installed any lighting for nighttime. For everyone's safety we will need some lighting along the sides of the stairs and on the 20’ raised ceiling (need professional help for this part).  

Security System: We do have one that was in the unit already,which was made before 60% of the founders were born. We found that sourcing VHS tapes for blurry black and white video would not be very cost effective. It will do for now while we are in construction, but we need a better system once all the equipment is in. We found a few replacement options that would be cost effective and provide security for the doors, bar and high traffic areas. 

Sound Baffling: Performing arts can be quiet and introspective, loud and rambunctious, and everything in between. We want to make sure that the Education Center has good sound reduction. Our friend Lock Lynch provided us some great cost-effective options to reduce the sound from outside and between each classroom. 

Stage Lighting: During the expansion of the theater area, we removed a dividing wall where we discovered that there was extensive duct work above that limited our ability to remove and flatten the ceiling for lighting. Through Rory’s theater tech experience, he found alternative low profile lighting that we can use that won’t cook the audience but costs $1,000 above budgeted allowance.

Ceiling Renovation: We also found a hole in our ceiling / the nice hardwood flooring of our upstairs restaurant neighbor. As nice as the tenants are upstairs, we want to make sure drinks and dip from the restaurant don’t drip onto our community. Removal of portion of ceiling, fix the hole, and patch the ceiling.

We do have the minimum funds to cover some of these issues, and your support will help us regain our lost ground covering these surprise costs. The sooner we can work towards covering these expenses, the sooner we can work toward our vision as Downstage Honolulu!

 

Stretch Goals

We are so fortunate to have our new home in the heart of Chinatown. We have watched this arts district grow over the last decade with niche food havens, holiday block parties and a bustling scene of music and performances. We want to live up to this new Chinatown look and would like to be able to open with some flair. After our needs are taken care of any additional funds you beautiful people bless us with will be used towards the following.

Podcasting: We have a podcast room full of awesome equipment and comfortable chairs from Pepper. If we have left over donations, we would like to sound baffle this room as well. With the bar right outside we want to make it extra audio-friendly.

Live-streaming: We have a wonderful professional live-streaming technician that has offered her expertise to set up our space with live-streaming capabilities. We would love for her to come assist us with installing the proper equipment to live-stream and record shows for performers to use for festival submissions and promotions. 

Bathroom Upgrades: Since we’re sound baffling everything else why not the bathrooms. It's just more comfortable when you know that any sound coming out the door is reduced by a few more decibels. Better fan ventilation never hurts either. 

 

What Do You Get?

We brainstormed real good and hard over the perks we could give for your generous support. We also wanted to make sure that we had options for everybody both in our neighborhood and across the world!

All perks will come with (1) ticket to our Indiegogo Thank You weekend! With your Indiegogo donation, you will get the red carpet treatment into our new home for any show during our Thank You Fundraiser weekend. It is our way of saying thank you for your support for helping us on our way! Weekend dates to be announced pending on COVID-19 status (please see Update #3).

For those that like stuffs: we have stickers, patches and a LIMITED-EDITION T-SHIRT! We created a limited shirt design for our supporters that can only be collected through this Indiegogo fundraiser. Once they are gone, they’re gone! In line with our vision of supporting Hawaii businesses, our limited edition shirts and stickers are locally produced by our neighbors up the street from us: Blank Canvas! 

We have some perks that will appeal to our local friends and fans

  • Date Night Pass: For couples or pals, this one's for you two! Get two tickets to any 10 Downstage Honolulu produced show and two drink tokens during your date (20 tickets/20 drinks). The perfect date night!
  • Season 1 Event Pass: Flash this baby at the ticket counter and get automatic access to any Downstage Honolulu produced events for our first season (April 2020 – July 2020). *This pass is for Downstage Honolulu produced events only.
  • All Year Event Pass: You’ll never have to worry about buying a ticket to a Downstage Honolulu produced event for the rest of 2020. With this pass you’ll be able to watch every Downstage Honolulu produced event inside our walls. *This pass is for Downstage Honolulu produced events only.

For our supporters near and afar, these might intrigue you:

  • The Name Game with Rory and Larissa: Two of our founders and veteran improvisers of Think Fast Improv wanna play a game with you! They will use the name of whoever claims these perks as character names in every scene FOR ONE WHOLE SEASON! *Must be legitimate moniker, no unsavory shenanigans please.
  • Tiny Box Window Seat Reservation: Have a mini seat reserved in the box window overlooking our stage! These two-inch tall red velvet chairs will catch all our events that will have your name lovingly written on a tiny card to reserve your tiny seat for one whole year. The tiny box window seat is perfect for those who wish they could be here.
  • Step into 2020 Sponsor: For helping us make the first step into our first year, we will etch your name on a plaque and display it on a stair on our grand staircase. All who leave our home will see that you helped us take the first steps!

 

The Downstage Honolulu Vision 

Making Hawaii a location, not a destination for performing arts: We have always known that this community is full of incredible artists who deserve to be given a home of their own. We have seen so many super talented folks leave Hawaii to make a name for themselves, only when they’re gone does Hawaii recognize their worth. We want to change that to the best of our ability by encouraging a positive growth of the community. These things will take time, but they are worth it, and our community deserves it!

Putting Local Business First: We strive to support the local businesses here, when it comes to choosing who to turn to for merch production, construction materials, and venue supplies. We will choose our island neighbors first and work towards methods to reduce our carbon footprint as much as we can. 

Fostering Growth in our Community: Hawaii has a unique community thanks in part to the being physically removed from the rest of the improv, stand-up, and performing art meccas. It also can limit our challenge to grow. We can help to change this by providing opportunities to learn by 

  • Bringing premium talents to our stage
  • Hosting workshops by masters of improv and stand-up
  • Working with emerging new writers and directors to produce theater that intrigues audiences and challenges performers
  • Mentor new talent in areas of show creation, event production, branding, media interaction, and networking. 

Paying the Performers: We have always known since we joined the performing arts - improv and stand-up comedy - that this is a labor of love first. With Downstage Honolulu we have a chance to give performers what has been long overdue. Our vision is to start paying performers for their time, energy and creativity. 

 

What are our Risks?

As a business dedicated to performing arts- improv and stand-up comedy- we are relying on the creative talents and supporters of the community. To expand potential income and minimize risks, we are working with other creative and business leaders outside of improv and stand-up to share our stage, and collaborate to add additional events and classes to our calendar. Which means everybody wins!

We have worked to minimize potential risks by;

  • Using licensed professionals to guide our renovation and complete the work we cannot.
  • Purchasing expanded insurance to provide greater coverage
  • Consulting with businesses to determine best practices for the finances, bar operation, and construction.

When our lease for 1128 Smith Street expires, we have options to extend the lease. When that time comes, we will have some serious decisions. Know that we have full intentions to keep going and will strive to continue our mission of being completely dedicated to our community and its growth.

Your support towards our little venue is something that we cannot ever convey in the best words how grateful we are for it. We have dreamed of this moment for over 10 years, and you have helped us bring it into reality. We are forever thankful. 

 

So How Can I help?

Yes! We love your enthusiasm and gusto! Even if you’re not able to contribute to this fundraiser there are other ways you can help support the Downstage Honolulu vision. 

Share the Fundraiser: Share our fundraiser on your Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook profiles to help us gain visibility. Tell your friends and followers why they should join you in supporting us and what the arts mean to you!

Show Some Love: Follow and like the Downstage Honolulu profiles on Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook! If you haven’t yet, please do! We post updates, pictures of our progress and our calendar of cool events and classes!

Come out to a Show: Supporting the scene is a great way of showing your love towards our vision. Come out and enjoy a night of fun. Have a chat with us and we’ll catch you up on our progress!
story_txt:
Who and What is Downstage Honolulu?Downstage Honolulu is a collaborative performing arts space for interactive performances featuring stand-up, improv, theater, music and any art that can fit on our stage. It is the combined vision of Think Fast Improv and Powerful Comedy to create an entertainment venue with a stage, bar and education center for performing arts. Think Fast Improv has been performing and teaching the art of improvisation in Honolulu since 2011. We have performed over 700 shows, 5 festival appearances and taught close to 900 classes and workshops, cultivating new generations of improvisers into the Honolulu scene and beyond.In 2017 Pepper Lamb decided to combine his love of weightlifting with his love for comedy and created Powerfull Comedy. Since its founding, Pepper has opened for multiple mainland comedians and produced events all over Oahu. After performing and promoting together for a few years we found a unified desire for a space of our own. A space that was not a bar first, stage second and a place where we could perform more than twice a month. We visited many potential locations around Honolulu until we found a perfect space for our new home. Located on 1128 Smith Street in Chinatown Honolulu, downstairs in the historic Tan Sing building built in 1900 (across the street from the delicious Little Village Noodle House) Downstage Honolulu was born. Downstage Honolulu is quickly becoming ready to open our stage and training rooms to whatever art will fit on our stage! We’ve been blessed by an amazing community of volunteer improvisers, comedians, poets, musicians and people that just love the arts who have helped us on our way. We are constantly reminded though their excitement and passion that this space is ultimately for them.  What do we need help with?So far, we have overcome and completed some pretty big accomplishments:
Paid our 3-month deposit
Covered our Insurance
Revived the rock wall once hidden by drywall and plaster
Hired a lawyer and began the process of acquiring our liquor license
Removed the old office layout with our own hands and sheer determination
Booked contractors to help us navigate our construction, plumbing, electrical and AC needs. 
The Education Center, bar and podcast side of the basement are nearing completion. The podcast room is taking shape, complete with some great podcast chairs Pepper acquired. We have even begun taking room reservations for podcast recording sessions, improv team rehearsals and classes, as well as welcomed established show promoters planning to move their events over to our stage. It is all very exciting for us and for the community!With the guidance of our general contractors, we have done most of the heavy lifting for the demolition and remodeling on our own which also help us save money. We were able to salvage much of the previous tenant’s reception desk and will be re-purposing the wood for the ticket booth and theater area. Our friends have also helped us secure discounts on construction materials for the rebuild as well as donated wood for the stage from our good friend Shain Miller.  We have invested 8 years of savings and sweat into Downstage Honolulu. As with 120-year-old buildings, a couple of surprises were hidden behind walls, in the ceiling, and under tiles. Even with extra budgeting for unseen expenses, the costs are beginning to exceed the extra budgeted for surprises.We are turning to Indiegogo for your help to get our community center back on track to open as a gathering space for improv, stand-up, and whatever art will fit on our stage. While we are on target to meet our immediate goals, this fundraiser will be an immense help to our future goals to take off running towards bigger productions and broader classes. Here is where your support will go towards:AC System:  We were told that the unit had AC, and it does, it just needs some serious ductwork and maintenance that we discovered after starting renovations. We’re going to get some contractors to tell us what the cost of reworking the ducts is or if a new AC system is cheaper. Theater Floor: The huge reception desk was sunk below and attached to the subfloor instead of on the floorboards. Our friend Shane shared that patching would be more expensive in the long run than putting in a new floor now. He is going to get us additional quotes from his industry friends on floor replacement options. He has a very creative and cost-effective idea that will look amazing. Main Entrance: Our main entrance is in the center of the exterior of the building, opening into a grand staircase that descends down to our future ticket booth. The natural lighting in the day makes the entry look fantastic. However, because the previous tenants were all daytime hours, they never installed any lighting for nighttime. For everyone's safety we will need some lighting along the sides of the stairs and on the 20’ raised ceiling (need professional help for this part).  Security System: We do have one that was in the unit already,which was made before 60% of the founders were born. We found that sourcing VHS tapes for blurry black and white video would not be very cost effective. It will do for now while we are in construction, but we need a better system once all the equipment is in. We found a few replacement options that would be cost effective and provide security for the doors, bar and high traffic areas. Sound Baffling: Performing arts can be quiet and introspective, loud and rambunctious, and everything in between. We want to make sure that the Education Center has good sound reduction. Our friend Lock Lynch provided us some great cost-effective options to reduce the sound from outside and between each classroom. Stage Lighting: During the expansion of the theater area, we removed a dividing wall where we discovered that there was extensive duct work above that limited our ability to remove and flatten the ceiling for lighting. Through Rory’s theater tech experience, he found alternative low profile lighting that we can use that won’t cook the audience but costs $1,000 above budgeted allowance.Ceiling Renovation: We also found a hole in our ceiling / the nice hardwood flooring of our upstairs restaurant neighbor. As nice as the tenants are upstairs, we want to make sure drinks and dip from the restaurant don’t drip onto our community. Removal of portion of ceiling, fix the hole, and patch the ceiling.We do have the minimum funds to cover some of these issues, and your support will help us regain our lost ground covering these surprise costs. The sooner we can work towards covering these expenses, the sooner we can work toward our vision as Downstage Honolulu! Stretch GoalsWe are so fortunate to have our new home in the heart of Chinatown. We have watched this arts district grow over the last decade with niche food havens, holiday block parties and a bustling scene of music and performances. We want to live up to this new Chinatown look and would like to be able to open with some flair. After our needs are taken care of any additional funds you beautiful people bless us with will be used towards the following.Podcasting: We have a podcast room full of awesome equipment and comfortable chairs from Pepper. If we have left over donations, we would like to sound baffle this room as well. With the bar right outside we want to make it extra audio-friendly.Live-streaming: We have a wonderful professional live-streaming technician that has offered her expertise to set up our space with live-streaming capabilities. We would love for her to come assist us with installing the proper equipment to live-stream and record shows for performers to use for festival submissions and promotions. Bathroom Upgrades: Since we’re sound baffling everything else why not the bathrooms. It's just more comfortable when you know that any sound coming out the door is reduced by a few more decibels. Better fan ventilation never hurts either.  What Do You Get?We brainstormed real good and hard over the perks we could give for your generous support. We also wanted to make sure that we had options for everybody both in our neighborhood and across the world!All perks will come with (1) ticket to our Indiegogo Thank You weekend! With your Indiegogo donation, you will get the red carpet treatment into our new home for any show during our Thank You Fundraiser weekend. It is our way of saying thank you for your support for helping us on our way! Weekend dates to be announced pending on COVID-19 status (please see Update #3).For those that like stuffs: we have stickers, patches and a LIMITED-EDITION T-SHIRT! We created a limited shirt design for our supporters that can only be collected through this Indiegogo fundraiser. Once they are gone, they’re gone! In line with our vision of supporting Hawaii businesses, our limited edition shirts and stickers are locally produced by our neighbors up the street from us: Blank Canvas! We have some perks that will appeal to our local friends and fans

Date Night Pass: For couples or pals, this one's for you two! Get two tickets to any 10 Downstage Honolulu produced show and two drink tokens during your date (20 tickets/20 drinks). The perfect date night!

Season 1 Event Pass: Flash this baby at the ticket counter and get automatic access to any Downstage Honolulu produced events for our first season (April 2020 – July 2020). *This pass is for Downstage Honolulu produced events only.

All Year Event Pass: You’ll never have to worry about buying a ticket to a Downstage Honolulu produced event for the rest of 2020. With this pass you’ll be able to watch every Downstage Honolulu produced event inside our walls. *This pass is for Downstage Honolulu produced events only.
For our supporters near and afar, these might intrigue you:

The Name Game with Rory and Larissa: Two of our founders and veteran improvisers of Think Fast Improv wanna play a game with you! They will use the name of whoever claims these perks as character names in every scene FOR ONE WHOLE SEASON! *Must be legitimate moniker, no unsavory shenanigans please.

Tiny Box Window Seat Reservation: Have a mini seat reserved in the box window overlooking our stage! These two-inch tall red velvet chairs will catch all our events that will have your name lovingly written on a tiny card to reserve your tiny seat for one whole year. The tiny box window seat is perfect for those who wish they could be here.

Step into 2020 Sponsor: For helping us make the first step into our first year, we will etch your name on a plaque and display it on a stair on our grand staircase. All who leave our home will see that you helped us take the first steps!

These things will take time, but they are worth it, and our community deserves it!Putting Local Business First: We strive to support the local businesses here, when it comes to choosing who to turn to for merch production, construction materials, and venue supplies. We will choose our island neighbors first and work towards methods to reduce our carbon footprint as much as we can. Fostering Growth in our Community: Hawaii has a unique community thanks in part to the being physically removed from the rest of the improv, stand-up, and performing art meccas. story:
Threads Dance Nexus is the future home for Threads Dance Project to operate, grow and most importantly, provide a center for the community to learn, experience, create and connect through movement.  A formal commitment is required from Threads by July 1st in order to move forward with the development of this space in the Focus Arts Building in the Seward neighborhood of Minneapolis.

This unique opportunity has arrived at a time of uncertainty for sure. Within the last week, this diverse and thriving community has been hit hard with physical damage and devastation in the aftermath of George Floyd’s murder. We are committed to embodying our mission of connection, using the unique power of movement in healing the community we are hoping to call home and moving forward with open hearts and minds.  Threads board and staff see this as an chance to demonstrate hope in our future and commitment to the community.

Threads cannot fulfill this dream without your support. Our goal is to raise $235,000 to finance the build out of the Threads Dance Nexus by June 13th. We are proud to say that we have $83,000 pledged towards our goal with the majority of contributions coming from our Board of Directors and foundations. If you are in a position to help, we humbly ask that you support this one-time request with a gift in any amount.  Your support of the Threads Dance Nexus will enable us to move forward boldly, fulfilling our mission to provide programming that meets the community’s needs both today and tomorrow.

If you can donate to aid us in fulfilling our mission, please do so by June 13th 

 

Looking hopefully towards the future,

Karen L. Charles – Artistic/Executive Director

story:
My name is Alberto Vazquez and I have a been and actor (45 years), an acting teacher since 2004, and a screenwriter for many years.  I have directed and produced shows in my career.  Doing this play (Ellie, Mom and Me) would be the topper in my career.  Contributors will help me achieve my career ending dream.

 

In order to create a really great production, I know a $10,000 fund raiser would make this happen.  This will include front row seats to opening night (or any night you choose to attend), and being invited to the wrap party, which is exciting to mingle with all the creative people involved.

 

If I don't reach my goal, I will donate the monies to my favorite charity, The March of Dimes.  This show is important because it makes us reflect about our family, our shortcomings as humans, and our character flaws that hinder our personal growth.  

 

I know there are risks involved here: and show business is an industry driven by rejection, but I am never one to let that affect me.  After forty-five years in this business, I am well armed with (great) contacts to achieve my goal.  Nothing will stop me from getting the show up!!!

 

Maybe you won't contribute to my project, but you can pass the word around and help me that way.  "Six degrees of separation" always works.  Use Indiegogo (share tools) to help me in that way.  I really would appreciate that.

story:
Please Note:

Donations on IndieGoGo are not tax-deductible. You may make a tax-deductible donation on Fractured Atlas: Rude Grooms' Commons Series is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Rude Grooms' Commons Series must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.​

When making a donation, make sure to enter a whole number without a decimal point (i.e., 35 rather than 35.00) -- contributors have reported issues with decimal points when backing the project. If you have any questions or issues, please reach out to us directly and we'll figure it out.

In Brief:

We are a Startup Theatre Experiment run by experienced actor-creators with a successful track record of producing Elizabethan and Jacobean plays that come to the public rather than making the public come to them. With your help, we'll bring a free professional, accessible, and family-friendly performances of William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet to audiences in areas of Queens, NY, not served by traditional theatre companies.

This show is a continuation of our commitment to bring high quality, free productions of classic stories to our diverse Queens communities as immersive, interactive, and irreplicable experiences.

The ensemble of this production includes veterans of Shakespeare's Globe, The Old Globe, Asolo Repertory Theatre, New York Classical Theatre, Classic Stage Company, Trinity Shakespeare Festival, and Seven Stages Shakespeare, among many other national and international companies.

Bringing world-class, approachable productions of these timeless stories directly to an audience is more important than ever in our increasingly fragmented society. By supporting this production, you will be playing a very active role in bringing communities together to share in joy, understanding, and empathy.

You can make a meaningful difference with even the smallest contribution. Our perks will make sure that your investment is well rewarded; more importantly, with even the smallest donation you are planting a seed to grow understanding and build community.

What's in it for You (and Us)?

As an experiment in translating the Elizabethan theatre troupe model intro 21st Century Startup vernacular, our donors are incredibly important to us and we strive to give you even more unique and exciting activities than the general public (like our Secret Shakespeare Hunt, which guests have called "by far THE COOLEST THING I'VE EVER DONE IN New York City").

Here is exactly where your $4,500 will go:

$2,250 - Artist Stipends- though the production is free, we are committed to ensuring that our collaborating artists receive stipends above the minimum transportation reimbursement required by Actors Equity Association. As a company, we plan to move aggressively towards paying our artists at least minimum wage for their skilled work; in the meantime, all artists involved in the production receive an equal favored nations stipend of $150 for the two week commitment, including our two Acting Apprentices.

$1,250 - Production Costs -  this includes costumes, props, wardrobe and musical instrument maintenance, an additional 10x10 canopy for changing area and basic scenic requirements, City Park permits, theater rental

$1,000 - Rehearsal Expenses- this includes rehearsal space rental (for rehearsals where we cannot be accommodated by our producing partner, Long Island City Artists at the Plaxall Gallery) and stage management expenses during the hectic one-week rehearsal process.

In addition to joining our extended family, the following contributions will get you unique perks:

$1 - Upstart Crow - a video thank you from the cast, an Elizabethan social media holla, access to exclusive behind the scenes updates throughout the process.

$30 - Player's Hide - all of the Upstart Crow perks plus a playbill signed by the entire cast and a listing in our playbill and on our website (donation must be received before August 12 to guarantee inclusion in the playbill), and a custom Shakespearean meme made just for you from a production or rehearsal photo instead of the social media holla.

$65 - Shake-Scene - all of the Player's Hide perks plus access to VIP seating area for one and a Rude Grooms water bottle.

$100 - Muse of Fire - all of the Shake-Scene perks, plus access to VIP seating area for two (or you and a guest), an original sonnet composed to you (or the person of your choice) by Rude Grooms’ Master of the Revels Montgomery Sutton, and a signed poster instead of program.

$150 - Feast of Crispian​ - all of the Muse of Fire perks plus a picnic basket of snacks to enjoy during the show.

$250 - Moonshine Reveller - all of the Feast of Crispian perks plus 2 additional spots in the VIP area (4 total), an apothecary box put together just for you by our Production Designer Sara Slagle, and an invitation for you and up to 3 guests to the opening night private "Capulet Ball" cast party (8/16/2019) on a rooftop in Astoria which includes a mask hand-decorated for you by Costume Designer Laura Piccoli. (limit 7; please note: the apothecary box and mask may require 1 week notice to pick up).

$5,000 - Lord Chamberlain - all of the Moonshine Reveller perks plus a private performance at your own venue (you provide transportation if outside of NYC).

$10,000 - Queen - all of the Moonshine Reveller perks plus a custom, immersive theatrical event created just for you and up to 20 guests.

The Production

We are led by actor-manager Montgomery Sutton (Twelfth Night at Shakespeare's Globe) and produced in partnership with Long Island City Artists at the Plaxall Gallery and the Astoria Park Alliance, made possible (in part) by the Queens Council on the Arts with public funds from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council.

Sutton says “Encountering Romeo and Juliet as a teenager cracked Shakespeare open for me for the first time. Its enduring resonance with audiences young and old alike reconnects us to our shared humanity, an impulse which is at the core of our Commons Series: free performances of timeless stories in active public spaces to strengthen our Queens community through cultural engagement.”

“The show is a 90-minute, family-friendly romp with live acoustic music that features award-winning professional artists and is completely free. By activating familiar spaces in new ways and bringing world-class performers out into our communities, our Commons Series is an act of shared imagination that tears down barriers of entry into artistic programming, barriers between actor and audience, and barriers between audience members themselves.”

In addition to Sutton, the acting company includes Elisabeth Ahrens, Milagros Bobier, Jerome Harmann Hardeman, Carroll Herring, Dhruv Iyengar, Rachael Jenison, Daniel Kemper, Laura Piccoli, Deb Radloff, Rachel Schmeling, Montgomery Sutton, Casterline Villar. 

Becca Kaplan is the Stage Manager, Paulina Tovar is the Stage Management Apprentice, Sara Slagle is the Production Designer, Kaitlyn Farley and Jared Kirby of New York Combat for Stage & Screen are the Fight Directors, Kara Arena is the Composer, Bridget Bose is the Dance Choreographer, Laura Piccoli is the Costume Designer, and Jessica Latour is Associate Producer.

More Ways to Help

The smallest contribution will have a major impact on this production, and through it, the communities that it touches. But there are many more ways you can help:

  • Share this campaign all over your social networks. Connect us with people in your circle who have the desire and ability to help launch unique arts organizations.
  • Come and see us, and bring your friends! The best way for us to build word of mouth and find new patrons and sponsors is with bodies on the grass. Make reservations at https://rudegrooms.com/productions/romeo-and-juliet/
  • If you or a family member know of corporations with an interest in supporting arts and cultural programming, please point us in their direction to make an appeal.

Stretch Goals

If, beyond our wildest dreams, we not only meet but exceed our initial goal, here is our plan for how additional funds will bolster the production.

$5,000-$8,550 - Artist Stipends- every dollar raised between $5,000 and $8,550 will go directly towards increasing artist stipends

$8,550-$10,000 - Additional PR and Marketing- more targeted online advertising, printing posters to put up near performance venues, etc.

$10,000+- Moving Towards a Living Wage- anything above $10,000 will be allocated equally among artists until they each reach the equivalent of NY State minimum wage for hours worked on the production. Beyond that, it will be an investment in our next free, public Commons Series production.

Please Note:Donations on IndieGoGo are not tax-deductible. You may make a tax-deductible donation on Fractured Atlas: Rude Grooms' Commons Series is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Rude Grooms' Commons Series must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.​When making a donation, make sure to enter a whole number without a decimal point (i.e., 35 rather than 35.00) -- contributors have reported issues with decimal points when backing the project. If you have any questions or issues, please reach out to us directly and we'll figure it out.In Brief:We are a Startup Theatre Experiment run by experienced actor-creators with a successful track record of producing Elizabethan and Jacobean plays that come to the public rather than making the public come to them. With your help, we'll bring a free professional, accessible, and family-friendly performances of William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet to audiences in areas of Queens, NY, not served by traditional theatre companies.This show is a continuation of our commitment to bring high quality, free productions of classic stories to our diverse Queens communities as immersive, interactive, and irreplicable experiences.The ensemble of this production includes veterans of Shakespeare's Globe, The Old Globe, Asolo Repertory Theatre, New York Classical Theatre, Classic Stage Company, Trinity Shakespeare Festival, and Seven Stages Shakespeare, among many other national and international companies.Bringing world-class, approachable productions of these timeless stories directly to an audience is more important than ever in our increasingly fragmented society. By supporting this production, you will be playing a very active role in bringing communities together to share in joy, understanding, and empathy.You can make a meaningful difference with even the smallest contribution. Our perks will make sure that your investment is well rewarded; more importantly, with even the smallest donation you are planting a seed to grow understanding and build community.What's in it for You (and Us)?As an experiment in translating the Elizabethan theatre troupe model intro 21st Century Startup vernacular, our donors are incredibly important to us and we strive to give you even more unique and exciting activities than the general public (like our Secret Shakespeare Hunt, which guests have called "by far THE COOLEST THING I'VE EVER DONE IN New York City").Here is exactly where your $4,500 will go:$2,250 - Artist Stipends- though the production is free, we are committed to ensuring that our collaborating artists receive stipends above the minimum transportation reimbursement required by Actors Equity Association. As a company, we plan to move aggressively towards paying our artists at least minimum wage for their skilled work; in the meantime, all artists involved in the production receive an equal favored nations stipend of $150 for the two week commitment, including our two Acting Apprentices.$1,250 - Production Costs -  this includes costumes, props, wardrobe and musical instrument maintenance, an additional 10x10 canopy for changing area and basic scenic requirements, City Park permits, theater rental$1,000 - Rehearsal Expenses- this includes rehearsal space rental (for rehearsals where we cannot be accommodated by our producing partner, Long Island City Artists at the Plaxall Gallery) and stage management expenses during the hectic one-week rehearsal process.In addition to joining our extended family, the following contributions will get you unique perks:$1 - Upstart Crow - a video thank you from the cast, an Elizabethan social media holla, access to exclusive behind the scenes updates throughout the process.$30 - Player's Hide - all of the Upstart Crow perks plus a playbill signed by the entire cast and a listing in our playbill and on our website (donation must be received before August 12 to guarantee inclusion in the playbill), and a custom Shakespearean meme made just for you from a production or rehearsal photo instead of the social media holla.$65 - Shake-Scene - all of the Player's Hide perks plus access to VIP seating area for one and a Rude Grooms water bottle.$100 - Muse of Fire - all of the Shake-Scene perks, plus access to VIP seating area for two (or you and a guest), an original sonnet composed to you (or the person of your choice) by Rude Grooms’ Master of the Revels Montgomery Sutton, and a signed poster instead of program.$150 - Feast of Crispian​ - all of the Muse of Fire perks plus a picnic basket of snacks to enjoy during the show.$250 - Moonshine Reveller - all of the Feast of Crispian perks plus 2 additional spots in the VIP area (4 total), an apothecary box put together just for you by our Production Designer Sara Slagle, and an invitation for you and up to 3 guests to the opening night private "Capulet Ball" cast party (8/16/2019) on a rooftop in Astoria which includes a mask hand-decorated for you by Costume Designer Laura Piccoli. (limit 7; please note: the apothecary box and mask may require 1 week notice to pick up).$5,000 - Lord Chamberlain - all of the Moonshine Reveller perks plus a private performance at your own venue (you provide transportation if outside of NYC).$10,000 - Queen - all of the Moonshine Reveller perks plus a custom, immersive theatrical event created just for you and up to 20 guests.The ProductionWe are led by actor-manager Montgomery Sutton (Twelfth Night at Shakespeare's Globe) and produced in partnership with Long Island City Artists at the Plaxall Gallery and the Astoria Park Alliance, made possible (in part) by the Queens Council on the Arts with public funds from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council.Sutton says “Encountering Romeo and Juliet as a teenager cracked Shakespeare open for me for the first time. Its enduring resonance with audiences young and old alike reconnects us to our shared humanity, an impulse which is at the core of our Commons Series: free performances of timeless stories in active public spaces to strengthen our Queens community through cultural engagement.”“The show is a 90-minute, family-friendly romp with live acoustic music that features award-winning professional artists and is completely free. By activating familiar spaces in new ways and bringing world-class performers out into our communities, our Commons Series is an act of shared imagination that tears down barriers of entry into artistic programming, barriers between actor and audience, and barriers between audience members themselves.”In addition to Sutton, the acting company includes Elisabeth Ahrens, Milagros Bobier, Jerome Harmann Hardeman, Carroll Herring, Dhruv Iyengar, Rachael Jenison, Daniel Kemper, Laura Piccoli, Deb Radloff, Rachel Schmeling, Montgomery Sutton, Casterline Villar. Becca Kaplan is the Stage Manager, Paulina Tovar is the Stage Management Apprentice, Sara Slagle is the Production Designer, Kaitlyn Farley and Jared Kirby of New York Combat for Stage & Screen are the Fight Directors, Kara Arena is the Composer, Bridget Bose is the Dance Choreographer, Laura Piccoli is the Costume Designer, and Jessica Latour is Associate Producer.More Ways to HelpThe smallest contribution will have a major impact on this production, and through it, the communities that it touches. But there are many more ways you can help:
Share this campaign all over your social networks. Connect us with people in your circle who have the desire and ability to help launch unique arts organizations.
Come and see us, and bring your friends! The best way for us to build word of mouth and find new patrons and sponsors is with bodies on the grass. Make reservations at https://rudegrooms.com/productions/romeo-and-juliet/

If you or a family member know of corporations with an interest in supporting arts and cultural programming, please point us in their direction to make an appeal.
Stretch GoalsIf, beyond our wildest dreams, we not only meet but exceed our initial goal, here is our plan for how additional funds will bolster the production.$5,000-$8,550 - Artist Stipends- every dollar raised between $5,000 and $8,550 will go directly towards increasing artist stipends$8,550-$10,000 - Additional PR and Marketing- more targeted online advertising, printing posters to put up near performance venues, etc.$10,000+- Moving Towards a Living Wage- anything above $10,000 will be allocated equally among artists until they each reach the equivalent of NY State minimum wage for hours worked on the production. Beyond that, it will be an investment in our next free, public Commons Series production.

story:
Overview:

          Hi! We're Beating of Wings, a determined group of women artists committed to building an inclusive  and supportive artistic community and to producing new, vital, and socially conscious work. 

         We're taking on our first major production project with this developmental workshop of A Sad Tale’s Best for Winter, a new feminist adaption of William Shakespeare's The Winter’s Tale written and directed by BoW Founding Artistic Director Anna Miles- and along the way, we're also starting a conversation about the classic theatrical canon through fresh, innovative text and storytelling. Performing one night only, on Sunday, November 17th at 6:30 PM upstairs at A Noise Within Theater in Pasadena, CA- tickets are all general admission and pay-what-you-can, and are available now at anoisewithin.org/noise-now!

       But we can't do it alone- we're fortunate to be developing and performing this play in residency with the Noise Now program at A Noise Within Theatre, but we still need your help to breathe life into this exciting new play!

     

 

How the play was born:

            A Sad Tale’s Best for Winter was born a year ago, while writer Anna Miles was watching a production of William Shakespeare’s The Winter’s Tale in an Orange County park- as the play unfolded, she grew increasingly frustrated with how easily and quickly the male protagonist, Leontes, was forgiven in the play, even after wreaking violent havoc on his wife and children. But when Anna tried to imagine how she could direct the classic work in such a way that would reckon with the real-life complications of such forgiveness, she fell short. The text, after all, was the text.

            The only way to use the story to subvert its own themes would be to change that text.

            The only thing to do was rewrite it.

            Anna and Beating of Wings are excited to be developing this play with the Noise Now program at A Noise Within Theatre- and it’s pretty cool that the company is producing the source material as part of their season, providing an ideal platform on which to present this new theatrical companion piece.

                     

 

What makes the play important:

            William Shakespeare’s The Winter’s Tale could be said to ask the question: “how can we forgive?” But in 2019, when violence is a daily reality for many women and when movements like #MeToo and #TimesUp are finally starting to force a reckoning between victims and perpetrators, a more poignant question to ask might be: what about the times when we can’t forgive? Is it possible to move forward, and to heal, in those moments when catastrophic violence can’t be erased with miraculous forgiveness?

            Through text both classic and original and through song, dance, and modern poetry, A Sad Tale’s Best for Winter explores these questions by interrupting and disrupting Shakespeare’s text- bringing the story into a fantasy world where women live isolated from men, where bears hide behind trees in relentless pursuit, and where a new generation struggles to undo centuries' worth of fear, pain, and violence in the hopes of creating a new, better world. 

            A Sad Tale's Best for Winter celebrates and preserves the language and resonance of Shakespeare's original text, while also creating a new story uniquely appropriate for our current time- and a new story uniquely geared toward expressing a version of the female experience in a way that is understandable and relatable for all audiences.

                       

 

What We Need, and What You Get:

          A Noise Within is generously offering us the in-kind donation of free rehearsal and performance space; however, we are entirely responsible for funding every other production cost ourselves, including set and costumes, marketing, and of course, artist stipends.  

            Beating of Wings is proud to say that 85% of our funds to be raised will be going directly toward paying our artists (such as Chris Meissner, who made our amazing promo video for us!). Besides Chris, we also have twelve actors, a choreographer, a composer/music director, a director, and an assistant director who all deserve to be compensated for their incredible talents-  and funding the production upfront allows us to keep our tickets "pay-what-you-can," ensuring maximum audience accessibility.

If we reach our stretch goal of $7,300, we'll also be able to offer small stipends to each producer on our producing team, who have been working tirelessly (and completely for free) since January!

            And you won't be alone in supporting us: over fifty people have already shown us their support by attending and donating to our fundraising event in July, through which we were able to raise 10% of our budget. At said event, thirteen incredible women also donated their time and talents in support of our show and our mission. We are also the beneficiaries of in-kind costume donations from The Woodland Opera House and further in-kind space donations from The Wit Theatre. They all believe in us, and we hope you believe in us too!           

 

Perks!

            So, what's in it for you, besides the warm fuzzy feeling that comes with supporting awesome and important art? We've come up with a few perks to sweeten the deal when you donate, including:

  • custom Beating of Wings merch
  •  VIP seating
  •  tickets to our future projects
  •  the chance to earn some bespoke art made just for you from one or more of our incredible artists!

 

                 

           

Why You Can Trust Us With Your Contribution:

            Beating of Wings has a consistent track record of producing unique, interesting, and excellent work: in only seven months, the collective has produced two original concert and storytelling events, organized the production of an original photo series, and has partnered with members on two short films as well as participating in a nation-wide play reading event aimed at encouraging voter registration. Not only that, but we're an incredibly tenacious group: all of our previous projects have been produced with zero-to-no budget, completely independently. We know how to make theater happen, and make it happen well- and it will be the same with A Sad Tale's Best for Winter. The only difference is, this time, with your help, we'll be able to pay everyone!

           

The Team:

Anna Miles, Writer and Director

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Anna Miles is the Founding Artistic Director of Beating of Wings. Some of her most recent projects include the extremely successful productions Daddy Long Legs: The Musical (Director) and Think of Me, Fred Weasley (Writer, Director, Performer). Her plays have been performed at the Chance Theater in Anaheim, and her flash play, “Girls and Boys, When They Sit in Trees and Share Their Toys,” was recently published in the Santa Ana River Review. Favorite acting credits include Frozen: Live at the Hyperion at Disneyland (Young Anna/Young Elsa) and The Heidi Chronicles with Trinity Repertory Company (Fran/Lisa/Denise). Anna holds a BA in Theater and Creative Writing from Northwestern University and an MFA from Brown University/Trinity Repertory Company's MFA Programs in Acting and Directing.  

Valerie Larsen, Producer, Composer, Music Director, and Actor (Hermione)

Val Larsen is an actor, singer, dancer, producer, and musician with a BFA from The Boston Conservatory. She is a trained pianist and harpist as well as a self-taught guitar, ukulele, and bass player. Recent LA theater credits include Frozen: Live at the Hyperion at Disneyland, The Women at The Group Rep, and Mutt House: The Musical at the Kirk Douglas Theater; she also recently performed a solo songwriting concert with Breaking Sound. Val currently serves as the Associate Artistic Director of Beating of Wings, and has co-created several projects with the collective.

Megan Ruble, Producer and Actor (Perdita) 

Megan Ruble is an LA actor, singer, and producer and currently serves as Beating of Wings’ Producing Director. Megan's credits range from Sondheim to Shakespeare and include companies such as Sierra Repertory Theatre, Chase What Flies, and New Musicals, Inc. She recently co-produced a producing of “Homeward LA” at The Boston Court Theater and just finished co-producing and performing as Lady Macbeth in “Macbeth LA.” 

Himerria Wortham, Choreographer 

Himerria Wortham is a dancer, choreographer, and actor who has danced in shows such as Crazy Ex Girlfriend, the AMAs, the Academy Awards, and America’s Best Dance Crew. Her most recent choreography credits include a music video for Rachael Cantu, a music video for Miguel’s “Pineapple,” and the award-winning short fantasy film “Thistles and Thorns.” Currently you can catch Himerria working on site specific dance performances with the Heidi Duckler Dance Theater, with whom she recently traveled to Chile for the International Ideas Festival (Puerto De Ideas) and taught dance at the Chino Women’s prison. Himerria is an ensemble member with Beating of Wings. 

Miranda Clement, Assistant Director 

Miranda Kelly Macbeth is recently graduated with a Bachelor’s in English and Theatre, with an emphasis on directing, from Brigham Young University. She is an award winning director, playwright, poet, and a new business owner. Her company, The Wit Theatre, hopes to open their doors in Long Beach later this year. 

Jonathan Fisher, Actor (Leontes) 

Jonathan comes to Southern California by way of South Florida, Chicago and Rhode Island, and holds a BA in Theatre and English Literature from Northwestern University. Some favorite recent theatre credits include: Henry V (Henry V) and Comedy of Errors (Antipholus of Ephesus) (Shakespeare By The Sea); Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead (A Noise Within); Elevada, Tribes and he Eight Reindeer Monologues (Chance Theater); Macbeth (Sacramento Theatre Company) and Henry IV Part 1 (Shakespeare Orange County).

Tristan Waldron, Actor (Florizel)

Originally from Sherborn, MA, Tristan has found his home in Los Angeles as an actor, director, and producer. He is the acting director of Occidental College's critically acclaimed Children's Theater, just finishing its 24th season. Recent producing credits include "Homeward LA" at the Boston Court Theater and "Macbeth LA," in which he also played the title role. 

Brendan Kane, Actor (Polixenes)

Brendan was raised in an Air Force family and brought up all around the country, and has found a home in Los Angeles. A graduate of Oklahoma City University, he was last seen as The Dauphin/Williams in Henry V and Dromio of Syracuse in Comedy of Errors at Shakespeare by the Sea. Other past credits include:  Lend Me a Tenor (Long Beach Playhouse); California Suite (Noisy Nest); The First and the Last (Hollywood Fringe 2018); As You Like It (Culver City Public Theatre); Macbeth (Annapolis Shakespeare Company); Much Ado About Nothing (Oklahoma City Repertory Theatre).

The Beating of Wings Team: 

Also helping make this play happen are Beating of Wings' board members (clockwise from top left) Christine Ferguson, Katie DeShan, Helen Jane Planchett, Melissa Dunham, and Charlie Marie McGrather- read more about these incredible women here!

Stay tuned for more exciting cast and team announcements as our process continues!

 

The Partners:

            And if the qualifications and passion of Beating of Wings and our team aren't enough to convince you, we also have the renowned A Noise Within behind us!

            A Noise Within, named “one of the nation’s premier classical repertory companies” by The Huffington Post, is a leading regional producer based in Pasadena, CA which produces classic theatre as an essential means to enrich our community by embracing universal human experiences, expanding personal awareness, and challenging individual perspectives.

            Noise Now is an enhanced commitment to being of service to all audiences. We aim to illuminate and activate underrepresented populations, communities of color, young people, and all others not equitably represented at the theatre.

Read more about A Noise Within and Noise Now at https://www.anoisewithin.org/ and https://www.anoisewithin.org/noise-now/

 

Other Ways You Can Help

            First- you're already helping by reading about our project and watching our video, so thanks for that!

            If you're a little strapped for cash right now but still want to help us, there are many ways you can do it- you can:

  • Come see the show at A Noise Within on November 17th, and bring a friend or two!  
  • Share this campaign with your friends and family, in person and on social media- you can share right here from this IndieGoGo page!
  • When the time comes, share show info with those same people!
  • Follow US on social media- Instagram @beatingofwingsco, Facebook.com/beatingofwingscollective
  • Lend us your skills, now and in the future! Reach out to us at: beatingofwingscollective@gmail.com and we'll keep you in the loop about audition and volunteer opportunities!

For more info and questions, visit beatingofwingscollective.com or email us at beatingofwingscollective@gmail.com.

 

Thanks for helping us take flight!

Follow US on social media- Instagram @beatingofwingsco, Facebook.com/beatingofwingscollective

Lend us your skills, now and in the future! Reach out to us at: beatingofwingscollective@gmail.com and we'll keep you in the loop about audition and volunteer opportunities!
For more info and questions, visit beatingofwingscollective.com or email us at beatingofwingscollective@gmail.com. Thanks for helping us take flight!

story:
About Us! 

Buzzworks Theater Company was formed in Minneapolis, Minnesota in 1992. Over the following four years we traveled across the Midwest producing shows in Chicago, Mackinac Island, Michigan, and Green Lake, Wisconsin. Then in 1996, Los Angeles beckoned and Buzz decided to heed the call.  Since our move to California, we have produced over 25 plays and continue to cultivate our unique identity within Los Angeles.  Created by Andrea Hutchman, Buzzworks has become home to innovative professionals from many walks of life dedicated to giving you the theatrical buzz you seek and enriching our community through art. 

Non-Profit

As a non-profit organization, we need your help in raising $5,000 to produce an amazing season!  Your money will directly enable us to have: 

  • A stage!
  • Backdrops and scenery!
  • Various props ie: chairs, trashcan, desk, severed head on a stick!  
  • Incredible lighting!  
  • Sounds!  
  • Costumes on actors!  
  • The Magic of Live Theater!

Help us help you by giving you the entertainment you deserve!  Not to mention, you can write off a donation to Buzzworks on your taxes, for donating to a non-profit!  Sincerely, we are so grateful to any and all contributions.  In addition to the perks we are offering, we want you to know that any donation from $1 truly makes a difference.  Thank you!  

The Impact

We believe in the power of theater, in giving the community a night to look forward to, in spreading empowering messages, encouraging philosophical thought and sparking conversation, of bringing people together through performance, and of having fun!  Magic happens when we come together to be joyful and celebrate life.  By supporting Buzzworks, you are creating that magic.  

Create a Buzz!  

A way you can support Buzzworks if you're unable to donate, is by spreading the word!  Share our Indiegogo to family and friends, and stay tuned with us on Facebook at Buzzworks Theater Company and at our website buzzworks.org.

story:
Dear one,

We hope this letter finds you healthy and happy, and active in your imagination. We are writing to you because we are making a work of dance-theater to premiere January 2020 in NYC, and we humbly and excitedly ask for your help.

Here's a bit about our show:

A land creature and a sky creature who are deeply in love learn that the earth is falling out of the sky.

At the intersection of dance and theater, abstraction and narrative, sci-fi and fable, The Pigeon & The Mouse is a love story about two people forced to leave home in the wake of civil war. We, co-choreographers and performers Tony Bordonaro and Ingrid Kapteyn, invite you, our audience, to join us in the practice of what homo sapiens do best: use fiction and fantasy as a means to survive.

Here's a bit about us:

We, Tony and Ingrid, first met while performing in Sleep No More NYC in 2013, and we later spent a year together in China as part of the original cast of Sleep No More Shanghai. Our first creation, CAMPFIRE, tested the limits of human empathy through a story about the last two people on earth. We premiered it with a run of sold out shows in an office space in downtown Shanghai that was still under construction, where the audience moved with us through an entire gutted floor of a building strewn with rubble and debris. We later presented CAMPFIRE in The Tank's intimate 56-seat blackbox in midtown Manhattan, with a two-part immersive scent sculpture that diffused toxic-seeming metallic notes into the hint of campfire embers. The Pigeon & The Mouse acts as a kind of alternate-universe prequel to CAMPFIRE.

Here's why we need you:

In order to offer you, our audience, the truest possible experience of our love story, and to honor the creative work we've been pouring ourselves into for the last year, we are investing in the quality of our production and our collaborators. We seek the support of our community to help cover some of the expenses that come with self-producing:

  • Rehearsal Space Rental
  • Performance Venue Rental
  • Sound Design
  • Lighting Design
  • Set Design
  • Logo Design
  • Videography
  • Video Editing
  • Photography
  • Publicity
  • Costumes
  • Stage Management

Please consider making a tax-deductible donation to The Pigeon & The Mouse. Your contribution supports independent artists and art-making and is nothing less than a gesture of faith in the transformative power of the imagination - and an expression of the story we are all living in one way or another: love.

With thanks and love,

Tony & Ingrid

P.S. If you are unable to make a donation right now, you can also help by spreading word of our campaign via social media or Indiegogo's share tools!

And here's a bit more about us, if you're curious:

Tony Bordonaro is a choreographer, director, and performer based in New York. Most notably, Tony performed in Punchdrunk’s hit show Sleep No More in New York and Shanghai. In 2017, he choreographed and performed in the Oscars® winning student film Opera of Cruelty. He has choreographed for commercials, film, and theatre. His love for physical storytelling is the driving force behind his solo work and collaborations like Passport, a performance art piece with Guggenheim fellow Robert Whitman, and CAMPFIRE, an immersive duet with Ingrid Kapteyn. He has a BFA in Dance Performance/Choreography from Rutgers University - Mason Gross School of the Arts. As a teaching artist he has taught dance technique and improvisation at both Rutgers and Long Island University. tonybordonaro.com @tonybordonaro3

Ingrid Kapteyn is a lifetime student of listening with a BFA in Dance from The Juilliard School. She currently swings eight roles in Punchdrunk's Sleep No More NYC, and she spent 2017 building and performing a new version of Sleep No More in Shanghai. While in China she also conceived, directed, and performed two independent installations called CAMPFIRE and POP. She went on to present CAMPFIRE with Tony Bordonaro at The Tank in NYC in January 2019. Ingrid has performed with Brian Brooks, Danielle Russo, and The Metropolitan Opera, and she was an actor in Martha Clarke and Alfred Uhry's Angel Reapers at The Signature Theatre in 2016 along with Clarke’s GOD’S FOOL workshop in 2018. She has taught internationally, including for Juilliard Global Ventures/Nord Anglia Education (in Shanghai, Dubai, Switzerland, Qatar, and NYC), FRESH Dance Intensive, UNC: School of the Arts, and Princeton and Bucknell Universities, and she served for a year as Assistant to the Artistic Director of Springboard Danse Montréal. In January 2014 she cofounded HEWMAN, a collaborative collective that reimagines the traditional model of a dance company run by one choreographer by engaging individual artists with distinct voices to collaborate as equals in creative process.

 

 

Conceived, Created, Produced, and Performed by Tony Bordonaro & Ingrid Kapteyn

Videography and Photography by Thomas Rowell

Video Editing by Michael Suyeda

Song "Go" by Daniel Emond

Logo by Andrew Hodge

Fiscally Sponsored by the National Performing Arts Funding Exchange

She went on to present CAMPFIRE with Tony Bordonaro at The Tank in NYC in January 2019. Ingrid has performed with Brian Brooks, Danielle Russo, and The Metropolitan Opera, and she was an actor in Martha Clarke and Alfred Uhry's Angel Reapers at The Signature Theatre in 2016 along with Clarke’s GOD’S FOOL workshop in 2018. In January 2014 she cofounded HEWMAN, a collaborative collective that reimagines the traditional model of a dance company run by one choreographer by engaging individual artists with distinct voices to collaborate as equals in creative process.  Conceived, Created, Produced, and Performed by Tony Bordonaro & Ingrid KapteynVideography and Photography by Thomas RowellVideo Editing by Michael SuyedaSong "Go" by Daniel EmondLogo by Andrew HodgeFiscally Sponsored by the National Performing Arts Funding Exchange

story:
ABOUT h o w e v e r

Friday, January 31 & Saturday, February 1

7:30pm, Fulton Street Collective

Inspired by our own experiences and relationships with dance and Chicago’s dance community, however is a performative conversation. Using a chair as a plain inanimate prop, mode of expression, and even a dance partner, however, explores the ideas of empathy, community and support. however, signifying a change, also serves as the launch of con-CEP+ Dances.

 

ABOUT Concept Dances

con-CEP+ Dances is an emerging Chicago-based platform whose goal is to foster collaborations, elevate productions, and overall support the dance field, through methods of movement, styles of performance, and logistical assistance. Founded by a collective of Chicago-based dance artists, con-CEP+ Dances offers services and programs to support the productions of conceptually and intuitively driven work that reach through to the deep layers and outstretch the dimensions of a vision, bringing attention to divergent ideas.

 

Production Cost for h o w e v e r

$10 = 1 hr of rehearsal space rental

$40 = 1 set of theatrical lights

$100 = 1 set of costumes = Music composition & performance

$150 = printing of 500 postcards

$200 = Technical staff for performances

This doesn't even include the amount of work and time we've put into this!

 

Your donation TODAY will help fund:

1. The production of h o w e v e r

2. Our Administrative Support platform

3. Future operations and productions of con-CEP+ Dances

story:
We are Isabella Kuëss and Max von Lütgendorff and are both opera singers based in beautiful Vienna, Austria! In January 2020, we co-founded BelCanto Arts (www.belcantoarts.at), a nonprofit concert agency creating innovative productions that re-imagine classical concepts onto the concert and opera stage.

In 2020 it is even more important to us to be able to support our hard-hit artistic colleagues and build up a grassroots aspect of the cultural scene. We are stubbornly building that future right now.

So how do we plan to do all this?

BelCanto Arts is bringing FIDELIO on stage in a new production by German director Annegret Ritzel. Not content with being one of a hundred companies who interpret Fidelio for Beethoven's 250th birth year, we have decided to do something special: framing the opera as it was written with a surrounding storyline that incorporates the idea of Beethoven's famous Immortal Beloved as well as playing around with the isolation we have all one way or another experienced this year.
Our cast of brilliant international soloists under up-and-coming conductor Daniel Strahilevitz will be accompanied by our own Chorus BelCanto and the United Europe Orchestra. We are playing four performances this November (19., 22., 27. and 29.11.2020) and are planning another series for 2021.

We are very excited that we can actually produce this opera in November 2020, but like everyone, we had to cancel quite a few concerts that should have supported our big production this year. We are also planning a CD and making a live video production of our Fidelio Performances for DVD, that will also be downloadable from our website www.belcantoarts.at.

 

We need your help to reach our goals:

- paying every soloist, chorist and musician fairly (total of €12000)

- recording a CD instead of the concert series we should have done this year (€3000)

- creating a live video recording of our Fidelio production for everyone who can't come and experience it live. (€3000)

 

If you love opera as much as we do, want to support artists and be part of this amazing project, we are looking forward to your support!


Make some noise about our campaign, tell your friends and share our campaign with the world!

story:
Intimations Dance is modern/contemporary dance company creating brand new interdisciplinary dance work. Over the last three years, Intimations Dance has had a significant impact on the Boston dance community through a number of traditional and site specific performances, classes and workshops, and opportunities for emerging and established choreographers to present new work. Help us continue to bring innovative, collaborative modern dance to the city and beyond!


Our Impact

In 2014, we were awarded two choreographic residencies, produced and hosted the second annual National Choreography Month Boston performance, taught workshops to over fifty people across New England, performed alongside the best of our dance community in the Boston Contemporary Dance Festival, and performed at First Night Boston to celebrate the New Year!


Already in 2015, we have offered a month long series of workshops, informal showings and classes for National Choreography Month (NACHMO), and staged a dance takeover at Aeronaut Brewery with live music and four other collaborating choreographers. In February we will produce the third annual NACHMO showcase where we present alongside 18 local companies and choreographers. The convergence of choreographers, dancers and audiences have hatched a variety of new projects and connections.


Our Work

"Intimations" has multiple meanings: to express as a whisper, to express as a shout, a person’s essential or innermost meaning, and a close friend or confidant. The mission of Intimations Dance is to give voice (as both a shout and a whisper) to our social concerns through collaborative, process-based dance choreography to connect with our audience’s shared experiences. Right now our work is focused on what is most visceral and salient for us as dance-makers: body image, selfies, social media, obsession and peer pressure. We are rehearsing weekly to prepare for upcoming spring and summer performances at The Dance Complex March 13-14th and April 10-12th.


Company members and collaborators participate in our creative process as both dancers and choreographers, honing their own artistic skills and voices. In this way, the company positions performers and participants as central and necessary to developing our work. Intimations Dance also  collaborates with local composers, musicians, video artists, and organizations to create a multi-sensory experience for the audience. Intimations Dance creates dance for traditional proscenium venues and enjoys setting site-specific installations outside the dance studio. Most recently, the company has staged interdisciplinary dance performances at the foundation ruin of Old Manse in Concord, MA, and Aeronaut Brewing Company in Somerville, MA.


Our Programs

National Choreography Month Boston

With the support of partners in the Boston dance community, Intimations Dance hosts a month-long series of events in honor of National Choreography Month. Choreographers are charged with creating new dance work over the span of one month; the celebration culminates in a fully produced theatre performance showcasing the new work of 20+ local emerging and established choreographers. In lead-up to the performance, NACHMO provides a month of movement workshops in improvisation, composition, partnering, and informal showings.


Company Classes and Workshops

Intimations Dance offers modern/contemporary dance master classes and open company classes throughout the season for little to no cost. The company has led classes for the Dance for World Community Festival, Moving Target Boston, OnStage Dance Company, Collective Motion Arts, and Newton Community Education.


Our Costs

During our current 6 month season (November 2014 - April 2015), Intimations Dance expects to incur $8000 in costs.

  • $2400 to pay 8 dancers a fee for the season (each dance receives $300 for 6 months of work, including 4 hours of rehearsal/week and performances)

  • $1000 for venue rental and technical fees for performances

  • $950 for rehearsal space

  • $700 for live musicians and composed music

  • $600 for professional photographs and video

  • $500 for costumes

  • $400 to offer NACHMO workshops and performances

  • $350 for general liability insurance

  • $300 for graphic design and marketing

  • $250 for travel and parking

  • $200 for video projection

  • $300 for miscellaneous costs

We depend on ticket sales, stipends, and residencies for income, but these do not nearly cover our expenses.


Get Involved

  • Make work with us! We are also always looking for new dancers, collaborators, musicians, composers, costume designers, photographers and film makers to work with on upcoming projects. Send an email to jessica[at]intimationsdance[dot]com
  • Like us on Facebook! Follow us on Twitter and Instagram
  • Subscribe to our mailing list
  • Spread the word and share this campaign with your family and friends

Thank you for your support!

story:
Why I am doing this. 

My name is Elizabeth Bowering and I have a terminal neurological disease called Multiple System Atrophy (MSA). Most people have never heard of MSA. It is very aggressive and devastating and there is no treatment at this time. Research in the area has been limited due to a lack of funding. There has been no ice bucket challenge for MSA like there has been for ALS, a disease with similar symptoms and outcome.  Advances in earlier diagnosis and treatment for MSA are desperately needed and I want to help make this happen.

What I plan to do

I am going to remount a play that I wrote in 2006 which enjoyed much success at Edmonton’s International Fringe Theatre Festival. I plan this as a fundraiser for research and an awareness campaign for MSA. The play is near and dear to my heart because it is based on the true story of my grandmother. At age 16, she saved the lives of those on board a sailing vessel when it met with peril at sea. Wind in her Sails is an historical play that takes place entirely on a schooner off the coast of Newfoundland in 1907.

In November 2015, with the help of a devoted team of volunteers, this show will run for ten days. After expenses, proceeds from the production will be directly earmarked for clinical trials to be conducted by Toronto movement disorder specialist Dr. Anthony Lang who is investigating new ways of diagnostic imaging for this disease.

What we need

We need seed money to put on this production! Although there is a strong group of volunteers, we must pay the cast, rent, insurance, playbills etc. Rest assured that your support will take us one step closer to fulfilling my dream of helping to fund a clinical trial for Multiple System Atrophy.

Any research will unlikely be of any help to me at my stage of the disease, but Dr. Anthony Lang’s clinical trials in Toronto are leading the way in Canada to finding an earlier diagnosis for MSA. The sooner it is detected, the sooner treatments may be discovered.

What you can do

I wrote Wind in her Sails as a tribute to my grandmother’s courage. Your donation to the production of this play will help us honour the courage that everyone facing MSA must have…and we are grateful.  Please donate and spread the word.

Please visit our website http://www.windinhersails.com for more information on the production.
