treatment at this time. Research in the area has been limited due to a lack of funding.
There has been no ice bucket challenge for MSA like there has been for ALS, a disease with
similar symptoms and outcome.  Advances in earlier diagnosis
and treatment for MSA are desperately needed and I want to help make this happen. 
What I plan to doI am going to remount a play that I wrote in 2006 which
enjoyed much success at Edmonton’s International Fringe Theatre Festival. I plan
this as a fundraiser for research and an awareness campaign for MSA. The play is
near and dear to my heart because it is based on the true story of my
grandmother. At age 16, she saved the lives of those on board a sailing vessel when
it met with peril at sea. Wind in her
Sails is an historical play that takes place entirely on a schooner off the
coast of Newfoundland in 1907. 
In November 2015, with the help of a devoted team of
volunteers, this show will run for ten days. After expenses, proceeds from the
production will be directly earmarked for clinical trials to be conducted by Toronto
movement disorder specialist Dr.
Anthony Lang who is investigating new ways of diagnostic imaging for this
disease. 
What we needWe need seed money to put on this production! Although
there is a strong group of volunteers, we must pay the cast, rent, insurance, playbills
etc. Rest assured that your support will take us one step closer to fulfilling my
dream of helping to fund a clinical trial for Multiple System Atrophy. 
Any research will unlikely be of any help to me at my
stage of the disease, but Dr. Anthony Lang’s clinical trials in Toronto are
leading the way in Canada to finding an earlier diagnosis for MSA. The sooner
it is detected, the sooner treatments may be discovered.
What you can doI wrote Wind in her
Sails as a tribute to my grandmother’s courage. Your donation to the production of this play will help us
honour the courage that everyone facing MSA must have…and we are grateful.  Please donate and spread the word. 
Please visit our website http://www.windinhersails.com for more
information on the production.

story:
Art Changes Live. Art Saves Lives.

Project mission: Our mission is bringing renewed awareness to the HIV/AIDS epidemic in the city of Philadelphia, which is 5% above the national average in terms of new cases reported. This project uses the play as a context to address sensitive subjects and will ultimately achieve three goals; bring awareness, create dialogue, and increase testing. By using the medium of Theater and a multi-location panel discussion we will open a dialogue about the motifs and themes of the play including, HIV/AIDS awareness, the stigma surrounding those who test positive, the development and progression of the gay rights movement since the 1980’s and the cultural impact of interracial relationships.

Proposal Summary: This project will launch on November 30th the day before World Aids Day and AIDS awareness month. On November 30th, in partnership with Temple University Paley Library we will hold a panel, 'Religion and the LGBT Community: Post Marriage Equality" . We've confirmed a stellar line up of religious leaders, scholars, media professionals, and politicians to spark a dialogue on the impact of  the issues highlighted.  From December 2nd - 6th, the show will take go up at Studio 5  @ The Walnut Street Theatre. Rapid HIV testing will be available during a show.

Project background and biographies: You Gotta Eat Dirt Before You Die is a play written by Dr. Kimmika Williams-Witherspoon and directed by Malcolm Kenyatta-Greeen. The play, set in the 1980's follows, Jeffery an African American business professional whose lover Nick,  is dying from Aids at the very start of the epidemic, simultaneously his mother is dying of cancer. Written in an almost novella format it transports you to a time when HIV and AIDS were not readily discussed above a whisper and interracial relationships, especially gay ones were looked at with more than a wayward glance. It's a story that causes us to re-examine the progression of treatment since the 1980's to present day, exploring where we've come and where we have left to go.

-Kimmika Williams-Witherspoon, PhD (Cultural Anthropology), M.A. (Anthropology), MFA (Theater), Graduate Certificate)Women's Studies, B.A. (Journalism); is an Associate professor of Urban Theater in the Theater Department at Temple.

Along with collaborator Eugene Martin (Film and Media Arts) Williams-Witherspoon is the 2008-2009 winner of the Provost $50,000. Seed Grant Award, the 2001 Independence Foundation Theater Communications Group Grant, the 2000 winner of the PEW Charitable Trust $50,000 fellowship in scriptwriting, and the 1999, winner of the DaimlerChrysler "Spirit of the Word" National Poetry Competition (Seattle) at the Unity'99 Conference, Kimmika Williams has also been the recipient of a host of awards and honors, including: the DaimlerChrysler Regional Poetry Contest (Philadelphia), the 1996, Lila Wallace Creative Arts Fellowship with the American Antiquarian Society and a two-time returning playwright with the Minneapolis Playwrights' Center and Pew Charitable Trusts Playwrights Exchange. As a playwright, Williams-Witherspoon has had fourteen of her plays produced in professional theater, including "From Brillo Pads To Feminine Pads: Raw Abrasives" (Women's Festival/Painted Bride), "Dog Days: The Legend of O.V. Catto" (Venture Theater),"By What Price: 4

Unity" and "Nappy Truths" (Penumbra Theater, Saint Paul, Minn.).

-Malcolm Kenyatta-Green, BA (Strategic Communication), M.S. Candidate (Public Communication) is a young star on the rise. A fixture of the Philadelphia collegiate poetry scene, he founded Babel (Temple's Poetry Collective) in 2008 and the created one of Philadelphia's biggest performance art shows Babylon. Malcolm has worked as a reporter for Comcast Newsmakers, covering the youth angle of the 2012 presidential election. He has performed and spoke at events throughout the east coast. At just 25 years old he is the youngest member of the Liberty City LGBT Democratic Club, Board of Directors and a winner of the Bread & Roses LAX Scholarship for dedication to the LGBT community. Malcolm has directed or assistant directed close to 20 shows involving poetry or theater and made a name for himself as the assistant director for another play written by Dr. Williams-Witherspoon, Countdown to Boom which was featured in the 2012 Philadelphia fringe and revived in 2013 for a grant funded performance at the historic PA State Museum in Harrisburg, PA. In 2015 Malcolm was selected as a 2015 BMe Leader.

-Terrell Kenyatta-Green, a Philadelphia native, graduated from Marymount Manhattan College with dual concentration in Acting and Speech Therapy. Terrell has also received a certificate from Oxford University in Shakespeare Performance and intensive training in Marionette puppeteering with the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theater and the Lambert Puppetry Theater of Ireland. He has also taught and performed puppetry for the City of New York, Parks and Recreations department. Terrell is the co-editor of two full length text books with publishing company operated by McGraw-Hill. Terrell is a teaching artist that has taught with almost a dozen arts based non-for-profits, most notably with Philly Young Playwrights, Taller Puertoricano, and the Mighty Writers. Terrell has performed or helped produce a litany of plays in the Tri-State area, and in 3 countries. Terrell is the recipient of multiple oratorical awards, with events sponsored by UPENN and the NAACP.


Target population :

This project will bring together a wide array of individuals, but will focus on the target communities that are impact by the disease the most aggressively (LGBT individuals and Communities of Color). In addition to seeking out local and national media attention we will target universities, public health organizations, the gayborhood, art based organizations and non-for-profit organizations to reach out to the audience we seek. We will also  utilize tools such as social media, palm cards, and if budget permits we’ll seek out low cost highly visible marketing tools (i.e. Septa ads or bill board ads)

Project funding: This project is being funded using every method possible (donations: tax deductible and non-deductible, crowd funding, and business contributions, and playbill ads; truly a grass roots effort.

Want to create ad in the playbill to show support or honor a love one who has passed from the epidemic?

Email mmkenyatta@gmail.com

Non profit or for profit business who wants to become a sponsor or partner?

Email mmkenyatta@gmail.com

story:
THE CAMPAIGN

Big Shot received international attention in the form of an invite to perform for a week at the San Diego Fringe festival in Summer 2015. One of the most exciting arts and culture events in North America. The Big Shot team is now working to raise the necessary funds to take Big Shot stateside. The opportunity to perform at the San Diego Fringe is significant not only for Big Shot but for the entire sphere of Irish Arts, with particular benefit for the promotion of original Irish musicals. 

THE STORY

Big Shot, an original Irish musical, tells the story of one Jeremy Crocker, a savvy defense lawyer thriving in New York City’s bustling legal profession. Despite his ambitions Crocker falls in love with Carrie, a struggling Irish artist who works in Jeremy’s go-to café in Downtown Manhattan. 

Although the two become ever more infatuated by each other the, romance threatens to derail Jeremy’s career-with particular regard to Carrie’s connection to a suspicious defense case Jeremy has recently acquired

THE WRITER

Big Shot is the brainchild of Lauryn Gaffney, a North Dublin native and graduate of St. Patrick’s College Drumcondra. Lauryn is now a part-time vocal trainer and has been writing songs since her early teens. It was one day two years ago when Lauryn began writing a song that, in her mind, sounded perfect for the role of a lawyer. Taking inspiration from this initial song Lauryn set about writing what was to become Big Shot the musical. 

After composing some of the songs on a clunky old grand piano in an MIT frat house while on a working holiday in Boston. Lauryn returned home to Ireland to finish the musical and successfully recruited the talents of the Big Shot cast and band. The show debuted at The Helix DCU and his since been performed on several more occasions at the O’Reilly Theatre, St. Patrick’s College.

story:
The Park Players of Allendale, New Jersey will be performing charity shows of Monty Python's "Spamalot" to raise funding for children, of families in financial need, to participate in acting classes and workshops at the Saddle River Youth Theatre. SRYT is a non-profit 501c3 organization dedicated to giving children, ages 7-18, the confidence and skills to perform in youth productions on their award-Winning stage.  Our mission is to provide 10 (or more!) Children with scholarships to attend SRYT starting in 2016. 

The Park Players is a free community theater group up made up of local actors, parents and students dedicating their time and talents to keeping theater education alive in their community for many years to come

We are raising funding for costumes, props and settings for "Spamalot". Please help our worthwhile organization in any way you can. Performing arts education teaches children to celebrate the differences between themselves and others and learn discipline, self-respect, perseverance and cooperation.

story:
About Actor's Rep

The Actor’s Repertory Company is a not-for-profit theatre dedicated to illuminating the eclectic character of American life by presenting multicultural alternative theatre (i.e., the seldom performed classic or prize-winning play, the new or experimental play) in a repertory fashion by its professional multicultural resident company of actors and technicians.

Actor’s Rep has been training and developing actors since 1980, but it is now forced to turn away students from its programs because it has outgrown its current space at 1009 N. Dixie Highway.

This will be the most ambitious fundraising campaign in the organization’s 35 year history. A bigger space will allow it to expand and operate in a more profitable manner.

“If we had a facility as bright and as beautiful as the future of the students who study here, we’d be unstoppable,” said Kathleen Kenny, Actor’s Rep instructor and education coordinator.

Currently, Actor’s Rep has three divisions:

The Actor’s Workshop creates and provides a workspace for local actors to train by means of study, exercise and critique, culminating in work on stage as professional actors.

The Youth Actors Guild is a multicultural group of highly trained, dedicated and talented young students of the theatre who donate their time as production assistants providing support and service to its not-for-profit professional theatre. In return for their time, they receive free classes.

The Youth Academy consists of students – ranging from 5 to 18 years old – who pursue their theatrical training at Actor’s Rep. Many of the students attend the local arts magnet schools, such as G-Star, BAK Middle School of the Arts and the Alexander W. Dreyfoos High School of the Performing Arts.

Why we need your help!

We are currently in negotiation to lease a new space at 301 Datura Street in the heart of Downtown West Palm Beach. The space is owned by the same gentleman who has been our landlord for the past 3 and a half years. He would very much like to see us in the space. 

Furthermore, we have received verbal support from The Downtown Development Association (DDA), The Community Redevelopment Agency (CRA), and The Economic Development Director for the City of West Palm Beach. 

We are working to raise $18,000 for our Architect's Costs: 
  1. Building plans from Borglund Associates - $6,000
  2. Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing Drawings - $10,000
  3. Architectural Engineer Fee - $2,000

Our Challenges

The space at 301 Datura St. is in high demand. We need to secure it as soon as possible before other parties lease the property.

As with any major construction project, there seems to be an endless list of permits, rules, and other requirements to transform this location into a thriving theatre. Our team has been working tirelessly for several months, preparing grant documents and construction plans.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share, share, share! Social media is incredibly powerful tool. A quick shout-out on Facebook or Twitter is free and helps spread the word to your entire network!

story:
Hi there!  We are Traveling Showcase Productions...

After having an AMAZING time at our home base of Three Clubs at last year's Hollywood Fringe, we want to take our show Lydia Trueblood: The Black Widow of the Atlantic Coast to the next level...all the way to the biggest Fringe Festival in the WORLD!  

At HFF'14, we were extended three times, we won the DOMA Award for Best Achievement in New Musical, a Best Of Fringe extension, the Encore Producers Award.  

We know there is an audience for this show, but we need help getting the show in front of one of the largest & most receptive audiences to which we might ever hope to have access.  We hope you'll become part of our team...  

 Lydia Trueblood is a macabre musical comedy about one of America's first female serial killers.  She murdered her husbands for revenge and for sport, and she's finally going to tell (and sing) all!

So here's what's up...

  • Yes, we are asking for a big chunk of change - getting five people (three performers, 1 director, 1 tech person) across the sea, housing them, renting our venue, advertising the show - these are all expensive things...
  • BUT we believe in this show, in this story, in these songs.  We desperately want to expose it to the international audience at Edinburgh Fringe, an audience to which we would have NO access under other circumstances.
  • We are covering a large chunk of our expenses with personal finances, but we are asking for help to make up the difference.  We want to be really transparent about exactly where your funds are going, so see below for a more specific breakdown of our budget!

...but what do I get out of this?

  • This is a show co-written by a woman and a gay man, directed by a person of color, starring two KILLER female characters - this is something we all know absolutely does not happen often enough.  We knew we wanted to tell a different kind of story, and we've gone outside of traditional production routes to do it.  Please, help us to tell this story and to get our perspectives out into the world.
  • And...

THERE ARE SO MANY FABULOUS PERKS FOR YOU TO CHOOSE FROM!!!!

We hope you'll join us for our ONE NIGHT ONLY Farewell to the USA performance of, "Lydia Trueblood: The Black Widow of the Atlantic Coast," followed by raffle and reception!

Or maybe you'd prefer a Thank God For Whiskey t-shirt?  Or a CD? Or an Everybody Loves Me button?  Or you just want EVERYTHING!?  We can't wait to send you gifts - we've got perks for every budget.  Speaking of budgets...

Welcome to THE BUDGET PORTION!

We put on Lydia Trueblood at Hollywood Fringe in 2014 - and we were a hit! We were called, "The Hidden Gem of Fringe 2014," "Phenomenal," "The Top of My List," by critics, we sold out shows, we won awards!  And we aaaaalmost broke even, financially.  We viewed that as a triumph.  

But this is a much bigger initial investment, one that would ruin us if we were completely on our own.  So we are turning to our community, to our friends, to kind folks the world over. We are asking for your help...and in the name of transparency, here are our BUDGET BASICS!

  • Air Travel - $3,500  3 plane tickets from LA to Edinburgh - 2 performers & our director.  We are covering the other 2 plane tickets (between $2300 & $2400, we think) out of pocket.  The airlines seem to have figured out that there's this big festival in Edinburgh this time of year, and 'deals' are basically nonexistent even 5 months out.

  • Venue - $3,100 The non-negotiable cost of using the fabulous SpaceTriplex, a dream venue, for our 2 week run.

  • Housing - $3,800 The absolute cheapest apartment we have been able to find that is even remotely close enough to our venue costs this much, and comes out to about $760/person for two weeks.  Remember, we won't have a car - we will have to carry a harmonium, accordion, ukulele, banjo, trumpet, along with our props and costume pieces to and from the theater every evening, and to and from the Royal Mile for busking each day, so let's just say that location is key.

  • SOOOO CLOSE! -Advertising - $1,500 This will cover a single 1/8th page ad in the Edinburgh Fringe Programme.  It's steep, but it is our best opportunity to reach our audience.  We will be paying for flyers, posters, and any other ads out of pocket.  And busking daily, of course, right out on the Royal Mile!

  • FUNDED - THANK YOU!!! Insurance - $200 We are required to show proof of insurance by our venue.

  • FUNDED - THANK YOU!!! Fringe Registration - $450 We gotta pay up to join the PARTY! 

  • Other costs (and there are a lot!)...are a responsibility we are taking on.  Feeding ourselves. Costuming the show. Designing the show for our new venue.  Flyers, posters, additional ads. We will have to pay a Foreign Entertainers' Tax...and all this is just to start.  More costs are going to come up.  But with your help, none of us will end up too far in the hole before we even begin.  We are hoping to raise more than our goal, but we are trying to be (a little bit) realistic, as IndieGoGo takes a much bigger cut of funds raised if we don't at least reach our goal.  

  • TOTAL BUDGET...$14,850+ 

  • TOTAL IndieGoGo FUNDRAISING GOAL...$10,000

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everybody has the $$$scratch$$$ to make a donation - we still love you and deeply appreciate your support!  I can't believe you've read all the way down here.  THANK YOU!  We hope that you'll share our campaign with your social media networks.  Keep checking back in - we'll be posting new videos every week!  And come hang out with us on...

Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/lydiatruebloodshow & please feel free to use our hashtag #LydiaTrueblood

Twitter - https://twitter.com/WidowTrueblood & please feel free to use our hashtag #LydiaTrueblood

Instagram - https://instagram.com/widowtrueblood/ & please feel free to use our hashtag #LydiaTrueblood

**In Person** - several events are coming up soon - please follow us to find out more <3

THANK YOU FOR READING, SHARING, WATCHING, DONATING, BEING HERE NOW, COMING ALONG LATER, HEY, WE LOVE YA!

- Liz & Efrain & the whole Lydia Trueblood team
story_txt:
Hi there!  We are Traveling Showcase Productions...After having an AMAZING time at our home base of Three Clubs at last year's Hollywood Fringe, we want to take our show Lydia Trueblood: The Black Widow of the Atlantic Coast to the next level...all the way to the biggest Fringe Festival in the WORLD!  At HFF'14, we were extended three times, we won the DOMA Award for Best Achievement in New Musical, a Best Of Fringe extension, the Encore Producers Award.  We know there is an audience for this show, but we need help getting the show in front of one of the largest & most receptive audiences to which we might ever hope to have access.  We hope you'll become part of our team...   Lydia Trueblood is a macabre musical comedy about one of America's first female serial killers.  She murdered her husbands for revenge and for sport, and she's finally going to tell (and sing) all!
So here's what's up...

Yes, we are asking for a big chunk of change - getting five people (three performers, 1 director, 1 tech person) across the sea, housing them, renting our venue, advertising the show - these are all expensive things...
BUT we believe in this show, in this story, in these songs.  We desperately want to expose it to the international audience at Edinburgh Fringe, an audience to which we would have NO access under other circumstances.
We are covering a large chunk of our expenses with personal finances, but we are asking for help to make up the difference.  We want to be really transparent about exactly where your funds are going, so see below for a more specific breakdown of our budget!

...but what do I get out of this?

This is a show co-written by a woman and a gay man, directed by a person of color, starring two KILLER female characters - this is something we all know absolutely does not happen often enough.  We knew we wanted to tell a different kind of story, and we've gone outside of traditional production routes to do it.  Please, help us to tell this story and to get our perspectives out into the world.
And...

THERE ARE SO MANY FABULOUS PERKS FOR YOU TO CHOOSE FROM!!!!
We hope you'll join us for our ONE NIGHT ONLY Farewell to the USA performance of, "Lydia Trueblood: The Black Widow of the Atlantic Coast," followed by raffle and reception!
Or maybe you'd prefer a Thank God For Whiskey t-shirt?  Or a CD? Or an Everybody Loves Me button?  Or you just want EVERYTHING!?  We can't wait to send you gifts - we've got perks for every budget.  Speaking of budgets...
Welcome to THE BUDGET PORTION!
We put on Lydia Trueblood at Hollywood Fringe in 2014 - and we were a hit! We were called, "The Hidden Gem of Fringe 2014," "Phenomenal," "The Top of My List," by critics, we sold out shows, we won awards!  And we aaaaalmost broke even, financially.  We viewed that as a triumph.  
But this is a much bigger initial investment, one that would ruin us if we were completely on our own.  So we are turning to our community, to our friends, to kind folks the world over. We are asking for your help...and in the name of transparency, here are our BUDGET BASICS!

Air Travel - $3,500  3 plane tickets from LA to Edinburgh - 2 performers & our director.  We are covering the other 2 plane tickets (between $2300 & $2400, we think) out of pocket.  The airlines seem to have figured out that there's this big festival in Edinburgh this time of year, and 'deals' are basically nonexistent even 5 months out.
Venue - $3,100 The non-negotiable cost of using the fabulous SpaceTriplex, a dream venue, for our 2 week run.
Housing - $3,800 The absolute cheapest apartment we have been able to find that is even remotely close enough to our venue costs this much, and comes out to about $760/person for two weeks.  Remember, we won't have a car - we will have to carry a harmonium, accordion, ukulele, banjo, trumpet, along with our props and costume pieces to and from the theater every evening, and to and from the Royal Mile for busking each day, so let's just say that location is key.
SOOOO CLOSE! -Advertising - $1,500 This will cover a single 1/8th page ad in the Edinburgh Fringe Programme.  It's steep, but it is our best opportunity to reach our audience.  We will be paying for flyers, posters, and any other ads out of pocket.  And busking daily, of course, right out on the Royal Mile!
FUNDED - THANK YOU!!! Insurance - $200 We are required to show proof of insurance by our venue.
FUNDED - THANK YOU!!! Fringe Registration - $450 We gotta pay up to join the PARTY! 
Other costs (and there are a lot!)...are a responsibility we are taking on.  Feeding ourselves. Costuming the show. Designing the show for our new venue.  Flyers, posters, additional ads. We will have to pay a Foreign Entertainers' Tax...and all this is just to start.  More costs are going to come up.  But with your help, none of us will end up too far in the hole before we even begin.  We are hoping to raise more than our goal, but we are trying to be (a little bit) realistic, as IndieGoGo takes a much bigger cut of funds raised if we don't at least reach our goal.  
TOTAL BUDGET...$14,850+ 
TOTAL IndieGoGo FUNDRAISING GOAL...$10,000


Other Ways You Can Help
We know that not everybody has the $$$scratch$$$ to make a donation - we still love you and deeply appreciate your support!  I can't believe you've read all the way down here.  THANK YOU!  We hope that you'll share our campaign with your social media networks.  Keep checking back in - we'll be posting new videos every week!  And come hang out with us on...
Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/lydiatruebloodshow & please feel free to use our hashtag #LydiaTrueblood
Twitter - https://twitter.com/WidowTrueblood & please feel free to use our hashtag #LydiaTrueblood
Instagram - https://instagram.com/widowtrueblood/ & please feel free to use our hashtag #LydiaTrueblood
**In Person** - several events are coming up soon - please follow us to find out more <3
THANK YOU FOR READING, SHARING, WATCHING, DONATING, BEING HERE NOW, COMING ALONG LATER, HEY, WE LOVE YA!
- Liz & Efrain & the whole Lydia Trueblood team

story:
Thank you!

We're well on our way to our goal! For those of you who missed the Indiegogo campaign, additional tax-deductible contributions can still be made directly to Fractured Atlas here.

Thank you to everyone who gave their support to help take Talking with Angels to Edinburgh! --TWA is a powerful statement about what Brené Brown calls 'wholehearted' living.  It's also a testament to wonder and creativity in the midst of lawlessness and bullying.  For me, it's  a real thrill to bring this story to life for audiences facing the challenges of the 21st century.

We will be having 6 rehearsals in LA in July so stay tuned for the dates, you're invited!  I hope you will be able to see TWA in Edinburgh, LA or beyond, and that the story contributes to many meaningful  conversations and connections for all of you.
With gratitude and thanks,
Shelley
www.TalkingwithAngels.com

Our Audience

TALKING WITH ANGELS is first and foremost an inspirational message for those who have questioned mainstream religion yet remain deeply spiritual in their own way. Self-awareness, mindfulness and authenticity are at the center of many conversations these days, and these subjects are at the center of Talking with Angels. 

This play is about the power of a few people and their tremendous spiritual power as individuals.  Talking with Angels is not simply vehicle for entertainment and not solely a spiritual text meant for solitary study; this performance is a co-creation where audience meets actor for a spiritual infusion.

Based on a True Story

TALKING WITH ANGELS is the true story of four young Hungarian artists, their search for meaning and their encounter with transcendent forces.  Over a period of 17 months, despite the chaos in Nazi-occupied Hungary, the artists Gitta Mallasz, Lili Strauss, Joseph Kreutzer and Hanna Dallos held weekly meetings every Friday afternoon from June 1943 to December 1944. During these meetings, Hanna received messages from four angels --four distinctly different personalities-- who gave counsel and comfort to the quartet.  In 1976, Gitta Mallasz turned the transcripts from these meetings into the book Talking with Angels which Shelley Mitchell then adapted into her critically acclaimed one-woman play.

TALKING WITH ANGELS is a tour de force by Shelley Mitchell. Solo on a bare stage with just mind, body, imagination and chutzpa to sustain her, she morphs herself through different characters and creates a marvelous ensemble drama out of thin air. Its a wonder to behold. CARROLL BALLARD, filmmaker (The Black Stallion)
Pages from Lili's notebook.

Gitta Mallasz

Gitta Mallasz, a professional graphic artist and theatrical set designer,  survived the war and immigrated to Paris in 1960.  She took the twelve notebooks containing the dialogues with her, hidden from the Hungarian border guards who would have destroyed them. They were published in 1976, as Dialogue avec L’Ange and immediately became a bestseller.  (Juliette Binoche, an ardent fan of the book, keeps it as a constant companion and inspiration for her work as an actress.)  The book in its original language (Az Angyal Vàlaszol) was so controversial it was banned by the communist regime in Hungary until 1991. In May, 2012, Yad Vashem awarded Gitta Mallasz with Israel's highest civilian honor as Righteous Among Nations.

Shelley Mitchell

Shelley Mitchell discovered Talking with Angels in 1982 when it was first published in English. She was thunderstruck by it's non-dualistic, Buddhist and Sufi-like message and instantly wanted to dramatize it, but like Gitta, she lived with the dialogues for a couple of decades before doing so. She saw a connection between the artistry of Eleonora Duse, the great 19th century actress (and where the word 'doozy' comes from), the ground breaking teachings of philosopher Alan Watts and her Jewish heritage.  --With the blessing of the book's publisher, Robert Hinshaw at Daimon Press,  Shelley brings this story to life, word for word. Her adaptation and performance of Talking with Angels , directed by Robin Fontaine, has been seen over 300 times at festivals, salons and small theaters in Europe and the USA.   It is an extraordinary east meets west story exploring spirituality, quantum physics and metaphysics.  Past venues include The California Institute of Integral Studies, The Institute of Noetic Science, The Carl Jung Institutes of Chicago and San Francisco, The 2004 Joseph Campbell Centennial in Atlanta and the NYC, San Francisco, Dutch and Irish International Theater festivals.  
But Edinburgh is a horse of different color...

The Edinburgh Fringe Festival

The Edinburgh Fringe Festival is the oldest and largest theater festival in the world.  Every August over 2,500 plays are presented attracting press, promoters and producers who are on the lookout for new projects; it's a giant theatrical showcase and competition to get their attention is fierce. 

TALKING WITH ANGELS is also fierce.  Its interfaith message of mindfulness and authenticity was way ahead of its time. That's one of the reasons why Gitta Mallasz waited over 30 years to speak publicly about her experience and publish her book.


SCHINDLER'S LIST meets MY DINNER WITH ANDRÉ

As a guide to living fully and authentically, Gitta Mallasz's Talking with Angels is on a par with The Diary of Anne Frank and Victor Frankel's Man's Search for Meaning. 


What We Need

The budget is $30,000 to successfully get to Edinburgh and produce our show. It will be performed every day from August 4 to August 31;  totaling 24 performances in a 100 seat theater right in the heart of Edinburgh. Ticket sales don't begin to cover the cost of production.  Performers get about $10 for every ticket sold at the Fringe and it usually takes about a week or two before performances generate some heat and start selling out.  That's why we're trying to raise funds to underwrite our project, and that's why we need your help.

$30,000 Total Budget:
Expenses
  • Theater rental - 15%
  • Travel and housing - 15%
  • Tech crew - 5%
  • Promotion in the form of flyers, posters and ads - 30%
  • Production Costs and Compensation 25%
  • Indiegogo and Fractured Atlas fees 10%
Income
  • Ticket Sales - 30%
  • Donations - 70%

The Impact

By donating to Talking with Angels you become a part of the story.   Many people are questioning mainstream religions. Some are choosing an independent path in an effort to understand how to live in times of radical social and environmental change.  Others are in inter-faith relationships that lead them to ask new questions about life and meaning, and as a result they are making their own hybrid rituals and ceremonies.  

From Talking with Angels, Friday, November 17, 1944
To Lili -Your song is: heal the wound!
To Hanna- Your song is: offer your heart!
To Joseph- Your song is: breath of Heaven that the earth has lost!
To me (Gitta)- Your song is: bring down the Light that is given to you!

Your contribution in any amount will help cover the up-front costs and any shortfall we encounter.  Check out our perks for donations of $25 and up.   If we come out of Edinburgh with a profit we will put the proceeds into future Talking with Angels productions like the one scheduled at St. John's Cathedral in LA on November 21, 2015.

Reviews and Endorsements


The play is truly riveting...a performance with rich vocabulary of movement, speech and gesture. JEWISH WEEK 


"She's the real deal!" SEAN PENN


Other Ways You Can Help

If you're interested in helping but don't have financial means:

  • Let your friends know about Talking with Angels and have them make some noise about it on their favorite social media platform.
  • Make use of the Indiegogo share tools!

And if you've read this far, thanks for taking the time to get to know our project!

story:
'For Love & Duty Players' is an emerging theatre company located in NYC in its second year! After the success of our original Titus Androncius adaptation "Martyr'd Signs" in the 2014 Planet Connections Theatre Festival and our 24 Hour "As You Like It" event in Central Park, we're exploring deeper, and further into modern and classical works. We are asking for help in fundraising donations for our Mainstage Season which includes William Shakespeare's "The Winter's Tale", David Auburn's "Proof", and Lee Blessings "Independence".  

  • Shakespeare’s The Winter’s Tale
  • Lee Blessing’s Independence  
  • David Auburn’s Proof

We also have some exciting events besides these coming up such as 

  • "Shake-in-a-Day" event  - May 17th ! More info coming soon!
  •  10-Minute Play Festival 
  • New Works Playwright Competition!

Your donations will go to raise money for -

$600 – Artist Stipends

$540 – Rights for published plays

$500 – Production and Administration costs (printing of programs, scripts, props, costumes)

$100 – Marketing of the Shows (Postcards, online ads, etc)

$1200 – Space Rentals (Rehearsals, auditions)

THE IMPACT

'For Love & Duty Players' started its existence by working in tandem with the Planet Connections Theatre Festivity - through this, each show was paired with a charity.  We were inspired through this festival to continue bringing theatrical works that not only present an evening of entertainment, but also provide thought provoking  issues which can be starting points for discussion.  This time we're choosing to explore different types of mental illness and the affect this has upon the family unit. We're hoping to ignite discussion, but also present opportunities for solutions and outreach through talk-backs from mental health professionals, information provided at shows, and personal involvement with a charity.  You're donations will allow us the ability to reach our artistic goals so we can follow through with our mission.  

Thank you for any type of support you can give!

story:
COWBOY MOUTH

'Cowboy Mouth' is a play written by Sam Shepard and Patti Smith in 1971. In 2015, we are thrilled to be bringing this amazing play to Sydney, and to be performing it in one of our city's most iconic and memorable spaces - HIBERNIAN HOUSE!

Directed by the brilliant, Arky Michael, and starring Nicholas Denton as SLIM, Diana Popovska as CAVALE, and Jonny Hawkins as LOBSTER MAN, 'Cowboy Mouth' is going to be one of this years most exciting independent plays to see! AND WE ARE SO ECSTATIC TO BE BRINGING IT TO YOU!

WHAT'S IT ABOUT:

The scene opens in a run-down motel room, after one too many mornings. The floor is strewn with miscellaneous debris: hubcaps, raggedy costumes, an old .45, rum, beer, and white lighting. Cavale, "a chick who looks like a crow, is a partly crippled, former mental patient", and has kidnapped Slim, "a cat who looks like a coyote", from his wife and child, but they have fallen in love.

. 

To Cavale, rock and roll is religion and her one dream is to find a man who she can turn into a rock and roll savior - a Jesus with a cowboy mouth. Slim, volatile and unfulfilled, once dreamt of being a rock and roll star but had given up on the idea. Until now.

Photographs: Eliza Harrison
WHAT CAN YOU DO!

As a team, we are independently producing this play and we need YOUR help to get it off the ground! We need to raise $3,000 in order to get 'COWBOY MOUTH' in front of an audience! 

The funds raised will go to:

  • Paying for a rehearsal space
  • Paying for the venue hire (Hibernian House)
  • Paying for a costume and set designer (Costumes/Props/Set)
  • Paying for the rights to be able to perform this play each night to an audience
  • Paying for Insurance
  • Paying our phenomenal director for his time, effort and contribution
  • Paying for food and liquids during those long days and nights in the rehearsal room (SUSTENANCE!)
  • ... and Therapy, because I'm sure we'll all need it once our run of shows are over!
Your help would mean SO much to us! No donation is too small! Everything counts and I assure you, every dollar will be absolutely appreciated! We would be so incredibly humbled by your contributions and very grateful, because for us, it grants us the opportunity to do what we love! And for us that is to create interesting theatre, which will hopefully inspire you all and entertain you just as much as it has entertained us to create it!
So we ask that you please help us by donating! And we will see you at the theatre!
HIBERNIAN HOUSE:
Level 2, 342 Elizabeth Street, Surry Hills




SHOWS:
Wednesday 22nd April - Preview
Thursday 23rd April - Preview
Friday 24th April - OPENING NIGHT
Saturday 25th April - Show
Sunday 26th April - Show
Monday 27th April - Show
Tuesday 28th April - Show
Wednesday 29th April - Show
Friday 1st May - CLOSING NIGHT

TEAM: 
ARKY MICHAEL: Director 
Arky Michael graduated from NIDA in 1982, and has worked extensively for most of the performing arts companies in Australia over the past 25 years, including Sydney Theatre Company, Melbourne Theatre Company, Queensland Theatre Company and Bell Shakespeare, both here and on international tours. In 2005 he won best film and actor at Tropfest for his film Australian Summer. Recently he performed in Missing the Bus to David Jonesfor Theatre Kantanka, Love Me Tender, a co-production between Thin Ice, Griffin and Company B, and Measure for Measure for Company B. For version 1.0 Arky devised and performed in This Kind of Ruckus and The Table of Knowledge. 

NICHOLAS DENTON: Slim
.
Nicholas has grown up around some of Australia’s entertainment industry elite. His passion stemmed from a young age training at St Martins Youth Theatre, he engulfed himself in high school and university performances in theatre and television until taking part as a student in New York at the Atlantic Theatre Company. Nicholas has worked with some incredible teachers and mentors in Australia and abroad including Larry Moss, Marie Dumont and Baz Lurhman. Nicholas’ theatre credits include ‘Out of Gas on Lovers Leap’, where he was praised by Art Hub Australia as ‘Stunning’, as well as ‘The Glass Menagerie’, ‘Monologue for a Murderer’ and later this year to perform in ‘Europe’ by Michael Gow in Melbourne. Most recently Nicholas had roles in the Australian film ‘Holding the Man’ and ABC’’s new TV series ‘Glitch’.

DIANA POPOVSKA: Cavale

Diana Popovska is an actor, writer and director. During high school, Diana developed and unshakable passion for acting, which led her to studying at NIDA, where she graduated from the NIDA Young Actors Studio in 2008. Here she would meet some of her most inspirational mentors, who would later on turn into artistic collaborators. These people included: Sam Haft, Chum Ehelepola, and Australian royalty, Baz Luhrman. Cowboy Mouth will be the first play that she has produced, although Diana is no stranger to the theatre. Diana's theatre credits include 'Macbeth', 'The Hypochondriac', 'The Small Poppies', and extend to her appearances on stage as a spoken word poet at 'Art Party' and 'Outspoken'. In 2013 Diana assistant directed 'Penelope' under director, Kate Gaul, which premiered at Sydney's TAP Gallery. Most recently Diana had roles in ABC's TV series'RAKE' and 'PLANS', which she also wrote, produced and directed.

JONNY HAWKINS: Lobster Man

Jonny Hawkins is an actor who recently, in 2014, graduated fromWAAPA. Jonny returned to Sydney in 2015 and started living the acting cliche; no money, unconventional share house, and having to deal with the profound anxiety that comes from audition after audition - However, Jonny does host the best parties! His most notable roles include Helge in David Eldridge's 'Festen', and John in Eden Falk's production of 'The Hour of The Wolf.' 'Cowboy Mouth' will be Jonny's first theatre production since returning back to Sydney, and as a huge Patti Smith fan, he is very excited to be performing one of his favourite plays!

AND WE ARE SO ECSTATIC TO BE BRINGING IT TO YOU!WHAT'S IT ABOUT:The scene opens in a run-down motel room, after one too many mornings. The floor is strewn with miscellaneous debris: hubcaps, raggedy costumes, an old .45, rum, beer, and white lighting. Cavale, "a chick who looks like a crow, is a partly crippled, former mental patient", and has kidnapped Slim, "a cat who looks like a coyote", from his wife and child, but they have fallen in love.. To Cavale, rock and roll is religion and her one dream is to find a man who she can turn into a rock and roll savior - a Jesus with a cowboy mouth. Slim, volatile and unfulfilled, once dreamt of being a rock and roll star but had given up on the idea. Until now.
Photographs: Eliza Harrison
WHAT CAN YOU DO!


As a team, we are independently producing this play and we need YOUR help to get it off the ground! We need to raise $3,000 in order to get 'COWBOY MOUTH' in front of an audience! 
The funds raised will go to:

Paying for a rehearsal space
Paying for the venue hire (Hibernian House)
Paying for a costume and set designer (Costumes/Props/Set)
Paying for the rights to be able to perform this play each night to an audience
Paying for Insurance
Paying our phenomenal director for his time, effort and contribution
Paying for food and liquids during those long days and nights in the rehearsal room (SUSTENANCE!)
... and Therapy, because I'm sure we'll all need it once our run of shows are over!
Your help would mean SO much to us! No donation is too small! Everything counts and I assure you, every dollar will be absolutely appreciated! We would be so incredibly humbled by your contributions and very grateful, because for us, it grants us the opportunity to do what we love! And for us that is to create interesting theatre, which will hopefully inspire you all and entertain you just as much as it has entertained us to create it!
So we ask that you please help us by donating! And we will see you at the theatre!


HIBERNIAN HOUSE:Level 2, 342 Elizabeth Street, Surry Hills






SHOWS:Wednesday 22nd April - PreviewThursday 23rd April - PreviewFriday 24th April - OPENING NIGHTSaturday 25th April - ShowSunday 26th April - ShowMonday 27th April - ShowTuesday 28th April - ShowWednesday 29th April - ShowFriday 1st May - CLOSING NIGHT


TEAM: 
ARKY MICHAEL: Director 

Arky Michael graduated from NIDA in 1982, and has worked extensively for most of the performing arts companies in Australia over the past 25 years, including Sydney Theatre Company, Melbourne Theatre Company, Queensland Theatre Company and Bell Shakespeare, both here and on international tours. In 2005 he won best film and actor at Tropfest for his film Australian Summer. Recently he performed in Missing the Bus to David Jonesfor Theatre Kantanka, Love Me Tender, a co-production between Thin Ice, Griffin and Company B, and Measure for Measure for Company B. For version 1.0 Arky devised and performed in This Kind of Ruckus and The Table of Knowledge. NICHOLAS DENTON: Slim

.


Nicholas has grown up around some of Australia’s entertainment industry elite. His passion stemmed from a young age training at St Martins Youth Theatre, he engulfed himself in high school and university performances in theatre and television until taking part  as a student in New York at the Atlantic Theatre Company. Nicholas has worked with some incredible teachers and mentors in Australia and abroad including Larry Moss, Marie Dumont and Baz Lurhman. Nicholas’ theatre credits include ‘Out of Gas on Lovers Leap’, where he was praised by Art Hub Australia as ‘Stunning’, as well as ‘The Glass Menagerie’, ‘Monologue for a Murderer’ and later this year to perform in ‘Europe’ by Michael Gow in Melbourne. Most recently Nicholas had roles in the Australian film ‘Holding the Man’ and ABC’’s new TV series ‘Glitch’.DIANA POPOVSKA: Cavale




Diana Popovska is an actor, writer and director. During high school, Diana developed and unshakable passion for acting, which led her to studying at NIDA, where she graduated from the NIDA Young Actors Studio in 2008. Here she would meet some of her most inspirational mentors, who would later on turn into artistic collaborators. These people included: Sam Haft, Chum Ehelepola, and Australian royalty, Baz Luhrman. Cowboy Mouth will be the first play that she has produced, although Diana is no stranger to the theatre. Diana's theatre credits include 'Macbeth', 'The Hypochondriac', 'The Small Poppies', and extend to her appearances on stage as a spoken word poet at 'Art Party' and 'Outspoken'. In 2013 Diana assistant directed 'Penelope' under director, Kate Gaul, which premiered at Sydney's TAP Gallery. Most recently Diana had roles in ABC's TV series'RAKE' and 'PLANS', which she also wrote, produced and directed.JONNY HAWKINS: Lobster Man


Jonny Hawkins is an actor who recently, in 2014, graduated fromWAAPA. Jonny returned to Sydney in 2015 and started living the acting cliche; no money, unconventional share house, and having to deal with the profound anxiety that comes from audition after audition - However, Jonny does host the best parties! His most notable roles include Helge in David Eldridge's 'Festen', and John in Eden Falk's production of 'The Hour of The Wolf.' 'Cowboy Mouth' will be Jonny's first theatre production since returning back to Sydney, and as a huge Patti Smith fan, he is very excited to be performing one of his favourite plays!

story:
La mission  d’EKASRINGA et de son Spectacle VIE DE CIRQUE est de promouvoir l’art équestre ainsi que le cirque traditionnel et de produire des spectacles équestres itinérants, en piste ronde, dans une ambiance foraine, où le bonheur des artistes humains et animaux est primordial. L’objectif de la coopérative est de toucher le public aimant les lieux à taille humaine,  ainsi que de créer la proximité et la rencontre avec les créateurs et les animaux artistes de leurs œuvres.

Ce dont nous avons besoin et ce que vous obtenez

EKASRINGA à besoin de 5000 $ pour produire  son spectacle : Vie de Cirque, c'est la mise en scène de la vie de la débrouille  et de l'entraide...nous  touchons les âmes, avec nos amis les animaux,  grands thérapeutes et   nous apportons à tous un peu de bonheur, dans nos messages  d'amour et de solidarité...

Par ces temps d'austérité nous positivons la situation en apportant de la joie et de l'espoir aux spectateurs, pour cela nous avons besoin de L'AIDE  de TOUS nos ZAMIS   et en retour nous pourrons offrir des spectacles pour tous,  mais aussi  aux plus démunis, aux enfants malades, aux personnes agées....et susciter  des vocations...pourquoi pas ?

    L'impact

    La vie de cirque c’est :

    - La vie avec nos animaux. Le lien extraordinaire que nous avons développé avec eux, le respect qu’on se porte mutuellement. L’admiration que nous avons pour ces animaux et ce qu’ils nous apprennent de la vie. On partage nos vies et la scène avec nos 10 magnifiques chevaux, un chien, un chat  et un cochon extraordinaire.

    La vie de cirque c’est :

    - Aussi et parfois les moments difficiles et c’est là que le mot «entraide» prend tout son sens. La vie de cirque, c’est la force que l’on trouve en l’autre et qui nous pousse à vouloir vivre toujours de plus en plus fort.

    La vie de cirque c’est:
    - une dizaine d'artistes en devenir,  issu de l'école du cirque, du milieu du dressage équestre , ou bien plus aguérris mais trop méconnus....
    De plus, Ekasringa veut amener un certain nombre de jeunes à faire partie du spectacle cet été. « Dans le projet Vie de cirque, on a l’intention d’inclure certains jeunes », dit-la Fondatrice Frédérique Foiret,  en déclarant que c’est dans ses intentions de prendre contact avec les écoles pour amener des enfants à venir faire de la figuration ou à chanter durant les représentations ...de quoi susciter quelques vocations ???

    Risques et défis

    Nous prenons de risque de faire 10 représentations du 10 au 23 Juillet à Baie St Paul - Quebec , mais tout ceci  en auto production pour faire connaitre notre troupe et notre thérapie de la Débrouille et du Bonheur. Nous ne recevons aucune subvention, et nous employons une vingtaine de personnes dont une dizaine d'artiste du cirque, en devenir ...

    D'autres façons d'aider

    Certaines personnes ne peuvent pas contribuer mais cela ne veut pas dire qu'elles ne peuvent pas aider :... faites passer le message et surtout PARTAGEZ l'info sur vos réseaux sociaux !!!

    GROS MERCI À TOUS

story:
About Me

   I'm an actor and musician who has appeared on Broadway in Natasha, Pierre, and the Great Comet of 1812, Doctor Zhivago, and CBS' Survivor.  I grew up playing the piano and writing songs, but I got the idea to start writing musicals one summer when I found myself unemployed.  I decided to not just sit around moping about not having a job, and go ahead and CREATE a job for myself, and eventually other people.

About the Project

 I finished writing the first draft of ALIVE! 5 years ago.  Since then it's received updates, a reading, and most recently a sold out concert of the music at ARS NOVA starring my amazing and talented cast from The Great Comet.  The plan from here is to host a workshop of the show with some well-known actors and creative team here in NYC, and then invite producers, investors, and theatre owners to a performance at the end of the workshop.  This is a much needed step in getting the show to Broadway.   All the money raised for this project will go toward the costs of this workshop.  Costs include: payment to actors, director, music director, writer, stage manager, pianist; payment to secure a rehearsal space; office supplies including scripts for everyone in the production; and other misc. outgoings that are required for doing a professional equity workshop.

story:
The Project

She-Wolves is an original one-woman performance blending dance, theatre, song, animated projection and sound design. An adaptation of the book by historian Helen Castor, it portrays little-known episodes in medieval history when royal women attempted to rule in a world where power was inescapably male. Five historical figures and their astonishing stories are brought to life for modern audiences by combining historical detail with contemporary arts and fashion. Each queen (or almost-queen) is given individual flavour through a collaboration with an artist in a different creative medium.

The show will go on to tour the UK and the US with an accompanying programme of educational activities designed to celebrate unrecognized women in England's history. We are especially excited about bringing the show to the historical sites where the action really happened, such as battlefields, castles and abbeys, which are often located in rural areas that are under-served by professional art-makers. We'll connect with local groups such as schools, libraries, women's groups and historical societies with the goal of creating positive and inclusive environments for self-expression, group reflection and discussion, and conflict transformation.

To find out more, visit our gorgeous website

And please explore and share on Instagram and Twitter @shewolvespro - there will be a daily behind-the-scenes sneaky peek as we count down to our Edinburgh Fringe debut on August 13!

Our Team

Creator and performer Laura Careless has over a decade of international experience working at the top of her field in performance, creation and education. From 2008-2016, she received an Extraordinary Ability visa from the US government sponsored by Company XIV, a New York-based physical theatre company. She was a Principal Performer and creative collaborator in productions recognized by the Drama Desk, Bessie and NY Independent Theater Awards, and Critics Picks in NY Times, NY Magazine and Time Out NY. She is also a Visiting Artist and Curriculum Specialist for Juilliard Global K-12 Programs.

Our creative team also includes Helen Castor, Historical Consultant; Jonathan Watkins, Contributing Choreographer (2016 UK National Dance Award winner, Best Classical Choreography) and Belle Mellor, Illustrator and Projection Designer (BBC Film Network award-winner). Click here to find out more about our fabulous roster of collaborators

She-Wolves in Edinburgh

The Edinburgh Fringe Festival is the largest arts festival in the world. Debuting the show there will allow us to refine the artistic side of the project while also making contact with the presenters, producers and media who can help us move the project forward. The Arts Council of England (where the project is based) does not fund  activities in Scotland, so this is an exciting opportunity for you to become a Producing Partner of the project! Every contribution is important and your support is deeply valued.

The money we're asking for will contribute to 

- final development costs, such as Belle's beautiful illustrations and Anne's gorgeous costumes

- venue hire

- travel and accommodation for the artistic team

- marketing materials such as flyers, posters and photocalls

Our total costs come out to more than we are asking for, and so we'll be funding with private money as well. We believe in this show and the power of these stories!

As a thank you for your donations, we have some fabulous She-Wolves goodies available. Declare yourself part of the She-Wolves pack with prints, t-shirts and tote bags specially designed by Belle, or nurture your inner animal with an original movement meditation or private movement coaching session from Laura. There are even producer credits up for grabs - a beautiful opportunity to publicly support a project created by and about wild and powerful women!

If we don't make our full target, we'll still use the money as planned and continue to look for funding elsewhere.

The Malala Fund

Malala Fund breaks down the barriers preventing more than 130 million girls around the world from going to school.  It is fighting to give back to girls what poverty, war and discrimination tried to take away. She-Wolves Project will donate 10% of our profits from this campaign to this wonderful organization. Find out more on their website.

Other Ways You Can Help

If a financial contribution is not possible for you right now, you can still help us by donating your time! Please share this page, and connect with us on social media:

Instagram: @shewolvespro

Twitter: @shewolvespro

Website: www.shewolvesproject.com

Thank you for your support!

story:
The Story 


The Asian Pacific American (APA) population is seriously under represented on screen and on stage. "Our Perspective: Asian American Play Readings" is a performance series that intends to provide inspiration, space, and audiences for Midwestern APA playwrights, directors, and actors. There will be four staged readings in 2018: February 12, and August 13 at Goodman Theatre, and May 21 and November TBA at Steppenwolf Theatre. The May reading will be marketed as part of Chicago’s APA Heritage Month activities. The August reading will possibly be included in the Consortium of Asian American Theaters & Artists national conference. Admission to the staged play readings is free.

Series curator Mia Park is a Korean American actress and playwright working in Chicago for almost twenty years. As Guest Curator in the Arts Incubator program of the non-profit organization, Asian Improv aRts Midwest (AIRMW)'s AA Arts Incubator, Mia believes that our universal voice is best developed by hearing local voices. Chicago’s theatre community is a microcosm of our global theatre’s lack of APA opportunities and AIRMW is dedicated to providing more of these opportunities.

By donating to AIRMW, your tax deductable support strengthens APA voices by providing the infrastructure for these staged play readings to take place and by paying the writers, directors, and actors. This is a first of its kind, history making event that can only happen with your help.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to pay the writers, directors, and actors. Here's our budget:
Payment for Actors: 40 actors x $50 = $2,000
Payment for Directors: 15 directors x $50 =  $750
Payment for Playwrights: 15 playwrights x $50 = $750
Binders: $5 x 15 = $75
Photocopies: $90
Theatre Public Relations: $2,000
Indiegogo Costs: $320 + $.30 per donation (50x.30=$15) = $335
Total: $6,000.00
Donation from AIRMW Board: $2,000.00
Total Needed: $4,000.00

Perks galore and info: Please note that the $25 perk of one VIP seat has a "suggested" retail value of $40. Admission to the readings are free and do not actually cost $40. There are amazing benefits to donating to AIRMW, in addition to feeling great for strengthening Asian Pacific American voices. Receive massages, acupuncture, career consultation, music, drum lessons, yoga - all kinds of perks for self-care and perks that make great gifts! TRIPLE your impact: 1) support APA voices on stage, 2) give a perk as a gift, 3) receive a tax write off. 

Your Impact: Curator's Statement from Mia Park

Time Magazine’s recent article on the lack of Asian American representation on television confirms what we already know: the Asian Pacific American (APA) population is seriously under represented. The same can be said for APA under representation in the oldest form of public story sharing, the theatrical stage. NBC News reported on Asian Americans in theatre speaking out against the white-washing of Asian roles in entertainment and the challenges the APA community faces in the acting industry. 

Chicago’s theatre community is a microcosm of our global theatre’s lack of APA opportunities. As a Chicago based Korean American actress and playwright for almost twenty years, I’ve experienced directly how, locally, our APA voices are often unheard in plays and on-screen. Since 2016, I’ve advocated for the training of local Asian American actors by hosting workshops in order to promote a qualified talent pool for casting directors to choose from, so that the explanation of “Chicago doesn’t have talented APA actors” can no longer apply. 

I recognize that an important way to continue advocating for APA representation is to encourage the creation of content created by the APA community. I intend to provide inspiration, space, and an audience for local Asian American playwrights, directors, and actors in the series, "Our Perspective: Asian American Play Readings".

There will be four staged readings in 2018: February 12, and August 13 at Goodman Theatre, and May 21 and November TBA at Steppenwolf Theatre. The May reading will be marketed as part of Chicago’s APA Heritage Month activities. The August reading will possibly be included in the Consortium of Asian American Theaters & Artists national conference. Admission to the staged play readings is free.

I believe that our universal voice will be best developed and strengthened by focusing on local talent. The only way to be heard and seen is to speak up and have presence, and "Our Perspective: Asian American Play Readings" aims to accomplish these goals. 

What's In The Way?

The main obstacle in the way of this staged reading series succeeding is apathy. What if no one wants to hear APA voices onstage? What if this is not important enough to donate money towards? What if no one cares?

If we don't reach our $4,000 goal, the playwrights, actors and directors won't get paid and as professionals, they should be. To pay APA theatre artists as professionals, we need your help since admission to the readings is free. Treating these artists as the professionals they are is a way of honoring their experiences and showing that their voices and stories matter. Help validate: donate.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, spread the word! Please use the Indiegogo share tools. Paste this link onto your social media, newsletters, and email blasts: https://igg.me./at/APAStagedReadings

Use the following on Twitter or Facebook:

Twitter: 
Donate to validate. 2018 Asian Pacific American play readings at @GoodmanTheatre and @SteppenwolfThtr need your tax deductable support. https://igg.me/at/APAStagedReadings  #apa #stagedreadings #playreadings #asianamerica #theatre

Facebook:
@GoodmanTheatre and @SteppenwolfTheatre host Asian Pacific American play readings in 2018. They believe in our voices, do you? Donate to validate. Your tax deductable donation makes a huge difference and the perks make great gifts. Thanks:  https://igg.me/at/APAStagedReadings

Thanks so much for your help!

Your Impact: Curator's Statement from Mia Park
Time Magazine’s recent article on the lack of Asian American representation on television confirms what we already know: the Asian Pacific American (APA) population is seriously under represented. The same can be said for APA under representation in the oldest form of public story sharing, the theatrical stage. NBC News reported on Asian Americans in theatre speaking out against the white-washing of Asian roles in entertainment and the challenges the APA community faces in the acting industry. 
Chicago’s theatre community is a microcosm of our global theatre’s lack of APA opportunities. As a Chicago based Korean American actress and playwright for almost twenty years, I’ve experienced directly how, locally, our APA voices are often unheard in plays and on-screen. Since 2016, I’ve advocated for the training of local Asian American actors by hosting workshops in order to promote a qualified talent pool for casting directors to choose from, so that the explanation of “Chicago doesn’t have talented APA actors” can no longer apply. 
I recognize that an important way to continue advocating for APA representation is to encourage the creation of content created by the APA community. I intend to provide inspiration, space, and an audience for local Asian American playwrights, directors, and actors in the series, "Our Perspective: Asian American Play Readings".
There will be four staged readings in 2018: February 12, and August 13 at Goodman Theatre, and May 21 and November TBA at Steppenwolf Theatre. The May reading will be marketed as part of Chicago’s APA Heritage Month activities. The August reading will possibly be included in the Consortium of Asian American Theaters & Artists national conference. Admission to the staged play readings is free.
I believe that our universal voice will be best developed and strengthened by focusing on local talent. The only way to be heard and seen is to speak up and have presence, and "Our Perspective: Asian American Play Readings" aims to accomplish these goals. 

What's In The Way?
The main obstacle in the way of this staged reading series succeeding is apathy. What if no one wants to hear APA voices onstage? What if this is not important enough to donate money towards? What if no one cares?If we don't reach our $4,000 goal, the playwrights, actors and directors won't get paid and as professionals, they should be. To pay APA theatre artists as professionals, we need your help since admission to the readings is free. Treating these artists as the professionals they are is a way of honoring their experiences and showing that their voices and stories matter. Help validate: donate.
